PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: Petitions
PETITIONS The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Tobacco Advertising
To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bjelke-Petersen (from 25 citizens), Senator Bourne (from 96 citizens), Senator Burns (from 24 citizens), Senator Chapman (from 64 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 50 citizens), Senator Crane (from 25 citizens), Senator Crowley (from 23 citizens), Senator Jones (from 98 citizens), Senator Kemp (from 50 citizens), Senator Kernot (from 25 citizens), Senator Knowles (from 24 citizens), Senator MacGibbon (from 25 citizens), Senator Maguire (from 73 citizens), Senator McKiernan (from 26 citizens), Senator Patterson (from 50 citizens) and Senator Zakharov (from 51 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Abortions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That every abortion kills an unborn human baby.
That the right to life to all humans is the most fundamental and essential of all human rights.
That the Government's first duty is to protect this right to life.
That the most defenceless and threatened lives are those of unborn babies for whom the Government is duty bound to take extra steps to protect.
That in 1987/88 taxpayers funds through Medicare provided Medical Benefits for 61,879 abortions totalling $6.4 million.
That in the same year Commonwealth grants to the States indirectly financed the deliberate killing of thousands of other unborn babies in State Public Hospitals.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament carry out its duty to protect the right to life of Australian babies by ceasing to fund abortions through Medicare, restricting grants to the States and by all other means at its disposal.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 136 citizens), Senator Childs (from 211 citizens) and Senator McLean (from 118 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and senators in the Senate assembled.

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesmanlike leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:-

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Childs (from 20 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 67 citizens) and Senator Zakharov (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned,
(i) are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii) call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (IACO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by IACO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Crowley (from 125 citizens), Senator Lees (from 120 citizens) and Senator Schacht (from 120 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Ownership
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned notes that the level of foreign ownership and control of Australian assets is of concern to many Australians.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) establish a register of foreign ownership.
(b) limit foreign ownership of real estate.
(c) control foreign investment in Australia so as to protect the national interest.
(d) increase the powers and resources of the Foreign Investment Review Board.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Goods and Services Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate proposals to introduce a goods and services tax and points out to the Senate that a 15% tax on funerals will cost a pensioner an extra $300 for a low budget funeral.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate will not agree to such a tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Country Hour
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

Having regard to the proposal of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to alter the format of the Country Hour to a single national programme; the valuable community service provided by the Country Hour; the role of the Country Hour in extending agricultural research extension, market and weather information to farmers on a local basis and the need for local rather than national information.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will:
Call on the Federal Government to ensure that the Country Hour is retained in its present form with predominantly State and localised input to retain its relevance to the farming community.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Senate to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and denial of information to print-handicapped and other Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Senate will, as a matter of urgency, establish a Committee of enquiry into
a) the export of Australian military hardware and services;
b) the adequacy of existing controls over Australian arms exports;
c) the implications of the international arms trade and ways in which it might be reduced.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in Syria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
WHEREAS:

A. The Syrian Government has adopted the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and is a signatory to the International Covenant on civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on the Elimination of all forms of Racial Discrimination;

B. In violation of Universal Declaration of Human Rights Articles 2 (Freedom of Religion), 13 (Right to leave) and 14 (Freedom to Emigrate), the Syrian Government oppresses and discriminates against certain of its citizens on account of their religion and/or ethnic identity and prohibits them from emigrating;

C. In further violation of its international obligations, the Syrian government punishes those of its citizens who attempt to exercise their internationally-recognised right of emigration with arbitrary imprisonment without charge or trial and with beatings and torture of the most cruel and barbaric kind; and

D. As a consequence of those repeated and grievous violations of international law, the Syrian government has been censured by the European Parliament and the governments of a number of democratic nations.
YOUR PETITIONERS THEREFORE PRAY THAT THE AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT RESOLVE TO:
I. CONDEMN the government of the Arab Republic of Syria for:

1. Its denial of fundamental rights including the right of all its citizens to emigrate and to family reunification; the right to life, liberty and the security of the individual; protection against arbitrary arrest and detention; the right of an accused person to a fair public trial before a jury of his or her peers; the right of free expression, assembly and association.

2. Its use of the police, law courts and other state organs to carry out arbitrary arrests, detention, beatings and torture in respect of certain of its citizens and otherwise to exact arbitrary penalties against such citizens solely on the basis of race, religion, sex, national or ethnic origin or political belief.
3. Its use of government-controlled communications media to incite hatred and prejudice against its Jewish and other minorities.
II. RAISE the foregoing matters for public discussion in the United Nations and other international forums with a view to imposing economic sanctions upon Syria until the aforementioned abuses cease.

III. ENCOURAGE AND ASSIST inter-government bodies, non-government human rights organisations and International Jurists to bring political and public pressure to bear on the Syrian government to honour its international commitments to respect the human rights of all its citizens.
AND your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Croatia and Slovenia

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MCMULLAN; SHORT; CAMPBELL; MCMULLAN; COONEY; SHORT; BAUME; CAMPBELL

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, and on behalf of Senator Cooney seek leave, to present two petitions which are not in conformity with the Standing Orders as they are not in the correct form.

Senator SHORT (Victoria)-I seek leave, and on behalf of Senator Michael Baume seek leave, to present two petitions which are not in conformity with the Standing Orders as they are not in the correct form.
Leave granted.
Senator CAMPBELL (Western Australia)-I seek leave to present to the Senate a petition which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form.
Leave granted.
The petitions read as follows-
To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

That 92% of Croatians who voted in a referendum on 25 April 1991, supervised by the Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia, declared their support for Croatia as a sovereign and independent State and their opposition to Croatia remaining in the Yugoslav Federation;
That 88% of Slovenians who voted in a referendum democratically expressed their support for Slovenia as an autonomous and independent State;
That both Slovenia and Croatia have declared themselves to be independent Republics and that each Republic is prepared to defend its territorial integrity.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should request the Australian Government to:

Establish diplomatic relations with the legitimate representatives of each Republic and of any currently subjugated country whose residents by a democratically expressed popular vote have declared their wish to be independent; and
Established trade relations with the Croatian and Slovenian Republics, to take advantage of the very favourable attitude which exists between the people of these Republics and the Australian people.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
by Senator McMullan (from 651 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 1,327 citizens), Senator Short (from 1,425 citizens), Senator Michael Baume (from 122 citizens) and Senator Campbell (from 119 citizens).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the recent few months there have been three particularly significant developments in the way in which we expect the Australian community, led by this Parliament, to join in a process of reconciliation with our original Aboriginal inhabitants. We are debating this morning a Bill for a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has been brought down in the last couple of months, and the Hon. Robert Tickner, MP, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Aboriginal Reconciliation, recently made a statement to the United Nations working group on indigenous populations in which he announced that the Australian Government had agreed to accession to the first optional protocol of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Taken together, and with the fine degree of cross-party support that we are receiving for this particular Bill, I believe that we stand on the threshold of a new era. Perhaps we will have to wait for a few years to see it come to fruition, but we have before us here a very auspicious beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill itself has an extremely important preface which recognises the occupation by Aboriginals of Australia for a very long time before the British settlement at Sydney Cove in 1788. It goes to the dispossession and dispersal of Aborigines from their traditional lands, acknowledges that there has been no formal process of reconciliation and says that by the year 2001, the centenary of Federation, it is most desirable that there be such reconciliation. As part of the process, the Commonwealth will seek an ongoing national commitment from governments at all levels to cooperate and coordinate with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as appropriate to address progressively Aboriginal disadvantage and aspirations in relation to land, housing, law and justice, cultural heritage, education, employment, health, infrastructure, economic development and any other relevant matters in the decade leading to the centenary of Federation in 2001.

The Bill contains initiatives for promoting reconciliation by leadership and education. It fosters a national commitment to reconciliation, establishing forums for discussion of issues that are relevant, advising the Minister and leading consultation and participation. These are the objectives of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation which will be established by the carrying of this legislation.

The role of Commonwealth, State, Territory and local governments is integral to the success of this process. Non-government organisations will be closely involved, as will communities generally. Recommendations made by the Council are to be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 days of their being made to the Minister. The powers of the Council are carefully delineated in the Bill and strategic plans are laid forth. In other words, this is a working document. As I have said, it is extremely encouraging that the document itself has the approval of all parties in this Parliament.

I find it ironic that Senator Michael Baume in his contribution to the debate yesterday suggested that this Council, of all councils, should be discriminated against in that remuneration should be only on the basis of compensation for expenses incurred by members of the Council. I cannot see why this Council should not be in the same position as every other consultative council that is established by this Government. Why, for example, should members of the National Council on Violence Against Women be remunerated on the basis of a per diem payment, or whatever the Remuneration Tribunal has determined, but not this Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, which is surely intended to overcome the discrimination against Aborigines which has occurred for a very long time?

The report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which has been with us now for several months, engendered a ministerial statement in response. This statement includes a distressing picture of the lives and deaths of the 99 people whose deaths-at an average age of 32 years-were considered by the Commission. Of the 99 people who died, 43 had experienced childhood separation from their natural families through intervention by State authorities, missions or other institutions. Eighty-three of the 99 were unemployed at the date of their last detention. Forty-three had been charged with an offence at or before the age of 15. Only two of the 99 had completed secondary education. Forty-three were taken into custody in the period immediately before their deaths on matters related to the overuse of alcohol. In the remaining cases, alcohol had been a contributing factor. The standard of health of the 99 varied from poor to very bad. The average age of those dying from natural causes was a little over 30 years.

Two principles which loomed large, according to the Minister, as central to change for Aboriginal people, were empowerment and self-determination. As a senior and experienced lawyer with considerable knowledge of Aboriginal issues, Commissioner Johnston referred to the `pinpricking domination, abuse of personal power, utter paternalism, open contempt and total indifference which confronted Aboriginal people in their everyday lives, with no personal control over their own children, their employment, personal savings or decisions as to whether to buy a car or other personal belongings. Agendas were being set elsewhere. Assumptions as to what was best for Aboriginal people were made elsewhere'.

According to Commissioner Johnston, the first prerequisite for the empowerment of Aboriginal society is the will for renewal and self-determination. He also stressed the important role played by Aboriginal community-based organisations. The role of these organisations is continually emphasised in the recommendations of the report. At every level control of lives and communities must be in Aboriginal hands in the same way that non-Aboriginal Australians expect to control their lives and communities. According to Commissioner Johnston, there was impressive evidence of the efforts being made all over Australia by Aboriginal organisations and communities at local and wider levels to demonstrate that this could be done, and indeed is already being done. Aboriginal people do have the determination and capacity to succeed.

The points made so emphatically and poignantly in the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody principally about the tenuous hold on life of so many young men apply with few variations to young women of the same generation. Tragically, many are not reaching middle age. These women were also separated from their families through official intervention. Few, though probably more than their brothers, have completed secondary schooling. Some, whom I have been privileged to count among my friends, have obtained tertiary training and significant positions in various bureaucracies.

However, many of this generation were children of poorly nourished mothers living from infancy in substandard conditions in reserves and fringe camps. Some have been exposed to radiation from the testing of atomic devices at Monte Bello and Maralinga. There is a devastating number of deaths of women in this group from medical conditions such as cardiovascular disease-stroke and heart attack-severe diabetes and its complications and diseases of that nature which in our non-Aboriginal society are associated with old age. There also is a high incidence of cancer of the breast, cervix and lungs amongst women of that generation. Alcohol abuse by the women or their partners is a contributing factor in some cases and can occur in two ways-by destroying women in their relative youth and, much more often, by making women the victims of violent abuse. Empowerment of women is a crucial element of the three developments of the last few months that I have described: this Bill; the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody; and the protocol to which we have acceded, which makes it possible for the first time for Aborigines to have access to the international structures which would allow their complaints to be dealt with.

The capacity of very many Aborigines to succeed, given half a chance, is graphically illustrated by the women's council of the Pitjantjatjara Council as recounted and beautifully illustrated in a publication entitled Minyma Tjuta Tjunguringkula Kunpuringanyi-Women Growing Stronger Together. The book documents 10 years of extremely productive activity by the Aboriginal women of central Australia. They first met as a council in 1980 and at that time, having established their council, chose a chairwoman from each of the three States covered by the three language groups in that area. In the Northern Territory section there are five major communities and more than 60 homelands, while in the Western Australian section there are 11 major communities and at least 45 homelands the number of which is increasing quite quickly, I suspect. In South Australia, there are 10 major groups and at least 50 homelands.

The document that was provided as a history of the activity of this Council over 10 years included an account of some extremely impressive major projects that have been undertaken during that time. These include assisting women to obtain funding for the establishment and upgrading of art and craft centres in the communities and to acquire funding for women's only vehicles to assist women to attend meetings, visit and care for sites, partake of ritual business, collect wood for hunting and gather art and craft materials for craft enterprises.

It is very liberating for women to have their own vehicles. In many communities of which I am aware the women's vehicles are for the women only-nobody else is allowed to touch them. In some cases, women have painted their own symbols on these vehicles to make certain that nobody else takes them. It also means that women in some cases are able to establish income generating activities such as catering, helping to dispose of rubbish and providing transport.

Other projects include assisting with the erection of women's museums for the safe storage of women's sacred objects; organising major art exhibitions highlighting the diversity of women's work; assisting women in the registering and protecting of the women's sacred sites of Uluru; organising and coordinating 45 women from 18 different communities to participate in the Festival of Pacific Arts in Townsville; arranging for many women to participate in important interstate conferences on a range of matters dealing with health, land management, birth rights, education, housing and women's cultural affairs.

The Council has also produced magazines recording women's stories and, of course, it has produced this quite wonderful document which records it all. It has conducted a comprehensive research project examining the care and needs of the elderly and disabled in the area; assisted in the production of videos about women's laws and stories; assisted in the research and planning of the Congress Alukura-the birthing place for Aboriginal women in Alice Springs.

It has organised site visitation trips for women wishing to follow dreaming tracks and renew bonds with their country; supported Arrernte women's efforts to protect a women's site from a proposed dam in Alice Springs; organised training courses for its Executive; organised interpreter courses for women in communities; organised women members of parliament to tour through communities-the list goes on and on.

When people go into Alice Springs from the outlying communities they are assisted by the Council women. They may need help with money matters, hospital business, accommodation and language in many cases. This Women's Council has been functioning in this extremely constructive way now for a very long time.

The document to which I am referring also recounts a number of instances where there has been a lack of official knowledge of women's dreaming sites, tracks and particular sacred sites. An extra role for these women-and a very important one, one which they would probably say was amongst their most important-has been to identify sites and work with the mining companies to make certain that those sites are not damaged.
There are anecdotes throughout the book. There is a reference to the women at Wingellina, which is in my electorate of Western Australia. It states:
You know we were just talking in a meeting with some women from Wingellina about the new mine. What were they saying?
The response was:
They don't want those men to come.
They-
talked about the important Dreaming stories, but the others have not understood it all yet.
It is going to need a great deal more talking. It continues:
But . . . as of now, maybe in a month . . . the men from the mining company will come to take samples back to Kalgoorlie. They will clean it . . . and examine it and have promised they will come back
This is where their real anxieties come through.

They will build up this area, put up buildings, an aerodrome for their planes and a school for their kids. Right in the middle of Wingellina community reserve. Then they will be the strong ones and this community will be crowded out.

We hope that with our new Council operating over the next few years to bring Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal communities together to discuss their very real concerns-such as I have just quoted-confrontations will become less and less common.

There is another extract I would like to quote from here. If there is no objection I would also be very happy if it could be included in Hansard in the language of the Ngaanyatjarra people, as it is before me here.
Leave granted.
The extract read as follows-
TJUKURPA WANATJITI

Dora: Nyaa panya wanatjiti panya wangkanytja. Tjinguru ngayulu pakuringkala. Ngayuku kuringku wangkanyi, ``Warpungkula palyala tii, yaltji tjungka. Mainti wiya''. Munu ngayulu wangkanyi. ``Ngayulu pakuringanyi ngayulu mara kutjara wanatjiti wiya''.
Kana kuwari pakuringanyi mara kutjara ngayulu. Ka nyuntu yaaltji-yaaltji panya Englishngka wangkanyi?
Suzy: My mother would say ``I've only got one pair of hands''.
Dora: Ka paluru wanatjiti wangkanytja wiya?
Suzy: Wiya, paluru ngurpa wanatjitiku.
Dora: Ka anangungku wangkapai wanatjitingka tjungura.

``Hai, ngayulu pakuringanyi nyaakunin nyuntu ngayunya rawangku witu-wituni? Mara kutjarani pakuringanyi ngayulu panya wanatjiti wiya palu wanatjitingku kutju mara tjuta Kanyini''. Tjana alatji wankapai anangu.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the benefit of the Senate I will read the interpretation. This is a very short story entitled the Centipede. Dora is talking to Suzy, a white woman:

SPEECH.PARA: Dora: Now, what was I saying about centipedes? Just say I was tired and my husband said: ``Hurry up and make tea. Where's the sugar? Do we have any food?'' and I'd say ``Well I'm really tired and I've only got two hands. I'm not a centipede''.
Dora: How would you talk about this in English?
Suzy: My mother would say ``I've only got one pair of hands''.
Dora: And she doesn't mention a centipede?
Suzy: No she doesn't know anything about centipedes.

Dora: Well anangu talk about the two things together. ``Hey I'm really tired, why do you keep on nagging me? What's the matter with you, I've got just two hands and I've had enough. I'm no centipede. Only centipedes have lots of hands''.
This is what people say.

I read that as an illustration of how close we really are and how, when there is the opportunity to exchange anecdotes of whatever level of significance, whether it is about an enormous mining company coming into the area or whether it is about women exchanging their everyday experiences, it is extremely important that we have the capacity, the forum, the Council which will make this not only possible but an everyday occurrence in the very near future, I would hope.

I also refer very briefly to the activities of some of the women in the Fitzroy Valley in Western Australia, quite a long way from central Australia, which we have been discussing for the last five or 10 minutes. It was decided by the Aboriginal women in that area not so very long ago that they simply must have a women's refuge. The level of domestic and familial violence in the area was very high, with deaths and injury to women extremely common.

In order to establish the need, to put together a working group and to also become incorporated, the leading women in Fitzroy Crossing had then to deal with 20 different language groups from the Fitzroy Valley. This was a matter which took an enormous amount of time, effort and diplomacy. There are not only language groups, but there are 20 different hierarchies. Although the need was clearly and quickly identified, all those power structures had to be appropriately incorporated in the venture if it was to go ahead. This has been achieved in a relatively short period of time, and the women in the Fitzroy Valley will have their refuge at Fitzroy Crossing before very long.

Empowerment of not only Aboriginal women, of course, but also Aboriginal men, as has been emphasised in the documents that I have quoted, is absolutely essential to the aims and objectives of the Bill that we are debating this morning. With the support that has been promised by the other parties in this Parliament and with the goodwill of all Australians involved, I feel quite certain that it can be the door to a new era of relationships between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This Bill seeks to establish a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to promote a process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the wider Australian community. Under the proposal the Council will consist of up to 25 prominent people, including at least 12 Aborigines and two Torres Strait Islanders, as well as a secretariat of 10 people located within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. It is estimated to cost $2.2m in its first full financial year.

SPEECH.PARA: The Council will have two major functions: first, to undertake initiatives leading to reconciliation between Australia's indigenous people and the wider community; and, second, to play an educative and leadership role in bringing about a deeper understanding of the culture and disadvantage facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
The shadow Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, my colleague Dr Michael Wooldridge, announced the Opposition's support for this Bill in June when he told the House of Representatives:
This is significant because it is the first time in eight years that there has been bipartisan support for a major piece of Aboriginal affairs legislation.

Our support came after six months of deliberation, work and consultation during which the Government addressed many of the concerns we placed before it. I refer in particular to a letter from the Leader of the Opposition, Dr John Hewson, to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) dated 14 May 1991. In the concluding remarks of that letter Dr Hewson says:

It is our view that for any process to succeed there must be consultation with all Australians and not just one section of the community. This will ensure wide community involvement, which is essential if any ``process of reconciliation'' is to succeed.
Consultation with the wider community can be particularly beneficial as, in itself, it can lead to greater understanding and respect by Australians of Aboriginal culture and issues.
A process which improves broad community understanding and Aboriginal self-esteem offers the best hope of an environment in which Aboriginal advancement programs will succeed.

My response to you comes after wide consultation with Liberal and National Party leaders and organisations throughout Australia. If you are prepared to set up a Council that will focus at a community level on the well-being of Aboriginal people, that does not have an Instrument of Reconciliation as a means to a Treaty as its stated or even unstated aim and that will undertake genuine consultation with all Australians, then there is a basis on which we can go forward.

The Opposition is determined that this Council should focus on a process of reconciliation at the community level rather than pursue vague national concepts. The Opposition also believes that the process of reconciliation should work to establish agreed goals and annual benchmarks for progress in areas such as education, health, housing and infrastructure. In other words, that the process of reconciliation should provide a tangible improvement in Aboriginal well-being.

For a moment let us put this in the context of what we mean when we talk about reconciliation for Aboriginal people. There are roughly 220,000 Aboriginal people in Australia; I hope the recent census will update that figure and give us a more appropriate measure of where we stand today. However, the statistics with which we generally work imply that 220,000 people in this country claim that an Aboriginal heritage is important to them. Of these, I estimate that 100,000 are participating well and routinely in the general community. While there are many special government financial programs to assist many of them because of their Aboriginal heritage, they generally operate, as I said, well and routinely in the community. I would categorise the remaining 120,000-and I hope I do not offend anyone in doing this-into two groups: I believe about half, around 60,000 people, are still traditional, ceremony-linked people living in isolated and remote communities throughout Australia, and the other 60,000 people are generally what are described, sometimes unfairly, as fringe-dwellers who live an abject and rotten lifestyle where awful health standards and shocking alcohol abuse, and the ramifications of these issues, pose major social problems throughout our community.

My own family relationships with the Aboriginal community and my electorate of the Northern Territory bring me into daily contact with all sectors of Aboriginal society. I have formed the view that all Aborigines, no matter what grouping they may identify with, have no alternative but to live in two cultures simultaneously, with the conflicting and competing values and standards of those two cultures.

The other 17 million Australians basically have to cope in only one culture. Generally, the values and standards that we have inherited from Europe, Asia or elsewhere are very similar, despite the ethnic differences. The issues that we have to seriously address on the topic of dealing with Aboriginal Australians generally relate to two main subjects that need to be debated and continually considered. The issues that we need to give priority to are the issues of disadvantage and discrimination.

Over the past four years I have asked thousands of questions in the Federal Parliament and in Senate Estimates committees relating to the waste and inefficiency in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. I make no apologies; my motives in concentrating on this portfolio were and are to improve the efficiency of service delivery, to demand accountability for taxpayers' funds and to guarantee that Aborigines get improved access to basic services, not bloated bureaucracies. I have continually concentrated on aspects of funding in the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio that ends up being wasted, primarily in administrative functions and salaries for white bureaucrats who often do not meet the important needs that I would like to see met in Aboriginal communities.

TALK.START.PARA: —And who have a different agenda.

—Not always, but occasionally, yes. I am therefore relieved that this Council will be subject to an annual assessment of its performance. The Prime Minister agreed to this request when he wrote to the Leader of the Opposition in May this year proposing the measures of accountability. These included a strategic plan stating the goals, objectives and strategies of the Council, as well as a requirement to report annually. The Prime Minister indicated that a copy of the annual report would be laid before each House of Parliament and a further copy would be referred to the chairperson of the House of Representatives committee responsible for matters relating to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister acknowledged the Opposition's concern that the process of reconciliation should not have as its aim, hidden or overt, the achievement of an instrument of reconciliation. I think that is most important. In her comments Senator Giles referred to the recent statement by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Robert Tickner, on 31 July 1991 to the Working Group on Indigenous Populations of the United Nations. In that address I note that Mr Tickner has tempered the remarks that have been made on previous occasions to the same international working group. The language he has used is no longer what I would term provocative in the political sense. It is certainly seeking an aim and an objective consistent with this legislation.

On this particular issue of concentration on a `treaty', or whatever name it goes by, the Minister has acknowledged that a function of the Council will be to determine whether reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people would be advanced by a formal document or documents. It is a matter for the consideration of the Council but it is not a primary goal or a predetermined factor. This has certainly been an issue that has been most provocative in the community in the past.

In a political statement by a Minister there are always issues with which we would disagree or on which we would take a different viewpoint. I certainly noted in Mr Tickner's Geneva statement that there were points with which I disagreed, in particular, his comments relating to the recent mining decision at Coronation Hill. He said:

The Australian Government concluded that mining would constitute a desecration of Jawoyn religious beliefs . . . should be seen as a significant victory for those who respect the rights of Aboriginal people to maintain their traditional religious beliefs and to custodianship of their sacred sites.

I believe that many of my Aboriginal constituents in the Northern Territory and a large number of the Jawoyn people would disagree with that statement by the Minister. I have certainly had representations from my electorate and from the Jawoyn people in that regard.

Nevertheless, we are today addressing a new Council and a new process that is going to look, importantly, at objectives that the Government and the Parliament have been addressing recently. I note that the central objective is set out in clause 5 of the Bill, which states:

The object of the establishment of the Council is to promote a process of reconciliation between Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider Australian community, based on an appreciation by the Australian community as a whole of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander cultures and achievements and of the unique position of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders as the indigenous peoples of Australia, and by means that include the fostering of an ongoing national commitment to co-operate to address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage.
I mentioned earlier that in our community the two main topics to be addressed are those of disadvantage and discrimination.

Firstly, we need always to bear in mind and to place in proper context that at the moment there are millions of other Australians in poverty and struggling without the benefit of the special schemes and arrangements that are in place for many Aboriginal people. This in itself produces discrimination and automatic comment by other people. There needs therefore to be a proper understanding of Aboriginal issues, particularly by other people who are discriminated against and also disadvantaged.

Secondly, we also need to be aware that we live in a multicultural society and that ethnic new Australians will often be sceptical and not attracted to many of the issues and topics that arise because of the special cultural differences of Aboriginal Australians.

Thirdly, there are many people who live in remote and rural parts of Australia who need to have a major say in the style and the character of their own communities mainly because they must live alongside and with Aboriginal people.

As I mentioned, I am fortunate to have an Aboriginal family association and relationship. I find that is something that complements my lifestyle and my appreciation of Aborigines. The fact that my electorate is at least 25 per cent Aborigine gives me a very sensitive approach to this issue, and makes it necessary that I do so. But we always need to be aware that envy is a two-way street, particularly if either an idea or the essential funding for something is being driven from Canberra, Melbourne or Sydney. We need always to be aware of the priorities of people who live in the remote parts of Australia.

I believe that three fundamental principles underline discrimination in Australia generally. They are, firstly, alcohol abuse; secondly, poor public community health standards; and, thirdly, a reaction to unacceptable, noisy behaviour. If we look at these three issues we will see that they are the fundamentals on which any community discriminates in any neighbourhood. We need to address them carefully in the relationships within a neighbourhood, particularly as people live together with Aboriginal people throughout Australia. They are the three significant issues that produce discrimination.

The opposite side of the coin is to look at the positive areas where results are evident. I put on the record a couple of points that need to be recognised. One is public education and the other is public health. For example, the education systems that are being developed by the Northern Territory and various State governments that recognise Aboriginal culture and the needs of Aboriginal people are terribly important. It is only through education improvement and a change in community attitudes that we can counter discrimination.

On public education I am also attracted by the role that is being played by television in the community. In my electorate, Imparja Television operating from Alice Springs is an Aboriginal owned organisation which essentially operates as a commercial television station to the wider community. Because of its ownership, it does have a special consideration for the Aboriginal people of outback Australia. Through those television programs, whether they are special interest programs for Aboriginal communities or whether they are traditional programs, we are seeing very dramatic changes, particularly in the Aboriginal community.

I recount a recent visit that I made to Ngukurr, a community in my electorate, where I sat down with elders of the council, I asked them what their favourite television programs were and what programs they felt were most meaningful for their community. One of the elders looked me straight in the eye and said-I am paraphrasing in a white English style-that his first priority was the news and his second priority was The Cosby Show. I pursued that and asked: `Why The Cosby Show?'. His answer was-again I am paraphrasing in a white English way-that for the first time he had seen what it was like inside my lounge room, my bedroom, my kitchen, and how I managed my relationships with my teenage kids. I believe that appreciation comes from the fact that usually an Aboriginal person would not get into my house in a normal operational way. Of course, we know that television has a dramatic effect throughout the community, but on this particular issue it will be vitally important.

When I address issues such as public health, a number of people will recall the Australia Day statement that I made in Katherine this year when I said that I would rather see a television set put into every Aboriginal humpy before a water tap. It produced quite a reaction. A number of people felt that I was being heartless and cruel in not putting in the essential water tap first. But I was really saying that if we would put in a means of communication, the water tap would soon follow and it would be used properly in the administration of health.

Similarly, one of the major concerns of public health in the isolated Aboriginal communities in my electorate relates to a very simple thing; that is, mattresses. Mattresses are on view openly in every community. As I walk through the communities, it is obvious that the mattresses have probably been there for years; they have been soiled; and they have been used and abused or whatever. From my discussions with the community health workers, I believe that a simple thing like a mattress replacement program in those communities where they are generally available at the supermarket and where they would be destroyed monthly would see an absolute turnaround in public health in many of those remote communities. It is a simple thing. This process needs to bring out many of those examples so that we can get simple programs that can be very effective consistently.

I have mentioned that there is also the need to concentrate on the positive impacts that are happening in the community. In dealing with the Aboriginal affairs portfolio, we always need to be mindful that we must step back from being patronising, embarrassing or offensive. Many people quote the recent improvements in the Moree community. It is not just an isolated example of community improvement. There are hundreds of communities throughout Australia making great strides locally. We need to concentrate on the other positive impacts in the relationships between Aboriginal Australians-for example, the voting participation in the Australian electorate since the 1967 referendum; the work of the churches, the social agencies throughout Australia and the many people who have approached the communities as missionaries or as people with a very special concern in the particular area; and the major programs by State, Northern Territory and local governments.

For example, in the Northern Territory I can quote the success of the community government scheme, which is a special adaptation of local government to suit the needs of the area and has been particularly successful since self-government in the Northern Territory in 1978. What about the positive impact of the sports field? Many people identify with Aboriginal Australians who have a remarkable prowess in sport. What about the concentration on arts appreciation? Aboriginal art is unique. Whether it is in the form of paintings, artefacts or the performing arts, Aboriginal people have a lot to teach us. Their art is very special and valuable.

We need also to recognise the sympathetic media attention that is attracted to this area. I draw a comparison in saying `sympathetic media attention' because too often people in the media-journalists and others who have had very little exposure to an understanding or an appreciation through a daily working relationship with Aboriginal people-tend to engage in looking at issues that relate only to the ghastly, the tragic or the awful side of many aspects of health areas or issues such as the wastage of funds.

Other areas, such as the joint venture tourism projects, are now being developed throughout Australia, particularly in central and northern Australia. This poses problems for traditional Aborigines to compromise in many respects some of their cultural aspects. But at the same time the participation for employment, for investment and for the future is terribly important and worth noting.

Finally-and I have probably missed a number of other issues-I pay credit to the role of Aboriginal broadcasting. The broadcasting to remote Aboriginal communities scheme-BRACS-has been specially developed for individual Aboriginal communities. We have also seen the development of special media training units. I am aware of several in the Northern Territory and I am sure that there are others in New South Wales and Queensland. Aboriginal broadcasting forms a very special bridge of understanding between Aboriginal people and the wider community. Whilst there are 220,000 Aboriginal people in Australia out of a population of 17 million-odd, we need to recognise that we must go down the track of accepting that reconciliation is a very important concept.

Similarly, I would take issue to a certain extent with the comments of Senator Kernot yesterday in this debate when she drew a parallel to and a comparison with the objectives of this piece of legislation and the other political debate that is going on in the community with regard to republicanism for Australia. I would point out to the Australian Democrats that rhetoric does not solve real problems. The issues in the Aboriginal community are predicated on first addressing the real problems. That can be done only by practical measures and a very intense understanding and appreciation by all members of the community.

We ought not to confuse the date in this Bill of 2001 for its sunset clause with the other objectives that many people may have, and the Democrats may well have, with regard to a republic for Australia. It would be a crime if the focus on republicanism forced the Aboriginal community to be drawn in as part of that debate. The issue that we are addressing here in the reconciliation issues for Australia and Australian Aborigines is a much bigger, wider and very special project.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak in support of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991. I am particularly pleased that there is all party support for this legislation, which also has the support of a wide range of individuals and organisations in the Australian community, from both indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. I pay tribute to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Robert Tickner, and the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, Michael Wooldridge, for the commitment they have shown for this process of reconciliation, which has led to a major step in that process-the introduction of this Bill. It is noteworthy that one of those who spoke strongly and convincingly in support of the Bill in the House was the former Leader of the Opposition in this chamber, Fred Chaney.

SPEECH.PARA: It has taken over 200 years for us to reach this point in the process of reconciliation and even then, in a formal sense, it is a first step. As the preamble to the Bill states, and I quote in part:
(c) to date, there has been no formal process of reconciliation between Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and other Australians; and
(d) by the year 2001, the centenary of Federation, it is most desirable there be such a reconciliation.
This Bill is thus the beginning of a formal process to achieve aims which many of us have held for a very long time, recognising, and again I quote from the preamble, that:
(a) Australia was occupied by Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders who had settled for thousands of years, before British settlement . . . on 26 January 1788; and
(b) many Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders suffered dispossession and dispersal from their traditional lands by the British Crown . . .

And, of course, more recently, without the benefit of the British Crown. Those responsible for the preparation and drafting of this Bill should be congratulated not only on its being written in plain English but also on the fact that the language is readily understood with the bare minimum of legal technology. So it should be widely accessible to the Australian community.

I have said that it has taken us 200 years to reach this point, but I should add that we have come a long way, if belatedly, in recent years. I can remember taking part in a campaign back in the late 1940s to urge the then Menzies Government to act to include Aboriginals in the census and to grant citizenship rights to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders. At that time not only were they not counted but we still had laws which allowed for segregation on reserves, the compulsory removal of people from their tribal lands-their traditional home-the removal of children from their parents in the name of the child's welfare, and even in some cases for Aboriginals' own bank accounts having to be operated by a socalled protector, often in remote areas the local policeman.

I remember feeling ashamed of white Australia when, in the 1950s, I found myself able to drink in the bar at the local hotel in the Latrobe Valley in Victoria while the Aboriginals had to drink in the lane outside. A major change came after another 20 years when the referendum of 1967, with cross-party support again, enabled constitutional change to allow for what was effectively full citizenship rights for Aboriginal and Islander people. I say cross-party rather than universal support because there were still groups in the community who opposed the passing of the referendum and were prepared even to hand out how-to-vote cards to that effect. Some of those groups will still, I am sure, be opposed to this legislation. We all know how difficult it is to get a positive result from a referendum, which requires not only a majority of electors but also a majority of States for success. It is noteworthy that the Yes vote in that 1967 referendum left no doubt about the electorate's opinion. It was one of the highest Yes votes ever recorded in Australia.

This legislation will allow for the establishment of a Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. The functions of the Council, as set out in the Bill, are to provide a forum and an instrument to undertake the promotion of reconciliation between Aboriginals, Torres Strait Islanders and the wider Australian community through the processes of education and discussion, fostering cooperation to address Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander disadvantage and consultation with the Minister on relevant policies to pursue those aims.

Further, the Council is to consult Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and the wider Australian community on whether the reconciliation would be advanced finally by a formal document or documents of reconciliation, and following that consultation it will report the outcome to the Minister. If the Council believes that such a document would benefit the Australian community as a whole, it would then make recommendations to the Minister on its nature, content and implementation. So the establishment of the Council will initiate a very important process, with no prescribed action at the end but the clear expectation that appropriate action will result.

Attitude change, as we all know particularly in this place, is always a slow process. But I believe the powers and functions of the Council will enable it to assist in accelerating the rate of change of attitude through the consultative and reporting functions set out in the Bill. This process will, of course, run in parallel with the implementation of policies of direct and practical concern in the areas of, for example, Aboriginal health, education and housing. Senator Tambling has focused on a number of areas where that action is needed.

I have said that the work of this Council is to carry out a process. The Bill specifies some of its powers without limiting those powers-for example, the power to hold inquiries, conduct research, and organise public education activities. It is also required to develop strategic plans for each three-year period up until the year 2001. These plans will be placed before both Houses of Parliament, as will the annual reports. The Bill contains a sunset clause; the Act will cease to be in force on 1 January 2001. Clearly there is an expectation that the Council's work will be satisfactorily completed by that date.

I will refer briefly to the composition of the Council because that reflects the cross-party and community consultation which preceded the introduction of this Bill. One member will be nominated by each of the Minister, the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and any non-Government party of at least five members that is not part of the Opposition. At the moment, of course, that would be the Australian Democrats, but it could involve other parties in the future. The total size of the Council allows for this and other flexibilities by providing that membership must be at least 15 and at most 25, of whom at least 12 must be Aborigines and at least two Torres Strait Islanders. I support what Senator Kernot had to say yesterday about the importance of the Torres Strait Islanders being recognised in their own right.

There is a further innovation in the clauses relating to meetings which might on occasion and with adequate safeguards be adopted by Senate committees and possibly other parliamentary committees. Clause 16(8) states:

If the Council so determines, a member may participate in, and form part of a quorum at, a meeting of the Council by . . . telephone; closed-circuit television; [and] any other method of communication determined by the Council.

There have been occasions, particularly when plane schedules have been disrupted by bad weather, when hearings of our committees here have been postponed or even aborted. Such cases occur when one person is not able to fly in and consequently a quorum cannot be formed. A provision such as that contained in clause 16(8) would enable a committee to proceed in that case.

I welcome the provision in the Bill giving members of parliaments and local government bodies the capacity to be members of the Council. Their involvement may greatly assist the Council's role. For example, it would allow direct access to State education policy. In the debate in the House of Representatives, several speeches referred to shameful examples of what appeared in school textbooks in some States in the not so distant past-within the last 20 years. References were made to Aboriginals in appallingly racist terms. I hope those examples have disappeared from curricula. It is important to ensure that all school children have the opportunity to learn about Aboriginal history and Aboriginal culture.

When I was at school-and that was in the 1940s-I did not get my first insight into Aboriginal culture until year 12, and not many, particularly girls, got to year 12 level in those days. We studied Eleanor Dark's novel The Timeless Land. That had a considerable impact on me, and I later followed up some of the questions she raised and became very impressed by Aboriginal culture and beliefs.

This sort of experience needs to happen much earlier in children's education so that they can grow up with that knowledge and appreciation and, importantly, without the prejudice that regrettably we still see exhibited by many adults. An understanding of the history of the dispossession of the Aboriginal people must surely bring an understanding of their present position of disadvantage. On that understanding can be built a resolve and activity to end that situation.

As parliamentarians, we have a special responsibility to back policies to address past and present disadvantage through the implementation of, for example, the national Aboriginal health strategy. In order to do this, we need the support of State governments and local government bodies. All this depends, at least in part, on the total electorate being more aware of the needs and rights of Aboriginal and Islander Australians. We must support the passage of this Bill in the Senate and then continue to take an interest in and show support for the work of the Council.

I can think of no better way to celebrate our real 100th birthday as a nation in the year 2001 than to have achieved a measure of reconciliation between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. I believe that this Bill is a strong step towards that goal and I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat hesitant to speak on the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991, and I did think twice about doing so. But the Opposition does strongly support this measure as an all-party piece of legislation. I was hesitant because although in my lifetime I have lived in four States of Australia and the Australian Capital Territory-I now live in Tasmania-I have rarely known many Aboriginals at all, so I feel singularly unqualified to speak on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in my past I had a role model-a fine Aboriginal man who taught me to ride a pony when I was a very small girl. When I was a university student, I was a member of the student representative council at the Melbourne University when Aboriginal scholarships were introduced for the first time. We students raised money to establish the first Aboriginal university scholarships. Margaret Valadian and one young man whose name I cannot remember were the first recipients of those Aboriginal scholarships. I am glad that I had a tiny part in making that possible. Now, many more Aboriginal people go to university. As a Liberal, I am proud of the fact that Senator Neville Bonner was a Liberal Aboriginal senator in this place before I was elected. I have always had high regard for Charlie Perkins, who was a role model for many Aborigines in Australia.

Those people are not why I am speaking today, although I think of them with honour. I have responsibility in the Opposition for assisting Dr Hewson in the status of women portfolio. To do that more effectively and knowledgeably, this year I have paid a succession of visits to the Northern Territory and central Australia to try to make myself better informed about Aboriginal women in rural Australia. I hope to make myself better informed shortly about women's issues in urban and semi-urban regions of Australia. I am very grateful to my colleague Senator Tambling for facilitating my visits in the Territory. I visited a number of communities, all very different, some more remote than others. In none of those communities have I ever heard of a wish for apartheid.

It is only when I go home to Tasmania and hear Michael Mansell speak that I begin to wonder whether there are any others like him who seem to have an appetite for separate development. As an Australian, I am glad to think that the Aboriginals that I have met so far have expressed no such wish at all.

I recognise that there are special pressures on the Northern Territory and on those States which have large Aboriginal populations-pressures which we in States which have small Aboriginal populations do not face and, therefore, do not well understand. I recognise that those who have large communities in urban situations have different problems to cope with, but I always believe that there is a need for Aboriginals to have participation in the full, wider Australian community.

As I say, I do not profess to come here with answers, or even with much knowledge at all, but I do come here with messages. Only last week I was sitting with women in the desert in central Australia. They said to me so urgently, `Take a message to Canberra for us. We want you to take a message to Canberra. Help us to help our men and our sons'. Of course, that does not mean to say that they were not concerned about themselves and their daughters, but they are so concerned about their men and their sons because in some communities they are concerned about kava; in most communities they are concerned about alcohol abuse; and in some communities they are concerned about petrol sniffing, particularly by the boys.

In the community I visited last week, the women had formed themselves into a night patrol. They were told that there was no money for uniforms for their night patrol. They felt it was important that they be seen to have some official capacity and, therefore, they thought uniforms were appropriate. So they set to and raised the money in order for this group of older women to have `night patrol' embroidered on their uniform dress. They spend their evenings patrolling their community to see whether illegal drinking is taking place because that community has banned alcohol altogether. Where they find alcohol being consumed they report it to the police and normal action takes place. It is a bit like our Neighbourhood Watch, I guess, but with special emphasis on their special needs.

In that community they spoke to me about their need for a refuge for women from violence brought about by drink. In another community I visited, the women talked about the women's centre that they had already established, and the need to put a high fence around it so that men could not get in when under the influence of drink and attack their women who had run to the refuge for protection. They were setting up a system of putting an older woman on duty each night in the women's refuge in order to protect the younger women seeking refuge, but they felt even that was not enough and they needed a high fence as well.

Women were telling me about those things. They told me also about their concerns that, because of the addiction of a number of their men to alcohol, these men were now refusing to go bush and take the young men with them. Not only was alcohol debilitating the men, but it was also preventing the young men and boys from learning of their culture and their tribal skills. The young men were also growing up with role models of men who were continually under the influence.

In every community women spoke about the lack of jobs and their despair at what would happen to their young men and women without the hope that employment brings. They do not seem to have any satisfaction at all from being able to draw a welfare cheque. They want work for their young people. They very proudly showed me the artwork and the crafts that they did. They showed me how it was done and in some places it was extremely well displayed. They are also now able to turn some of these skills into very good economic value for their communities. Some of the work I saw was beautiful.

I visited a training centre at Nungalinya in Darwin. I think it is a theological college, but a special program is being run under the auspices of that college that is not related to the theological part of it. In this program, women from all over northern Australia-from the Torres Strait Islands, the Kimberley and throughout the Territory-are brought in for a year. From a community a woman is chosen who has some quality of leadership which will enable her, once she gets extra skills, to go back and act as a leader for other women in her community.

The women spend a year away from home and for some of them that is extremely difficult because they suffer great pangs of homesickness. I think they get home once or twice during that year. A number of them, of course, are mothers and that can provide difficulties, too, with them either bringing their children with them or leaving them back home with a grandmother. During that year, literacy and numeracy skills are supported and encouraged. What is very interesting to me is that small business skills are developed so that the art and the crafts, which they produce so well, can be turned to good effect, and so that they have the business management ability to make sure that their goods are costed properly, they can keep proper records and apply for financial assistance for capital, where needed. They also receive training in health and nutrition.

They find great value in learning of each other's culture because they tend to live in communities where they do not have access to communities hundreds of miles away. The women I spoke to found it extremely valuable to learn what others cooked, what sort of paintings they did, what songs they sang and even what jokes they told. As I say, they go back to their people at the end of the year to be leaders amongst the women in their community.

Only recently, I read in a Territory newspaper that one of the major companies-I cannot remember whether it was a petrol company but it might have been Esso; Senator Tambling might recall-had voted some money to help this training scheme to continue, because the women do live on a very small financial allocation. The program seems to me to be very effective and the women are very pleased with it.

I want to reflect for a moment on the well-meaning actions of the past. There have been so many attempts over the years by white Australians to do what they thought was the right thing at the time to help Aboriginals, but so many of them have reaped most unfortunate-certainly unplanned-results. I am thinking about, for example, the changes to the stockman's pay in the 1960s. We would all recognise that a person is entitled to a fair pay for a fair day's work. The changes to the stockman's pay was seen to be a matter of equity-no doubt it was-and yet, certainly in the Territory, it has very clearly led to a great loss of jobs and, in many instances, to a loss of the health and welfare support which many families received on the stations.

Another change that has not all been for the good has been the review by the churches of their involvement in Aboriginal work. Although I recognise that in the past there have been some communities where missionaries perhaps or the churches have had patronising attitudes, the caring role of the missionaries has diminished since that review. What is not widely recognised, perhaps, is how important the role of the church was-particularly the Catholic Church, I understand-in enhancing the status of women in some communities.

I know that might be surprising, because sometimes we think that the Catholic Church has not been all that great for the status of women in some white countries. But I understand that in earlier days a bishop in the Territory bought women brides and was then able to free up those women to become wives in love marriages which, of course, gave them a special status. The examples of the nuns as women in positions of authority in the schools and the hospitals has also been very valuable for a number of Aboriginal women.

Another well-meaning action in the past, which I think had some appalling results, was the removal of children to be placed in white foster homes, as Senator Zakharov mentioned earlier. I spoke to one woman who for 20 years knew nothing of her mother, and only now that she is a grandmother herself is she able to share the joy of her children and her grandchildren with her own mother. Some people never found their families again and grew up in a half world where they did not have access to their cultural ties.

Another well-meaning action, if you like, was when Aboriginals were in fact allowed to drink alcohol freely. That certainly means equality with other Australians but the unplanned result is the ghastly problem which is being grappled with now by so many of the communities.

Lastly I mention health care and social security payments, which are obviously so important and so vital for all Australians, but where there are people in remote communities, especially if they have been nomadic people, the requirement to stay in one place to have access to some of these services means that they are losing their traditional ways of living and their survival skills.

I do not want to concentrate on the past. Today is a time for looking to the future. The Council for Reconciliation is a positive exercise, and we must look to what can be done in the future. I do not think stacks of money is the answer. Money is important but there have been billions of dollars spent in the past, much of which has been wasted by both blacks and whites.

This is a Council for Reconciliation, as I say, but sometimes I think it could have been better named a council for understanding. We need to concentrate on things which we see are fair and equitable for all Australians because the problems being faced in Aboriginal communities are frequently the same as those faced by all Australians. They may have different ways of decision making and of approaching their problems, but they are problems-especially for women-that we face all around the country.

What are the basics which we must insist that all Aboriginal people share with us? I believe that all Australians need a legal system which protects Aborigines no less than we are protected. They need health services which will allow them to raise their children to good, healthy adulthood. They need to be able to look after their elderly. I believe, above all, that all Australians need education if they are to break out of a cycle of disadvantage. It is doubly important if Aboriginals are to cope with the two cultures in which they live.

When I say education, I mean both formal school education and cultural education. For one reason or another many Aboriginal children are not spending enough time in school and are missing out on the chance to break out of their disadvantage. As I mentioned earlier, many of them are also starting to miss out on their cultural education.

Aboriginal children also need role models. In the past Aboriginal soldiers and footballers were important role models. Aboriginals still have sports and military skills. But they need other role models-cultural and artistic ones, and tertiary graduates. I look forward keenly to the day when we see white advisers moving aside and handing over to qualified Aboriginals.

As I said at the beginning, I am only a newcomer to these issues. I do not profess to have expertise, but I do speak today to fulfil a promise which I made to the women in the Northern Territory. They asked me to carry a message to Canberra. They asked me to tell of their worry about the grog. They want that to be widely known. They want Canberra to know about the violence that that grog brings and of the example it gives to the young of the way adults live, thus perpetuating the problem. It helps to keep their children from school; it is reducing the nourishment available to those children and it is affecting their health. It is causing a lack of self-esteem in the communities.

The women are trying all sorts of measures to deal with that problem. They are trying to prevent their boys taking to alcohol and petrol sniffing but they are having great difficulties. They need support and understanding. I am told that the hope for the future lies with the women. On every hand I have been told that-by the women themselves, by white advisers, and by bureaucrats. Everybody says that the hope for the future lies with the women. Those women I have met so far in the Northern Territory have impressed me with their clear-eyed assessments of their communities and of the need for action from within the communities. I have only begun to learn from Aboriginal women so that I can work with my colleague, the shadow Minister for Aboriginal affairs, Dr Wooldridge.

As we said, we support the Council for Reconciliation. We do not want to spend the time, however, in warm, woolly goodwill. We look very earnestly to the important strategic plans outlined in the legislation. We look for practical achievements in reconciliation. The first step must surely be, however, for those of us who have not had contact with Aboriginals, to make sure that we learn and thereby understand. We are one nation and we will all share our achievements as we share our problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to make a contribution to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991. I do not want to canvass the broad issues which other speakers have covered. I do not want to run over a whole litany of the goods and bads from times past. I do want to make a couple of points, though.

SPEECH.PARA: One point is reconciliation, and what reconciliation might mean. It is an interesting word. I looked it up in the dictionary and it seemed to say, `To encourage opposing views to get to be at one', or sentiments along those lines. It is a curiously interesting definition of reconciliation. It seems to describe differences and getting to a position of togetherness, but it does not mention the process of reconciliation. That process is not contained in the definition. I would have thought that if we were serious in addressing this Bill we would need to understand that process of reconciliation. In some ways the contents of the Bill try to address that, and in one important way I suspect they might have missed it.

Other things which are not written into the legislation come under the heading of reconciliation. By the way, I would say too that I find it curious that it is called the Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill. I suppose it is not an unreasonable title, but who are the Aboriginal people being reconciled to or with? It really ought to have a title like the Australian Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill. I do not like the inference that the Aboriginal people are to be reconciled. To my way of thinking the other side of that reconciliation equation is implicit, but it would be better stated.

Another dimension which is important to reconciliation is the notion of forgiveness.
