We are dealing here in particular with the importance of white people forgiving themselves for the sins committed by their forebears. The history of white people in this country is utterly disgraceful in large areas. It is a matter of the current generation of Australians learning that history. We cannot afford to keep sweeping it under the carpet or out of view. We have to bring that history into the full light of day. We have to confront it and we have to forgive ourselves for being part of it.

I think it is also very important that we do not then become confused about guilt that should be ascribed to people from two and three generations ago. But we have to appreciate the process of forgiveness that has to be gone through. I do not believe we can move to a satisfactory reconciliation without admitting that those things happened and without going through the process of acknowledging and appreciating it and forgiving ourselves for it-or our parents and grandparents-because that forgiveness is part of a healing process that is necessary before we can satisfactorily work together or achieve reconciliation.

I think a lot of people in this country have to confront issues such as shame, anger and responsibility. It is not only black people who might want to be angry; there are many white people who might want to be very angry. I think we have to allow an opportunity for people, both black and white, in this country to confront that anger. Until we acknowledge it and confront it, I think it has the chance to fester and bubble up from time to time and prevent an adequate process of reconciliation. Under the heading `Functions', clause 6(1) (b) states:
6.(1) The functions of the Council are:

(b) to promote, by leadership, education and discussion, a deeper understanding by all Australians of the history, cultures, past dispossession and continuing disadvantage of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders and of the need to redress that disadvantage . . .

I am very concerned about that definition of a function, because it is easily able to be read in terms of the history of disadvantage, the history of evils done and the history of injuries, dispossession and crime against Aboriginal people. In that definition I do not see a strong enough urging for a recognition of the greatness, wisdom and understanding of Aboriginal people.

We sometimes refer to Aboriginal culture as though it is all we need to know to understand the strengths and values of Aboriginal people. One of the things that sometimes makes me very angry is the loss of information and wisdom that we have suffered because we did not know-did not want to know-that black people in this country had things to tell us, whether that was in the late eighteenth century or the nineteenth century.

I almost suspect it was not until we invented the Bush Tucker Man that we understood that Aboriginal people knew how to feed themselves. That is a bit flippant, but I do not think it is too remote from the truth. People have marvelled at how Aborigines survived for 50,000 years, as though it were something that was rained on them. That these ridiculously insufficient people could have survived for 50,000 years never seemed to challenge white people or suggest that the Aborigines were a wise people who had a lot of skills and information.

In learning the history of Aboriginal people, I hope that we do not confine it to the history of white people's ills against Aboriginal people, but that we make sure history addresses the culture, stories, legends, strengths, wisdom and knowledge of Aboriginal people. The very best way for us to be reconciled is to appreciate the qualities of Aboriginal people. For many years it has been pointed out that the Aboriginal people had no qualities and, in many cases, were less than human-they were sub-normal-so we did not have to regard them with the same respect. That is the kind of attitude and history that we have to undo. In looking at that history, I hope we do not focus only on the litany of disadvantage and dispossession. They are vital for us to know, but they are really for us to know about ourselves. I think we must make sure that we honour and learn Aboriginal history. I hope that is powerfully told by this legislation. When I first read that definition, I did not feel that the words, which would encourage a good story to be told about Aboriginal people, preferably by themselves, were said strongly enough.

I raise a couple of points that I think we have to appreciate. I was delighted that Senator Newman thought that the Catholic Church might have advantaged women by having bishops buying black women. I wish she had told the whole story-it sounds wonderful-about the Catholic bishop who buys Aboriginal women. I think this is to redeem them from planned marriages. Let us hope that the Senate and all those listening are fully aware of the whole story because, at the moment, this bishop has an exciting reputation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is dead.

—Presumably, he was alive when he was doing the buying. I am delighted that there might be some ways in which we could look at any church-Catholic, Protestant or of whatever ilk-in this country that did anything honourable for women. It is not the history of christianity over the last 200 years. One of the really sad things is that both the church history and the colonial history of white male superiority has been perpetrated in this country. Women, even white women, know the struggle we have had to get fair recognition of the rights of women in this country. One certainly would not want to have the double disadvantage of being Aboriginal and a woman.

SPEECH.PARA: While I am not going to object or totally oppose Senator Newman's conclusions, I am glad there was one stunning exception to the general rule. Women, in particular, were foully abused, and Aboriginal women were more foully abused, as white male supremists ran this country to their preferred view.

It is very interesting to examine, for example, why children were removed from Aboriginal communities. It would be very interesting to know the parentage of the children who were removed. Very often the children who were removed were the children of white fathers and black mothers. A lot of people have not wanted to face up to that fact. These were not full-blooded Aboriginal children who were removed from their reservations, they were half-castes. It is a history of appalling abuse of black women and the further appalling abuse of denying them their children. We have seen, and are now able to read, the stories written by some of those children. I do not suppose that there are any better written than the stories of Sally Morgan about the consequences and the damage done to those children.

I have met Aboriginal women in South Australia who are not fearfully old. They can show me the cards they were asked to carry-indeed, were required to carry-that exempted them from being Aboriginal so that they could be employed and paid white rates for house cleaning and that kind of work. But to enter into the paid work force, they had to have a card-a certificate, a little booklet-issued to them that exempted them from being Aboriginal.

We have committed most appalling crimes against Aboriginal people, and we have done that with very little self-awareness of what we were doing, not only to Aboriginal people but also to ourselves. Some of those battles for the rights of people, black or white, and the rights of women, I think, mean that this reconciliation Bill has the prospect of allowing some very constructive and useful reappraisal of past history. We have very little to be comfortable about.

In conclusion, I support the intention of this legislation. We admit to our consciousness the importance of appreciating the contribution of Aboriginal people; more particularly, their rights to be full Australian citizens. We have dispossessed them of those rights, and now, in returning some of those rights to Aboriginal people, we have to acknowledge the part played in that by white people. As I said earlier, I think that is a very necessary step before full reconciliation can proceed.

I also suggest that it may be a journey of fairly exciting discovery because, in learning about Aboriginal culture and history, people in Australia, black and white, will only be the richer for that knowledge. This Bill will help us to understand that Aboriginal people are not of one type but are as varied and as many as the Aboriginal communities around this country. It will also allow us to focus on the sorts of ways Aboriginal people ask for assistance. If we have learnt anything, it is that until people are in a position to campaign for their own rights those rights cannot be given.

The history of Aboriginal reserves, cultures or groups in respect of alcohol in this country is probably a very illustrative case in point. Sometimes these groups were denied access to alcohol and had dry areas, and so on. That denial was done at best as benevolent paternalism and at worst as a number of other things that we could describe as oppressive or whatever.

These measures were never satisfactory. People do not do well by being denied the right to make their own choices. The fact that in the end people may choose wrongly is their right. We have seen the culture change so that Aboriginal people could choose to have alcohol or alcohol was no longer forbidden to them. They have come to face the fact that, for many of them, alcohol is a very destructive and fatal drug. It is now very interesting to see Aboriginal people making the decision that alcohol is destructive for them and that they want to make decisions about how much and what access they have to it. That is the way to sanity, good health and proper government, and that is what Aboriginal people have been denied for some 200 years.

I would have thought it would be splendid if this reconciliation Bill could clear the deck absolutely of any of those repressions or areas where Aboriginal people are not able to make decisions for themselves. When those decision making processes can be more aligned with the decision making processes of everybody else in this country-that is, the more we are one-the more that will be a constructive outcome of this Bill. I commend the idea behind the Bill. It is a fairly challenging concept to introduce something like a conciliation Bill. If this is a step that will allow a healing process between white and black in this country, it should be approved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As my Party predecessor in this debate, Senator Kernot, has already pointed out, the Australian Democrats strongly support, and always have, the idea of the conclusion of an instrument of reconciliation between the indigenous and non-indigenous people of Australia. During the debate on the ATSIC legislation, we deliberately removed the preamble from that Bill to ensure that this process was given a much more prominent place in the process of reconciliation.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I have some reservations about the wording of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill 1991 and some of the directions which it seems to me that the wording indicates the Government is taking. As Senator Crowley and other speakers have pointed out, Aboriginal people have been in Australia for a very long time. The estimates vary, but a figure of 40,000 to 50,000 years is not at all unusual.

In recent years, we-and I say `we' in the sense of the white, predominantly European culture in this country-have recognised the need to move our whole cultural system towards what we have come to call sustainability. We recognise a system of attitudes to the use of resources such as land and the exploitation of people and the environment. If we can regard that as the total cultural system within which the dominant culture in Australia operates, we have come to recognise that that system is not sustainable, that we are heading for destruction and degradation in the quality of life of our children and our descendants. If we cast around for an example of a culture which did contain the notion of, and understood the requirement for, sustainability and which did preserve, albeit with some significant changes-I am not denying that-a cultural understanding deeply embedded at its roots, we need look no further than the indigenous culture of Australia, our own Aboriginal culture.

In dealing with this question of reconciliation, it seemed to me for some time that it is not simply a matter of saying to Aboriginal people, `We are sorry for what has happened in the last 200 years. Come across, for we now accept you into full citizenship. You can become a part of our predominant culture society'. It must become more a process by which we discover the mechanisms by which we weld together those elements of the Aboriginal culture and other elements of the dominant European culture and build a totally new culture. To my mind, that is what reconciliation needs to be about.

The introductory clause of this legislation begins with the word `because' and refers to how Australia was occupied by Aborigines, et cetera, for thousands of years. It also talks about their dispossession, and so on. Part (d) states:

as a part of the reconciliation process, the Commonwealth will seek an ongoing national commitment from governments at all levels to co-operate and to co-ordinate with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission as appropriate to address progressively Aboriginal disadvantage and aspirations in relation to land, housing, law and justice, cultural heritage, education, employment, health, infrastructure, economic development and any other relevant matters in the decade leading to the centenary of Federation, 2001:

I am suspicious that those words are based yet again on the notion that what we have to do is simply welcome, at long last, Aboriginal people into white society so that they become, as it were, like us. If that is the basis of this process which we are putting in train, not only will it fail but also it will fail the majority of the Australian population because it will have failed to pick up that essential quality of Aboriginal culture which allowed it to survive in this country for 50,000 years and which attitude is absolutely necessary for the dominant, white, exploitative, market driven, competitive culture to adopt.

If we do not, we have lost a marvellous opportunity. As I have said earlier, we will leave a damaged world to our children. But if we do choose this alternative path towards reconciliation, then in the process we will be saying to Aboriginal people, `We recognise that within your culture you have something which is supremely valuable, so valuable that it is necessary that it be shared and built into a new culture and shared by every person and every process in this country. We need to become a lot more like you, not you like us'. In doing that, we will really be giving back to Aboriginal people the dignity and the respect which we have taken from them progressively over the last 200 years.

Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, like most indigenous people throughout the world, developed a culture which was dependent on a specific relationship with land and with the natural environment. It was a factor which resulted in a more caring, indeed a spiritual, relationship in these cultures which is not shared by the industrial societies which have come to look on the natural environment as a commodity merely to be traded for profit. One needs only to look in our newspapers each weekend to see how land has simply become a commodity. One can contrast the growing price of land with the Aboriginal attitude, which was no different from that of most other indigenous people around the world. It was indeed the attitude which our own forebears had to land for many tens, and possibly millions, of years. It is an attitude that we need to rediscover. If reconciliation is to be achieved, I believe the process must include the explicit recognition of this difference and, on the part of the non-indigenous population, the recognition of the legitimacy and the value of this central element of indigenous culture.

This does not mean merely a recognition of land rights, although, of course, this is important. It means a mind shift in mainstream Australian thinking. Bringing about this mind shift is a task which I suggested first at the time of the Bicentenary. It is a mind shift which I have already indicated is necessary if proper reconciliation is to occur. I would suggest that, while the successful negotiation of an instrument of reconciliation is an important step, it is only the first step. One of the keys to the survival of industrial civilisation is to be found in the special relationship which Aboriginal and Islander people had with the natural environment. The conscious acknowledgment of the value of what these old Australians can bring to this new culture-this integrated culture-would seal the process of reconciliation.

I wish to make one final point before I sit down. Successive statements by government, particularly the Labor Government in recent years, have spoken of the original occupiers and owners of this land being dispossessed and dispersed without compensation. When I was responsible for the portfolio of Aboriginal Affairs, I travelled quite extensively around Australia and spoke to Aboriginal and Islander groups. I frequently asked them the question, `Have you ever been consulted as to your attitude to bringing more people into Australia?'. As far as I can determine, the indigenous people of this country have never-I repeat, never-been consulted as to whether they want more people to be brought in.

It is quite clear that expressions of concern about dispossession are meaningless-in fact, they are dishonest-if that dispossession is continued without consultation. The present immigration program represents an extension of dispossession for three reasons. The first is the lack of consultation to which I have already referred. The second is based on the general proposition that, if all of Australia is owned by all Australians, the larger the number of non-indigenous Australians the smaller the proportion of Australia nominally owned by the indigenous people-and that is simply a mathematical calculation. Thirdly, and most importantly, the economic emphasis in the present immigration program-especially the business migration and skills migration parts of that program-means bringing into this country people who are inimical to Aboriginal culture and to the synthesis of the two cultures to which I have been referring.

I have an indelible memory of an interview with one very rich American immigrant who had bought a large pastoral property in the Northern Territory. When he was asked the reasons why he came to Australia, he gave as his primary reason, and I am quoting him as best I know, `You know how to treat your niggers in this country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now you are smearing all Americans. You are astonishing.

—I felt sickened that we were bringing such people into Australia and, through the transfer of wealth, according them considerable power to influence the economic and cultural direction of this country. I am interested in Senator Tate's interjection. I suggest to him that, under the present immigration laws, if there were a person identical in every respect to an Aboriginal person who was outside this country, that person would not be admitted as an immigrant to Australia. That to my mind indicates the culturist nature of the immigration program.

SPEECH.PARA: We are deliberately selecting people who have shown an exploitative tendency and whom we believe will fit in more vigorously with the mainstream, competitive, market driven, environmentally damaging approach to economic development. We are discouraging the alternative sorts of people, those who care for the environment. In fact, understanding or care of the environment has never been a factor in our selection of immigrants. It seems to me also that in this attitude to immigration, the way in which we select people, we are simply saying to the Aboriginal people, `We do not respect your culture. Your culture has nothing to give to a new and sustainable Australian culture. You must become like us. We are simply going to bring more people in who are like us to dominate this country'.

We need to overcome that attitude. We need, as I have said, to be able to say to Aboriginal people, `You do have within your culture something which is supremely valuable, without which none of us will survive into the distant future'. We need to make that element central to a new culture. That is the path to sustainability. We can do it by recognition of the value of Aboriginal culture, and that process will give back to Aboriginal people a dignity and a pride in what they are contributing to an Australia which, hopefully, will be here not just for our children and our grandchildren but also for our descendants well into the very distant future. If we do not do that, if we simply see reconciliation as making Aboriginal people clones of white European Australians, I think we will have lost a very valuable opportunity to the detriment of everybody, and not only will this legislation have failed but we will have failed to take up the opportunity to build a truly sustainable society in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill. The coalition is supporting this legislation as a genuine attempt to achieve what it says, a better understanding between Aboriginal and other Australians. We do, however, acknowledge that it has been amended to recognise some very proper concerns that the coalition has raised.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, it is important that a positive note be struck in place of the emphasis on failure and grievance that may gladden the hearts of the trendy middle class, so often over-represented in our structures of government, but does nothing to secure a better understanding between ordinary Australians. Thus, I believe it is essential that clause 5 refer to the appreciation of Aboriginal culture and achievements in place of earlier stress on dispossession and disadvantage.

It is equally important that the functions of the Council enumerated in clause 6 refer also to the wider Australian community and the need for any final document to benefit the Australian community as a whole. That is a real start. It is a positive note, and it is the first time we have actually seen that type of statement in regard to this issue.

For too long such a recognition has quite clearly been absent from the policies of the Hawke Labor Government. It is extremely important to me particularly, as a Western Australian senator, that under clause 6(2) (c) the Council is directed to consult the State and Territory governments, because quite often we see attempts by this Government to override the wishes of the States and the Territories, when in fact it should be the ultimate decision of the States and Territories as to what they impose on their people. Failure in the past to extend real cooperation to State governments that continue to provide so many basic services to Aboriginal people has resulted only in wasteful duplication and divisive policies.

I also very much welcome the fact that a sunset clause ensures that the Act will terminate at the end of the decade. The last thing that we need in the field of Aboriginal affairs is yet another self-perpetuating structure. On the other hand, I must voice certain reservations about this Bill. In the preamble, item (b) refers to `dispossession and dispersal from their traditional lands by the British Crown'. Again, there is a reference in clause 6(b) to promoting, inter alia, understanding of `past dispossession' of Aboriginals.

I am concerned not so much about arguing the facts of history as about the potential for these statements, when taken out of context, to be used in justification of a future campaign for some kind of national land rights legislation. It has been made quite clear to me over a very long period of time that the people in Western Australia simply do not want any form of land rights and will not countenance governments superimposing land rights over property in their State. I think it is important that this Government recognise that now, because it has had plenty of opportunity to know and understand the feelings of the people in Western Australia, and to date has not done so.

Land rights have been a most divisive feature of policy debate over the past decade, and I can assure the Senate that the concept of enforcing such a policy is, as I say, totally and utterly non-negotiable and unacceptable to the people of Western Australia.

I note that, if the Council is to have between 15 and 25 members, with a minimum of 12 Aboriginal and two Torres Strait Islander members, there may not be a great deal of scope for many non-Aboriginal community representatives. The Council will not succeed if these people are not representative of the general community, and we will not do Aboriginal Australians any favours whatsoever, in the short or long term, if these appointees are known to be biased in favour of land rights and against mining, or are people with uncritical acceptance of radical Aboriginal viewpoints.

Knowing the sorts of views that those appointed by the Labor Party and the Democrats are likely to hold, I have a very grave concern that the Council may be saddled with some predictable views that are out of sympathy with the great mass of Australians, who have a very genuine concern to see Aboriginals improve their conditions but who are properly wary of trends to separatist approaches and the overriding of development in the national interest.

We are seeing that time and time again with this Government: it takes the side of lobby groups to prevent the advancement of development, which development of course will create more employment at a time when we are facing dramatic levels of unemployment. Only last week did we see more mining being struck down by this Government in the interests of minority groups.

All we can do in the Senate today is approve the best possible structure. We must not confuse a consultative mechanism with outcomes. Nonetheless, no Australians can be more conscious than those in the western third of the continent as to the need to bring Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians together.

Western Australians in the city, as well as those in rural and remote areas, do not need to be told that there are massive problems that manifest themselves in alcohol abuse and juvenile crime. What concerns me when I visit the north-west of my State is that I see so many Aboriginal people who are simply having money thrown at them to resolve their problems, in preference to constructive measures being taken to better their lot and to ensure their health, their housing, their education and better lifestyles.

Aborigines do not need to be told about supposed white guilt, but they do want positive solutions that will bring them into the general community as self-respecting, participating members. There will be no reconciliation so long as extreme activists are given support and credibility in the structures of government in taking action that harms the economic future of the State and nation. To put it bluntly, no reconciliation can be achieved when a Labor Government makes a decision such as that affecting mining at Coronation Hill, when a quite clearly divided response from Aboriginals becomes the means to deliver a promise to the green lobby to the detriment of the economy and the creation of jobs for all Australians.

The Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will begin to succeed in its objective only if it is prepared to take a stand against extreme Aboriginal activists and their supporters on matters where Aboriginals are divided and where there is a clear community interest under threat. It is always tragic to go to these areas and see some of the white activists who are really looking after themselves-No. 1-and the interests of the Aboriginals come a very poor last. Yet it is invariably the white activists, not the interests of the Aboriginal communities, to whom the Government listens first.

The redress of Aboriginal disadvantage in the areas of employment and economic development, noted in the preamble to the Bill, cannot proceed if necessary projects, supported by many Aboriginals, can be blocked by a voracious sacred site industry. The prime example is the controversy in the Eastern Gold Fields of Western Australia regarding the Yakabindie nickel project, which the Ngalia Heritage Research Council and the Swan Valley Fringe Dwellers are seeking to block, claiming that sacred sites will be affected.

However, it must be noted that this is only part of the story. On Saturday at Wiluna, a meeting of local Aboriginals, who best know where the sacred sites are, gave their unanimous approval to the Yakabindie project provided that they received some of the jobs that would be created and which were guaranteed by Dominion Mining. That is not an unreasonable request. But what has happened?

To my mind, reconciliation and cooperation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians is epitomised by the reported remarks of Kalgoorlie businessman Don Green when he addressed the meeting. He said:
Aborigines are still living and sleeping in the dirt when they could benefit from mining.

They are his words, not mine. That very clearly states the position. Again at Leonora on Tuesday, another meeting of local Aboriginal people affirmed support for the project, condemned the Aboriginal Legal Service for its failure to consult with traditional elders and rejected the need for any further anthropological research.

This $350m project will supply 3 per cent of the western world's nickel and cobalt requirements and generate essential foreign exchange for Australia. Surely that is important, but it is not considered important by this Government. What is most relevant to this debate is that development of this kind can benefit Aboriginals and will be welcomed by them without the sacrifice of their cultural values. If that is so-and it is-why does this Government still refuse to act on these projects?

Reconciliation depends upon improving the economic circumstances of Aboriginal Australians. The process is directly threatened when a professional activist such as Bob Bropho seeks to interfere with the beliefs and interests of Aboriginals hundreds of kilometres from his area and gets the uncritical support of Senator Vallentine, who is not even here to put her case and has not been seen in the Parliament this week.

Senator Vallentine should listen to the advice given her by Mr Stephen Sprigg, who just happens to be President of the Kalgoorlie South Division of the Liberal Party. He urged her to speak with those local people who understood the issues rather than `siding with the radical misinformed losers'. Mr Sprigg is desperate to see the lot of the Aboriginal communities improved. He is encouraging Senator Vallentine to speak with them and understand the issues. She chooses not to do so. Should the Hawke Labor Government take action that impedes the project, it will be making the same mistake and giving the same wrong signals.

We will never achieve understanding, and the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation will be wasting its time, if the Mansells and the Brophos are effectively given licence to appropriate the beliefs of other Aboriginals in order to impose their own agenda. That is what concerns me. These people, particularly Mr Mansell, who is more white than I am in summertime, is given more credence as to what Aboriginal people want than the Aborigines themselves.

Non-Aboriginal Australians acknowledge the need for special assistance to remedy disadvantage. They may think it reasonable for accommodations to be made for undisputed Aboriginal sites. What Western Australian people will not tolerate is the trashing of social and economic development that benefits Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians alike at the behest of a radical minority that includes many non-Aboriginals.

In conclusion, the coalition, as I stated at the beginning, supports the objective of a council that works towards understanding and reconciliation at a community level. Much will depend on the personnel of the Council and their willingness to take a view that is squarely based upon economic reality. It must be recognised that hostility to economic growth constitutes a condemnation of Aboriginals to poverty and dependence. If this attitude continues to prevail the Council will achieve nothing.

I hope that this will not be just another bureaucracy. I hope that this is not just throwing more money at the problem and resolving nothing. It continues to concern me that when visiting areas such as the Gold Fields, Pilbara and particularly the Kimberley, we see more and more structures and offices being set up. Whether they be the Aboriginal Legal Service or the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission-this, that or whatever-they all relate to the Aboriginal community but they are not really improving their living conditions.

We are spending more and more taxpayers' money without changing anything. I sincerely hope that this will not be a further extension of that, that this piece of legislation will achieve what we hope it will and that the Aboriginal communities and the non-Aboriginal Australians can get on with improving Australia generally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill for the establishment of the Council of Aboriginal Reconciliation. I am also happy to support the preamble to the Bill as it speaks of addressing progressively Aboriginal disadvantage and aspirations in relation to land, housing, law and justice, cultural heritage, education, employment, health, infrastructure, economic development and other matters relevant in the next decade as part of that reconciliation process.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is a land of very great diversity and natural wealth. Part of this diversity and wealth is its peoples-all of them, no matter what their background. As a nation we must give the opportunities to progress and proceed by providing incentive and encouragement. As a Liberal I am committed to the individual and opportunity. I want to encourage all Australians to excel and to succeed. That success and excellence is a subjective term; it is in the eye of the beholder. I suppose it means happiness and contentment-satisfaction with one's lot.

But human beings cannot be happy and contented and achieve success if they are plagued by lack of opportunity, poor health, inadequate or unsuitable education, inappropriate housing, and lack of investment, which might produce long term economic problems. But, more importantly, human beings cannot be happy and contented if they lack self-esteem; if they are continually and historically treated as being different.

That is why I, along with my colleagues, support the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Bill in the hope that the operation and functions of the Council will achieve a oneness and unity for all Australians and go a long way to understanding disadvantaged groups in the community and rectifying those disadvantages so that all Australians have the same opportunities; so that there is an appreciation by all Australians-whether they be white or black, old immigrants or new immigrants-that we are one nation and that we must work together for our collective good.

I mention an encounter I had recently in Cairns with a group of Aborigines who were giving evidence to the Senate inquiry into satellite communications. That group of Aborigines said that we could not take their land at Temple Bay simply to bail Australia out of the economic mess which, as they said, `You got us into'. But I pointed out to those Aboriginals that I had not got them into the mess and that I say the same things to this Government; the Government got us into this mess and now it is taxing us to get us out of it.

I said to those Aborigines, `You are a proud people; you don't want to spend the rest of their lives getting government hand-outs. Don't you want to create employment in the areas of Cape York so that your children can get worthwhile employment and gain the self-esteem and self-respect that comes with not being on hand-outs all the time?'. Those people agreed with me. They do see lack of opportunities and lack of employment as a real curse for their children. They are coming to the realisation that opportunities must be provided in those areas so that their children can have the employment and, therefore, achieve the self-esteem to which they, and all other Australians, are entitled.

I recognise that in the past some Australians have committed horrific acts against other Australians. But I do not have any personal guilt about those actions. I am sorry that they occurred; I regret the way things have happened to all Australians who have been disadvantaged or who have had these things happen to them. I recognise the disadvantage that may have occurred in many parts of Australia and I want to lessen and-if possible in this imperfect world-eliminate completely all of that disadvantage for all Australians.

But I think that the separate development actions of the past in relation to Aboriginal and Islander people have been wrong, and I submit that they have been shown to be wrong. I look to the potential of the future, not to the blame of the past. I look forward to a day when there will be no need for special legislation or special rules for any group of Australians, when no group of Australians will be disadvantaged by reason of race, religion, origin or background.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are as diverse as any other group of Australians. It is often said that the people of Victoria are different from the people of Queensland. What a very boring and, I might say, very poor place it would be if we were all like Victorians. Similarly, the Aborigines and Islanders are as diverse as their geographical origins and residences. We must never fall into the trap of thinking that city-based Aborigines and Islanders are representative of, or even speak for, rural or remotebased Aboriginal and Islander people. I think it is important to recognise that the attitudes of many non-Aboriginal and non-Torres Strait Islander Australians towards Aborigines and Islanders also vary. Attitudes have been built up in the past in different places where different historical relationships have existed and been formed. That is why it is important to recognise and address the different forms that reconciliation might take.

That is why it is very important that the selection of the Council members by those entrusted with the job is done very carefully. There must be the widest possible range of members on the Council. It should not be comprised of well-meaning highly-educated city academics and social workers; there must be representatives of ordinary Australians-both Aboriginal and Islander people and non-Aboriginal and Islander people. More particularly, there must be representatives on this Council of those who have daily and permanent contact with each group in the community: those who live in close proximity to each other, those who interact and understand the needs, aspirations and prejudices of their fellow Australians-be they white, black or any shade in-between.

The group of fellow Australians of Aboriginal and Islander origin with whom I have interacted in my lifetime have the same attitudes, failings and aspirations as all other Australians. I do not think they want special treatment because of their race or origin. However, they do need a recognition of the disadvantages that they suffer and they also need solutions for those disadvantages. Special treatment for any group of Australians brings division and a feeling of separation, not integration and unity.

The disadvantage suffered by many groups of Australians manifests itself very differently in all of those different groups. I want to mention some of the disadvantages evident in places in north Queensland. Of course, I do not presume to speak in any way for other parts of the nation which I am not very familiar with, but those disadvantages do manifest themselves in different ways.

In the country towns of north Queensland one of the disadvantages is the separate existence which highlights the divisions and differences between Aboriginal and Islander Australians and other Australians. I think that matter has to be addressed. There is also a disadvantage in that many Aborigines and Islanders really desire not to be treated differently, but they are treated differently by the Government. They are subjected to different rules, different payments and different assistance, which make them stand apart from the rest of the community. I think that is wrong.

The Aboriginal and Islander people with whom I have had a lot of contact wish to have the same equal opportunities of access to the same jobs; they wish to have the same educational opportunities-and, I might add, the same educational opportunities that do not separate them, do not put them apart and do not identify them as being different.

In the cities of north Queensland, homelessness, drunkenness and domestic violence are real problems. I believe these problems arise from the fact that people are taken out of their natural environment and dumped in the cities. I think, on occasions, they have been lured into the cities with thoughts and suggestions of how they could attain happiness there, but it often does not work that way. The homelessness and drunkenness that one sees in cities really involves an enormous lack of self-esteem for those people. As I said before, all Australians must have self-esteem and a vision of the future.

In rural areas-and, again, I speak particularly of north Queensland; I am no expert, but I do have some limited knowledge-I believe that the aspirations of the Aboriginal community centre on obtaining that self-esteem. I believe the Aboriginal people as a whole recognise that, while they have an affinity with, and yearn for, the old ways, they are living in an ever-changing and modernising society which they understand they must be part of.

I believe the Aboriginal communities of Cape York are most terribly concerned about the alcohol problem. It is obviously a problem that is not natural to these Aboriginal communities; they are now grappling with this immense problem which white communities around the world have attempted to resolve all of this century. The Aboriginal communities are now just starting; they have been left with this problem and they are trying to do something about it.

I wish I had a solution to offer those communities, particularly those on the western side of the Cape, where I have been recently, as they grapple with this problem. Complete prohibition has been proposed as a solution. I wish communities with such programs well. In the western Cape York area one Aboriginal community is enforcing complete prohibition while a neighbouring community is not attempting that because it believes prohibition will not work in practice. I wish I had a solution, but I do not. That is one of the sadnesses of our society generally.

Communities are concerned to see that their children have an education and therefore opportunities to advance. The possibility of advancement is needed to give children with education some prospect of employment-and employment in the types of jobs they are happy with. Too often Aborigines and Islanders are thrown into the most menial jobs. We have to work towards getting them into employment that they are happy with and that gives them self-esteem and a prospect for the future.

An ever-increasing number of Aborigines and Islanders are taking advantage of education in Australia. Some of them have reached the very highest echelons of the employment tree in Australia. That is one of the reasons I have little hesitation in supporting projects for the Cape York area, including the space base and the extension of the alumina refinery in the Weipa area. I believe bringing those sorts of job creation projects to an area where a lot of Aborigines and Islanders live will give them employment opportunities and skills in the technical work that will be part of these new projects for northern Australia. Projects such as these provide the best long term opportunity for Aboriginal, Islander and other Australian youth to become part of the future of Australia.

Throughout Australia there is a misunderstanding of the rich culture, heritage and ability of Aboriginal and Islander people. At times, it seems to be greater in areas that have close contact with Aboriginal and Islander communities. If people encounter only disadvantaged and unwell Aborigines in city communities, they cannot but have a very negative and patronising view of their race but, if people can move out into the environment in which Aboriginals and Islanders find themselves most naturally placed, they cannot but be impressed by their vision, determination to succeed and aim to provide for their peoples and by their caring and supportive way of life. One cannot help being impressed by their concern for the health and welfare of their people, particularly their children and their elders, and by the recognition of the communities that they have a part to play in the future of Australia. The Torres Strait Islands people are a very proud and fine race and have a very important future in Australia as we enter our third century as a nation.

The days when white bureaucrats in Canberra and Brisbane determined questions of health, social welfare, housing and justice for Aboriginal and Islander people are, hopefully, fading fast. I look forward to the day when decisions on the management of and direction for Aboriginal and Islander communities are the province of those communities. I believe there exists a very good case for more autonomy and regional government for Aboriginal and Islander communities, particularly in the Cape York and Torres Strait Islands areas. I hope that as we proceed further in this decade those communities will be able to get more autonomy-more say in where the money is spent. The money that appears to be spent on white, city-based bureaucrats would be much better directed to areas which would significantly, and in reality, benefit Aboriginal and Islander communities. The decisions on what benefits Aboriginal and Islander communities are best left to people in those areas, rather than being made in Canberra or Brisbane.

I look forward to the day when the paternal attitude of separate development can be abolished forever and when all Australians can live with dignity and self-respect. In so far as the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation can achieve or work towards achieving those aims, it has my total support.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time being nearly 12.45 p.m., I understand the Minister wishes to make a statement.

INTERJECT.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator McMullan) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 10 May 1990, of message No. 4 from the House of Representatives .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate concurs in the resolution transmitted to the Senate by message no 4 of the House of Representatives relating to the appointment of a Joint Committee on the Parliamentary Zone subject to the following modification:
Paragraph (2), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

``(2) That the committee consist of the President of the Senate, the Speaker of the House of Representatives and 10 other members, 3 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Government Whip or Whips and 2 Members of the House of Representatives to be nominated by the Opposition Whip or Whips or by any independent Member, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, 2 Senators to be nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate and 1 Senator to be nominated by any minority groups or independent Senators.''

(2) That the foregoing resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message, with a request for the concurrence of that House in the Senate's modification of the resolution transmitted to the Senate by that House.
I thank the other parties for their cooperation in the negotiation of this agreed motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We will now proceed to the debate on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Queensland has 19 members of parliament in the Labor Caucus, yet it has only two junior Ministers and a Parliamentary Secretary in the Ministry, with no representation whatsoever in the Cabinet. This situation has become such a disadvantage to my State, Queensland, that the Premier, Mr Goss, recently found it necessary to appoint a Western Australian, Mr Kim Beazley, as Queensland's representative in the Cabinet. According to Glen Stanaway in the Courier-Mail on 12 July:

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier, Mr Wayne Goss, and ALP State Secretary, Mr Wayne Swan, first approached Mr Beazley several weeks ago to help out Queensland . . . their concern was simple. Queensland has only two junior Ministers in the Hawke Government . . . Mr Goss and Mr Swan were concerned that because Queensland lacked a Cabinet Minister, it needed an extra bit of clout in pushing its case on issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Beazley should represent Western Australia first.

—I think he has trouble doing that, but he has been asked by the Queensland Labor Premier to represent Queensland's interests in the Cabinet. One would think the Hawke Government does not have any confidence in the abilities of Queensland Labor members of parliament to handle the job of a Minister. This is probably true, but is not the main reason Queensland is gagged in the government decision-making process. The Prime Minister simply takes Queensland for granted; he has carefully fashioned his ministry not on the grounds of talent but on the basis of factional deals and pay-backs. Former Senator Mr John Black from Queensland shed more light on this process when he explained recently that the Government had already decided to overlook Queensland yet again in the next ministerial shake-up. The Courier-Mail reported Mr Black as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister was tied to a deal with the Left Faction.
The Left is set to choose the Northern Territory's sole voice in the House of Representatives, Warren Snowdon, not Queensland's Keith Wright.
Mr Black said that the Left had surrendered a previous ministerial vacancy due to them to allow the Right's Simon Crean into the Ministry at the request of Mr Hawke.
Mr Black said that the Queensland Right had made the mistake of not extracting a promise of ministerial positions in return for supporting Mr Hawke in the leadership.
For the sake of Queensland, let us hope the Queensland Labor parliamentarians do not make the same mistake when round two of the world's greatest leadership challenge comes along.

Representation in Cabinet and the Ministry is essential-not just for the State's balance but because of depth and breadth of experience. There is no substitute for experience. We cannot just breeze in and out of areas and become experts on them-particularly in a State as vast as Queensland. It is difficult for me to understand local issues in, say, Wynnum, where Senator Boswell comes from, or to feel a real sense of what is happening in the new Brisbane City Council, as my colleague Senator MacGibbon might do as he lives in that area. But Senator Reynolds and I know the northern feeling. We disagree on the emphasis we take, but we understand the north, unlike the rest of my Queensland colleagues, who are only visitors to the north.

Queensland has been treated dismally over the years in terms of representation in Labor Ministries and shadow Ministries. If one looks at the figures one will see that under the coalition Queensland voters could expect a representation in the Ministry twice that which they could expect under a Labor government. Just to prove the point, Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to table a list of State representation in the Ministries and shadow Ministries since the 1972 Whitlam Government.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A study of the figures makes obvious the vast disparity between the importance that the coalition places on Queensland and that which the ALP places on it. Of the 289 positions in coalition Ministries and shadow Ministries since 1972, Queensland has received 39 positions, or 13.5 per cent. Of the 252 positions in corresponding Labor Ministries and shadow Ministries, only 19 positions have been allocated to Queensland MPs. That is only 7.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1983, under the Hawke Labor Government the position has deteriorated further, despite a large increase in Queensland representation in the Labor Caucus. Of the 114 positions available in the four Hawke Cabinets, only seven have gone to Queenslanders. Mr Deputy President, you, in particular, will be as disgusted as I am to realise that, in fact, Mr Hawke has the dubious honour of being the first Prime Minister since Federation to preside over a Cabinet with no representative from Queensland. This is the first government since Federation without a Queenslander in the Cabinet! That is the attitude of this Government and of Mr Hawke in particular.

It is an absolute disgrace, particularly and especially for all the Queensland Labor MPs who have been willing to accept this situation. Every Prime Minister in Australia's history has seen fit to include at least one Queenslander in Cabinet-but not Mr Hawke. I ask you, Mr Deputy President, and your colleagues: what is wrong with our present Queensland Labor politicians? Are they no good? Are they incompetent or is it simply that they have chosen the wrong faction? I suppose it is self-evident that they are incapable managers, therefore they could not be good Ministers, because they did not think to get the agreement from Mr Hawke to get extra Ministers in exchange for their support in round one of the Labor leadership spill Australia had to have. They were bullied into it by some union bully boy, unelected by the people, who seems to have control over the preselection process in Queensland. They are more interested in jobs on Government-controlled committees and in selection for overseas trips than they are in doing their bit for Queensland.

Why has the Government overlooked Queensland MPs? Are they seen as not intelligent enough, not well educated enough, or are they just not good mates of the Prime Minister? Where in the Ministry is the Queensland representation in the Senate? What is wrong with you, Mr Deputy President? What is wrong with Senator Burns? What is wrong with Senator Jones? What is wrong with Senator Reynolds? I will tell you what is wrong: the Prime Minister could not give a stuff about Queensland.

A quick look at the composition of the Hawke Ministry proves that beyond doubt. In the House of Representatives, only two of the 15 Queensland Labor Party members have Ministries. In the Senate, as I have mentioned, not one of the four Queensland Labor Party senators has a Ministry.

Compare this with the other States. Victoria has the same number of Labor politicians representing it, 19. Eight of the 14 Victorian Labor members in the House of Representatives are Ministers. Of the five Victorian Labor senators, two are Ministers. As well, there are nine Cabinet Ministers, including the Prime Minister and his Deputy. Heaven knows why the Victorian people continue to back the Labor Party when they see the mess that it has done to the Victorian State economy-but it has nine Cabinet Ministers in the Hawke Government.

The Australian Capital Territory, which the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) represents, has two representatives in the House of Representatives, one of whom is a Minister. It has one Labor senator representing it, and he is a Minister. That is not bad for Canberra. Of the three Labor politicians representing Canberra, two are in the Ministry. Queensland has 19 representatives but has only two in the Ministry.

There are two Labor Party members representing the Northern Territory, one in the House of Representatives and one in the Senate. One is the Parliamentary Secretary and the other a Minister-two out of two. Queensland has 19 representatives but only two are Ministers. And so it goes.

Even the Democrats do better than that. Senator Kernot, from Queensland, will at least become the Deputy Leader of her Party. The Labor Party could learn something from its fourth faction. It should do something more to give Queenslanders such as you, Mr Deputy President, a go in the Ministry and the Cabinet.

I compare this with the situation in the coalition. The Queensland Liberal Party has 10 parliamentarians. Mr Jull is a very senior shadow Minister in Dr Hewson's shadow Cabinet, and will be in his next government. We have one in the outer ministry. That member is here in the Senate. We do, at least, have some representation in the Senate from Queensland.

My colleagues from the National Party have six parliamentarians, one of whom is a shadow Minister as well. One of our shadow Ministers is from north Queensland, where I come from. The last government that we were in had a Minister from the very most northern seat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've also got Senator Boswell, a shadow Minister without portfolio.

—What a marvellous observation. It is pretty obvious that Senator Faulkner will never be in the shadow Cabinet-that is all it will be if he gets there, but he will not. Honourable senators should look at what the Queensland Labor Premier thinks about it. He thinks we need a bit more representation, so he asked someone from Western Australia. It is physically a long way away. Beazley has about as much knowledge--
—Mr Beazley to you.

—Mr Beazley has about as much knowledge of Queensland as I have of Perth-and that is not very much at all. Even in his VIP jet, it is still six hours away from where he lives. For the rest of us, of course, it is a whole day trip. I can understand why Mr Beazley is thinking of visiting Cairns next week. I suppose it is the first of his familiarisation tours in his new role as Queensland's Claytons Cabinet Minister. I am surprised that he has any time to spare. If he were in any way good at his job, he would be cleaning up the mess in the Western Australian Labor Party-WA Inc and all the crooks over there-rather than coming to look after the Queensland interest in Cabinet, which you, Mr Deputy President, and your colleagues should be doing. If he keeps as good an eye on Queensland as he did on what was happening with Burke and his cronies over there, then we will be much better off without Mr Beazley.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to you, Mr Deputy President, and your Queensland colleagues: show a bit of the stuff you are made of. Let us get together and approach Mr Hawke or Mr Keating. I understand that Mr Keating has offered a few of his mates in Queensland as many as two more ministerial posts in the Cabinet when he becomes leader.

Perhaps you, Mr Deputy President, and your colleagues in the Left and the Right should rethink your support for Mr Hawke, given his complete disregard for Queensland in his Ministry. I might emphasise that all five northern Queensland Labor members of parliament have been excluded from the Ministry. The position is much worse in north Queensland. Senator Reynolds, the only Labor Minister from north Queensland in the entire life of the Hawke years, was the only female Minister from north Queensland in history, to my knowledge, yet she was unceremoniously dumped after the 1990 election in yet another factional deal.

Her protestations to the media at the time that she was happily making way or passing the baton to a younger person barely disguised her disappointment, particularly as the Labor Senate front bench now has no female representation at all-something that I am sure Senator Reynolds has some very strong views about privately.

In Rockhampton, the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), who was an Opposition Leader in the Queensland Labor Party, has been snubbed by the Prime Minister. Former Senator Black has already made clear that there are sordid details behind Mr Wright's coming omission in the next reshuffle. The honourable member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, has served Townsville-where one of my offices is located-since 1983. Visiting MPs have repeatedly mentioned that he has ministerial potential. The Prime Minister, on a recent visit to Townsville to shore up Mr Lindsay's vote in round two of the leadership challenge, said on radio 4TO that Mr Lindsay would make an excellent Minister. Mr Hawke has admitted that there is a geographical imbalance in the make-up of Cabinet which excluded representation from north Queensland. He said that he hoped to remedy the matter in the not too distant future.

Who is it going be? Methinks yond Robert Hulls has that mean and hungry look and maybe he is the one that Mr Hawke is looking at. But what is wrong with Lindsay, Gayler and Reynolds? What is wrong with Wright? What is wrong with all the other north Queensland people?

—Mr Deputy President, recently Mr Gayler said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Workers Union which has a stranglehold on the (Labor) Party in Queensland--(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator McLean, some comments were made about me in the chair. I would like to mention to honourable senators that when I take the chair I am party neutral.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I am sure we are very well aware of that. As honourable senators will be aware, I have in the past drawn the attention of the Senate to the activities of the ICLE Bank-more correctly and fully known as the Instituts Nazionale Di Credito Per Il Lavoro Italiano All'Estore; I hope my Italian is interpretable-and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia in relation to the downfall of the mineral water company, Huon Valley Springs Pty Ltd and the charges of fraud brought against the founder of Huon Valley Springs, Miss Donna Marie Batiste.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I would like to draw the attention of honourable senators to a potentially much more serious state of affairs involving the former parent company of ICLE Bank, namely, the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, the Commonwealth Bank and the Australian European Finance Corporation, now a wholly owned subsidiary of the Commonwealth Bank.

In February this year the manager of the Atlanta, Georgia, branch of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, or the BNL, one Mr Christopher Drogoul, and nine others were indicted by a United States federal grand jury charged with making more than $US4 billion in unauthorised loans. The recipient of those unauthorised loans was the Iraqi regime of President Saddam Hussein and the period over which they were issued was between February 1988 and July 1989. Those are significant dates because, as I will explain in more detail in a moment, for much of that period the Commonwealth Bank of Australia was in partnership with BNL through its holdings of the merchant bank, the Australian European Finance Corporation.

Newspaper reports on the scandal claim that investigators in the United States have now established that more than 25 per cent of the funds had been backed by the Commodity Credit Corporation, an arm of the Department of Agriculture which provides guarantees to help sell US farm products. But rather than helping American farms, intelligence officials now say that the money was used by Baghdad to fund its chemical, biological and nuclear missile projects.

It is established that some of those funds went towards producing the Condor II missile, which is capable of carrying a nuclear payload to Jerusalem and other Israeli cities. Other BNL funds financed the chemical weapons which killed 5,000 Kurds in northern Iraq in 1988, the invasion of Kuwait and the Scud missile attacks on Israel and Saudi Arabia during the Gulf war.

During an arms embargo against Iraq, BNL Atlanta supplied funds which bought 40 electronic trigger devices, discovered by British Customs en route from the United States at Heathrow in March 1990, which were probably destined for the Condor II missile. It is believed that BNL funds were also used to develop Iraq's so-called `super cannon', a device also designed to deliver chemical and nuclear warheads. The super cannon's inventor, 62-year-old Canadian rocket scientist, Gerard Bull, was assassinated in Brussels shortly before British Customs discovered the triggers. Parts of Bull's cannon, manufactured in Sheffield and said to be destined for an Iraqi oil pipeline, were also impounded by British Customs. Twelve months before Bull's murder, his company, Space Research Corporation, had been linked to Iraq's network of European companies supplying missile technology financed by funds from BNL.

Investigators in Rome have identified more than 20 American, British and European companies which ignored the Iraqi arms embargo. News reports in both Rome and London say that within hours of the BNL scandal breaking in 1989, the Chairman, Nerio Nessi, and General Manager, Giacomo Pedde, resigned claiming innocence of the Atlanta dealings. However, since June that year, they and four other senior BNL officials had been under investigation by Italian authorities for involvement in an illegal arms deal with Iraq's warring neighbour, Iran. Investigations on both sides of the Atlantic are continuing.

In the United States the House Banking Committee is grilling officials from a range of government agencies to establish whether knowledge of the illegal loans extended as far as the Executive Office. The United States Attorney-General, Dick Thornborgh, has warned that the BNL affair raises national security concerns. But despite this warning Banking Committee Chairman, Henry Gonzales, is pressing ahead in the face of strong pressure from the Bush Administration to stop.

I have recently travelled to Washington to meet with representative Gonzales to raise with him the question of any possible Australian involvement in the BNL Atlanta scandal-questions which I am sure every responsible Australian will want answered. My major concern is to establish whether any Australian money was illegally funnelled through the Atlanta branch of the BNL, money which may have gone towards the purchases of arms which were then arrayed against our own Australian servicemen during their support of the allied offensive in the Gulf war earlier this year.

My fears arise from the fact that the Commonwealth Bank of Australia-that is, our people's bank-was in business with BNL for much of the period that BNL Atlanta was illegally financing the Iraqi war machine. In fact, during my talks in Washington, I was told that some of the weaponry purchased with those Atlanta funds was deployed against allied forces during the Gulf war, including Australian sailors.

In the 1980s, when the scandal really began, Western governments, led by the United States, turned a blind eye as Saddam Hussein went on a buying spree which was to make his army the third best equipped in the world. So much money flowed into the Iraqi coffers that the US congressional investigators now believe that the National Security Agency, the CIA and the Defence Intelligence Agency were deliberately looking the other way. American banking regulators are now speculating that the banking scandal goes all the way to the White House. A Cable Network News report quotes the US Justice Department as saying that much of the Atlanta money came from many of the West's leading and most trusted financial institutions, including the Banque Nationale de Paris, Barclays, National Westminster, the Bank of Tokyo, the Fuji Bank, Mitsubishi and American Express. According to top secret records of the transactions lifted from the so-called `grey books' of the Atlanta branch of BNL, even Israeli banks lent to Iraq's weapons fund.

What most Australians do not know is that for much of the period from February 1988 to July 1989 when the Atlanta branch of BNL was illegally and secretly financing the Iraqi war machine, BNL, the Banque Nationale de Paris and the Dresdner Bank AG were partners with the Commonwealth Bank. All held equity in what was then Australia's only consortium merchant bank, the Australian European Finance Corporation Ltd, AEFC, established in 1970 and ranked in Australian's top four merchant banks with total assets of almost $A2.5 billion. The Commonwealth Bank had a majority 51 per cent shareholding.

In March 1989, five months before news of the Atlanta BNL scandal leaked, the Commonwealth Bank bought out its partners for an estimated $A48m. The takeover was instigated by the Commonwealth Bank with none of the three other partners voluntarily pulling out. The Commonwealth Bank was moved to defend its actions in the light of the claims by some banking analysts who expressed doubt over the funding of the purchase at a time when the banking industry was entering a period of rationalisation and contraction.

During that same period, BNL was 70 per cent owner of the ICLE Finance Corporation Ltd, a merchant bank established in Australia in April 1986. Among the directors of the ICLE bank at that time were Franco Belgiorno-Nettis and Carlo Salteri, founders of the giant construction business Transfield and co-builders of the Sydney Harbour tunnel. Belgiorno-Nettis and Salteri also held more than two million of the five million issued shares, all but two of the remaining three million being held by the BNL.

I mentioned at the start that I had in the Senate previously named the ICLE Finance Corporation, BNL, the Commonwealth Bank and the AEFC in relation to the collapse of the Huon Valley Springs mineral water company. Journalists Tony Dickinson and Jerry Cornford first raised the Commonwealth Bank-BNL link with me. I thought it serious enough to go to Washington to have discussions with representative Henry Gonzales, who is the Chairman of the United States House Committee on Banking. During my banking talks with him, I outlined my fears that Australian money may have found its way to Saddam Hussein via the Atlanta BNL connection and may have been used to purchase weapons that were later lined up against our boys in the Gulf.

Representative Gonzales told me that it was very possible that Australian money had been funnelled through BNL-Atlanta and he has undertaken to have his staff thoroughly search all available transaction records in the grey books in an attempt to establish whether this was, in fact, the case. Representative Gonzales also urged me to investigate possible Australian involvement in the current Bank of Credit and Commerce International scandal, due to that bank's high profile in the South East Asian region.

It was because of all this that yesterday I asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, as the Minister representing the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), to investigate these possible links. In view of my disclosures today, I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether the Treasury is aware of the business links between the Commonwealth Bank and the BNL via the Australian European Finance Corporation during the majority of the period that BNL's Atlanta branch was issuing un authorised credits to Iraq?

I also ask whether the Treasurer will undertake to inquire whether any money from the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, BNL Australia or the Australian European Finance Corporation was illegally funded to Iraq via the BNL Atlanta Georgia Branch and whether it was used to purchase weapons which were later deployed against our servicemen in the Gulf? I further ask: Will the Treasurer establish whether, during that period, the ICLE bank, which was at that stage 70 per cent owned by BNL, or any other Australian financial institution may have wittingly or unwittingly provided funds which were later to be forwarded illegally to Iraq by the BNL Atlanta Georgia Branch?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now approaching nine years since the Hawke Labor Government was first elected to office. This Government has promised a great deal, but delivered very little. It has been nine years hard labour.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us cast our minds back to the Budget speech of the former Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), on 21 August 1990. The then Treasurer announced that the trends were clear. Exports were supposedly on the increase and imports were down. The current account deficit was falling and inflation was on the decrease, according to Mr Keating. Inflation has fallen, but the current account deficit remains a continuing disaster. We see the occasional improvement in one set of figures, only to see the next set show a continuation of this country's endemic current account problem. For instance, the 1989-90 current account deficit figure was $22.28 billion. The 1990-91 current account deficit figure was forecast at $15.3 billion. However, the current account deficit for the 1990-91 Budget was revised in July 1991. The revised figure was $21.15 billion, an increase of $5.48 billion.

Such an economic performance makes a sheer mockery of the notion of repaying the Australian people for their faith in this Government. The Hawke Government clearly bases its policies on whatever is politically or economically opportunistic at the time.

Over the years we have seen the Government twist and turn on economic policy. In 1983 the Hawke Government had a policy of fighting unemployment first through the assistance of the so-called accord. This has since changed to the balance of payments being the Government's main economic concern followed, most recently, by a `fight inflation first' policy. It is really a case of the Government making the best of a bad economic situation.

Nobody should believe that the inflation target of below 4 per cent was a goal that this Government always intended to reach. Rather, it was a result of the worst recession since the Second World War. This Government has literally driven the country into recession through a policy of record interest rate levels from mid-1989 through to late 1990.

We have seen a record number of bankruptcies, particularly among small businesses, and a rate of unemployment of around 10 per cent. Clearly, the Government has an extremely poor overall record on economic policy. Obviously, the Hawke Government has decided that the only thing it can salvage from the mess it has created is a low inflation target.

What kinds of winners are the Australian people in this kind of economic mess? Right from the very first major economic disaster of the Hawke Government in 1985, when economic activity collapsed, inflation began to accelerate and the value of the Australian dollar collapsed, followed by a debt explosion, every Australian has paid dearly. Every single Australian has had to suffer because of this Government's economic mismanagement in terms of high interest rates accompanied by a dramatic cut in living standards.

The unemployed, of course, are suffering particular hardship. Let us pause for a moment to examine the unemployment figures. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) clearly has a short memory. In 1983, the Prime Minister clearly believed that youth unemployment was something not to be tolerated. As Senator Baume mentioned in the Senate on Tuesday, in 1983 the Prime Minister stated:
No Australian government should ever be forgiven for creating the levels of youth unemployment of the last couple of years, which cannot and should not be tolerated.
Of course, the difference then was that the Fraser Government was allegedly the culprit. How those words have come back to haunt Mr Hawke and his Government.

The levels of youth unemployment involving young Australians aged 15 to 19 who cannot find full time jobs are now far greater than at any time during the Fraser Government. Yet this Labor Government still has the temerity to paint itself as the true party of full employment. In the past 12 months alone, 129,200 young Australians have lost their jobs. This represents the biggest 12-month loss of jobs ever recorded for young Australians.

In a few days time, the Government will unveil its Budget for 1991-92. Can we expect an answer to our economic problems? The Hawke Government clearly has no economic answers or vision for Australia as this country moves into the 1990s. It is too riddled with factional battles and leadership tensions to summon the will to take the decisions which are really necessary if Australia is to escape from its economic morass. Instead of interminable leadership bickering and quick fix solutions to economic problems, largely of their own making, the Prime Minister and his Ministers should go out and talk to those people in the community who are really suffering-the unemployed, the bankrupt and the manufacturers, farmers and miners who are trying their hardest to compete in international markets.

Why is this Government not grappling with the real issues so that business is not handicapped in competing with the rest of the world? Where is the urgency in dealing with such important matters as excessive transport costs, excessive waterfront and shipping charges, unnecessary government regulation and red tape, black bans, go-slows, stop works and Labor market deals? All of these problems only serve to impede Australia's progress in the world. In its own way, the picket line outside this building today is symptomatic of this same malaise. As with that problem, this Government shows no desire to deal with all of these problems. All we see is the continuation of a leadership battle between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. Who cares? Only this week Mr Keating busied himself with attacking the Government for maintaining interest rates at relatively high levels despite the fact that when Treasurer he imposed a high interest rates policy himself. Meanwhile, Mr Hawke and Mr Kerin find their time consumed by way of fighting a rearguard action against Mr Keating's leadership ambitions rather than concentrating on Australia's dire economic problems.

If we are to have a chance of stabilising our foreign debt, it will require a shift of nearly 4 per cent of our production into exports. That would not, however, reduce our debt; it would merely stop it growing faster than what we produce as a nation. Just how significant this task is can be evidenced by the fact that Australia has not realised anything like a 4 per cent shift in net exports in any five-year period since 1945. Indeed, even if we did match our best performance of the postwar period, our debt would still not stabilise this decade. Yet the Hawke Government has barely scratched the surface of performing this policy task.
