In the year since the last Budget, the Government has thrown away another chance to correct the dismal state of the Australian economy. Why has the Government not done the three most necessary things? Firstly, government expenditure should be cut rather than have a reliance on using interest rates to cut private spending; secondly, the Government should reshape our tax system in order to restore incentives and also remove the damaging bias against our badly needed export industry; and thirdly, the Government should boost national savings.

The 1990-91 Budget has failed on all of the above counts and there are still no signs of the Government finally showing the determination to tackle the real issues. The 1991-92 Budget will fail because of this same paralysis. Perhaps the clearest sign of the Government's determination to play politics rather than tackle the real issues has been the attitude of the Government to the Opposition's proposed goods and services tax, a tax which, despite their denials, was supported by Mr Hawke and his Cabinet, including the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, in 1985. But what do we see from the Hawke Government regarding the goods and services tax? We see a pathetic attempt to mislead the electorate concerning the true purpose of this tax, a tax which 21 out of 23 OECD nations already have.

The Government will not fool the Australian people with this blatant hypocrisy regarding the goods and services tax. The Australian people will see that this tax will benefit them overall. It will mean less tax, both total and personal. It will remove the current hidden wholesale sales tax system which is levied from 10 per cent to 30 per cent on various items. For instance, orange juice is currently taxed at 10 per cent and washing powder at 20 per cent, while at the same time pornographic magazines face no tax at all. It is one thing for the Government to play its usual political point scoring on the goods and services tax but what is the Government's alternative? Clearly, it does not have one. This is a government which fiddles and manipulates issues while the Australian economy burns.

The upcoming Budget, which John Stone described in today's Australian Financial Review as the Budget that will `achieve the rare double of being both a non-event and a policy failure', will undoubtedly display no vision or policy for restructuring the current indirect tax mess. But, most importantly, Australia will become more competitive with its exports as, under the Opposition's policy, that vital sector of our economy will no longer be taxed.

This Government's economic performance has been based on what is best for the Labor Party's short term electoral prospects; the Australian people's needs come second. Only under a coalition government's economic policies will the real problems of crippling international debt, the current account deficit crisis, micro-economic reform and record unemployment be rectified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking today during the discussion of matters of public interest, I will address the issue of the disarray of industrial relations in Australia. Two things are clear to me: firstly, the centralised wage fixing system is finished; and, secondly, the accord has failed and is in total disarray.

SPEECH.PARA: The centralised wage fixing system, established through the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, was torpedoed when both the Federal Government and the ACTU refused to abide by the umpire's decision at the last national wage case. The decision by the AIRC of a 2.5 per cent wage increase did not endorse accord mark VI. Of course, that left Mr Keating out in the cold because that was the deal that he sold to the Australian public prior to the last election. It was the first time in the eight years of the Hawke Government that the Commission had asserted its authority.

I have never supported the centralised wage fixing system. It has no relevance in the Australian system. It has no sensitivity to varying conditions between States and, more importantly, to sensitivities on the shop floor. Employer-employee contracts on the shop floor are the only way we will ensure long term employment and lift productivity to best world standards. The accord has been totally discredited. Mr Keating claims that it is responsible for the low inflation rate of today. That is absolute rubbish. If it were true or possible, why did it take more than eight years to come about? The accord rewards mediocrity.

Let us now look at what the accord has produced in Australia over that eight years. As mentioned by my colleague Senator Herron, it has produced sustained high interest rates. Even today when we hear members of the Government talking about how much interest rates have come down, at the current inflation level they are still at least two percentage points above what they should be-possibly more. We are still living with a relatively high interest rate regime.

The accord has produced record unemployment; a recession we had to have; and, worst of all, the blow-out in the national debt. It took this country 83 years to get the national debt to $23 billion net. In the last eight years, that figure has risen to $161 billion and this country is going to pay the price for that increase for a long time into the future. It will require a sustained effort to pull us out of it.

We have fallen behind in micro-reform. I must mention the waterfront in that context. What a joke when we think back to those long meetings by the Prime Minister to get something done on the waterfront. The employees were promised an increase of $12 per week in their wages to sit down and talk about reform. Fancy rewarding somebody to sit down and talk about the reform of those work practices which have held this country to ransom. Reward should come only when productivity has increased.

Let us look at what the political writers are saying about the current industrial relations situation in Australia. The Sydney Morning Herald carries the headline `Government pay decision threatens PSU awards'. The article goes on to say:

The bench member who deals with the Commonwealth Public Service, Commissioner Greg Smith, is expected to grant a 2.5 per cent pay rise before the end of this month. In line with the commission's policy, he would not allow retrospectivity, and would require the PSU to make no extra claims until November 1.
Yet in the same article Senator Cook yesterday reaffirmed the Government's promise to backdate the $12 to May 16. The article said:

In his statement, Senator Cook said the Government not only would backdate the $12 to May 16 but would continue to pay it until November 1 in cases where the 2.5 per cent expected from the commission amounted to less than $12 a week for low-paid public servants.
That highlights the disarray. In an article in the Sydney Morning Herald entitled `Government looks to ``short'' Accord for wage deals'-even though accord mark 6 has failed-we read:
``Maybe I'm talking about a short Accord, or 6.75 or something like that . . . ''

One must ask why it is 6 3/4 per cent? Why not 6 1/8 or 5 3/4 per cent? It is an incredible way to run industrial relations policy in this country. An article in the Australian was entitled `Cook trapped in the old union culture'. This is the fundamental problem we have today: industrial relations in this country have not moved with the times and with what is required. The editorial says:

Senator Cook, the Minister for Industrial Relations, is a reasonable man but he remains a captive of the culture in which he has made his career. In his union days and in his portfolio, his perspective has been from the centre looking outwards.

How true that is. Let us go a little further, to the AAP news, in a reference to the former Treasurer Paul Keating. This is a classic example of what is happening now in the Government and the undermining that is going on. I quote:

Former Treasurer Paul Keating and his close friend, ACTU secretary Bill Kelty, held a long meeting behind closed doors at Melbourne airport as a prelude to the escalation of Mr Keating's leadership campaign this week . . .

It would be interesting to know, apart from the comments that were made in Perth last week, what other deals were cooked up at that meeting. Let us go a little further, once again to the AAP reports of 8 August. We read:

ACTU president Martin Ferguson today denied that Accord Mk VI was falling apart, despite another major public sector union breaking from the government-ACTU agreement. Mr Ferguson said most ``Australian government unions continue to support our position''.

His comments follow a move by the Australian Nurses Federation to pursue a 2.5 per cent pay claim in line with the April wage case decision, instead of the $12 offered in the Accord agreement. Another public sector union, the 9,000-strong Professional Officers Association (POA), yesterday won a 2.5 per cent pay claim in the Industrial Relations Commission.
This is further proof that the accord is in disarray and is running all over the place. The partnership between the ACTU and the Federal Government-and within the ACTU itself-is falling apart.

Let us look a little further, to yesterday's Australian and Commissioner Maddern's decision to refer the future of the centralised wage-fixing system back to the Commission to revise its guidelines. The article says:
The centralised wage-fixing system could be abandoned before Christmas after a decision by the Industrial Relations Commission yesterday to reconvene the national wage case.

I make two particular points here: firstly, employers will call for an end to the multi-industry awards as part of the enterprise bargaining push; secondly, the ACTU must decide within three weeks whether to take part in a review of the system.
Today's Australian, in an article entitled `Business puts plan to cut strikes', said:
The Business Council of Australia yesterday proposed a sweeping reform of the nation's industrial law in an attempt to cut industrial action.
The council called for fixed-term industrial awards and agreements, during which parties would be bound by ``peace obligations'' on the contents of the deals.
The article says that the main points are:
Fixed terms for industrial awards and agreements, with a ban on industrial action during life of deal.
Action allowed during renegotiation but present laws to apply in the short term.
Limited right to take action during renegotiation in longer term but some constraints still applying.
Key role for the Industrial Relations Commission in settling disputes.
Enterprise agreements to establish own rules for compliance and renegotiation.
Then, in the same paper, we read:
Unionists reject anti-strike proposal.

These quotes refer to the industrial relations system that is developing-or maybe one should say, not developing-in this country. Today's Australian Financial Review contains an article under the heading `Government abandons sanction consensus' which reads:
The Federal Government has abandoned its efforts to forge a tripartite consensus on more effective sanctions in the industrial relations arena.

These quotes put into perspective just where we are at today in terms of industrial relations in this country. The only way that we are going to overcome these problems and address a number of the aspects that the previous speaker, Senator Herron, raised in terms of lifting our national performance, is to come to grips with our industrial system and get it back to the shop floor. Negotiations between employers and employees need to be conducted in a fair and sensible manner. If we do not do that, we are going to continue with the current disarray. We are going to have a continuation of the industrial disputation which is paralysing much of this country at this time.

But, worse than that, we are being prohibited from tackling work practices in this country. Until such time as we seriously address that aspect, lift our performance at all levels-starting from the waterfront and working back-and allow our exporters to compete in an effective way internationally, we will continue to fall behind; we will continue to have a level of unemployment of around, or in excess of, 10 per cent; we will continue to see our national debt blow out and this, of course, will be a mortgage on our future, our children's future and our grandchildren's future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to refer to the national accounts statement that was released today. One reads and learns to one's profound disappointment that for this quarter there has been a further drop. In other words, Australia is still continuing its downward spiral. The document Australian National Accounts, National Income and Expenditure, June Quarter 1991 contains the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: The most commonly used measure of economic growth is the income-based estimate of constant price gross domestic product (referred to as GDP(1)). Seasonally adjusted GDP(1) fell by 1.0 per cent in the June quarter.
The trend estimate of GDP(1) fell by 0.3 per cent in the March quarter 1991, its fourth successive quarterly fall.

The only component of private gross fixed capital expenditure to record a rise in June quarter 1991 was dwellings (up 1.6 per cent in constant price, seasonally adjusted terms, but still 7.2 per cent lower than in June quarter 1990). Total private gross fixed capital expenditure declined by 4.7 per cent in constant price, seasonally adjusted terms.

This grim, depressing news can be added to all the other figures. We constantly need to remind this Government that it has brought about the plight of the economy in Australia. Unemployment rose from 9.3 per cent to 9.8 per cent in July, after a collapse in the number of jobs of 83,100 in one month alone. This is the only reason for the fall in the inflation rate to 3.4 per cent. It does not take the world's greatest Treasurer, cum leader-in-waiting, to appreciate that such a massive surge in unemployment will allow for some classic Phillips curve trade-off in inflation.

There is a fundamental recessionary weakness in the labour market which has been demonstrated by a 2.4 per cent fall in average, ordinary time, earnings of full time adults in the last quarter. This should not be seen, however, as some success in wage restraint brought about by the Government's centralised wages policy or the much discredited accord. Instead, the fall is a direct consequence of the recession, with record levels of bankruptcies and a substantial excess supply of labour. The only response of the labour market-even this overregulated labour market-could have been a plunge in wage rates.

An examination of the unemployment figures shows simply that last month's result means that the number of jobs has fallen by a massive 305,300, or 3.9 per cent, over the last year to match the severity of the 1982-83 employment slump. This Government, as we went through the plight of sustained high interest rates, kept trumpeting from its turrets that, despite all the pain and suffering that was being endured by the economy, it had managed to keep employment rates up.

I saw an interesting figure the other day which showed that the cost of the jobs that were created by this Government, in terms of wages paid, was exactly equal to the amount of capital that was imported into this country during the period this Government has been in office. It is the servicing of those loans which is keeping our annual deficit growing at the rate of something like $18 billion a year.

On top of the figures which the Government admits to-that is, that 9.8 per cent of the work force is unemployed-it is important to realise that the rise in the official unemployment rate is being softened by the fall in the proportion of Australians who are in the so-called participation rate; that is, the number of Australians who have lost their jobs but are actively seeking another job and have not simply given up by being dispirited.

The participation rate continued to slip last month; it has slipped from 63 per cent to 62.6 per cent. The labour force-that is, unemployed plus employed-shrank by more than 40,000 people as disappointed job seekers simply stopped looking for another job. In other words, if we are truly honest about what has happened, we will concede that we already have an unemployment rate of over 10 per cent. Once we hit 10 per cent, there is not a family in Australia which is not touched by it. It is embedded in the psyche of every Australian family because families see the suffering.

Over the last two days we have had a debate in this chamber concerning the picket line surrounding Parliament House, which some could say, justly in some ways, was seen to be self-serving. The point that needs to be made is that trade union member after trade union member on the Government benches of the Senate shed crocodile tears for 40 people who no longer enjoy the work practices that existed in this building. Yet there was no apology-not a single, solitary murmur of solace-to the 800,000 people who are being put out of work by the deliberate policies of this Government. To call this Government hypocritical is to undervalue the word `hypocrisy'. This is a Government without any conscience, without any caring for the real plight of Australian families.

It is important to note that the greatest impediment to the clearing of the labour market is the centralised wage fixing system. It is the accord which has become the greatest single source of unemployment. The accord has denied equilibrium to the market wages, it has guaranteed an excess supply of labour, and it now ensures a mammoth level of unemployment. As I said, if we are honest, we will admit that the real level of unemployment is 10 per cent.

Despite this very real human tragedy, the Government's response is to maintain tight monetary policy through high real interest rates. We all got used to Treasurer Keating pushing the nominal interest rate high, and we got used to hearing of it in terms of 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22 and 23 per cent. What we did not hear so much about was how the high inflation rate lowered the real level of interest rates. But now, with inflation having come down-and in no way, shape or form can this Government claim that the aim of its policy was to reduce inflation; it has become a side effect of inflation-real interest rates have remained among the highest of any of the OECD countries and, indeed, one could say the highest.

A quick look at a recently published chart showed that real interest rates for OECD countries range over factors of 0.52 per cent for Sweden, 1.28 per cent for Switzerland, 1.6 per cent for the United States, 2.6 per cent for Canada, 3.48 per cent for Japan, 4.75 per cent for Germany, 5.33 per cent for the United Kingdom, 5.71 per cent for Belgium, 5.92 per cent for the Netherlands, 6.28 per cent for France, 6.81 per cent for Spain and 6.82 per cent for Australia.

It is exactly that high cost that is imposed upon the Australian economy that has prompted the NSW Farmers Association to write, I presume, to most senators calling for the high real interest rate to be addressed and to express its enormous concern. In its letter, the Association makes the following statement:

If we do not get an investment led recovery, especially in the international trading sectors of the economy, we will continue along the path of `stop/go' economic management that will bring us to another recessionary crunch after a consumer spending led recovery.
It goes on to say:
The costs to the community are being seen in our rising foreign debt, rising unemployment and falling living standards.

The positive approach must be to allow real interest rates to fall. Only then does Australia have a chance of being able to increase investment to allow us to raise our living standards, service our overseas debt and provide the job opportunities that Australians require.

What I have outlined very simply is a litany of all things that are wrong with our economy and all things that are wrong with Government policy, and yet the Government is locked in. It is locked in because the Federal parliamentary ALP which forms the Government today is nothing but the political wing of the trade union movement. The trade union movement calls the shots and the Ministers of the day oblige.

It is time that the Australian people were given some hope that there is a way out of this mire-and there is. The alternative government, that is the coalition parties, offer that hope. They offer it with a three-pronged attack-a three-pronged attack with a three-pronged reform package.

The first part of the package is taxation reform. Taxation in this country is crying out for reform. Our package is simple and straightforward and it is honest. We are straightforward in what we say we are offering as needed reform. First, it is to make people aware of the current wholesale sales tax that they pay-that hidden tax of which my colleague Senator Herron, just a moment ago, gave examples to show how inequitable and illogical it is. Tax is being paid on chocolate biscuits, but no tax is being paid on caviar or oysters; tax is being paid on Coca-Cola and orange juice, but no tax is being paid on that marvellous product Evian water imported from France.

In excess of $10 billion is raised annually by the wholesale sales tax. It is levied on products ranging from toothpaste to detergent to disinfectant to a whole range of things that the average housewife puts in the supermarket trolley. I can attest to doing just that and realising the tax component that I and every other Australian householder pays every time we go to the supermarket.

We will abolish that tax and replace it with a much fairer, equitable and more logical goods and services tax, a broad based tax which will ensure that even people who operate in the black economy will pay some tax. In addition, it will give a most important boost to savings because it will take away the present bias in favour of consumer spending and make saving more attractive.

As well as abolishing the wholesale sales tax we will reduce income tax rates. Of course, that will make saving more attractive. If people are faced with the choice of either investing or spending the after-tax dollar that they earn, the choice to spend is now almost overwhelming. People do not know what items have a tax; the taxes are hidden. We have the Government's secret tax, the Government's own GST.

People will feel that they get the full value for the dollar they spend now. It will not be attacked by inflation and will not have additional income tax paid on it, which would occur if people invested it. With a reduction of income tax, saving becomes very much more attractive and the fact that people know there is a tax to be paid on consumer spending makes the playing field-dare I say it?-more level.

In cutting income tax and introducing a compensation package for those who find themselves unable to take advantage of the tax reform, we are promising real reform in the tax area. When we couple that with industrial relations reform and micro-economic reform-that is, making the ingredients of business cheaper and making product more efficiently and cheaply produced-we see that we offer hope to Australian people by way of an improvement in the economy and an improvement in the standard of living, which presently, as I outlined earlier, is in serious decline.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about an aspect of the Government's economic policy and its adverse effect on a very important sector of the Australian economy. I talk about rural Australia in particular. I refer to the way in which the Government's monetary policy and high interest rates have wreaked havoc upon the small business community. I acknowledge that the problem has been compounded by low commodity prices in a number of areas, and that has inhibited cash flow in rural communities.

SPEECH.PARA: The low commodity prices are one component; another important component in the cost structure of the operation of that section of the economy is the cost of finance. Because this Administration has kept the cost of finance artificially high over a number of years, the farming community of Australia-and, as a result, the service industries to the farming community-has been brought virtually to its knees.

We see throughout rural Australia small country townships and cities struggling to survive. As these places struggle to survive and businesses close, the servicing of the rural community is being inhibited. As a result of the contraction of the servicing of those industries in the network of country townships and cities throughout Australia, people are having to rely on servicing, parts availability and a range of other backup services from major metropolitan centres. That brings additional and substantial costs to the operation of farming units and enterprises.

Of course, we also see in those small country townships and cities throughout Australia a contraction of job opportunities for young people. This is only going to compound the problem this country has of being the most urbanised country in the world. I live in the most urbanised State in Australia. The Government's policies-in particular its high interest rate policies-have, in fact, compounded that problem. The simple fact is that today's national accounts clearly support and endorse that view.

I speak about rural Australia and those small country townships with some feeling because my family has a small business located in one of those townships. Following the untimely death of my brother almost 12 months ago, I have had to have somewhat of a hands-on involvement in the operation of that particular facility. So, as a politician, I have seen first-hand the difficulties that have been compounded by high interest rate policies and the net effect of these policies.

I think Senator Bishop, the previous speaker, said that the national accounts for the June quarter, released today, show a negative growth of minus one per cent and 2.4 per cent for the year to the end of June. Last week's bad unemployment figures and the latest survey show a drop in consumer confidence. Is it any wonder that there is a drop in consumer confidence within the community? The national accounts offer no glimmer of hope for sustained economic recovery. So we have in the marketplace this psychological barrier, if you like, where people are not prepared to spend. Without consumer confidence and spending, we cannot break out of the cycle within the Australian community at the moment.

That is a legacy to all Australians that has been left by the former Treasurer, Mr Keating. As long as the team stays there, what we will see is a rolling recession. It will continue to eat away at jobs for Australians and at any prospect of improving living standards because there is no glimmer of hope or light at the end of the tunnel for these people.

Access Economics, in a paper that it has just released, clearly identifies and expresses some concern at the level of the deficit this year. It first notes that the Government will be seeking, I suppose, to grant tax cuts in the 1992 Budget, that is, the pre-election Budget. One would imagine that that is a course it would follow. Second, it says that these tax cuts are unlikely to be funded by spending cuts because it happens to be in an election year.

I would be interested if any Government Minister would be prepared to deny that that is the blueprint or formula that it will follow over 1992. If that is the case, we are going to have to have, and the Government will rely on, continuing high interest rates to keep the economy from growing too fast. It is that aspect of monetary policy, of high interest rates, that has brought significant difficulties and problems.

The Government talks about interest rates falling and the economy moving in the right direction; it talks about there being some signs in some sections of the economy that it is improving and says that there has been a substantial reduction in interest rates. The real test of the claim is the question, `What real rate of interest applies today?'. Despite the great deal of publicity on falling nominal interest rates, the situation remains the same-real interest rates are still extremely high in historical terms and certainly compared with a number of our overseas competitors and counterparts.

The Government has consistently used interest rates for macro-economic policy purposes. There is no difference between the approach taken by Treasurer Keating and that being taken by Treasurer Kerin to high interest rates as a form of macro-economic policy. The costs of that are clear and can be seen by all of us. They are incorporated in the statistics that have been released over recent weeks-our rise in foreign debt, rising unemployment and, coupled with that, falling living standards.

Recently, a number of organisations in the community have drawn the issue of high real interest rates to the Government's attention and notice. Despite the fact that a fortnight ago the Prime Minister indicated there might be some easing-Treasurer Kerin took a different point of view-there has been no easing of those interest rates. Until and unless there is some easing in the real interest rate cost, we will not have increased investment; we will not have increased productivity; and we will not have an improving economy for the benefit of all Australians. A range of policy initiatives need to be put in place.

I think it is about time that the Government started to understand the real impact of those high interest rates, and how its reliance on monetary policy is adversely affecting, in the instance that I referred to earlier, rural Australia, the servicing network of townships throughout rural Australia, and the important role it has played in the past and that is needed in future. If we do not take corrective action, it will wither on the vine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to draw the attention of the Senate to a situation where swift Government decision is required as a matter of both urgency and equity. In an Administrative Appeals Tribunal case of 26 April, the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs invited the AAT to comment on the effect of changes to the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 by the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act 1990. The Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Act took effect from 8 January. The AAT case and the legislative changes commented on relate to defence service home loan entitlements. In particular, they concern the issue of whether one member of a married couple, sharing the same dwelling place as his or her partner, is entitled to be issued with a certificate of entitlement when his or her spouse has already been issued with one.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case before the AAT, a wife whose husband had already taken out a DSH loan was seeking to exercise her entitlement on the basis of her eligibility. The AAT had to make its decision based on the legislation as it stood before 8 January. Although the Tribunal considered that the overall scheme of the Defence Service Homes Act was supportive of the wife's case, it concluded that a strict reading of the legislation meant a certificate of entitlement could not be issued and the wife's case was rejected. However, the respondent in the case, who was the Secretary to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, invited the Tribunal to make some observations on the effects of 8 January amendment of the Act. After carefully scrutinising the legislation in light of the changes, the Tribunal concluded, contrary to the Secretary's arguments, that it would seem the way should now be clear for the concurrent granting of a DSH loan entitlement.

The Government has yet to indicate a policy position on these issues. A Government response is needed urgently because of an impending 31 August deadline. Service members, who are eligible for a defence service home loan but have yet to take up their entitlement, have the option of revoking this entitlement and taking up an entitlement under the newly established Australian Defence Force home loan assistance scheme. This option has been available since 1 March. The deadline for a decision on this option has been set for 31 August.

For a number of people, a crucial factor in deciding whether to forgo their DSH entitlement is the Government's position on whether it accepts the comments of the AAT in relation to concurrent DSH loans. It is not possible for two married members to exercise an entitlement concurrently under DSH and ADFHLAS on the same home. It is therefore obvious that for married couples, where each person is eligible for a DSH entitlement and where one partner has exercised a DSH loan, a Government decision on the ability of the other partner to exercise an entitlement concurrently is critical.

It is worth noting that under the new scheme, it is possible for two married members to exercise their entitlement concurrently. If the Government decides that this concurrent exercising of a loan is not possible, then it may well be that the other partner will elect to chose the ADFHLAS option. However, such a decision clearly cannot be made until the Government makes its position clear on the comments offered by the AAT. The deadline for the option of choosing the ADFHLAS is approaching fast; it is now only 17 days away.

The Government has been aware of the comments offered by the AAT since April this year. It must not continue to keep a large number of people in the dark with regard to the options that are available to them. I understand the Prime Minister's office is seeking legal and financial advice on the ramifications of the AAT comments and the effects of accepting or rejecting them. I hope it is being sought as a matter of urgency. Today I have written to the Minister expressing the views I am putting here. Members of the Defence Force are entitled to have the Government make up its mind and show some concern on an issue of importance to Defence Force members.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by referring to the extraordinarily poor quality of the Minister's answers to my questions on each of the past two days. The quality was surprisingly bad, if I may say so, from someone who is so obviously still an aspirant for higher office, either in this place or in the other House. I trust that Senator Evans will today attempt to give the impression that he at least comprehends what my question is about.
—Order! I suggest that the honourable senator ask his question.

—I refer the Minister to the fall of one per cent in real gross domestic product in the June quarter and of 2.4 per cent for the year as a whole. I also refer him to the dramatic collapse in national savings and investment revealed by the figures and, in particular, to the eighth fall in private investment in plant and equipment in the last nine quarters. Does the Minister agree that this dramatic collapse means that the outlook for 1991-92 is for further falls in employment, increases in unemployment and a continuation of Australia's deep and rolling recession? Will the Minister give an undertaking to the Senate and to the Australian people that next week's Budget will be framed to provide sustainable growth in jobs and some hope for the millions of Australians now suffering the results of the Hawke-Keating Government's massive policy failures?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept, and the Government does not accept, that there is anything in the nature of a dramatic collapse in the economy demonstrated by these figures. The June quarter national accounts suggest that economic activity has continued to edge downwards over the first half of the year. The national accounts indicate that GDP fell, as Senator Short said, by one per cent in the June quarter after rising 0.4 per cent in the March quarter. It is appropriate to take both quarters together because to do otherwise does not take sufficient account of the volatility that is often apparent in quarterly numbers.

ANSWER.PARA: When one looks at the last two quarters together and compares them with the two previous quarters, September and December last year, one sees that the rate of deterioration-or decline, if honourable senators wish-in the economy has markedly diminished. For the September and December quarters the total was minus 1.8 per cent and for the March and June quarters the total is minus 0.6 per cent. That is consistent with the Government's expectations and understanding of what the underlying features of the economy are.

The broad picture shown by this is also evident in the Australian Bureau of Statistics measure of trend GDP, which fell by 0.3 per cent in both the March and June quarters. As compared, the comparable figures were 0.5 in September and 0.6 in December last year. Again this trend is evident when one looks at the inflation figures that are part and parcel of the national accounts. I am not talking about the consumer price index figure, but of course the implicit price deflator for non-farm GDP-the cost of production indication of inflation-which rose by only 0.1 per cent in the June quarter, bringing the total increase for the year to the June quarter to only 2.8 per cent. That is the smallest increase since the year to the March quarter 1964. It is further evidence, if any were needed, that inflation is on the way down in Australia.

The encouraging feature of these accounts concerns the longer term picture for exports. Net exports contributed positively to activity in the June quarter, bringing the total contribution for the final year as a whole to 3.1 percentage points. That is the highest contribution from the external sector in a financial year for nearly three decades. I repeat: net exports have increased and made a contribution of 3.1 percentage points to growth over that last year, which demonstrates that in that sector of the economy-crucially important for the recovery and for a sustainable and durable long term recovery-we are doing very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking about net exports. The positive contribution in the June quarter means that in all but one of the past eight quarters net exports have operated to boost activity. It is that contribution from expanded exports and reduced import growth that has underpinned the dramatic improvement in the current account deficit in 1990-91, despite the continued fall in our terms of trade. It is worth repeating what the improvement has been in the current account if we are looking at indicators for longer term durable and sustainable growth. The truth is that the current account deficit fell by 30 per cent in 1990-91, from $22.3 billion in 1989-90 to $15.7 billion in 1990-91. While private investment, which was also mentioned by Senator Short, including non-residential construction, fell in the June quarter, dwelling investment-the housing sector-grew slightly.
—Collapsed. Have a look at plant and equipment.
—Order! You have asked the question.

—The honourable senator has asked the question and he is getting the answer. This is consistent with the evidence given by leading indicators-that is, finance and building approvals; the housing sector is crucial, as we all know-the balance of which indicates that recovery has commenced in that sector. When we put all those things together it is evident that the economy, I repeat, is poised for a sustainable and durable recovery. The basis on which that will occur will be spelt out in detail in the Treasurer's speech next week.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason we are poised for sustainable and durable recovery is that we have the right policy settings in place. Official interest rates have been cut by over seven percentage points since early 1990, wages growth is being held in check through the accord framework and we are maintaining the structural integrity of the Budget. In addition, the indicators suggest, as I have already partially said, that the housing industry recovery has commenced, that the outlook for manufacturers has improved and that the run-down of business stocks has ended. Those indicators-there are others as well-will continue to be mixed until the recovery is well under way and, in particular, unemployment is likely to increase further, given that the labour market does, as we constantly acknowledge, lag behind economic activity. But the foundations for a stronger economy are being laid and nothing in the national accounts figures suggests otherwise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. We got the trifecta today: for the third day in a row the Minister has totally failed to answer my question. I ask again: will the Minister give an undertaking to the Senate and to the Australian people that next week's Budget will be framed to provide sustainable growth in jobs? In that context I also ask him the following supplementary question: can he advise the Senate whether the Government still holds to the former Treasurer's forecast at the Premiers Conference as recently as 30 May that the unemployment rate in 1991-92 will peak at 10 3/4 per cent and that average unemployment in 1991-92 will be 10 1/2 per cent?

—The Budget next week will be framed in such a way that it takes advantage of that environment which is one that will be conducive to sustained and durable growth in the future and the recovery of the economy that I have just been describing in loving and elaborate detail to Senator Short, and he manifestly was not listening. So far as unemployment is concerned, I am not going to attach any particular projection to a response except to say, as I already partially acknowledged in my first answer, that our view still is that unemployment will remain at levels that will be higher than we would like for a significant period and could go higher still. We regret that but we are confident that the policies now in place-it will be further spelt out in the Budget speech next week-will ensure sustainable growth in activity and, with the usual lags, sustainable growth in jobs.
—I ask that the Minister table the script from which he has been reading.
—It is a matter for the Minister.
—I do not propose to table it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister whether he could advise the Senate on the outcome of the initial round of Australia-United States consultations on agricultural trade issues, which took place in Washington, DC overnight. What is the evaluation of the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After a 10-hour meeting, the initial round of the Australia-US consultations on agricultural trade issues concluded in Washington early this morning, Australian time. Before that meeting the Australian delegation met separately with senior officials of the State Department, the US Department of Agriculture and the Office of the US Trade Representative.

ANSWER.PARA: All the discussions over the last two or three days, including the formal session, were comprehensive and certainly fulfilled the clear intention of both sides to explore the differences, which still undoubtedly exist, and our concerns in a constructive fashion. This consultative process is the only one of its kind that the US conducts with any country on these issues and, of course, it stems from the visit of the bipartisan delegation to Washington in March this year.

We have taken the view, on the basis of the reports of these talks that we have received so far, that they represented a positive and constructive start to what will continue to be a complex, ongoing consultative process. There are not any magic solutions. The EEP problem with the United States has already been with us for some six years. Its effects are necessarily going to stay very high on our agenda in the conduct of our bilateral relationship for the foreseeable future. Certainly we expect it to be further discussed when President Bush visits Australia later this year.

The discussions covered quite a wide range of issues, including the international market for grains. It was agreed-I guess that this is reasonably good news for farmers, to the extent that it holds up-that the current world wheat market fundamentals do provide real potential for price improvement. That is the judgment. The Australian and US export interests in individual markets were discussed. The operation of the EEP was, of course, discussed in great detail focusing, in particular, on the details of what may be involved in the assurances that we have formally received. The Uruguay Round was briefly discussed. A number of other bilateral issues including sugar, beef and dairy products were discussed, as well as the state of negotiations on the North America free trade agreement which is, of course, of immense interest to us, too.

For its part, the US reaffirmed that the prime focus of the EEP was countering the subsidy practices of the EC. Its position did not vary in that respect. Our emphasis in the discussions was to highlight the markets of significant commercial interest to Australia, including the Middle East, so that the US could be in absolutely no doubt-not just in a more generalised way, but in a very precise and specific way-of the effect on Australia of past or potential EEP activity in these markets. All aspects of the recent initiative to Yemen were discussed in detail.

We argued very strongly for consultations with Australia prior to individual EEP initiatives taking effect. For a range of reasons, largely based on acute commercial sensitivities-or claimed sensitivities-the US could not accept this concept. We have also advanced a number of ideas which I am not in a position to refer to in public at this stage. They were debated at some length and, while not resolved at this meeting, do remain on the agenda for further consultations. So the ground work has been laid for some further dialogue.

On the specific question of impact on particular markets, the United States has repeated its assurances that it will continue to do what it can to minimise the fallout of the export subsidy war on non-subsidising exporters such as Australia, and continue to seek specific assurances from importers as to their level of purchases from non-subsidising countries.

We all have to recognise that the export subsidy war is a symptom of the massive distortion of international agricultural trade which is arising from production-related subsidies and other barriers to trade. To cure the symptoms, we have to attack the cause, and the best hope for doing that remains the Uruguay Round. Along with our Cairns Group colleagues and the United States, Australia will be relentlessly pursuing a successful outcome to the Round. Again, we call on the European Community to show the political commitment which is necessary to move the agricultural negotiations in that Round forward to a successful conclusion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to a recent address given by the current Treasurer to the Irish-Australian Chamber of Commerce in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the most effective anti-poverty policy ever implemented has been sustained economic growth. It has brought increased social justice to hundreds of millions of people on our planet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep going.

—I will. In light of Mr Kerin's criterion for an effective social justice policy and today's appalling national accounts figures showing that in the year to June, rather than growing, the Australian economy actually shrank by 2.4 per cent, can the Minister advise the Senate of the social justice implications of Labor's deliberately engineered economic collapse for the years to come?

—There is no resiling from the proposition that sustained economic growth is the best way of securing social justice and a better balance and distribution of equity and benefits in any given economy. Nobody is arguing with that, and nobody is arguing about the desirability of getting this country back on to a sustained and durable growth path. But that is exactly the path we are on for all the reasons that I articulated at nauseous length in my answer to the first question.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Do I take it from that response that the Minister is either oblivious to or simply refuses to acknowledge the current social justice implications of the results that were announced today, the appalling unemployment figures of last week, the record low levels of consumer confidence, and all those other catastrophic indicators? Does the Minister seriously suggest that there are no adverse social justice implications? If not, would he please redefine social justice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Such adverse social justice implications as there are are amply dealt with in an Australian context by the very extensive and elaborate network of social security mechanisms we have in place, which have been made far more far-reaching, comprehensive and effective in their application to people most in need by the policies which we have been putting in place and which I have described in answers earlier this week so far as unemployment, and youth unemployment specifically, is concerned. The implications of that commitment are very evident in the Budget blow-out that we have experienced in the 1990-91 financial year and the difficulties that that will create in the framing of the Budget this year.

ANSWER.PARA: Of course we want very quickly to re-create an environment where there is not that necessary reliance on the social welfare system; of course we want to get durable growth back into the economy, but it has to be durable growth. It is no good creating bubbles that will burst. The kind of growth that we have been putting in place backed, as it is, by the inflation figures that I have described, which are spectacular and totally at odds with the kind of achievements that the coalition was able to make in the early 1980s when it was in government during a recession, have created the environment where that growth can be sustained into the future and will be durable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the Tasmanian daily newspapers, the Townsville Daily Bulletin, the Newcastle Morning Herald and the Illawarra Daily Mercury have all requested, but have been denied, free sets of all of the 1991-92 Budget Papers on the ground that those newspapers are not represented in the press gallery? Does this mean that the Government is imposing a financial penalty on these newspapers simply because they are not represented in the press gallery? Will the Government agree that it is important for these newspapers from these significant regional areas to have the full set of Budget Papers so that they can be analysed and so that the electors in these areas can see what the Government is doing in respect of issues of importance to them?

—I have no official advice from the Treasurer on that, but I am advised unofficially, no doubt reliably, by Senator Tate that the premise of Senator Harradine's question is true, at least so far as the Tasmanian newspapers are concerned. If that is so and it has that sort of impact, I believe there is a basis on which that decision should be looked at. I undertake to raise the matter with the Treasurer, with some help from Senator Tate, to pass on your representations and to suggest that in the circumstances it may be appropriate to make some exceptions.

—My question is also directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: has an interdepartmental committee been formed to develop a national plan of action in response to the World Summit and Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children in the 1990s? If not, when will the committee be set up? Who will be represented on the committee? Will the plan for Australian children be able to be produced by the end of this year, as promised at the summit? Finally, will non-government organisations already working in the areas involved be consulted in the process of organising Australia's response?

—As to the first question, an interdepartmental committee has not yet been formed. As to the second question, a formal departmental mechanism will be established soon. As to the third question about a plan for Australian children being able to be produced by the end of the year, I have been given the following answer: the national program of action will be completed by the end of the year. That is the target they are working to. As to the last bit about non-government organisations, yes, they will be consulted in the process of developing that program.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to an article in yesterday's Australian Financial Review, which goes by the self-explanatory title, `Bouquets to Australia for the first blue rose'. Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the Government applied any fertiliser to this project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am inclined to refer this question to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, because he has been doing so well so far in Question Time.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Beahan referred to the article in the Australian Financial Review headed, `Bouquets to Australia for the first blue rose'. I have heard of the British red rose and the white rose of Athens; it now seems we have an Aussie true blue rose.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the yellow rose of Texas?

—The yellow rose of Texas, indeed. It now seems we have an Aussie true blue, which one could say is a blooming story of flower power in Australia. Can I have leave to withdraw that remark, Mr President?

ANSWER.PARA: The Melbourne based company Calgene Pacific Pty Ltd recently filed a patent application for the gene, which should enable the commercial development of a blue rose. This is a significant milestone in a research and development project which started in 1987 with the support, under the biotechnology grants scheme, of the Industry Research and Development Board.

Calgene aims to take the genes which produce the blue colour in petunias and insert them into various ornamental species such as roses, gerberas, carnations and chrysanthemums which dominate the world's flower market. The world market for cut flowers is enormous. About $US5 billion worth of roses alone are sold in the world each year. It is a market where novelty commands high premiums, and a blue rose would certainly be novel.

Another Calgene project aims to prolong the life of cut flowers, which also increases their market value. The project has been assisted through the biotechnology grants scheme-a grant of $740,000 over three years-not only because of its potential for commercial success but also because the technologies being developed will be able to be used in a wide range of other commercial applications.

The majority of funding has come from capital raised by Calgene Pacific itself, from Australian shareholders and from the major Japanese firm, Suntory Ltd. Suntory will help Calgene penetrate the important Japanese market. The total cost of the project is expected to be between $15m and $20m by the time the blue roses appear on the florist shelves in Tokyo, with a price tag of around $A100 per stem. Calgene Pacific plans to raise further funds--

TALK.START.PARA: —Does this result from government policy?

—Senator Hill should not worry, his turn will come. I do not know what sort of rose we will award him. Calgene Pacific plans to raise further funds, hopefully in Australia, to maintain control of the technology and to carry through that technology to its final development phase.

—I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to his answer to my question on Tuesday about Australia's record 28.5 per cent full time youth unemployment rate where he claimed `We are now in a situation of a reasonable expectation of a sustained growth in activity in the job situation'. He also said `Policies are in place and are bearing fruit'. He did not describe the fruit. I ask the Minister: what real prospects exist for improved employment while there is an accelerating collapse in private sector investment in new plant and equipment, as revealed in today's national income figures, which show a worst ever postwar drop of 29 per cent over the last 10 disastrous quarters, of which 9 per cent came in the recent June quarter of the Government's deliberately engineered recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already acknowledged that investment was down in the June quarter, but these figures are volatile; they do move about from time to time. One has to look at them in the context of the total environment revealed by the national accounts. That total environment that is revealed by the national accounts does not indicate anything in the nature of an accelerating recession, but rather the contrary.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said at the outset of the first answer, the figures indicate an economy that was, during the first two quarters this year, continuing to edge downwards but at a slower rate than was the case in the two quarters last year. There are plenty of indicators all around the place suggesting that that particular process is bottoming out and that we are back on the road to a durable and sustainable recovery, one of the crucial elements of which will undoubtedly be a recovery in the commitment of the private sector to investment. The obvious help in that respect will be the inflation rate, dramatically reducing, hopefully followed by a reduction in interest rates. As I indicated yesterday and the day before, that is something which depends on a whole variety of judgments that cannot be regarded as being automatically triggered by any particular inflation indicator.

We do have an environment where the housing industry recovery has commenced; the outlook generally for manufacturers has improved in the ways I have described; and the run-down of business stocks has ended. All of those factors will obviously be very helpful in creating the kind of recovery environment that we are anticipating. Beyond that, these are issues that will be addressed by the Treasurer in detail in his Budget statement next Tuesday and I will leave it to him to fill out the further detail.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it possible and has it ever happened that there has been any sustained employment growth during a period of accelerating collapse in private sector investment in new plant and equipment? Obviously the Minister did not know that there has been an accelerating collapse. I draw his attention to the figures which show for the December quarter of 1990 a 6 per cent fall, for the March quarter of 1991 a 6.9 per cent fall, and for the June quarter a 9 per cent fall.
—I am not arguing about the figures for the last four quarters; they have not been good.
—They are continuing to get worse.

—They have shown an economy which has been in various states of recession during that period. But they do not at all show a situation of the economy continuing-as has been claimed by way of interjection-to get worse. On the contrary, there are many positive signs suggesting the alternative. The economy was getting worse- but at a lesser pace-over the first two quarters of this half of the year. It is not to be assumed that anything will be shown up over the course of this year other than a substantial return to positive growth, which the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have said will start before the end of this year. There is nothing in the particular figures that we have seen today which would operate in any contrary way to that kind of projection.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport to the level of road fatalities for June this year. I understand that there were only 142 fatalities nationally in the month of June this year. Was June the safest month on the nation's roads for nearly 30 years? What factors have contributed to the low road toll in recent months? Have government steps in recent years to lower the excise on low alcohol beer been one of the factors in helping bring down the road toll?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following response to Senator Maguire's question. The number of fatalities in June this year was, in fact, the lowest monthly figure for 29 years-which is very welcome news. It should be noted that there has also been a very large increase in population and vehicle usage over that period. There was a further reduction in fatalities in July to 178. The total number of road deaths from January to July was 13 per cent lower than for the same period last year.

ANSWER.PARA: Many factors have contributed to this improvement. Both the Federal and State governments have adopted a wide range of initiatives to improve road safety, including action to reduce drink driving and speeding and to increase the use of seat belts, increased enforcement and public education. The Government's 10-point road safety package announced by the Prime Minister in 1989 has renewed this commitment to road safety. Under the Federal Government's black spot program, $50m was provided to the States last financial year to eliminate about 1,000 of the worst road crash black spots in Australia. This program will continue over the next three years. We have not yet seen the full long term effects of these initiatives.

The Federal government is also committed to improvements in vehicle safety.The Minister for Land Transport recently announced a major program of research to identify the best ways of providing better protection for car occupants in a crash. The recent improved figures are good news but we must still recognise that road deaths and injuries are a major problem for this country. Apart from the human suffering, the cost of the crashes to the community is conservatively estimated at $6 billion a year. Road crashes are still the single major cause of death for people under the age of 45.

In respect of Senator Maguire's question about low alcohol beer, I will seek further information on that from the Minister. There is no question in my own mind that a combination of the concentration on encouragement for people by things such as reducing excise to drink low alcohol beer, combined with random breath testing, has had a very valuable effect in terms of the increasing community awareness that people should not drink and drive.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind him of his commitment yesterday to seek advice about the member of the Federal Government reportedly involved in the 1987 rescue of Robert Holmes a Court. I again ask the Minister: who was the member of the Government concerned, what was sought of the Government and what action did the Government take on the request?

—I have now had a chance to read the relevant sections of the transcript of evidence given to the royal commission. Mr Connell in the relevant evidence simply referred to `Mr Burke talking to someone in the Federal Government'. The context is utterly ambiguous, even as to the subject matter of any conversation that may have been held between Mr Burke and such a person. The matter having been raised in this way in the royal commission, if the commission believes that there is some hare worth chasing in this respect, no doubt that hare will be pursued within the royal commission. That is the proper place to do it, and the Government is not minded on the basis of any of the material before us to react in any other way.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why is the Minister, on behalf of the Government, not prepared to indicate to the Senate whether or not a Federal Minister was involved in the reported rescue attempt of Robert Holmes a Court in 1987? This is a serious matter which, as the Minister says, is before the royal commission. It has been suggested that a Federal Minister was contacted. Why is the Minister not prepared to inquire whether or not a Federal Minister was advised and advise the Senate accordingly?

—I repeat that the context in which the reference is made to a member of the Federal Government having been the subject of a telephone call with Mr Burke at the time the evidence is about is utterly ambiguous. No clear suggestion emerges in any way from the text that the subject matter of the conversation that Mr Burke was having at the time referred to had anything whatsoever to do with the Rothwells rescue. Under those circumstances, quite apart from any other consideration, there is simply no basis for any further inquiry being made.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has he seen reports that Dr Hewson and Mr Howard have proposed `radical changes to the industrial relations system which would emphasise what they claim is the efficiency and fairness of direct bargaining'? Is it a fact that the Government, by contrast, favours workplace level bargaining, with the Industrial Relations Commission acting as the umpire in individual disputes and negotiations, to ensure efficiency and protect the legitimate interests of employees? Does the Minister have any information which would illustrate what can happen to the legitimate interests of employees when workplace level bargaining is not supervised by the Commission acting as umpire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howard recently criticised me and remarks that I made criticising the Industrial Relations Commission. He said that my criticism of the Commission undermined the institution and meant that the institution could now be set aside, or words to that effect. That is a very black and white view taken by Mr Howard. The Government's attitude to the Industrial Relations Commission is best summarised by the comment of the French philosopher Voltaire when speaking of free speech--
—In French?
—I cannot do it in French, Senator Tate. I am sorry, I can only do it in English. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I disapprove of what you say, but I will defend to the death your right to say it.

We disagree with what the Industrial Relations Commission said in the national wage case, but we will certainly defend the right of the institution to continue to exist. It seems to me paradoxical that, in a pluralist and democratic society, criticism of an institution is being taken as a wish that it be abolished. That is not the case as far as the Government is concerned.

In our view the individual work contracts Mr Howard was talking about recently on a Four Corners program, which he said would be similar in form, if I understand his meaning, to those provided in New Zealand by the New Zealand Government, would have no place in Australia. They would be work contracts which would set aside an institutional role of scrutiny of what is fair in industrial relations by a body such as the Industrial Relations Commission.

I was also asked whether I am aware of any cases which might illustrate the point. I am aware of a case concerning an eminent and distinguished Australian who served his organisation very well and in a public way over many years. He had an individual work contract with that organisation. Upon the termination of that distinguished Australian's work contract he was gypped of back payment for annual leave. He was not paid his full entitlement of annual leave. If that is an example of an individual work contract, which I believe to be typical of the sort of example that the Opposition is putting forward, it is a shameful thing. The fact that the eminent Australian in this case is Mr Tony Eggleton and the employer is the Liberal Party of Australia which, upon the termination of Mr Eggleton, refused to pay him his full entitlement for annual leave, illustrates not only that the policy is wrong but that the party which is advocating the policy is also wrong.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to his statement on public sector pay dated 9 August in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: If the Commission converts the $12-
that is, the accord offer-
. . . to a 2.5 per cent wage increase, the Government will pay the $12 until November 1, where the 2.5 per cent is less than $12.

Is the Minister aware that in the Industrial Relations Commission today the representatives of the Government and the unions told the Commission that there had been no agreement between the Government and the unions to top up the difference between the 2.5 per cent and the $12 whenever that occurred? I ask: Has the Government's representative misled the Commission today or has the Minister misled the public by his statement?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the last two questions are no and no. This is a matter that came before the Commission this morning. As the Minister designated to issue instructions on these matters, I am certainly aware of what the instructions to our advocates were. I believe, and I have had reported to me, what they said. I do not have the benefit of a transcript to verify what they said, but I believe they carried out their instructions as directed, properly and fully. I do not see anything in those instructions, or in anything they said, that is inconsistent with anything that I have said publicly. If the implication of this question is that somehow we may be misleading either the public or the Commission, let me say immediately that that implication is not true-we are not.
—How do you know if you have not read it?

—I have not read the transcript. I said that I am familiar with the instructions, having issued them. I have had a report from the advocate who appeared. That report is consistent with the instructions, but I do not have the very words that he uttered to the Commission on transcript. I believe him to be an honourable person, and a person able to carry out those instructions, so I do not in any way quibble that he has. There is no attempt to mislead anyone in this. This is a clear case of public sector wages. It is a matter that is now waiting for a decision from the Commission, which I expect to receive this day.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I note the Minister's comments to the Malaysia-Australia Business Council on 22 July, and at his press conference the following day, in which he indicated his unwillingness to offend the Malaysian Government over the logging of rainforest timbers and the destruction of the way of life of indigenous tribes, such as the Penan of Sarawak. Can the Minister explain to the Senate why it is appropriate to avoid offending the Malaysian Government rather than seek an immediate end to the gross human rights violations being perpetrated against the Penan and other tribes? Secondly, does he accept that Australia's fundamental responsibility, as enshrined in the United Nations charter, is to protect the rights of peoples, not governments?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like so many other people, Senator Coulter has been misled by some very inadequate reporting of events in Malaysia, if he believes that at any stage I said that the positions that have been taken by parliamentarians and others within Australia on the logging issue were objectively offensive or were of a kind that should not take place in the future. I said nothing of the kind. What I did say was that a number of things that have taken place in Australia were seen in Malaysia to be offensive and, on some occasions, were seen to be downright insulting. The distinction is a fairly spectacular and fairly obvious one.
—It was only a half grovel, was it?

—It was a little too much for some people in the press to grasp, and it has obviously been a little too much for some people in this Parliament to grasp-even when it is pointed out to them-including Senator Alston, as he indicated very clearly in that interjection. There is a huge difference between committing oneself to some value judgment which may or may not be justified and, on the other hand, simply reporting what a reaction has been. There is no doubt as to what the reaction has been. That is the context in which I used that particular word.

ANSWER.PARA: I went on to make it clear that there were a number of issues-capital punishment was one and logging was another-on which, from time to time, there may well prove to be policy differences between Australia and Malaysia, or between individual Australians and people within Malaysia. It is not a matter of making any apology, acknowledgment of fault or anything of that kind in relation to such honest differences of policy opinion. It is a matter of explaining specifically what the positions are and hoping that they will be understood on that basis.
I think the particular reference to logging that I made in the speech is, in itself, an ample reply to the last part of Senator Coulter's question. I said:
Other issues which cause problems from time to time-
that is, cause problems objectively, because of the nature of the reaction in other countries-

do not involve firm Australian Government positions, but are presently the subject of lively public debate. One such issue is the logging of tropical timber-not just in Malaysia but elsewhere in the region and, of course, in Australia itself. I say now that Australia is extremely conscious of the significance of this issue for a number of our neighbours; that we do take careful note of Malaysia's very firm commitment on environmental issues in the National Development Policy; that we believe this whole issue is one that cries out for an agreed multilateral solution; and that-whatever the final outcome-Australia will certainly not act in a some capricious, unilateral way at Malaysia's expense.

That is simply acknowledging on the public record very specifically that this is a matter on which the Government has not yet formulated a final position. As is well known, the importation of tropical timber is something that will be considered shortly by Cabinet. It is the subject of a lively public debate at the moment. In respect of what I can say at this stage about the Government's position, I put it on the record in that way. So the premises of Senator Coulter's question are false and the conclusions that he draws from those false premises are equally false.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has not answered the second part of my question so I will repeat it. Should the Australian Government be more concerned about the rights of the indigenous Penan people to the protection of their culture or about the niceties of our relationships with the Malaysian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we should be concerned about the protection of the Penan people and other indigenous peoples around the world; we have made that clear in innumerable contexts. What we have to be sensible about is whether the policy strategies that flow from that concern actually help or hinder the plight of the people in question. One of the big concerns as far as some sort of blanket, across-the-board ban on the importation of timber from Sarawak where the Penan people live is that it may well have the totally unintended consequence of greater destruction of the forest habitat of those people because of the pressures that will then be created by an even greater exercise in uncontrolled clear felling for agricultural purposes by people displaced from the forest industry. That is exactly the sort of issue that we have to contend with in grappling with this topic.

ANSWER.PARA: That is why the kind of simplistic solutions that Senator Coulter and his fellow Democrats constantly come up with on these complex and sensitive problems are so often so comprehensively misguided. We cannot get by with emotion, rhetoric and sentiment; we also have to get by occasionally on just a little applied intelligence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications aware of the cutbacks by the ABC of its rural broadcasts, which are having disastrous consequences for many rural Queenslanders? I remind the Minister that Queensland is a highly decentralised State and, in a number of cases, the only State where a number of industries such as sugarcane growing, pineapples, peanuts and rare tropical fruits predominantly operate. Consequently, centralisation of many programs in Sydney by the ABC fail to account for local information and news needs. In view of the fact that the ABC is publicly funded, what responsibility does the Government take to ensure that those funds are spread equitably across Australia, not just in areas of high population, and thus enable the ABC to fulfil its obligations to the whole community?

—I sympathise completely with the position that Senator Bjelke-Petersen takes-and I must say on a regular basis-on these issues. I reiterate what I have said in answer to previous questions in a similar vein: the Government does provide the ABC with public funding for its operations, but the ABC is responsible, as it must be, for the priorities it sets itself in terms of its programming decisions. It must be, in my view and in the Government's view, free from any political interference. I will raise again with the Minister for Transport and Communications the concerns that Senator Bjelke-Petersen has brought into the Senate .

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade confirm reports that the death sentences imposed on the individuals who were convicted of involvement in the murder of the Prime Minister of Grenada have been commuted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to advise the Senate that the Prime Minister of Grenada, Mr Braithwaite, has just announced publicly that the death sentences passed on the 14 people involved in Grenada have all been commuted. The Australian Government has closely monitored developments in these cases. On several occasions during the last few weeks we have made direct representations to the Grenadian authorities urging that those death sentences not be carried out. The most recent such representation was made by the Government on Tuesday this week, 13 August, and there have been public statements made in my absence overseas by the then Acting Minister, Dr Blewett, on 29 July.

ANSWER.PARA: I understand that, in making his announcement, Prime Minister Braithwaite did acknowledge the representations the Government had received from a number of countries urging clemency. We recognise that in many respects the decision to commute those sentences was not an easy one for the Grenadian Government.
