The events of 1983 did cut very deeply into Grenadian society and there has been considerable domestic pressure upon the Government there to allow the executions of at least some of those 14 people to take place.

The decision to commute the sentences is therefore all the more to be welcomed not only by the Government but also by the many Australian citizens and others in this country who made representations to the Grenadian authorities over this matter. I do hope the humane act of that government will further encourage moves towards the long term goal, which is, of course, the worldwide abolition of capital punishment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. I ask: the next time you are talking to those people attempting to blockade Parliament House, would you consider advising them that last night a staff member, who was compelled to walk from the Senate entrance to Melbourne Avenue, arrived at the picket line suffering from a major asthmatic attack, an attack precipitated by exposure to the wet, windy and freezing conditions? Would you further remind those people of the high incidence of asthmatics in the Australian community and the very serious, sometimes fatal, consequences of an acute asthmatic attack?
—In reply to Senator MacGibbon's question, I am at this stage trying to organise a meeting with the people he has referred to for later this afternoon. I will pass his concerns on to them.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. In view of recent calls by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour for a review of the Government's waterfront reform program, can the Minister advise of the current progress of reform and his response to the AEWL employers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since Parliament last sat, there have been a number of positive developments in waterfront reform. The impasse reached by industry parties on finalising the new award classification structure, and the related wage increases, has been resolved to the satisfaction of the employers, the unions and the Industrial Relations Commission. The Government was instrumental in achieving that settlement.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a fundamental element of the reform program, complementing the new enterprise employment arrangements. The settlement gives added impetus to the reform by linking future pay rises to implementation of enterprise employment and delivered productivity improvements on the wharf. The last time the Parliament met we had concluded, in terms of agreements being implemented, only the national terminals enterprise agreements for the ports of Sydney and Melbourne.

Since the Parliament last met, the enterprise agreements which have been concluded and are now being implemented, in addition to the national terminals agreement for the terminals in Sydney and Melbourne, are as follows: Container Terminals of Australia Ltd-that is Conaust-agreements for the Sydney terminal; Union Shipping Australia Ltd agreements for its operations in Sydney, Melbourne and Hobart; the Strang Patrick stevedoring agreements for its Brisbane operations; the agreement concerning the Port of Darwin, being the first port to completely move to enterprise employment, with the approval of enterprise agreements for Conaust, Darwin Port Services and Federated Stevedores; and the agreement reached on disbanding the ancillary labour pools covering shipping clerks and stevedoring foremen in both Melbourne and Sydney, resulting in the exit of an additional 71 employees from the industry.

In addition to that, enterprise agreements which have now been completed and are in the process of being examined by WIRA for their endorsement are as follows: the Strang Patrick stevedoring agreement for the ports of Adelaide, Fremantle and Port Alma; the Brisbane Gateway Terminals agreement for its container terminal in Brisbane; and Conaust for its stevedoring operations in the ports of Adelaide and Port Pirie.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is anyone in the world less competitive than us?
—Are we really now competitive?

—In response to the interjections from those opposite, I can do no better than to quote a statement made on ABC radio yesterday by the Executive Director of National Terminals Ltd which, with Conaust, is the largest employer of waterfront labour in Australia. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: There are enterprise agreements all over the place. Employers haven't tried hard enough-they're blaming everyone except themselves and are now saying it's too difficult-I just don't subscribe to that and I haven't seen evidence they've tried hard enough to work out the reform process. You can't throw out the agenda unless you've really tried to make the agenda work.

The Association of Employers of Waterside Labour has called for the advancement of the general review already provided in the reform program which is scheduled to take place six months prior to its finish, in May next year. One of AEWL's major members-National Terminals-is not supportive of bringing this review forward and neither, as I know from having had discussions with the Executive Director of Conaust, is Conaust.

However, I am interested to note that a number of very informed media commentators lately have been making the statement-and they are right-that the waterfront debate is in fact far too politicised for its own good. One of the problems, in terms of a number of the parties participating in this debate, is that, despite the fact that the reform process itself is extremely difficult and more than a full time job, one does have to spend a significant period of time worrying about the politics rather than the reform.

AEWL is anxious about the high idle time costs for stevedoring labour arising from the downturn in cargo volumes as a result of the recession. The AEWL, and this is the position of an employer group and this is the reason for its dissatisfaction--

TALK.START.PARA: —A point of order, Mr President: it is an important subject, but this is now becoming a speech. If the Minister wants to put out a statement after Question Time, we can debate the statement, but this is not an answer to a question.
—There is no point of order, but it is becoming a very long answer, Senator Collins.
—Mr President, I regret once again that, in absolute despair at waiting for a question from the Opposition on this matter, I had to bring one on myself, and I will conclude the answer.
—No wonder you have been waiting for a question.
—I do not suppose there is any chance of lifting the height of that neck brace by another six inches, is there?
—Order!
—Mr President, can you ask the honourable senator to stop being offensive?
—It is not unparliamentary. Senator Collins--
—I cannot hear you, Mr President.
—Conclude your answer.

—In conclusion, the Government will not be agreeing to an early review of the reform process, nor will it be agreeing to apply taxpayers' money to pay out idle time. The only way to effectively reduce idle time is to proceed with the acceleration of the program and to complete the rest of the enterprise agreements, which is what we will do.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I ask the Minister to confirm, and give reasons why, the new $20m Alice Springs Airport terminal, which the Minister knows was to have been officially opened today, and the new $50m Darwin Airport terminal, for which the Minister has promised a grand October opening, will now be effectively mothballed for at least three months? Can the Minister give details of the additional costs and infrastructure delays to the Federal Government, the Federal Airports Corporation, the airlines, the tourist industry, and the travelling public because the Minister fails to keep his promises and is unable to effectively administer his own ministerial responsibilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I be given the discretion of making the answer as long as the question? The difficulty for Senator Tambling, as it has always been in this case, is this: Senator Tambling has not lifted a finger to assist in the 10-year slog to actually get the $80m worth of terminals established in Darwin and Alice Springs.
—Mr President, on a point of order: that is not answering the question.
—Order! I might hear the point of order if there is a bit of silence.

—The point of order is that it is not an answer to the question. He has got to answer the question. He was asked a question about why it has not opened and he now wants to talk about Senator Tambling. That is not answering the question.
—Order! There is no point of order. I thought Senator Collins was answering the question.

—Mr President, the major difficulty is that, those opposite having predicted for five years now that those terminals would never be built, they are unquestionably built and are about to be opened. The difficulty is that they are the first terminals--
—However, but.
—Can you let me answer the question, Senator Walters?
—Order! Would you ignore the interjections, please, Senator Collins.

—Mr President, it is very difficult to speak over the interjections. The difficulty is that the excellent terminals-and I am pleased to say that they are superb buildings-now in the process of being finally completed, to the great benefit of the Northern Territory, in both Alice Springs and Darwin are the first new terminals for which leases are being negotiated between the FAC and the airlines. As a result of that, the airlines are taking the view that these will be considered benchmark leases that will then apply to other terminals throughout the rest of Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: For this reason, these commercial negotiations are proving to be difficult-and I have acknowledged that publicly-but they will be concluded. The assertion that $80m worth of terminals will be mothballed is utter nonsense, as are most of the other statements made by Senator Tambling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I did not ask for a rendition on the bagpipes, I asked the Minister to confirm that the terminals would not be operable from the days on which he promised they would be operable. I also asked for the additional costs and their details to the Federal Government, the Federal Airports Corporation, the airlines, the tourist industry and the travelling public because of these delays.
—I have nothing to add to my previous answer.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to my answer to Senator Coulter during Question Time I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full text of the speech in question, delivered in Malaysia.

ANSWER.PARA: AUSTRALIA AND MALAYSIA: DOING MORE TOGETHER
Address by Senator Gareth Evans, Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, to Malaysia-Australia Business Council Dinner, Kuala Lumpur, 22 July 1991.

I am delighted to have this opportunity to address this MABC/AMBC Dinner on the occasion of your inaugural Joint Meeting, not least because of the central theme of this occasion: ``Doing More Together-Malaysia and Australia in the 90s''. We have achieved a great deal together in the past; we are certainly capable of achieving a great deal more together in the future; and I think we would all acknowledge that there is scope for doing at the moment just a little more together than we are.

There is no question but that our commercial relationship has been built on firm foundations, and has scope for major further development. Total trade last year was $1.6 billion making Malaysia our third largest regional partner, after Singapore and Indonesia-and the total stock of investment was around $1.5 billion. These are more than 120 projects with Australian equity currently operating in Malaysia. Australian success stories here in the last year or two have included contracts for the management for the Port Kelang container terminal, catering services for Malayan Railways, engineering supervision for the Pergau Hydro Electric Project, communications equipment to Malaysian Telecom, and management and training services for the hospital system.

There is a sense of excitement among Australian businessmen I talk to about the potential of this country, not just at some unspecified time in the future, but here and now. Prime Minister Mahathir-especially with his articulation in February this year of the ``2020 vision'' and his announcement last month of the National Development Policy-has generated an image of Malaysia as a dynamic and purposeful country which knows exactly where it is going.

With real GDP growth at 9.7 per cent in 1990, and expected to be maintained at 7.5-9.0 per cent until 1995, there is every justification for that perception. The whole economy following the blueprint of the 1986 Industrial Master Plan has moved from primary dependence on commodities exports to its present status as a leading ASEAN exporter of manufactures.

Australian businesses contemplating investment here are not doing so with an image in their minds of Malaysia as a low income, low production-cost, developing country-but rather as a country where there is a strong (and strongly growing) skill base, a dynamic potential for sustained further growth, and a position at the hub of a very dynamic regional economy. At the same time Malaysia is seen as a country of our own size, with a partly shared cultural heritage, a strong defence relationship with us, and a long history of personal contact at all levels-all of which makes access and communication easier than in many other places.

These are some of the themes which provide the background to the Trade and Commercial Development Program for Australia in Malaysia now being developed. This program-and the published strategy document that will be associated with it will very much reflect the confidence we have in the potential of this particular relationship, and the efforts we are putting in to making it work. Aimed at promoting greater economic engagement between Malaysia and Australia, the Program, among other things, identifies twelve separate areas as particularly attractive for Australian investment: infrastructure development, energy supply, agro industries and agriculture, timber-based industries, rubber-based industries, construction materials, electronic products, precision products, machine tools, marine management and vessels, defence equipment, education and tourism.

Of course we are acutely aware that in today's highly competitive environment, in Malaysia or anywhere else, we have to get our own act together. We know that we have in the past had a reputation-in at least some parts of Asia-as lazy and flabby: not only economically and socially indulgent but arrogant and patronising as well. If there was ever any truth in that image-and there may have been just a little-we have had it well and truly beaten out of us. We have seen many other countries in our region getting their economic and social acts together, and rapidly ascending the growth and income tables. We are still a wealthy country-with spending power, despite our small population, roughly equivalent to all six ASEAN countries put together-but our comparative position has been sliding over the years, and we know that we have to fundamentally change our economic culture if we are to retain and build upon that wealth.

The Hawke Labor Government has been acutely conscious of the need to fundamentally reshape our economy, and there have been breathtaking changes to that effect over our term of office involving, among other things, deregulation of the financial system, rewriting of the tax system, corporatisation and partial privatisation of major government business enterprises, fiscal and monetary policies designed to strip inflation out of the system once and for all, and-above all-the stripping away of nearly all the protectionist baggage accumulated over generations of belief that we could not compete without it. We know now that we cannot compete internationally with the levels of protection we had. None of this adjustment has been painless, particularly in the international recessionary climate we have all been experiencing-but it has been necessary, and it has happened.

Part of the business of getting our act together in Australia has been to come to grips with the question of our basic identity. Are we to be forever seen as a European outpost, a kind of cultural misfit trapped by geography in an alien environment? Or are we to recognise that Australia's future lies inevitably in the Asia Pacific region-that this is where we live and must survive strategically and economically, and where we must find a place and role if we are to develop our full potential as a nation.

I strongly believe, although it is not always completely visible to those outside Australia, that there has been in this respect a fundamental change in the centre of gravity of the country in recent years. Partly this has followed from the way in which we have become more fully and innovatively involved in the affairs of the region, for example in relation to the Uruguay Round (with the establishment of the Cairns Group to represent the interests of fair agricultural trading nations, including Malaysia), APEC, Cambodia and regional security matters. All of these activities have enabled Australians to see their own country not as a mouthpiece for anyone else, but engaged as partners with other countries in the region in finding cooperative solutions to regional problems.

Partly it is a matter of economic imperatives: we know we have to export more and faster, and not just in our traditional commodity areas, and the message has finally sunk in that we are living beside the fastest growing and most dynamic set of economies in the world. We did have, because of our commodity trade since the early 1960s, a Japan consciousness (as well as a United States and a European consciousness) but we did not have an Asian consciousness. That is rapidly changing.

Partly also it is a matter of much greater exposure to Asian people than has ever previously been the case for Australians-as a result of high immigration rates, growing levels of tourism each way, more and more Asian students coming to study in our schools and universities, and increasingly, the amount of new business Australians are doing in Asia and vice versa. It takes time for this to translate into a genuine, sensitive understanding of the subtleties of other cultures, so far as the population at large is concerned, but I believe we are gradually getting there.

The important thing is that, as countries living and working and doing business with each other in this region, we work actively at stripping away the stereotypes that undoubtedly continue to exist in each of our countries about the other. Australia and Australians certainly deserve, I think, by now, to be released from some of the perceptions about us-those I have already referred to-that we may, or may not, have richly deserved in the past. And certainly I think it is the case that knowledgeable Australians-in which category I certainly include the kind of business representatives here today-have long seen the stupidity of characterising Malaysia and other countries in this region in the kind of terms that may or may not have been appropriate in the colonial era.

Sometimes, of course, the messages we would like to be sending each other in this respect get a little fractured, and I think we are all conscious that some problems of this kind have developed in recent times in Malaysia-Australia relations. A number of different groups of Australians-some in the media, some in Parliament and some in pressure groups in the wider community-have acted in a way which has been seen as not only insensitive to contemporary Malaysian realities, but on occasions downright insulting.

Among the matters which have caused offence in this way in recent years have been the public stances taken by some parliamentarians and others on the logging of tropical timbers, the future of the Penan people in Sarawak, arrests under the Internal Security Act in 1987, and the execution in 1986 of two convicted Australian drug traffickers, together with-most recently-the screening in Australia of the ABC television series, Embassy. These kinds of things tend to have a cumulative impact, and we are seeing that now in the reaction of the leadership of this country.

Faced with that reaction, one possible response by the Australian Government might be wounded indignation. But that would not be helpful. It is far better for us to try and understand the nature of the problem, and do what we can to resolve it in a quiet way. It is a matter of explaining what can be explained, acknowledging fault where it is due, and trying to ensure that there is a better basis for understanding in the future.

Some issues are just the product of differences of policy opinion. Australia completely respects the integrity of the Malaysian legal system, and the policy choice that has been made here about the best way to deal with the abhorrent business of drug trafficking-but we do have strong views in principle about capital punishment, and will go on expressing them, as we do now, anywhere in the world where executions take place, be it for example China, the Middle East or the United States. We will also as a government occasionally want to raise-preferably quietly-other issues from time to time which we see, for better or worse, as raising human rights questions. In return we accept absolutely the right of anyone else to raise such issues with us, for example over the treatment of Aboriginal people where we have had over the generations a great deal to answer for. We simply cannot have double standards on any of these issues.

Other issues which cause problems from time to time do not involve firm Australian Government positions, but are presently the subject of lively public debate. One such issue is the logging of tropical timber-not just in Malaysia but elsewhere in the region and, of course, in Australia itself. I say now that Australia is extremely conscious of the significance of this issue for a number of our neighbours; that we do take careful note of Malaysia's very firm commitment on environmental issues in the National Development Policy; that we believe this whole issue is one that cries out for an agreed multilateral solution; and that-whatever the final outcome-Australia will certainly not act in some capricious, unilateral way at Malaysia's expense.

The Embassy series is a particularly tricky issue for an Australian government to deal with because of our long established tradition of media freedom-not least in respect to the public broadcaster, the ABC, which operates completely at arms length from the Government, with an independent charter. We can, and do, criticise the ABC and other print and electronic media when they get things wrong, or behave ignorantly and insensitively. We can, and do, express the hope in these situations that they will get things right, or behave more sensitively, in the future. We can and do dissociate ourselves publicly from particular reports or programs when it is our judgment that to do so is necessary to get our own position clear. We cannot and should not be expected to comment on everything the Australian media says about other countries, but where there is a danger of the report or program in question being taken as an official Australian position, we can and do distance ourselves accordingly.

Moreover, in the case of relations with other countries in our region, we have supported a number of exchange programs designed to give our journalists a better understanding of other cultures-most of which cultures tolerate less brashness and public aggression than our own-and of the ways in which at least inadvertent offence may be avoided. But while there are a number of things we can do, and are doing, what we simply cannot do, consistent with our own political and social culture, is to direct anyone in the media how to behave, and I believe that this is well understood in the region.

In the case of Embassy, the Government has been satisfied from the outset that no offence was intended by the program's producers. Moreover-as I wrote to my Malaysian counterpart shortly after the series started-the ABC has made clear to us that it very much regretted that any offence had been taken. But offence was taken, and it has to be acknowledged that there was some basis for that occurring. The program, filmed in suburban Melbourne and Fiji, dealt with what was meant to be a wholly fictitious country, ``Ragaan'', incorporating characteristics of some twenty real-life ones, and with plot lines drawn from incidents and issues arising all over the world. The difficulty, as I think we all have to acknowledge, is that the producers had located ``Ragaan''-in a rather fuzzy map appearing in the first episode-not only in South-East Asia, but in a bulge half way up the Malay Peninsula! They had also, inadvertently so far as we can establish, included at least one or two other matters in various scripts which seemed to have a specifically Malaysian origin. It was obviously unfortunate that these particular exercises of dramatic licence occurred. We have discussed these points with the program's producers, who are sensitive to the problems involved. We cannot guarantee that similar problems won't recur in the future, but we very much hope that they won't.

Politicians are more conscious than most people how stereotypes catch hold with particular kinds of publicity, and can take forever to eradicate, even with the most minimal reinforcement. Stereotypes can and do exist, similarly, about whole countries-and it can be important not only for a country's pride, but its prosperity, that that stereotype not be reinforced. The last thing any of us in Australia want to do in relation to Malaysia, or any of our other Asian friends and partners, is to perpetuate outdated, damaging images. Our regional friends, like ourselves, have been adopting new, independent, proud national identities-and we need to acknowledge and respect that about each other. We need to develop, and encourage in our respective countries, clear perceptions of each other, and real mutual understanding. Much remains to be done, but the price of not doing it-as this audience will know better than most-is too great for us all.

So let me end with a sincere appeal-to Australians and Malaysians together, to governments and media and businesspeople alike-to put stereotypes behind us and get on with the business of business, enhancing our cooperation for our common good. Let us behave, more thoroughly and more often, as partners together in this dynamic and powerful regional economy-to which we both, together and separately, have so much to contribute; and from which we both, together, have so much to gain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind Ministers that I have asked them repeatedly in the past that if a senator has a question about a question on notice, Ministers should stay in the chamber until that question is asked. I call Senator O'Chee.
—Mr President, on 4 June I put a question on notice No. 883 to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy--
—If I am not given notice, I will not stay.
—On a point of order, Mr President. Senator Tate ignored your ruling, and blatantly said so. He claimed we should put it on notice and he was leaving the chamber.

—On 4 June I put a question on notice to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. That question has now been unanswered for more than 30 days and I seek an explanation from the Minister about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator O'Chee for indicating to me at the beginning of Question Time that he would ask this question at the conclusion of Question Time. During the course of Question Time I was notified by my office staff that Senator O'Chee contacted them on Tuesday to indicate that the answer to this question was out of time, and as a consequence of that an answer was faxed to him and an explanation that the answer had not cleared the Department of Primary Industries and Energy but that was the answer being considered by the Department. If that is right, I must say that I think an answer has been provided, but the wheels of bureaucracy have not turned sufficiently speedily enough. As a consequence, I have arranged to contact the responsible Minister to see whether in the future these answers can be supplied within the relevant time. However, I have an answer to the question and if it is appropriate I will read it now. The answer to the question is:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question. I refer the honourable senator to the answer to the identical question which he asked of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, question No. 884.
The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has advised me he has no further comment.
That concludes the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! During Question Time Senator O'Chee advised me that he was going to ask a question on a matter that had been on the Notice Paper for over 30 days. To avoid the situation that arose today, it might be of assistance were honourable senators to tell me which Minister is involved so that I can ensure that the Minister is present in the chamber. I was not aware that Senator Cook had been notified.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I claim to have been misrepresented yesterday during Question Time when I asked a question of Senator Bolkus, the Minister for Administrative Services, concerning a package he distributed to members of the Australian Labor Party dealing with the advertising ban. Senator Bolkus chose to reply to my question as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The point I was making was that this self-same question was asked in this place some three months ago.
He went on to say:
Senator Bishop got a response then. I do not know who asked the question at the time, but exactly the same question was asked. Maybe the honourable senator needs to get a new researcher, for a start.

First, I take singular exception to a cheap, snide attack on one's staff and would draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that a search of the database discloses that no such question has ever been asked, that indeed my reference in the body of that question to one Mr Peter Westerway has only been referred to once since, by Senator Parer--

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a point of order, Mr President. To this stage I have not heard a single reference to any point on which Senator Bishop claims to have been misrepresented. She has made two points: first, that she is concerned about a statement made about her staff and, secondly, that she disagrees with the substance of the Minister's answer. I understand that the prerogative to raise points of order seems to lie only with honourable senators on the other side, but I have heard nothing from Senator Bishop that constitutes grounds for a personal explanation. It may be a matter about which a proper political speech should be made, but I suggest it is not the grounds for a personal explanation.

—Order! I think Senator Bishop raised a point when she said that Senator Bolkus had said a particular question had been asked and it had not. I think that is within a personal explanation, but I ask Senator Bishop not to debate the issue.

—Thank you, Mr President. I will not debate the issue, but will simply put on the record the fact that I was misrepresented as to the question having been asked before and that I was given an answer before. First, the question had not been asked before and, secondly, I certainly had not been given the answer before. To me, that represents a pretty fair misrepresentation. No reference to the Labor Party package was made in this Parliament before I raised the matter yesterday, and it came on the public record because Senator Bolkus, through his own ineptitude, happened to send a copy of the package to Senator Boswell, and he happened to send it to me, complete with all the quotes about how Government members are to answer the criticisms which we make of them. So Senator Bolkus was simply misrepresenting me on the basis of his own ineptitude and acute embarrassment.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for the Government to bring down a Budget next week that will restore growth, investment and jobs to the economy and hope to the Australian people.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government has plunged Australia into a very grave economic and social crisis. Its centralist experiment with the lives of average Australians has failed catastrophically. The recession engineered by the Australian Labor Party-the one we had to have-has destroyed thousands of businesses and families. If there were ever any doubt about that, one would just have to refer to the national accounts figures produced today for the June quarter and for the year 1990-91 as a whole. Those figures confirm without any doubt the deep, protracted and rolling recession that this country is in.

SPEECH.PARA: Contrary to the assertions that Senator Gareth Evans made in response to questions from myself and my colleagues at Question Time today, that recession is not easing and the rate of decline is not falling. The rate of decline is accelerating and the fundamentals that are required to turn that around and provide sustainable growth and jobs in the future are simply not there-in fact, the fundamentals are weakening month by month. One only has to look at the savings and the investment figures to confirm that.

In my view, the most serious and long term disturbing element revealed in the national accounts figures today is the collapse in national savings and investment. It is a massive collapse. If we look at what is happening to private investment in this country, the figures show that total private gross fixed capital expenditure in Australia has fallen in six of the last seven quarters. It has fallen in virtually all components of fixed capital expenditure.

If we look at the figures for fixed capital expenditure in plant and equipment, which is probably the most important single component of capital investment if we are looking at the building of a productive base for the future in this country, we will find that there has been a fall in investment in plant and equipment in no less than eight of the last nine quarters. Not only that, but the fall has been accelerating. Investment in plant and equipment in the June quarter of this year was in real terms 19 per cent less than in the June quarter last year. That means that the prospect of providing the base on which a recovery of jobs and productive activity in this country is to occur is simply not there. Not only is it not there, but also the prospects of it ever being achieved are diminishing quarter by quarter.

We will never get investment in this country without savings. If we look at the savings figures, we will find that according to the national accounts figures released today-I find the figure quite extraordinary-national savings in the last year fell by 62 per cent. According to the official statistics, there was a 62 per cent fall in national savings in 1990-91.

The household savings ratio, which a decade ago was of the order of 10 to 12 per cent, is now down-and has been for a series of quarters now-to between 3 and 4 per cent. In other words, there are virtually no savings going into the national pool from the household sector. If we look at the non-household sector-the manufacturing and operating sector, the company sector-we find that the situation is equally as bad. Over the last four or five quarters the profitability of companies has continued to decline and has fallen in each of the last five quarters as a minimum. For example, in the June quarter it fell by more than the figure in the March quarter, which itself was a fall of 7.6 per cent. The three preceding quarters showed falls varying between 3 1/2 and 7 per cent.

The collapse of savings and the collapse of investment is the really stark thing that comes out of the figures produced today. There is no evidence in the figures that came out today for 1990-91 as a whole-either the national accounts figures or the balance of payments figures-of the so-called structural reform that the Government has been claiming for itself as building the base for a productive and sustainable future for this country. Again, some of the fundamentals have gone the wrong way. For example, if we are going to build a more productive Australia and one that is more internationally competitive, we have to have a situation where the ratio of imports to sales of goods and services in Australia falls. According to the official statistics released today, in the last quarter alone there was an increase of no less than 6 per cent in the ratio of imports to sales. The figure has gone precisely the wrong way.

The balance of payments figures for the year just completed as a whole show that the cost of servicing Australia's overseas debt, which now amounts to an enormous $135 billion net and is climbing daily, was $17.3 billion. That figure was larger than our current account deficit as a whole. The problem has more than quadrupled since the Hawke Government took office. It underscores the high and rising burden which is now being borne by average Australians as a result of years of neglect of the worsening foreign debt situation by the present Government.

No less than one-third of all the goods that Australia now sells is committed simply to servicing our foreign debt-simply to paying the interest on our foreign debt, which is $135 billion and rising. That equals a burden of $8,000 for every Australian. This Government has plunged Australia into an international debt crisis. Paying off the mortgage is the legacy which this Government will leave to Australians in the future. The consequence of that is that if Australia is to stabilise its overseas debt, let alone get it down, the growth in domestic spending will have to be substantially less than the growth in domestic production for several years to come-indeed, right through the decade of the 1990s at least.

Unless we can sustain high rates of economic growth greater than 5 per cent per year, that high debt servicing burden means a cut in our living standards. The prospects of any change in that over the year ahead are absolutely nil. Every prospect, even on the Government's own figuring, is for the reverse. As recently as 30 May, the former Treasurer told the Premiers at the Premiers Conference that the current account deficit in 1991-92 was forecast by himself and the Treasury to be 4 3/4 per cent of gross domestic product in that year. If that figure turns out to be correct, we will have a current account deficit in this new financial year, 1991-92, of between $18 billion and $19 billion. That is a current account deficit which is $3 1/2 billion worse than the one that we have had this year.

This year's current account deficit is the third highest in the history of our country-it was a figure struck in the depth of recession-yet the Government is telling us that it will be $3 1/2 billion worse next year. At the same time the Government is trying to tell us that it has set in place the fundamentals so that we can have a sustainable recovery in the Australian economy in terms of investment, job growth and increased living standards. Those two are simply incompatible. If we run a balance of payments deficit next year of between $18 billion and $19 billion, when this nation quite indubitably will still be in recession, heaven help us when we experience the economy really starting to pick up later on during the 1990s. The simple fact is that the situation is absolutely unsustainable.

None of the policies that the Government has attempted to adopt has in any way tackled those fundamental problems. Indeed, the policies have been directed seemingly in the opposite direction. The policies have been completely irresponsible. It now seems impossible under Labor for government to operate responsibly at all. The Government is torn apart by internal divisions. It is distracted by its fight to the death over who should be the boss, whose ego is going to win out of all this. It does not worry about the more than one million Australians who are now on the dole queues seeking jobs or who have simply dropped out of the available work force because they know that there is no work. Hawke and Keating say, `Let's just concentrate on our having a fight to the death over who is going to run this country'. The top job is all that counts with this Government. Meanwhile, millions of Australians suffer.

In the meantime the country is leaderless and directionless. This Government has failed the people of Australia. It has given up. It has no vision. Even Labor's traditional supporters know that it has deserted them and that it has lost its way. Every month, with every statistic that comes out, we are reminded of this abject failure in economic policy. I have already referred to the symptoms of that malaise, but the most chronic and cruel symptom of all is the collapse in employment. More than 308,000 people lost their jobs or, to put it in another way, more than 308,000 jobs were lost in Australia, over the past year. That is almost 1,000 jobs lost each day of the year-and that outcome from a government that boasts about creating employment and talks about its concern for social justice. If anyone can find a more hypocritical statement than the assertions by this Government that it believes in social justice and in the means of improving the lot of Australians, I have yet to hear it.

We have a recorded unemployment rate of 9.8 per cent. We all know that, when allowance is made for the fact that the participation rate has fallen and that people have dropped out of the work force, the underlying rate of unemployment in Australia at the moment is actually over 12 per cent-that is, as I said before, there are more than one million people out of work.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is about 40 per cent for youth.

—That is a tragic waste for Australia and an even greater personal tragedy for the victims of the Government. As my colleague Senator Baume reminds us, the figure is most tragic when it comes to youth. There are more than one in four young people in this country today out of a job.
—That is according to the official figures.

—It is according to the official figures, and the unofficial figures would have it very much higher than that. That is a disgrace. It is enormous in its implications. It is cruel and it is destructive beyond belief. Just in case anyone is tempted to doubt the honesty of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the question of employment, I remind the Senate of how he so callously deceived viewers of the 7.30 Report just 12 days before the last election, in March last year, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: And I'll tell you what, if you vote for me what you'll get, what you'll get is a continuation of record employment growth.

That was the same Prime Minister who said 10 days later, and two days before the election in 1990, that Australians had no need to fear a recession. Let us tell that to the average Australian today! Obscene as it may sound-and to me it is obscene-this economic disaster, with its inevitable devastating social consequences, is the result the ex-Treasurer now claims credit for.

In the face of such manifest failure, who but a person consumed with self-delusion could say, as Paul Keating said at the weekend, `I am very happy about my term as Treasurer'? He should ask the business men and women what they think about that. He should ask the unemployed and the underemployed. He should ask average Australians who have been forced to bear crippling mortgage burdens because he got it all wrong. He should ask his own constituency, if he has one left. Again last week the former Treasurer claimed credit for the low June quarter inflation figure. The following day those horrendous unemployment figures came out. Was he there to claim credit for that one too? Not on your life.

I see that time is going by. My colleagues will be wishing to fill in on many of the matters that I would like to have dealt with today but which time prevents me from doing. Let me now just say what I and the Opposition believe needs to be done next week in the critically important Budget to come to grips with some of these issues. In the light of what has to be done to correct the Government's mismanagement of the economy and to set Australia on the path to recovery, it is perfectly clear that the fiscal requirement, the Budget requirement, is to increase national savings. If we do not increase national savings, the problems that we have seen compounding in our nation over the last couple of years as a result of the policies of this Government will swamp us.

This coming Budget is no time to embark on new expenditure programs or to cut taxes without corresponding cuts in outlays. To do so would be absolutely and totally irresponsible. That is because Budget deficits reduce national savings. They plunder the savings of households and firms. A Budget deficit next week would worsen, not help to correct, our fundamental economic problem of inadequate savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, are you saying there should be no Budget deficit?
—I am saying that a Budget deficit next week would worsen our fundamental economic problem of inadequate savings.
—Do you think there should be none?

—In essence, yes. That is correct, and I am on the record as having said that before. Next week will be the real test of the Government. We will see whether it tries to buy short term electoral popularity or whether it is prepared to provide responsible government and the opportunity for sustainable job growth. I must say that at the moment the matter is not shaping up too well at all.
—And the Left using votes for Hawke.

—As Senator Patterson says, the big worry about next week is that the votes of the Left enabled Hawke to retain the position of Prime Minister. What will be the pay-off next week? We will see that next Tuesday. It is not shaping up too well at all at this stage. The Treasurer is apparently looking at a deficit point of $4 billion to $5 billion. What he has not come out openly with is that the underlying deficit is much greater when one takes account of assets sales, transfers to the States of responsibility for financing their maturing debt and so on. Those changes will give a cosmetic cut to the Budget deficit, but they will still impact on economy.

SPEECH.PARA: All the indications are that this Government will continue with its gross fiscal irresponsibility. If it does that, the structural changes required-that is, the boost to savings and investment in tradeables industries-will not take place. As a result, interest rates will be higher than they would otherwise be and we will go further down the road that this Government has set us on: a road of lack of hope and despair for so many Australians at that time when it is of absolutely critical national importance that that be reversed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reading the terms of the matter of public importance before us, one realises that very few people in Australia and in this chamber would not be supportive of the idea that the Budget ought to be concerned with growth, investment and jobs. I think those objectives would be shared by both sides of this chamber. I say `both sides' deliberately because, if some honourable senators had crossed benches from time to time to express some severe reservations about economic growth as a desirable objective, I would leave them to justify that position for themselves. But Government and Opposition senators would share the objective of an economy creating jobs through investment as a product of economic growth.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the objectives that are stated from time to time in matters of public importance, urgency motions and statements of what should be objectives of government activity, because the goalposts do shift from time to time. I notice that the desirability of achieving a low-inflation environment has gone off the agenda. Since that has been achieved, it is suddenly dropped and does not get a mention.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute nonsense.
—I shall read the matter of public importance again. I listened to Senator Short, and it did not get a mention. The goalposts change from time to time as the objectives are achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: My main point is not to pursue that-that is a matter for debate on another occasion-but to say that it does not enhance the debate on economic policy in Australia if people profess a monopoly over concern about issues like growth, investment and jobs. It is a shared concern of most Australians and, with the qualification that I made earlier, of all senators. We need to talk about-and we approach this from different philosophical frameworks-the most appropriate means and mechanisms for achieving that, and I want to return to that.

There is one question that people who do not have the responsibility for implementing policy often tend to gloss over in discussions about statements of agreed desirable outcomes like growth, investment, and jobs; that is, what is the timeframe within which those objectives are desirable? Are we talking about immediately? Do we want more jobs tomorrow? Are we talking about a two-to five-year period? Are we talking about over a generation, a lifetime, a career? What is it that we are talking about? In the main I want to talk about the next 12 months because I think we would all like to be here debating the Budget next year in a context in which economic growth, investment and jobs have all increased. I believe it is almost certain that that will be the situation.

All the indicators show that on balance that is the most likely outcome over the next 12 months, and I will refer to some of the signs and predictions that indicate that. Realistically we all have to say that nothing that any government does, whether by way of a budget or otherwise, will change the employment situation tomorrow. There is a long lead time for the consequences of the sort of initiatives we are talking about. We are now starting to see the slow return on the investment of major reductions in interest rates which the Government has undertaken over the past 18 months.

We do need, because of the attempt to corner the market in concern about jobs and growth, to look briefly at the historical record in a slightly more comprehensive timeframe than merely the past 12 months. As I usually do in these debates, I shall take not an arbitrary timeframe but that which is set out in the publication issued by the Parliamentary Research Service of the Department of the Parliamentary Library entitled Monthly Economic and Social Indicators, because it is a document which is available to us all.

Let us just look quickly at the number of employed persons over the period measured by that publication. From July 1986 until June 1991 there was an increase in jobs of 800,000, so there were 800,000 more employed persons over that period. If we wanted to take the period of this Government as a whole, we could get a much higher number but that then would be picking through arbitrary dates, and let me not do that. People talk about the change in employment as if, in some way, the Government's achievements have been caused by a fortuitous decline in the participation rate; but over that period the participation rate in employment has actually increased.

By most of the criteria, if we extend the period to a more realistic one, on balance we get a substantial increase in gross domestic product, in jobs, in the participation rate, et cetera. That is not to pretend that the past 12 to 18 months has not been an extremely difficult period for Australian families and households with the recession that we have had to endure; it is simply to say that to look forward we need to set our timeframes correctly and to assess the past we should not be quite so selective.

I think that the evidence and the signposts showing that the recovery is on the way are clear, notwithstanding the enthusiasm by the Opposition for selectively quoting all the figures that might indicate the contrary. When we look for signs of improvement in most modern Western economies, the first thing we look at is housing: housing investment, housing approvals, housing finance approvals, and housing commencements. The first sign that the easing of monetary policies is likely to have the expected impact would be probably be seen there. We would expect to see that that would then start to flow through to demand for services in the manufacturing area-bricks, cement, et cetera. That is when, as the output of the factories that produce those goods starts to increase, the industry begins to operate at full capacity and we then see investment flowing. We do not see investment flowing before we come out of a recession; it tends to follow. It is not one of those leading indicators.

Most of the surveys of leading indicators suggest that the economy is expected to move into a period of moderate growth during this six months in which we now find ourselves-and the figures released today are figures to 30 June. Most people expect this six-month period to be the start of a moderate period of growth which should continue through the financial year. That was certainly the prediction of the OECD; it is the most recent prediction of Westpac, for example, in its publication of August 1991. It expected that for the 1992 calendar year real GDP would increase by 2.3 per cent, with inflation at 3.5 per cent. That is a more moderate recovery from recession than we have had in the past, and in some ways that is a welcome feature. Australia has tended to be plagued by the boom to bust problem. We have tended to be plagued by coming out of recessions with a great surge, where governments buy short term advantage by priming the pump, sending the economy through the roof and then having to slow it down again. That tends to create a climate in which the slowdown drives us back into another recession, and we are back in the boom and bust cycle. If Westpac's predictions are correct, if the assessment of the indications of the OECD and almost every other economic analyst except those in the Opposition are correct, we would expect during the course of this six months to see the first signs of that return to economic growth reflected in the statistics and flowing through into improvements in jobs next year.

I have said that the recovery is more moderate than we have experienced when emerging from previous recessions, and that may be for a variety of reasons. The Treasurer (Mr Kerin) set down some of those reasons in an address to EPAC on 12 July when he indicated a number of factors that may influence that, the first being that although the world economy is expected to remain relatively benign and that activity should pick up, international conditions are unlikely to provide a major fillip to growth in the next 12 months. I might interpolate that everybody is concerned about speculation of a slowdown in the Japanese economy and its consequences for the Australian and other economies, nevertheless, on balance, the international factors indicate moderate regrowth. Secondly, the rural economy is likely to remain weak; and, thirdly, the non-dwelling construction sector is likely to remain depressed. In a sense those are the three causal factors. The fourth point is the policy requirement for overall demand to continue to grow less quickly than production as a means of coping with the balance of payments problem.

Although there is no doubt that we are on the doorstep of recovery and that we can expect that to become evident during this or the next quarter, it is a recovery that will be somewhat more moderate than usual, although in many ways that is desirable so long as that moderate recovery is sustained and sustainable.

If honourable senators have read the matter of public importance, they will see that it refers to what role the Budget should play in this-although Senator Short nearly forgot to talk about that. He only got on to what the Budget should do in the last couple of minutes of his speech. I understand that now and again we all get carried away with enthusiasm for criticism and we forget to say the last bit. Fortunately, Senator Short found that page in his speech towards the end.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got to remember your past to be able to prepare for the future, and we have to start from that dismal position.

—That is a very profound contribution and I look forward to the rest of Senator Brownhill's contribution. It is important to consider the role of the Budget in a circumstance such as this. I was somewhat perturbed-although, as he correctly said, it is not the first time he said that-when Senator Short spoke about trying to achieve a balanced Budget this year, in a recession. That is taking us back to the Sir Otto Neimeyer school of economics-that one comes out of a recession by imposing harsher and harsher stringency.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not advocating a massive return to pump priming. However, I share the view expressed by the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and every other spokesperson for the Government that what is called in jargon the `automatic stabilisers' ought to be allowed to operate. What has changed since the awful depressions of the 1890s and the 1930s is that modern fiscal policy and modern social welfare policy create a situation in which, as unemployment rises, government expenditure automatically rises to meet unemployment payments, government revenue falls through declining tax receipts and that provides an element of stimulus to the economy to operate as an automatic stabiliser. That is entirely appropriate. It is the reason that modern fiscal management is more humane and effective than its predecessor of the pre-Keynesian period.

Even the most conservative of economists is loath to advocate a return to a zero deficit where we are starting with a no policy change Budget outcome of a $5 billion deficit. I think $5 billion is the going figure-Senator Short said between $4 billion and $5 billion, so let us not quibble. I think that is actually the most recent figure. To suggest that we should slash that by $5 billion is suggesting a massive cut and a significant compounding of the problems of the recession just when the role of government will be exactly the opposite. It ignores entirely the social justice obligations of economic policy.

As the Treasurer, John Kerin, has been saying in a series of speeches-including that which was so inadequately quoted by Senator Alston at Question Time-economic policy requires a balance between concerns for economic outcomes and social justice. They need to be balanced. In a statement jointly with the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) about the preliminary Budget outcome for the last financial year, and going on to comment about the forthcoming year, the Treasurer said:

The prospective sharp swing in the Budget from a surplus of $8 billion in 1989-90 to an estimated deficit of around $5 billion . . . will serve to cushion the downturn and facilitate the recovery in economic activity.
The Government will not be aiming to offset the cyclical impact on the Budget--
I reiterate that it is very important that it does not. If we are seriously talking about growth, investment and jobs, it is fundamental that we should not try to do that.

For the Opposition spokesperson on finance seriously to attempt to say that there would be a reduction to a balanced Budget-$5 billion worth of cuts or increases in taxes to balance the Budget in a recession-is alarming, and should cause significant fear and concern among all those who are reasonably concerned about the implications of the recession as we currently have it. Any prospects, with a $5 billion deficit, of only a very moderate recovery during the course of this financial year would be smashed by such a contractionary Budget. I reiterate:

The Government will not be aiming to offset the cyclical impact on the Budget-the broad objective will be to protect the structural integrity of the Budget so that as the recovery proceeds the Budget will swing back into surplus and contribute significantly to national savings and the repair of our current account position.

That is where I join with Senator Short-everyone is concerned about savings in Australia. I have a significant concern about the methodological approach to the measurement of savings not only in Australia but also internationally. That is an issue that anyone concerned with economic policy will need to address. Nevertheless, we appreciate we need to do something about it.

In the time available-having said how I see the recovery that is emerging, and the role of the Budget in creating the climate for that recovery to continue-I refer briefly to what I certainly can assure the chamber the Budget will not do. The Budget will not-and in this climate it is entirely appropriate that it should not and, in any attempt to achieve investment, growth and jobs, entirely appropriate that it should not in the short term and the long term-involve that massive recessionary policy of $5 billion of cuts that Senator Short is advocating.

The Budget will not propose abolishing the capital gains tax to open the way for investment in short term capital gains instead of substantial productive assets. It will not propose introducing a consumption tax to blow out of the water the inflationary achievements of the Government and of its policies. The preconditions for sustained and sustainable recovery are there at the moment. We are on the doorstep of that sustained and sustainable recovery. We will not introduce a Budget with any of those elements which would combine to smash the incipient recovery, distort the investment patterns and blow our inflationary achievements out of the water.

The concerns that Senator Short's matter of public importance refers to-although his speech scarcely did-about growth, investment and jobs, are shared by almost all in this chamber and certainly by Government senators, not because they are ends in themselves-I do not think anybody would advocate that they are. They are the elements of those policies which contribute to improved living standards for Australians now and tomorrow. Therefore, they need to be seen as part of a wider range of measures.

The other elements of the Budget are concerned with social justice and the programs and initiatives that are introduced to improve the lives of Australians-where they live, assistance to families and the improvement of the environment in which they live. Those are the issues that also need to be assessed in the Budget in terms of its impact on the living standards of Australians.

The Australian people have shown the capacity to make their judgments about this Government and about the Opposition, not just by the current circumstances in which we find ourselves, but over the last eight years of this Government and this Opposition and to assess the respective merits and performances of each. If we put ourselves in the position-as I indicated at the start-of looking back in 12 months time at the financial year which has just started and for which this Budget will apply, we will see that there has been an improvement in growth, investment and jobs.

We are better placed to achieve that sustained and sustainable growth with adequate and appropriate public and private investment and skilled, lasting and productive jobs for Australians to provide a basis for those improved living standards for this generation and for our children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating as a matter of public importance the need for the Government to bring down a Budget that will restore growth, investment and jobs. It is a matter of regret that the speaker for the Government was unable to offer any positive indication of any measures that the Government intends to introduce in the Budget to achieve any of these aims.

SPEECH.PARA: All he did was tell us what would not be in the Budget. Unfortunately, the Government appears to be content to continue to leave it all to the market, to simply sit back, fold its arms and say, `With a bit of luck the market will fix it. The indications are that we will get there, so let us not worry about our responsibility as the Government to achieve the aspirations of Australian people, let us simply leave it all to the market forces'.

It was the Opposition-the coalition parties, I should say, because it is no longer a true opposition-that moved this particular matter of public importance. I have listened very carefully indeed to Senator Short's speech. He quite rightly and correctly outlined the desperate position we are in. He said that for the year to June, there will be a 2.4 per cent real decline in GDP; that investment in plant and equipment had declined in the June quarter by 19 per cent, compared with the previous June quarter; and that household savings which a decade ago were at 10 to 12 per cent were down to 3 to 4 per cent. He outlined the overseas debt, which is at $135 billion, costing $17.3 billion to service. He mentioned the figure of 10 per cent unemployment and he correctly stated that that is simply the tip of the iceberg, that the real figure is close to 12 per cent.

Once again I have listened carefully to find out what the Opposition proposes to do to address these problems. Once again I find that Senator Short has stated that there is a need to boost savings and investment, but I failed to discover in his speech even an indication of the measures that the Opposition would take to bring that about. So we are faced with a situation in which both the Government and the coalition parties are essentially standing back and saying, `Let's leave it to the market'.

Perhaps I am doing the Opposition an injustice, because there are one or two measures that we have heard about. The Opposition is saying that it will abolish the capital gains tax so that the rich can get a little richer again. It is going to abolish the training levy. Apparently, we are a clever enough society. Of course, we are going to have the consumption tax. Unfortunately, far from even providing an alternative Budget approach, the Opposition has not even put any detail into its proposal for the consumption tax. All we know is that bread and milk will be dearer and Maseratis will be cheaper.

Fortunately, other people have done some figure work, and I refer here to the current issue of the Bulletin. Looking at that, the pattern of the strategy of the consumption tax becomes very clear indeed. We find that at the income level of a typical taxable income of $65,000, the additional cost imposed by the consumption tax is $3,845, according to the Australian Taxpayers Association, based on the Australian Bureau of Statistics 1988-89 household expenditure survey. That amounts to approximately 6 per cent. So those people on a $65,000 taxable income will pay an extra 6 per cent.

People on a typical taxable income of $31,500 will pay $2,226 extra. We are creeping up to 7.5 per cent. But wait for it; people in the lowest income bracket, $10,244, will pay an extra $1,295, close to a 13 per cent increase. That is all we know about the strategy of the Opposition to achieve greater investment, greater savings and a reduction in unemployment. Actually, I am grateful for the opportunity to reinforce today the message of the Democrats' alternative Budget proposals, particularly since we have already heard a great deal of misrepresentation from the coalition benches. I will deal with our proposals in some detail.

What we would like to see in the Government's Budget is a strategy to achieve a substantial reduction in unemployment and a decisive move towards a sustainable economy. These are the aims of the Democrats' alternative Budget and we will measure the Government's performance against them. The particular approach that we have outlined in our alternative Budget proposals is based on the belief that we cannot sit back and accept the figure of one million unemployed. We cannot sit back and accept the figure of 28.5 per cent of young people out of work. This figure is close to the 30 per cent unemployment amongst young people in Germany's Weimar Republic which paved the way for the extremist solutions of Adolf Hitler.

I think we should be conscious of the future that we are not giving our young people. Already we see that crime rates are up and today we read in the paper that our prison population is up by 10 per cent. The signs are on the wall. However, as I have said before, this Government and the coalition parties-which are no longer in opposition because essentially they are doing exactly the same thing as the Government-are prepared to turn their backs and abdicate their responsibility and leave it all to the marketplace. They are not prepared to make any attempt to contain imports, to boost exports, to boost small business, to protect our industries from foreign control, or to strengthen the Foreign Investment Review Board. Currently, 40 per cent of our industries are under foreign control but that does not seem to worry either the coalition parties or the Government.

Our alternative Budget proposals go on to suggest that the action we need to take is specific and targeted assistance to industry sectors. We want accelerated depreciation in industry sectors where we have a comparative advantage and where the future lies: in information technology, in environmental technology, in pharmaceuticals and in the service industries.

We want to take part in export facilitation schemes rather than cut small business out. According to the Government, which has the support of the Opposition, only the big companies should take part in export facilitation. We would like a 5 per cent bounty on new exports to generate economic activity in those sectors. But that is not enough. Very clearly, we need to do something about public infrastructure in Australia. We need to increase expenditure on schools, hospitals and transport and communications. The Budget provides for $750m in infrastructure grants to the States to finance that.

Inevitably, the question asked is: how is this to be achieved? The Opposition has called for more savings and for internal capital formation, because obviously we should not borrow more overseas. Let me state what the Democrats propose. Firstly, we propose a tax rebate on the first $1,000 interest from funds placed into a development fund. Secondly, we are suggesting that the Government take steps to direct part of the burgeoning superannuation funds into areas which will provide productive investment and work and employment for Australians. Some $15 billion is currently flowing into the coffers of superannuation funds. If we took most of that, including a proportion of what superannuation funds have currently invested, we could reduce our foreign debt by one-third within three or four days.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want superannuation funds to go overseas?

—Senator Kemp should again read what our policy says. We are suggesting that superannuation funds should not take their funds offshore, that they should in fact be prevented from doing so, and that the financial system should be re-regulated.

SPEECH.PARA: We already have an answer on record from the Government on this particular matter. In answer to a question yesterday, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans), who represents the Treasurer (Mr Kerin), said that the Government is not going to give any directions to superannuation funds. A major opportunity is available to us to mobilise and direct in a targeted fashion a major accumulation of capital in Australia, and we are not prepared to take that opportunity. But that is not where it ends. Clearly, we must become more efficient and more intelligent in the way in which we tackle the other countries which are competing against us.

The Democrats believe that we must become not only a clever country but also an intelligent society. It is unacceptable that thousands of young people cannot find places in our universities. Our Budget provides for an increase in university places and also for an increased emphasis on trade training schemes.

The question we really have to answer when looking at the proposals of the Australian Democrats-proposals we would like the Government to implement-is whether we are prepared to accept the sort of unemployment we have now which has created misery and hopelessness for 28 per cent of our young people. In the closing minutes of the time allotted to me, I wish to turn to some of the points raised by members of the Opposition. Senator Macdonald obviously objects to imposing additional taxes on tobacco and alcohol. Our Budget proposal would get an additional $1.1 billion. Clearly, Senator Macdonald believes it is better to leave 28 per cent of young people without jobs than to make those people who wish to indulge in alcohol and tobacco pay a little more.

Senator Macdonald clearly objects to a land tax. I point out to him that our papers indicate a tax should be levied on land owned by foreign absentee landowners. I wonder what objection he has to that. He also objects to our proposal to recover road costs from trucking companies. I point out that there are at least two major reports-one by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics and the other by the Inter-State Commission, which was part of Treasury-which indicate quite clearly that the costs of road usage by trucks is not recovered by the current rates of registration fees.

What does Senator Macdonald want us to do? Does he want the Government to ensure that taxpayers pay for the costs of trucks using our roads? Clearly he does. Senator Macdonald mentioned one other matter; that is, the cut in defence expenditure-(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to contribute to this matter of public importance brought on by Senator Short today, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to bring down a Budget next week that will restore growth, investment and jobs to the economy and hope to the Australian people.

This will be the Hawke Labor Government's ninth Budget. The past eight have led us down the gurgler. We are hoping that this time a plug will be put in the plug hole so that we do not go down any further.

The debate is being conducted against a background of an economy paralysed by lack of direction, incentive and capacity. It is also being conducted against a background of economic turmoil and squabbles between a man who was Treasurer and wants to be Prime Minister and a man who is Treasurer and gives the impression he would rather be somewhere else. Both these gentlemen want to take credit for their former portfolios. Mr Keating is taking credit for what happened in his former portfolio; Mr Kerin wants to take credit for leading the farmers down the road to the worst position they have been in since the 1930s.

Australia today has an economic record of which almost any developed nation would be ashamed. We in the Opposition are appalled by it; the man in the street is pretty disgusted by it; but those on the Government benches are scrambling to take the credit for it. In fact, in Question Time today, Senator Gareth Evans took credit for the state of the economy.

Recently one Labor Party backbencher asked: who should take the credit for nearly a million people out of work? As Senator Short said, one in four of our young people are out of work. Who should take the credit for our foreign debt which costs every man, woman and child in Australia some $8,000 a year to service? Who should take the credit for interest rates which are among the highest of any OECD country and which are the highest in Australia's history? Who should take the credit for a record number of bankruptcies, forced sales and business closures? There is no sign on the horizon of recovery in the short term, despite the almost daily suggestions or wishful thinking by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

As recently as Tuesday, the Westpac bank ruled out any chance of economic recovery in 1991. Instead, it suggested that unemployment will get worse and is likely to stay above 10.1 per cent for the next 18 months. If we analyse each part of this debate-growth, investment and jobs-we see that the Government's performance in each sector has been absolutely abysmal. Even more depressing is the realisation, which we in the Opposition have come to, that the Labor Government has no capacity and no agenda for improvement in any of those sectors.

Let us look at the question of growth in the rural sector. The high point for agriculture is the record growth in the number of farmers. Four thousand eight hundred farmers are now receiving assistance under the rural adjustment scheme and another 9,000 farmers have applied for rural assistance. Seven per cent of all farmers in Australia are asking for assistance from the Government because they have been driven to the brink of bankruptcy-some have been driven to bankruptcy-by this Labor Government.

It is therefore not surprising to realise that with the number of farmers applying for assistance increasing, the number of farmers remaining in production is declining. In 1988-89 we had some 125,000 farmers, compared with nearly 170,000 in 1985-86. However, there has been a long term decline in the number of farmers which has continued unabated through the entire Hawke Government period. That is a sad indictment on the Hawke Labor Government.

In the absence of any performance capacity in the manufacturing industries, Australia relies very heavily on exports of rural commodities. Over its years in office, the Government has soldiered on under the mistaken notion that somehow metropolitan-based manufacturing, transport, tourism and service industries and no wealth creating activities will somehow pull us out of the problem we are in. The decline in the rural sector has reached such a level that the Budget next Tuesday will need to provide more than just the hinted additional assistance of $100m for the rural assistance scheme.

Listening to the new Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean, addressing the Press Club yesterday, I suggest that the rural sector is in for another let down. Minister Crean appears to take the view that as long as Australian farmers become more productive and somehow find ways to value add, then their problems will be over.
