He failed to say how farmers in this country can be expected to become more productive, given that we are already among the most productive in the world and in an economic and trading environment which positively discriminates against them being so. He failed to suggest how we can make manufacturing industries in this country more efficient in order to allow any benefits of a value-added industry to flow through. He also failed to suggest where, how and to whom Australia could sell these value-added products when we have a wage structure and an economic climate that prevents us from being competitive on the world scene.

Certainly, we have growth in small businesses; we have record growth in the number of bankruptcies. In the year to June 1991, a record number of 12,991 businesses-nearly 13,000-were officially declared bankrupt. This was an increase of almost 52 per cent on the previous year which, in itself, was 15 per cent higher than the year before.

I go around many of the country areas all over this country-as I know, Madam Acting Deputy President, you do in South Australia-and I see the number of shops which are closing in country towns. These figures do not include those which have voluntarily gone out of business, or have reduced staff or their services.

A recent paper published by the Australian Chamber of Commerce suggests that the external reasons for the low success/high failure rates of small businesses are, firstly, the plethora of regulations imposed and, secondly, a deterioration in the economy. The paper said:
This debasement of the small business environment has been compounded by the Hawke Government's recession-inducing higher interest rate regime.
As I said earlier, the former Treasurer-the would-be Prime Minister-takes the credit for giving us the recession we had to have.

I imagine that any one of those 13,000 businesses would be offended by-I find it somewhat galling-a glossy colour photograph publication called Small Business in Australia, recently published by the Minister for Small Business and Customs, Mr David Beddall. It is an extremely expensively produced public relations exercise which, I suggest, hides the true picture of small business in Australia. What a pity the Minister did not tell the real story with more facts and less coloured photographs, like the National Farmers Federation country crisis financial survey. This ANOP survey indicates that some grain farmers this year will have a 94 per cent drop in income, and even the least affected beef producers will have 42 per cent slashed from last year's figures.

So where is the growth for primary producers? With growing unemployment queues and declining markets for our rural products, the future for farming looks bleak. The future for young farmers is one of increasing pessimism and hopelessness.

On investment, what has this Government done to stimulate the economy? We have a forecast current account deficit at the end of 1991 of $15 billion, or 3.9 per cent of our GDP. Servicing that debt costs every Australian $8,000 per year.

Westpac suggests that continued poor prospects for rural incomes will put the brakes on a full recovery for manufacturers for the next 18 months. The finance sector is expected to continue to face difficulties through next year. The Commonwealth Bank paints no happier a picture. It says that the household savings ratio has fallen to its lowest level on record and is coupled with a serious deterioration in consumer confidence. Retail trade figures released on Tuesday support that, retail sales having fallen in June. People are saving less and spending less simply because they have less disposable income, notwithstanding the magic cure-all of a lower inflation rate.

There is no incentive for anyone to invest in Australia at the present time. Notionally, interest rates are supposed to have come down. Housing loan rates are around 11.5 per cent. But talk to people in business, go and talk to any of the farmers, and one will find that they are not able to get any rate better than between 15 and 16 per cent. For those who are considered at risk, the margins are often some 5 per cent higher than that figure. The New South Wales Farmers Association wrote to me only yesterday expressing:

. . . extreme concern at the level of interest rates. Despite a great deal of publicity on falling nominal interest rates, the situation remains that real interest rates (the difference between stated bank rates and inflation) are still extremely high in both historical terms and compared to our overseas competitors.
The letter goes on to say:

The economy will not recover from a recession without a major increase in investment by business. If we do not get an investment led recovery, especially in the international trading sectors of the economy, we will continue along the path of `stop/go' economic management that will bring us to another recessionary crunch after a consumer spending led recovery.
I ask: how do we improve the economy? I will come to that in a moment. I know Senator McMullan wanted that question answered. He has now left the chamber-obviously he is not on duty at the moment.

When we move to the third element of the debate, the issue of jobs, we get to probably the most savage and heartless result of the Hawke Labor Government's handiwork. Unemployment, predicted at 10.5 per cent by the end of 1991, is higher than the UK at 8.9 per cent, the EEC average of 8.7 per cent and the OECD average of 6.8 per cent. Statistically, it sounds awful, but when we translate that to real people it is absolutely frightening. That is what this Government has shown no regard for.

There are currently nearly one million Australians looking for a job, and that does not take into account those who have given up the search. Last month over 44,000 people gave up looking for work; if they had not, unemployment would have been at 10.3 per cent. It will most likely reach that figure well before the end of this year.

The number of people receiving unemployment benefits grew by 10,000 to 700,000-odd in July, with 38,300 more people looking for work than in June. The cost of those on unemployment is estimated for 1990-91 to be just under $3.5 billion. Who pays for that-the ever-shrinking work force and businesses which do not have any incentives from the Government?

In this matter of public importance debate we have asked for policies which will restore growth, investment, jobs and hope to the Australian economy, but there are no signs that this Government is either willing to provide or is capable of providing the necessary reforms. It is a truism that leaders must lead, but this Labor Government, with at least two people at the moment wanting to lead it, is still leaderless.

The Opposition has a firm policy mix to restore incentive, growth, investment and hope to the economy and to the community. We must have taxation reform and a simpler tax system that gives incentives to people who want to work harder, earn more and save, so that they can have more money in their pockets at the end of the week to spend or save in the way they want to. As Senator Short said earlier in this debate, there has been a 62 per cent fall in savings in the last financial year.

We need labour market reforms. In some industries Australia is being dragged screaming into the twentieth century, with wage contracts removing at last the monopolistic powers of union bully boys who for too long have crippled industry and incentive in this country. We must have efficiency in telecommunications, transport, shipping, the waterfront and power generation. Despite the opinion of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that all is well and that real reform has started on the waterfront, it has not started in a way which will enable us to become competitive on world markets.

We have hopes-and I am sure that Senator Short, leading this debate, has hopes-that these vital issues will be addressed in next Tuesday's Budget. We have hope, but very little expectation, that this Government has the fortitude or the policies to do the right thing; that is, to take actions to restore Australia to prosperity. Let us hope that it has the guts to put the plug in the bath so we all do not go down the gurgler as we have been doing for the last eight Budgets that this Government has brought down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon we are debating a matter of public importance raised by the Opposition which, in effect, calls for an expansionary Budget next week. The Opposition is calling for that because it claims there is a need to boost growth and investment in jobs in the Australian economy. I interpret the motion as calling for an expansionary Budget next week.
—You had better understand your economics.

—I do. How can we do these things if the Opposition is not calling for an expansionary Budget? I find this quite strange. The point I was making on Tuesday when we spoke on a very similar subject was that economic activity in the present day and age does not reflect the policies in place in the present day and age; it reflects the policies that were in place in the past. There are enormous time lags in economics. One may talk about 15 to 18 months in some cases between changing policies and actually seeing a real effect on the economy. That is the reality of some aspects of monetary policy. We have to be very mindful that even though we might change a policy, it can be many months before there is a tangible impact on investment, production or jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: Economic policy in 1989-90 was very tight indeed. The objective of that was to restrain the demand for imports into the Australian economy. There was a large gap between the ability to spend and the ability of the Australian economy to produce, and that gap was filled by imports. The policy of the Government was to reduce imports, and it has succeeded in doing that.

Policy is now less restrictive than it was last year. Monetary policy has been relaxed. At the beginning of last year official cash interest rates were 18 per cent, and now they are 10.5 per cent. We have seen a 7 1/2 percentage point reduction in official cash interest rates. Borrowing is much cheaper. We have only to look at the surveys--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your high interest rates are right throughout the system.

—Senator Brownhill clearly has not seen the surveys of home affordability published in recent weeks, which clearly show that it is much easier to service a loan now than it has been in the last couple of years. Fiscal policy has been relaxed. From 1 January we have had a significant reduction in personal income tax. The cost of that to revenue was $2,500m in a full financial year. We have seen that impact on the level of household disposable incomes, through the increase in take-home pay. That has been attained in that way rather than through extra wage claims. Those tax cuts themselves should help boost economic activity.

SPEECH.PARA: We had a Budget forecast for the last financial year of a surplus of $8.1 billion, including the tax cuts. In reality, that was the fourth Budget surplus in a row. We have had also the impact of the so-called automatic stabilisers in the economic system, which reflected the position and the economic situation of Australia. Those automatic stabilisers worked both to reduce the Government tax take from the rest of the economy and to lift expenditure for cyclical reasons, for example, through higher unemployment benefits. Those two things-the lower revenue and the higher expenditure on benefits-have also helped to underpin and cushion the Australian economy over the last 12 months. Those automatic stabilisers saw the forecast Budget surplus reduced, in reality, to a preliminary figure of $1.8 billion.

When looking at the Budget this year, we must look at the setting for the Budget. Today the Opposition has raised a matter of public importance calling for what I have interpreted as an expansionary Budget. But let us look at the economic indicators. There has been a very tangible improvement in the balance of payments current account. That has been the number one objective of economic policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder-you have driven the economy through the floor!

—I remind Senator Kemp that unfortunately the balance of payments has been the main constraint on Australian economic growth in the post-war period. In 1989-90 the deficit was $22 billion. In the financial year which has just ended it was reduced to $15 billion, with an 8 per cent increase in exports. They are all official figures on the public record which show a tangible improvement in that part of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Inflation, I am sure, has been mentioned already this afternoon by honourable senators on my side of the House. We now have prices rising by a mere 3.4 per cent per annum. The figure for last year was 7.7 per cent. So in a financial year we have more than halved the rate of increase in consumer prices in Australia. We are now becoming much more competitive compared with our trading partners on the question of costs. The average rate of price rise in our trading partners was 4.3 per cent in the last financial year.

Interest rates are down; inflation is down and we are starting to get the economic fundamentals right in the Australian economy. However, there is great concern on this side of the chamber about the level of unemployment. The 9.8 per cent unemployment figure released last week showed the level of the problem in the Australian labour force. Unemployment is almost back to the recessionary figures of 1982-83. We understand the concern of the community and the anxiety in many Australian families about their livelihoods. We can certainly see the impact that the recession has had on opportunities for full time male employees. Today we have learned of the one per cent fall in gross domestic product in the June quarter. Obviously, that is of concern to this side of parliament. But in making that comment I note that the March figure has been revised upwards. One thing we have to be very mindful about with these gross domestic product figures is the numerous and significant revisions that are made to the data from time to time. So that is the current situation.

There are a number of other positive economic indicators in the marketplace that I am sure have been ignored today on the Opposition side of the chamber. The largest survey done in Australia of business expectations is the Dun and Bradstreet survey, which is coordinated through Melbourne University. It is a very large survey, with 1,000 business respondents. It is showing an expected September quarter which is much better than previous quarters. The index compiled in the Dun and Bradstreet survey of data for the September quarter is showing its second successive quarterly rise. More firms are expecting more orders, more firms are expecting higher dollar value sales, and the expectation is that the manufacturing sector will lead an economic recovery. I heard Senator Brownhill talking about housing and interest rates a moment ago. The reality in the housing sector is that in May a 1.1 per cent increase was recorded in the number of housing loans. Compared with May last year, a 10 per cent increase in the number of housing loans was recorded. That again reflects increased housing affordability in the Australian economy.

The Budget outline from the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) for this financial year has a starting point of a deficit of $5,000m. This will be the first deficit in five financial years, because we have had Budget surpluses in the last four financial years. That $5 billion deficit is a cyclical one, reflecting the decline in Government revenue and the increased payments through social security. It is not a structural deficit and it is not a long term deficit; it is one reflecting the stage of the economic cycle we are in at present.

It is legitimate to ask what the Liberals really want. What did they want when they put forward this matter of public importance today? For example, do they want a larger Budget deficit? They talk about restoring growth in investment and jobs. Are they in fact calling for a larger Budget deficit? One has to look at their track record to get to the facts, and the reality is that the Liberal Party in government, year after year, delivered Budget deficits. On the basis of that, I assume that those opposite are calling for a Budget deficit. Alternatively, would they follow their rhetoric about cutting government expenditure? Certainly, Mr Reith, when doorstopped on 1 July, laid out some very strong hints about cuts in government spending. Would the Liberals privatise the Department of Social Security? Dr Hewson has actually raised, for the first time in Australian history, the privatisation of that Department-as a means, I presume, of cutting Government spending. They are some of the measures that Liberal speakers need to explain and own up about.

One thing that we can be absolutely clear about is that the Hawke Budget to be brought down next Tuesday will not include a consumption tax. It will not include a value-added tax, as proposed by the Liberals. We will be doing quite the contrary. We will be reforming the wholesale sales tax. One of the initiatives to be taken in the Budget, which will cost the revenue $200m this financial year and $375m next financial year, will be to exempt more inputs into business production from sales tax. We are going to exempt a range of raw materials and equipment, inputs into business production, from the wholesale sales tax, at a cost to revenue of $200m.

We certainly will not be bringing in a general tax on expenditure, a value-added tax, which the Liberal Party has as the cornerstone of its policy. It wants to tax virtually all goods and services produced in the Australian economy at a rate of 15 per cent. So, for the first time in Australia's history, if a Liberal Budget were being brought down we would have a tax on food, clothing, footwear, services such as electricity and gas, bus fares and so forth. That 15 per cent tax would kick-start inflation and lift the consumer price index by 7 per cent in one go. I think the relevance of this matter of public importance, as the Liberals have called for a Budget to bring down growth, investment and jobs, is to ask: how would a consumption tax in a Liberal Party Budget boost jobs? After all, a consumption tax, by definition, is a tax on spending. If spending generates jobs, how does a consumption tax help to generate jobs?

One thing that is clear about this proposed tax is that it will cheapen the price of luxury goods. At present, luxury goods face a 30 per cent sales tax rate. Under the Liberals, we would see a 15 per cent tax on luxury goods. The reality is that overwhelmingly the luxury goods consumed in the Australian economy are imported. So the Liberals will cheapen the price of luxury goods and kick-start luxury imports. That is the reality. They will see people substituting luxury motor vehicles for Australian made motor vehicles because the top-of-the-range motor vehicles will be relatively cheaper. We will see production and jobs transferred offshore. So how on earth can a Liberal Budget, based around a value added tax or a consumption tax, generate jobs if it has this effect?

We could also ask how a new tax on food, clothing, fares, electricity and telephone bills would help the unemployed anyway? All these things would be taxed for the first time in Australia. It is clear that low income families spend a very high proportion of their total incomes on food and clothing-all the Budget studies show that. The Liberals would have a Budget which would tax equally margarine and Mercedes, yoghurt and yachts, and fruit and furs. This is the outrageous, unfair and unacceptable tax proposal that they would base a Liberal Budget around.

The point to bear in mind is that not only would this policy have these effects but also it would create more red tape. For years I have listened to Liberal Party members and senators talk about red tape for business and the amount of paperwork generated for business by government regulation, and so forth. That is their rhetoric.

When we look at the proposal for a consumption tax or a value added tax, as it will be known, we see the potential for an enormous escalation in the amount of business red tape and paperwork. For example, at present the sales tax in Australia is a wholesale tax. There are far fewer wholesalers than retailers. Approximately 75,000 wholesalers are the collection points for the current sales tax, but about 750,000 retail businesses would have to file returns and paperwork for the value added tax. So we will see a vast increase in the number of tax inspectors needed to check on the value added tax. For example, in the United Kingdom it costs $2 for every $100 of revenue to collect the value added tax. At present, the Australian sales tax costs 50c per $100 to collect; that is, a quarter of the cost of the value added tax.

Clearly, the Liberal Budget plans for jobs and the unemployed really revolve around a tax inspector led recovery. That is what the Liberals are on about because a value added tax would have to be to checked at every stage of production. We would have more bureaucracy and red tape and there would be thousands and thousands of jobs for tax inspectors. Our Budget next week will cushion the downturn in the economy, facilitate recovery and promote greater fairness. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the chamber today reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to bring down a Budget next week that will restore growth, investment and jobs to the economy and hope to the Australian people.

It has to be said that the Government has given up on employment and workers' living standards. I ask honourable senators in the chamber to reflect on this. Senator Sherry, who is a former trade union boss, might particularly like to do so. Who would ever have thought that at a national Australian Labor Party conference a motion suggesting that cutting unemployment should be Labor's top priority would be defeated? If we ever want to think of the difference between this mob over there and the Labor Party of old, I suggest that the defeat of that motion says it all.

Who could imagine a Curtin or a Chifley, or even that man whose name is not particularly hallowed in this place or around Australia-Gough Whitlam-would ever have been prepared to accept that unemployment was not of great concern to the Labor Party? In the old days we used to think that Gough Whitlam had run the worst government in Australian history. Indeed, that is what the new look Labor Party used to think. This Government makes Gough Whitlam's Government look not good but certainly not the worst government in Australian history. Even Gough Whitlam could not match the figures of this Government-the Government of the Hawkes, the Keatings, the Kerins and the Bolkuses.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Abeles and the Keltys.

—And the Abeles and the Keltys; that is a nice comment from Senator Short. A record fall in national income was announced today. They are incredible statistics which do not provide hope to people but indicate despair in the way this country is going. A record net foreign debt was announced of $133 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: Record unemployment is what this Government has given us. The Government has conceded that unemployment will rise to almost 11 per cent. Senator Evans was asked today by Senator Short to give his latest forecast. He twisted and turned in the wind, hedged and even refused to confirm the Government's existing figure of just under 11 per cent.

Record youth unemployment and a record fall in living standards-what a record for a Labor Government. I suggest that Senator Cook get his Department, as he always does, to go through the national accounts and look at what has happened to per capita household disposable income. If that is what Senator Cook uses to measure living standards, he will find that the living standards of the Australian worker and the Australian family have fallen even further. The Hawke Government and the ACTU-which comrade Ferguson told us not so long ago is part and parcel of this Government-are presiding over a human and economic disaster, the magnitude of which we have not seen since the Depression of the 1930s.

I give Senator Maguire and Senator Sherry points for standing up today to defend this pathetic Government. One would have to say that that takes an act of political courage; there is no question of that. In the old days, Labor used to say, `We will strike this accord with the trade union bosses. We have an accord so that we do not have to have a fight inflation first policy. We could drive this economy, spend up big, borrow big and avoid inflation and a major recession'. That was the rationale for the accord when Labor started it. But what has the Government done? It has run the economy and workers' living standards right into the ground. It is now cutting workers out of jobs which they have often held for years. For a Labor Government, the present Government is an absolute disgrace.

Senator Maguire talked about his general fears for a goods and services tax, the very tax that Keating and Hawke promoted so vigorously in 1985. Were they lying or were they telling the truth in 1985? Senator Sherry will be coming into the chamber and I will ask him that question. In 1985 Labor said that this was one of the major reforms to make a fairer tax system. We have volumes of quotes from Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, both of whom argued that point.
Labor is the world's expert at raising taxes. We shall be going to the next election with a program to cut taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the rich.

—Overall. That will be Labor's big problem; people will pay fewer taxes and they will pay them in a fairer way. Labor allowed the tax cheats to get off the hook. According to Mr Keating, one of the great features of this goods and services tax was that it would rip the hell out of the black economy. They are Mr Keating's words, not mine. What happened to that plan? Labor gave up on it because it was gutless.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the plan to get out of this recession? Senator Spindler stood up and told us the solution of the Australian Democrats. We can sum that up in a couple of words: more taxes. That is the Democrats' solution. There are over 50 new revenue measures in the alternative Budget entitled The Achievable Vision proposed by Senator Coulter and his colleagues to raise a huge $6.4 billion. That is the solution of the Australian Democrats. Do honourable senators know what that $6.4 billion would equal per family of four, and what sort of burden that would place on them? It is $1,300.

I can tell Senator Coulter that we will be going around the countryside debating the Democrats on their Budget. This Budget will come to haunt them. Everywhere they go, Australian families will be asking, `Why do the Australian Democrats want to impose these higher taxes on us?'. Then they will see this massive spending program that the Democrats have in this Budget-

TALK.START.PARA: —How much was that again for each family?
—Each family would be paying an additional $1,300 a year under this alternative Budget put down by the Australian Democrats.
—I will debate you any time.

—Senator Coulter has the chance to debate me any time. Make no mistake, this alternative Budget being promoted by the Australian Democrats is an invitation to the Hawke Government to bring in new taxes. It has 50 new revenue measures. The Democrats are telling Mr Hawke and Senator Bolkus, `Take your pick, because the Australian Democrats will pass these new taxes through this chamber like a shot'. There will be no argument on that basis.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats have got a capital gains tax, inheritance taxes, wealth taxes-all those taxes that they love so much. They are all in here and the Democrats are telling Mr Hawke, `Bring them in and we will pass them through this chamber'. That is their policy and they believe it is going to have some effect on this recession. What utter nonsense! I ask Senator Coulter: where will this $6.4 billion be spent? Not on the needy. Who are the big winners? It is the public sector and the special interest lobbies.

This is, to my mind, a dishonest document. The calculations are not only rubbery but also plainly wrong in a number of key areas. Senator Coulter should ask Senator Spindler to go back and calculate the cost of the increase in family allowances that he proposes. The calculation is not the figure he quotes of $500-odd million; it is over $2 billion. What a hole in this alternative Budget.

This is the sort of crazy Budget that the Australian Democrats have brought down in trying to convince the Australian community that they have a social conscience. Let us look at some of these things. Australia wants to encourage exports. Senator Spindler says that. Senator Coulter stands up here and says that. Yet they want to impose higher taxes on black coal exports, do they not? That is what they want to do. They want to stop woodchip exports-that is their policy. They want to prevent uranium exports-that is their policy. They want to stop live sheep exports-that is their policy. But they have the cheek to put in this document that what we need to do is encourage the export sector. They want to stop the export sector and bring it to a grinding halt.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to increase the export of grandmothers.

—I hope that as Senator Coulter goes around the Barossa Valley and the Murray Valley-where there are lots of people who have been listening to Senator Lees talk about Austudy-he tells the wine producers, and all those people and their families who are dependent upon the wine industry for their employment, that he wants to impose a 40 per cent increase on excise taxes in the wine industry. He would wipe out the wine industry in his State. I assume that Senator Coulter strongly supports this policy. I am sure there is no doubt that Senator Hill will make sure that all--
—That is totally dishonest.

—That is what is proposed in this document. We can go on. I assume that Senator McLean is happy to have the additional tax on black coal imposed on exports from the Hunter Valley. I assume that Senator Kernot is happy for the additional black coal tax to be imposed on coal exports from the Bowen Basin. I assume she is.
—No, I can't believe that.

—I hope that Senator Macdonald-because Senator Kernot is so happy about this-will visit the Bowen Basin and inform people that the Democrats' policy to get Australia back on track by encouraging exports is to put an export tax on black coal. I hope he goes out and makes that very clear. In Victoria, my own State, the Democrats now want to impose a tax on brown coal. That is what they want to do. That is their policy. It is in their policy-take a look.
—Not on exports. Read the words, if you can.

—Take a look. That is what the Democrats will be doing. They will be imposing a tax on brown coal. There is no argument there about brown coal. It is consumed in Victoria. They want to impose a tax on brown coal, do they not? That is what they want to do. I hope that when Senator Powell and Senator Spindler go down to the Yallourn Valley, where the Democrats have been cultivating voters as hard as they can, they will get out and sell the idea that somehow we must have higher taxes on these products. I think they have a huge task ahead of them.

SPEECH.PARA: What else do the Democrats want to do? They want to slash defence spending-as Senator Mcdonald has pointed out in this chamber. All those defence establishments around Australia are going to be absolutely delighted at the massive cuts that the Australian Democrats are proposing in defence. We know they do not believe in defence because of their behaviour over the Gulf war. The Democrats are one of the few parties in the Western world that were prepared to oppose that Gulf commitment. We know how the Democrats feel about defence, but I am proud to say that most Australians do not share those sentiments. If the Democrats want my view, the reason why the polls are showing that their vote is going through the floor is the crazy policies that Senator Coulter and his colleagues are going out and promoting day after day.

Senator Bolkus is in the chamber. He has been a Minister in this Government for many years now. He sits there grinning like a Cheshire cat. He looks at the paper and finds that the national income has gone through the floor today; he finds that the unemployment figures are rising and that young people leaving school and university cannot find jobs; yet he sits there and grins like a Cheshire cat.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not as big a failure as you are.

—It is a good joke for the Labor Party, but a few of us in the Liberal Party do not believe that. The reason why we have a major program to reform this country and its structures-our tax structures, privatisation policy, industrial relations policies, tariff policies-is to try to get this economy back on track so that we can tackle the issues that those opposite are too scared to tackle. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate, the areas I intend to deal with include the relationship between Australia and the rest of the world-which is pertinent in terms of our Budget strategy; the economy over the next 12 months; some of the initiatives of the current Federal Labor Government in its Budgets over the past decade; and also, in the Budget context, some of the initiatives that I hope will be contained within it.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I commence, I must say that I think it was a bit rich of Senator Kemp to make such heavy going of the 40 per cent tax on wine when, in fact, one of his solutions to the budgetary problems-and he boasts about one of the economic solutions the Opposition will be presenting to this country in its first Budget, if it is ever elected-will be a 15 per cent consumption tax. One of the three main solutions the Opposition has for this country is to impose a new tax on everything that is produced and moved in this country. If he has the gall to complain about a 40 per cent tax on wine-which I do not agree with-and if he has the gall to propose a 15 per cent consumption tax on everyone, we look forward to his trying to sell that.

In terms of the Australian economy and the world economy-which has not been touched on in this debate-there have been some very important changes over the last 30 years in respect of international conditions. During the 1980s there was increasing internationalisation of the Australian economy, and that is a trend that is conveniently ignored by those opposite. The result of this increasing internationalisation is that more than ever our economic fate is linked with the developments that are occurring in the world economy, and particularly in Asia. This change is reflected in our international trade statistics.

During the 1980s the volume of Australian exports of goods and services, as a share of gross domestic product, increased from 14.4 per cent to 17.7 per cent. Import penetration increased at a faster rate. So now in the last decade more than ever our future is linked with the international economy. Unfortunately, those opposite did not adopt the strategies during their very lengthy periods in government to enable us to move though that transitional economy in much better shape.

The difference in our performance on the two sides of the trade account is reflected in a larger current account deficit throughout the 1980s and, with the shift in financing towards debt and accompanying substantial increase in our external debt, although great mobility of international capital allows us time to get our current account down, the task of tackling this imbalance remains of the utmost importance. We have been tackling that consistently over the last eight years in the Budgets that this Government has presented.

In terms of the economy over the next 12 months, it is certainly correct that the economy remains subdued, but there are some encouraging signs of recovery. Because economic data does lag, some of the views of the economy are necessarily intuitive, but there is sufficient anecdotal evidence, backed up by judgments about changes in economic fundamentals, as well as the timing of the various factors. Some of the important recent indicators released include: building approval statistics, which contain the first hard evidence that the building activity may be turning around, especially in the private residential sector; the latest housing finance statistics, which show an increased interest in the housing market; the index of consumer sentiment, which has risen for the fourth consecutive month to its highest level since May 1989; and also the CAI-Westpac survey of industrial trends, which suggests that the decline in manufacturing may be bottoming.

Indeed, in commenting on this survey, its authors noted that the turning point in expectations recorded in the June quarter was similar to that which preceded the 1983 recovery in manufacturing production. These are early signs that indicate the economy will be recovering towards the end of this year and into next year. I have already mentioned that the dwelling sector is now showing signs of responding to the improved affordability of houses. Also important will be a modest pick-up in private consumption.

My colleague Senator Maguire has already outlined the devastating effects of a consumption tax on consumption. One does not have to look very far across the Tasman Sea to New Zealand to see that the consumption tax, amongst other factors, has flattened the New Zealand economy. The New Zealand economy is in a state of soporific torpor. It has just been completely wiped through the floor. The entire retail industry, which has been heavily affected by the consumption tax, has been falling apart, and that is one of the prescriptions that the Liberal and National parties want to impose in their first Budget, should they ever get the chance.

In the medium term, of course, business investment will play a crucial role in underpinning sustained growth in demand and employment. It is the Government's goal to put in place a policy framework that will foster business confidence and encourage strong growth in business capital.

The current state of the labour market gives me no satisfaction. The unemployment rate of close to 10 per cent-and in my home State 11.5 per cent-represents a significant cost to the Australian economy; and there is no doubt about that. It reflects the real hardship that is being suffered by hundreds of thousands of Australians. Ultimately, however, we must pursue policies that produce sustained growth in output and end the boom and bust cycles that this country has been through for the last 100 years. Those opposite have failed to meet the challenge. We have to break those cycles in this country, and the policies that this Government has adopted have contributed towards ending that sort of cycle.

We are enduring heavy costs in this recession, but we now need to take full advantage of the opportunities that exist to achieve sustained low inflationary growth. Again, when those opposite were last in office before they were removed by the Australian people, there was massive unemployment and significant inflation. In their seven or eight years-which, I note, many leading members of the Liberal-National Party considered wasted years-they did nothing to improve the fundamentals of this country. For years and years this country sat behind high tariff walls. When we had full employment, when we had the opportunity to make significant adjustments in a range of industries, what did those opposite do? They did nothing. They sat behind those tariff walls and, as a consequence, we have to catch up very quickly with the rest of the world in terms of the tariff adjustments that have to be made. It would have been much better for this country, and much easier, if those adjustments had commenced decades ago.

I turn to the medium term prospects, particularly in respect to inflation. Inflation is forecast to remain at around 4 per cent, which is comparable with the inflation rates of our major trading partners. Certainly, the latest figures would indicate that we are going to do better than most of our major trading partners. This compares with a relatively high rate of 8 per cent in the first year of the recovery, in 1982-83. The significant slowing in inflation over the past year also contrasts with Australia's comparatively high inflation rates over much of the 1970s and 1980s. There are also encouraging signs of declining inflationary expectations, and I think that is also particularly important. For two decades this economy has lived with high inflation expectations.

The gains to be made from this are considerable. In terms of fiscal policy and the contribution that this Government has made in the various Budgets that it has handed down, the revised estimate for the starting point for this year's Budget is a deficit of around $5 billion. That will be our first significant Budget deficit, and this represents a major achievement on what occurred when those opposite were in government. Year after year they had significant Budget deficits; they had no fiscal policy. That was another lost opportunity in their seven or eight years in office. Those opposite continually condemn themselves about those lost opportunities.

The Government has not attempted to offset the effects on the Budget of lower revenues and higher unemployment benefit payments. Certainly, I am hopeful and confident that next week's Budget will ensure that those relativities are maintained. This Government has allowed the automatic stabilisers to work so that it can moderate the effects of the recession. We will be running, I believe, a significant Budget deficit this year for the first time. We are grappling with the formulation of the 1991-92 Budget; we need to look at Australia's medium term economic health. It is important that we avoid decisions that boost the deficit, and I believe the aim should be to protect the integrity of the Budget and the Budgets that have been set down over the last eight years, particularly as the economy emerges from this recession. A clear fiscal policy will make an important contribution to restoring public sector saving and in the medium term will help repair the imbalance of our external account. We cannot afford any deterioration in the structure of the Budget in 1991-92. That would only make the medium term adjustments that we have to make a great deal more difficult.

In terms of our external account, over the past year we have made very major progress in reducing the current account deficit. For the 11 months to May the current account deficit was $14.7 billion, 30 per cent below the level over the same Budget period of last year. The outcome for 1990-91 will be significantly below the Budget forecast of $18 billion. This is very encouraging for the future of this country because, as I said earlier, for years we lived behind high protective tariff walls and failed to make the adjustments. We are now paying the price for that.

In terms of investment, in the medium term private investment is needed to underpin a sustained growth in our economy and I believe the Budget will ensure that happens. Some of the important lessons of the 1980s relate to the powerful positive influences of real wage restraint, which only this Government was able to achieve through the accord, and the factor share correction; these were very important in restoring investment and business confidence. There has been ongoing micro-economic reform and significant economic reform. In fact more has been accomplished during the past eight years than was ever accomplished in the 40-odd years of honourable senators opposite when they were in government. This Government has set the pace on those issues and has made change. The Government has ensured greater flexibility and productivity improvements in the economy through the changes it has adopted.

I believe the approach the Government will adopt in the Budget next week will stand in stark contrast to the sorts of policies put forward by the Opposition. If the Opposition were ever to gain government, the three main props of any budget it would introduce would be privatisation, a consumption tax and changes to industrial relations. The consumption tax has already been dealt with by my colleague Senator Maguire. How anyone in this country could advocate a significant new tax as a way out of our economic problems is a mystery to me; it is certainly a unique formula for economic recovery and I believe it will be treated justly by the Australian voters at the next election.

The Opposition's solution to industrial relations-so-called enterprise bargaining-is actually individual wage bargaining and is very similar to the changes introduced to industrial relations in New Zealand. I see that some honourable senators opposite are nodding their agreement; that is good to see because in reality the outcome of the industrial relations changes the Opposition wants to introduce will be that the safety net of annual leave, sick leave, superannuation and reasonable wage increases-such as those established by the Industrial Relations Commission in this country-will be done away with, except for a basic minimum wage.

The Opposition will ensure that individual workers have to negotiate their own wages and conditions with individual employers. If Opposition members believe that there will be fair, just and equitable bargaining in that process, they will only need to talk to workers when they vote at election time, because the workers understand the consequences of those sorts of changes. Again the Opposition's solution in its first budget would be to flatten the wages and conditions of workers in this country. Members of the Opposition are certainly not hiding those outcomes, and the Government will certainly highlight them in the next election campaign.

In respect of the elements of next week's Budget, I believe that the Government, as it has over the past eight years, will place great emphasis on Labor's commitment to a social justice program. This has been clearly set out in its social wage concept. I believe that some of the great initiatives and changes the Labor Government has made-for example, family payments and the introduction of superannuation for all-will be continued in this Budget. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —One absolutely certain thing to come from this debate is that the economic circumstances of this country will not be improved by the decerebrate invective of Senator Kemp. The alternative budget of the Australian Democrats says that a small levy will be applied to the consumption of fossil fuels, including imports, but excluding exports. Quite clearly when Senator Kemp was speaking he did not have his brain in gear.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to contrast the minimum proposal from the Opposition regarding a consumption tax with the very detailed proposals put forward by the Democrats. On the one hand, the Opposition is imposing a consumption tax on all goods and services. Now it is quite clear to anybody with an IQ above 50 that what goes into every piece of good and service is both labour and resource. To place a tax on the labour component of goods and services when we have high unemployment makes very little sense, quite apart from the questions of equity and justice in relation to disadvantaged people.

On the other hand, placing a tax on the resources component, which is precisely what our tax on fossil fuels relates to, makes a great deal of sense. It does not put a tax on the labour component of the goods and services that use those resources. Moreover, as we have already heard, the Opposition's consumption tax will increase the inflation rate by 7 per cent. Let me point out that our very modest tax on fossil fuels, which will raise $500m specifically in relation to the energy conservation part of our alternative, will have an inflationary effect of 0.12 per cent. However, even that inflation rate will be one-off and temporary because that money is specifically targeted for the development and implementation of technologies aimed at reducing the energy consumption required for production in this country.

Therefore, to the extent that the amount of energy consumed to produce a particular good or service is reduced, of course the effect of the tax and its application in that area will be strongly counter-inflationary. It will actually produce more goods and services at lower cost, which is precisely what is necessary to get the Australian economy going.

While we would agree with the general thrust of the Opposition's motion, we see nothing in its proposal so far that will do anything to deliver any better economy because clearly we need to be on about an ecologically sustainable society. If we simply tinker at the edges, which is what the Government and the Opposition are attempting to do, we will not move towards a society that is better, both for ourselves and for our children. The proposal of the Australian Democrats in relation to the spending of the extra revenue we will raise is to address precisely those areas that will benefit the economy in the long term and move it more positively towards ecological sustainability.

In the past the Democrats have been criticised because we have proposed areas in which we believe spending is needed and we have not, until last year, outlined very carefully precisely where the money was to come from. What we did in last year's budget and in this year's budget is draw up balanced budgets which show precisely where the money will come from, what the objectives are and where the money will go. That is something the Opposition has not done, has never done and is still not addressing in relation to its proposal for a broad consumption tax, which several senators, particularly from the Government side, have pointed out will be expensive and inequitable. (Time expired)
