DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect, and I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY, ``RESCUE THE FUTURE: REDUCING THE IMPACT OF THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT''
This is a statement presented by Senator the Honourable Peter Cook, on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Honourable Simon Crean MP.

The enhanced greenhouse effect is widely recognised as a global problem. International negotiations are underway which aim to produce an internationally concerted series of actions to address it. Australia is taking a leading role in those negotiations.

The Government also recognises the need for a domestic response, as shown by our announcement last year of an interim planning target to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases by 20% by the year 2005. There are many actions which can be taken in Australia which will not only contribute to reducing the global impact of the greenhouse effect, but also contribute to the welfare of Australia and Australians. However, in setting the interim targets, the Government recognised that it would be imprudent for Australia to proceed with measures which have net adverse economic impacts nationally or on Australia's trade competitiveness in the absence of similar action by major greenhouse gas producing countries.

The magnitude of the greenhouse problem came to prominence following the Toronto International Conference on the Changing Atmosphere, held in June 1988. The Senate, recognising the importance of the issues, followed up quickly by asking the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology to report on the implications for Australia of the greenhouse effect.

After some preliminary investigations, the Committee accepted that there was sufficient scientific evidence to indicate that global warming was occurring and that the greenhouse effect was being enhanced by human activities through emissions of gases such as carbon dioxide. Like the Government, they recognised the requirement for action to reduce the greenhouse effect. Therefore, the Committee tabled an interim report in June 1989 in which it refined the terms of reference to more action-orientated ones, namely to report on:
The contribution that Australian industry, science and technology can make to reducing the greenhouse effect, in particular:

- implementation of changes in energy production and distribution, consumption patterns, industrial production, and government policies which would help adapt to, slow and eventually reverse the global warming trend;
- the priority which should be accorded to such changes;
- technical, economic and institutional impediments to such changes; and
- realistic methods of overcoming these impediments.
The Report
The Committee's Report, entitled ``Rescue the Future'', was tabled on 12 February 1991.

In its Report, the Committee has concentrated on ways to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from the energy sector, which account for almost half of the warming effect of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions. We welcome the Committee's analysis of this part of the problem, while recognising that a comprehensive response to the greenhouse problem will have to also take into account other greenhouse gases, and consider not only sources but also ``sinks'' of those gases. A comprehensive response will also have to look at ways in which the world, and Australia in particular, can adapt to climate change.

As its basic strategy for reducing emissions of carbon dioxide from Australia, the Committee advocates improving the efficiency of energy use. The Government concurs with this approach, not least because, as the Committee point out, actions to increase the efficiency of energy use will result in resource and cost savings to the benefit of industry and the community, regardless of the greenhouse effect.

The Committee emphasised the importance of proceeding with action and made more than 40 detailed recommendations for measures aimed at reducing carbon dioxide emissions. These recommendations range in character from calls for more research on fuel-saving technologies, through information services, increased energy efficiency, changes in building regulations, to development of national action plans for urban transport and electricity supply and distribution.
Government Actions To Date
Senators will be aware that the Government has already taken substantial steps to address the enhanced greenhouse effect.

The Australian Government was one of the first in the world to accede to the Montreal Protocol which addresses protection of the atmospheric ozone layer through reducing emissions of the chlorinated fluorocarbons (CFCs). The CFCs are also a very substantial contributor to the enhanced greenhouse effect. We are well ahead of many other nations in our policy to phase out CFCs by 1997.

In October 1990, the Government again put Australia at the forefront of international action to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases, by adopting the interim planning target to which I have already referred, which reductions are in addition to actions already covered by the Montreal Protocol.

The interim planning target on greenhouse gas reductions was endorsed by the States and Territories at the Special Premiers' Conference in October 1990. The development of the National Greenhouse Response Strategy is a priority item being addressed through the continuing Special Premiers' Conference arrangements.

As a further positive step towards achieving this target, the Government also announced in October 1990 an expanded program of initiatives to improve efficiency of energy use. These measures include the ``Energy Guide'' now being distributed to every household in Australia, a new program of energy audits of industrial and commercial enterprises, demonstrations of energy efficient operation in commercial buildings, using Government buildings as models, and the establishment of energy managers in all Government Departments and agencies. These measures address several specific recommendations of the Committee.

Other areas of Government are looking at the complementary questions of how to adapt to climate change. For example, the National Health and Medical Research Council are finalising a study of the health implications of longer term climate change.
Co-operation with the States

Senators will realise that only some of the Committee's recommendations fall directly within the powers of the Commonwealth. The Government has, of course, paid particular attention to those recommendations.

But implementation, and even development, of some of the national action plans and regulations envisaged in the Report will, under our federal system of government, require consultation with the States. I am pleased to say that action on the greenhouse effect is one area in which there has been good co-operation between the States and the Commonwealth.

For example, the States and Commonwealth, through the Australian Minerals and Energy Council, had already taken collective action before the Committee finally reported in several of the areas raised by the Senate Committee. All States are now proceeding towards implementing schemes for energy labelling of new appliances, and a State by State evaluation is being undertaken of fuel substitution aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Similarly, the Australian and New Zealand Environment Council has been responsible for an important contribution, in its report ``Towards a National Greenhouse Strategy for Australia''.
National Greenhouse Response Strategy

One of the major recommendations of the Committee was for a ``10 year energy plan, to be ratified at the Special Premiers' Conference, setting out the nation's commitment to international greenhouse gas emission reductions, as well as specifying particular measures to be implemented''. We recognise the advantages of having a clear strategy for greenhouse action which sets out our national objectives and the timeframe for achieving them. The concept of a forward looking planned approach to reduction of greenhouse gas emissions is accepted, and will be embodied in the National Greenhouse Response Strategy. However, the National Greenhouse Response Strategy will have to encompass issues, such as sinks of greenhouse gases and adaptation to climate change, which would not be part of a strategy for the energy sector.

In the energy sector, it would be inappropriate to look upon a ``10 year energy plan'' as a rigid tool. Rather we will be looking to establish a clear policy framework within which the energy sector can operate dynamically, with the flexibility to respond to emerging issues. An important part of that framework is the microeconomic reforms that the Government is pursuing in several key sectors of the economy. For example, the Industries Commission has been examining energy generation and distribution, to see how it could be made more economically efficient for the nation. The Working Groups on electricity supply and transport set up by the Special Premiers' Conference are also expected to make valuable contributions to microeconomic reforms influencing the energy sector.

Moreover, a policy framework for the energy sector will necessarily encompass not only the National Greenhouse Response Strategy, but also many matters, such as access to resources, and returns to the community from resource use, that have little connection with greenhouse.

On a related recommendation, I am pleased to say that negotiations on reform of the national land transport system are well advanced. Achieving the maximum possible efficiency of the industry will result in greenhouse benefits from reduced fuel use.
Other Inputs to Greenhouse Strategy

To provide some more of the information needed to assist us in developing the National Greenhouse Response Strategy, the Government has directed the Working Groups on Ecologically Sustainable Development to report on options that will lead to the most cost effective combination of measures available for reducing greenhouse gases build-up. We have also asked the Industries Commission to report on the cost/benefit implications for Australian industry of an international consensus in favour of a 20% reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.

The Government sees the Senate Committee's report as an equally valuable input to the development of a National Greenhouse Response Strategy. As the Committee's report has appeared while the ESD Working Groups and the Industries Commission are still deliberating, the proposals put forward by the Committee are being considered by those bodies. For example, the ESD Working Group on energy use is considering a full range of options in several areas covered in the Committee's report, such as energy management in industry and commerce, building practices, and domestic energy use. Similarly, the ESD Working Groups on transport and energy production are considering a full range of options in those areas, including those raised by the Committee.

In this way, the Committee's recommendations will be integrated with ecological and economic considerations in the development of the National Greenhouse Response Strategy. Some of the Committee's recommendations emphasise the use of regulation as a policy tool. However, at this stage, the Government wishes to consider the widest range of policy instruments, ranging from economic and market-based measures, through information provision, to regulations. On a case by case basis, we will seek to implement the combination of measures which is most effective in achieving the desired ends, taking account of the implications for the environment, energy security and the economy as a whole.

Certainly, the Government believes that it is imperative that implementation of major measures and actions to meet the greenhouse gas reduction targets should be part of an integrated National Greenhouse Response Strategy.
Tabling

Mr President, I table an Attachment setting out the Government's response to each recommendation of the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, entitled ``Rescue the Future: reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect''.
ATTACHMENT
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY, SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY REPORT: ``RESCUE THE FUTURE-REDUCING THE IMPACT OF THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT''
(Report Tabled in the Senate on 12 February 1991)

Specific recommendations as set out in Chapter 7 of the Senate report are reproduced below, together with Government responses. The recommendations have been divided into sections as follows: (A) Overall Strategy; (B) Prizes; (C) Electricity Generation; (D) Transport; (E) Energy Management in Industry and Commerce; (F) Buildings; (G) Household Energy Use and (H) Research.
(A) OVERALL STRATEGY
Paragraph 7.7

The Committee recommends that a 10 year energy plan be developed for ratification at the Special Premiers' Conference setting out the nation's commitment to international greenhouse gas emission reductions as well as specifying the particular measures that are to be implemented. To be effective the energy plan requires a national approach. The Committee recommends that national strategies in the following areas be central elements of the plan:

- A new charter for energy authorities to manage energy use to provide energy services rather than energy. Least cost planning and demand management must replace traditional supply dominated approaches.

Interstate load sharing should be used to maximise electricity supply efficiencies without consideration of state boundaries. AMEC should co-ordinate electricity supply to minimise greenhouse gas emissions and maximise efficiency and cost benefit. Using this approach the Committee suggests serious examination of linking Tasmania to the grid to provide access to its peak power potential in return for base load mainland supply. Least cost planning and effective use of the grid could obviate the need for additional fossil fuel based plant within the first 10 year energy plan.
- An integrated national transport strategy should be developed as part of the energy plan. ATAC should be responsible for the development and implementation of the plan.

- Energy targets must be set for commercial and residential properties to ensure best energy design and to minimise running costs. Targets must be set as part of a national code and must be backed up by mandatory energy audits.
- Appliance efficiency labelling must be implemented nationally and cover a wider range of energy consuming products.

- Renewable and other advanced energy technologies must be supported through the funding of research and demonstration, including a commitment by governments (utilities), industry and research bodies to large scale demonstration programs.

THE GOVERNMENT RECOGNISES THE ADVANTAGES OF HAVING A CLEAR STRATEGY FOR GREENHOUSE ACTION WHICH SETS OUT OUR NATIONAL OBJECTIVES AND THE TIME FRAME FOR ACHIEVING THEM. THE CONCEPT OF A FORWARD LOOKING PLANNED APPROACH TO REDUCTION OF GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS IS ACCEPTED, AND EMBODIED IN THE GOVERNMENT'S NATIONAL GREENHOUSE RESPONSE STRATEGY AS INITIATED IN OCTOBER 1990. THE STRATEGY IS TO BE DEVELOPED CO-OPERATIVELY BY THE COMMONWEALTH, STATE AND TERRITORY GOVERNMENTS IN CONSULTATION WITH INDUSTRY, SCIENTIFIC AND CONSERVATION GROUPS AND THE GENERAL COMMUNITY. THE FIRST STAGE OF THE NATIONAL STRATEGY WAS THE ADOPTION OF AN INTERIM TARGET FOR PLANNING PURPOSES, SUPPORTED BY THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT'S REQUEST TO THE ECOLOGICALLY SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT (ESD) WORKING GROUPS AND THE INDUSTRY COMMISSION (IC) TO EXAMINE ASPECTS OF THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT ISSUE.

IN THE ENERGY SECTOR THE GOVERNMENT BELIEVES THAT IT WOULD BE INAPPROPRIATE TO LOOK UPON A ` `10 YEAR ENERGY PLAN'' AS A RIGID TOOL. RATHER WE WILL BE LOOKING TO ESTABLISH A CLEAR POLICY FRAMEWORK WITHIN WHICH THE ENERGY SECTOR CAN OPERATE DYNAMICALLY, WITH THE FLEXIBILITY TO RESPOND TO EMERGING ISSUES. AN IMPORTANT PART OF THAT FRAMEWORK IS THE MICROECONOMIC REFORMS THAT THE GOVERNMENT IS PURSUING IN SEVERAL KEY SECTORS OF THE ECONOMY. FOR EXAMPLE, THE INDUSTRY COMMISSION HAS BEEN EXAMINING ENERGY GENERATION AND DISTRIBUTION, TO SEE HOW IT COULD BE MADE MORE ECONOMICALLY EFFICIENT FOR THE NATION. THE WORKING GROUPS ON ELECTRICITY SUPPLY AND TRANSPORT SET UP BY THE SPECIAL PREMIERS' CONFERENCE ARE ALSO EXPECTED TO MAKE VALUABLE CONTRIBUTIONS TO MICROECONOMIC REFORMS INFLUENCING THE ENERGY SECTOR.
(B) PRIZES
Paragraph 7.8

The Committee recommends that AMEC introduce a national scheme of prizes and awards for innovations in energy efficiency in industry and the home. Commercial recipients of such awards would use the awards as part of their advertising campaigns thereby strengthening the impact of government sponsored public awareness campaigns.

A NATIONAL SCHEME OF AWARDS FOR INNOVATIONS AND ACHIEVEMENTS IN ENERGY EFFICIENCY IN ALL SECTORS OF THE ECONOMY INCLUDING HOUSING, AND ADMINISTERED BY DPIE, HAS BEEN IN PLACE FOR 10 YEARS. MANY OF THE AWARD WINNERS HAVE ACTIVELY USED THEIR AWARDS IN THEIR PUBLICITY.
A RELATED INITIATIVE IS UNDER CONSIDERATION FOR THE HOUSING SECTOR, AND THE GOVERNMENT AGREES THAT THE APPLICATION OF THIS CONCEPT TO OTHER SECTORS SHOULD RECEIVE FURTHER ATTENTION.
(C) ELECTRICITY GENERATION
Paragraph 7.9

The Committee recommends active encouragement of cogeneration. To help achieve this goal, the Committee recommends that the energy utilities be required to assess the potential for cogenerated power (as is being done in Victoria and New South Wales) and set targets concerning the minimum proportion of electricity to be obtained from cogenerated sources within a five year period.
THIS RECOMMENDATION WILL BE CONSIDERED BY THE AUSTRALIAN MINERALS AND ENERGY COUNCIL (AMEC). THE GOVERNMENT SUPPORTS ENCOURAGEMENT OF COGENERATION WHERE IT IS FEASIBLE TO DO SO.
Paragraph 7.10

The Committee is not advocating the construction of additional coal based power plants. However to the extent that their construction is necessary in the short term the Committee recommends that any future power stations which have to be built be based on the best available technology, and that targets be set for attaining energy conversion efficiencies.

MODERN AUSTRALIAN POWER STATIONS ARE ALREADY BUILT UPON THE BEST AVAILABLE TECHNOLOGY WHICH IS ECONOMICALLY VIABLE, AND HAS DEMONSTRATED RELIABILITY. WHILE ESSENTIALLY A MATTER FOR STATE GOVERNMENTS, THIS PRACTICE IS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE AS THE BASIS FOR PLANNING BY STATE ELECTRICITY AUTHORITIES.
Paragraph 7.11

The Committee considers that on the basis of current proven reserves, the option of using gas on a large scale for base load electricity generation can only be regarded as a medium term measure for bridging the time gap until more efficient technologies become available. While eighty years may be considered by many to be a very large reserve, it is in reality quite small if one considers that this is approximately equivalent to one human lifetime. An eighty year reserve could be rapidly diminished if demand for gas as a direct source of energy or as a transport fuel expands significantly. The versatility and attractiveness of gas as an energy source makes it a valuable resource which should be conserved rather than being totally depleted for short term gains, be they economic or environmental. The Committee therefore recommends against using gas for base load power generation.
DECISIONS TO USE GAS FOR ELECTRICITY GENERATION NEED TO TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE FULL RANGE OF ECONOMIC, SOCIAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS AND ARE PRINCIPALLY MATTERS FOR STATE AUTHORITIES.
Paragraph 7.12

The Committee recommends that the CSIRO and the energy utilities jointly establish demonstration projects of coal gasification and fuel cell technologies in Australia within a five year period, and that sufficient funding be provided to enable this to be achieved.

AUSTRALIAN ENERGY RESEARCH PRIORITIES REFLECT AREAS OF GREATEST PERCEIVED NEED AND WHERE THERE IS THE BEST POTENTIAL FOR SIGNIFICANT ADVANCEMENT. RESEARCH PRIORITIES ARE SET BY A NUMBER OF AGENCIES INCLUDING CSIRO, ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AND VARIOUS INDUSTRY GROUPS.
THE GOVERNMENT, THROUGH CSIRO, IS FAMILIAR WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF SOLID FUEL CELLS AND THEIR CONTRIBUTION AS AN ALTERNATIVE ENERGY SOURCE.

THERE MAY BE SOUND REASONS FOR A REVIEW OF GENERAL RESEARCH PRIORITIES TO TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE NEED FOR R& INTO GREENHOUSE RESPONSE MEASURES, AND THAT POINT WILL BE CONSIDERED IN A MORE GENERAL REVIEW OF RESEARCH DIRECTIONS BY THE AUSTRALIAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL (ASTEC), NOW UNDERWAY.
THE COMMITTEE'S VIEWS WILL BE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT IN THESE VARIOUS PROCESSES AND WILL THEREBY INFLUENCE THE PROCESS OF THE SETTING OF PRIORITIES FOR ENERGY RESEARCH.
Paragraph 7.13

The implementation of an energy `Charter' for utilities requires a commitment by all state and territory governments. In urging that commitment the Committee recommends that AMEC implement the measures required, which include:

- State Governments to require all electricity utilities to adopt least cost planning and develop effective demand management programs. These programs should immediately identify opportunities for reducing demand through energy efficiency and cogeneration.
- utilities should provide financing amortised over a long period for energy improvements in industry, the commercial sector and the home in preference to borrowing for extra generating capacity

- no further borrowings for new power station developments be permitted until all opportunities for cogeneration and energy savings through efficiency which can be realised at a lower cost than installing new capacity have been exploited
- the Commonwealth provide funding for the States to assist the introduction of demand management programs by the utilities
THE RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATION 7.7 ABOVE SETS OUT THE GOVERNMENT'S GENERAL VIEW OF THE PROPOSED ENERGY CHARTER.

THE AUSTRALIAN MINERALS AND ENERGY COUNCIL (AMEC) IS THE PRINCIPAL FORUM BRINGING TOGETHER STATE, COMMONWEALTH AND TERRITORY ENERGY MINISTERS AND OFFICIALS. AS SUCH AMEC PROVIDES A CONDUIT THROUGH WHICH THE STATES, TERRITORY AND COMMONWEALTH CAN EXCHANGE POLICY, AND TECHNICAL INFORMATION AND EXPERIENCE. HOWEVER IT WOULD BE UP TO INDIVIDUAL STATE GOVERNMENTS, RATHER THAN AMEC AS A BODY, TO IMPLEMENT THESE MEASURES. THE RECOMMENDATION HAS BEEN BROUGHT TO THEIR ATTENTION THROUGH AMEC.

WITH REGARD TO THE FOURTH DOT POINT, THE GOVERNMENT NOTES THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE INDUSTRY COMMISSION REPORT ON ELECTRICITY GENERATION AND DISTRIBUTION. UNDERTAKING DEMAND MANAGEMENT WHEREVER ECONOMIC SHOULD NOT REQUIRE COMMONWEALTH SUPPORT.
Paragraph 7.14

To achieve this objective, the Committee recommends that AMEC assess the potential for sharing generating capacity between the states and develop a methodology to effectively coordinate the operation of an enhanced grid and ensure equitable interstate energy pricing arrangements.
AND
Paragraph 7.15

The Committee further recommends that the Commonwealth provide financial assistance to the states to make necessary enhancements to the grid to ensure interstate generating capacity can be efficiently exploited. The target should be to have a fully integrated system operational by the year 2000.

THE COMMONWEALTH RECOGNISES THAT THE FINANCIAL DEMANDS OF ENERGY DEVELOPMENT FROM ELECTRICITY UTILITIES ARE TOO LARGE, AND TOO IMPORTANT TO THE ECONOMY FOR THEM NOT TO OPERATE EFFICIENTLY. ELECTRICITY ALONE INVOLVES INDUSTRIES WITH CAPITAL ASSETS OF OVER $100 BILLION, NET BORROWINGS OF SOME $25 BILLION AND EMPLOYMENT OF SOME 70 000 PEOPLE. ALTOGETHER THE ELECTRICITY SECTOR CONTRIBUTES AROUND 4 PER CENT TO GDP.

THE GOVERNMENT BELIEVES THAT MORE EXTENSIVE ELECTRICITY GRIDS ARE NOW A REAL POSSIBILITY AND THAT, IN CO-OPERATION WITH ALL STATES AND TERRITORIES, WE ARE CLOSER TO ACHIEVING APPROPRIATE RETURNS TO THE COMMUNITY FOR THE USE OF ITS RESOURCES. THE DRIVING FORCE IS THE NEED FOR GREATER ECONOMIC EFFICIENCY AND LESSER ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT. THIS VIEW IS SUPPORTED BY THE INDUSTRY COMMISSION REPORT ON ENERGY GENERATION AND DISTRIBUTION.

AN ELECTRICITY WORKING GROUP (EWG) WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE SPECIAL PREMIERS' CONFERENCE HELD IN OCTOBER 1990. THIS WORKING GROUP IS LOOKING SPECIFICALLY AT THE ECONOMICS OF ENHANCED INTERCONNECTION AND THE BEST ARRANGEMENTS FOR GRID MANAGEMENT. THE EWG IS DUE TO REPORT TO THE NEXT PREMIERS' CONFERENCE.

THE REPORT OF THE ESD WORKING GROUPS, TOGETHER WITH THE REPORT FROM THE ELECTRICITY WORKING GROUP, ESTABLISHED BY THE SPECIAL PREMIERS' CONFERENCE HELD IN OCTOBER 1990, WILL PROVIDE A FIRM PLATFORM FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN INTEGRATED ENERGY GRID WHICH WOULD ENSURE THE MOST ECONOMIC AND EFFICIENT EXPLOITATION OF NATIONAL ENERGY RESOURCES. THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.
(D) TRANSPORT
Paragraph 7.16
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth and States, through ATAC, work towards the establishment of an integrated national transport strategy within two years.
THE GOVERNMENT WILL BRING THIS RECOMMENDATION TO THE ATTENTION OF ATAC.

THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT IS PURSUING, AS A PRIORITY POLICY OBJECTIVE, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INTEGRATED LAND TRANSPORT SYSTEM IN COLLABORATION WITH THE STATES AND TERRITORIES. ATAC HAS BEEN FULLY INVOLVED IN THIS PROCESS. THE MAJOR ARMS OF THE GOVERNMENTS APPROACH ARE:
- TARGETED ROAD FUNDING PRIORITIES TO ROADS OF NATIONAL ECONOMIC SIGNIFICANCE
- ESTABLISHMENT OF A NATIONAL RAIL FREIGHT CORPORATION
- A NATIONAL APPROACH TO HEAVY VEHICLE REGISTRATION AND CHARGING
- HARMONISED ROAD TRANSPORT REGULATION

THE GOVERNMENT'S LAND TRANSPORT STRATEGY IS CONSISTENT WITH OVERALL ENVIRONMENTAL OBJECTIVES. BY ACHIEVING THE MAXIMUM POSSIBLE EFFICIENCY IN LAND TRANSPORT, THERE WILL BE CORRESPONDING REDUCTIONS IN THE INTENSITY OF ENERGY USE WITH RESULTANT GREENHOUSE EMISSION BENEFITS.
ATAC HAS ALSO COMMITTED ITSELF TO WORKING WITH THE ESD TRANSPORT WORKING GROUP AND WILL RESUME CONSIDERATION OF A TRANSPORT AND ENVIRONMENT POLICY ONCE THE RESULTS OF THE ESD PROCESS ARE AVAILABLE.
Paragraph 7.17

The Committee recommends that ATAC formulate a national action plan to make the changes needed to meet the requirements of urban transport users in the most energy efficient and cost effective way. This national action plan should be based on already available data and studies and take into account the comments and recommendations made in this report.
THE GOVERNMENT WILL BRING THIS RECOMMENDATION TO THE ATTENTION OF ATAC.

URBAN ISSUES, INCLUDING TRANSPORT, ARE CURRENTLY UNDER EXAMINATION IN A NUMBER OF FORA INCLUDING THE URBAN SETTLEMENTS WORKING GROUP ESTABLISHED BY THE SPECIAL PREMIERS' CONFERENCE, AND THE ESD TRANSPORT WORKING GROUP. THESE PROCESSES MAY PRODUCE RECOMMENDATIONS ON URBAN FORMS AND YIELD GENERALLY APPLICABLE PRINCIPLES IN RESPECT OF INFRASTRUCTURE PLANNING, FINANCING AND USAGE. THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.
Paragraph 7.18

The Committee recommends that a minimum fuel economy standard of 8 litres/100 kilometres be set for all new vehicles sold in Australia by 1998, and that this standard be reduced to 6 litres/100 kilometres by 2005.

THE DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS (DOTC) HAS INITIATED A MAJOR STUDY ON THE CAPACITY OF THE AUSTRALIAN AUTOMOBILE MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY TO DELIVER FUEL ECONOMY IMPROVEMENTS ACROSS THE NEW PASSENGER FLEET. THIS STUDY IS BEING CO-SPONSORED BY DITAC, DPIE, DASETT, AND THE VICTORIAN DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION AND ENVIRONMENT.
THE STUDY WILL, INTER ALIA,

- ASSESS THE TECHNICAL CAPACITY FOR IMPROVED FUEL ECONOMY IN MOTOR VEHICLES OVER THE NEXT 10-15 YEARS, INCLUDING THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE RATE AT WHICH DEVELOPMENTS IN TECHNOLOGY ARE INCORPORATED INTO AUSTRALIAN MADE VEHICLES. THIS WOULD INVOLVE IDENTIFYING THE CONSTRAINTS IMPOSED BY THE NATURE OF THE AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY AND ITS OPERATING ENVIRONMENT;
- ASSESS THE ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS (PARTICULARLY FOR THE MOTOR VEHICLE INDUSTRY AND THE CONSUMER) OF MEETING THE FOLLOWING NATIONAL AVERAGE FUEL CONSUMPTION TARGETS FOR NEW VEHICLES BY THE YEAR 2005:
- 6.0L/100KM, AND
IT IS EXPECTED THAT THE STUDY WILL BE FINALISED BY JULY 1991.

THE FEDERAL OFFICE OF ROAD SAFETY (FORS) IS DEVELOPING A MODEL WHICH CAN BE USED AS A TOOL TO ESTIMATE CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS FROM THE MOTOR VEHICLE FLEET IN ANY GIVEN YEAR, AND THUS DETERMINE THE EFFECT OF VARIOUS FUEL CONSUMPTION REGIMES.

THE PRODUCT OF THE STUDY OUTLINED ABOVE AND THE FORS MODEL ARE BEING DRAWN UPON IN THE ESD WORKING GROUP PROCESS TO ASSIST IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF RECOMMENDATIONS FOR ACHIEVING GREATER ENERGY ECONOMY IN THE AUSTRALIAN VEHICLE FLEET.
Paragraph 7.19
The Committee recommends that as part of the national action plan proposed in paragraph 5.46, ATAC develop a range of effective programs to:
- provide incentives for the purchase of fuel efficient vehicles by business and private buyers
- decrease the use of cars for urban transport where a viable public transport alternative exists
- effectively encourage efficient car use practices including car pooling
- replace high standing charges for car and truck registration and insurance with a system under which charges are levied proportional to use
THE GOVERNMENT WILL REFER THE RECOMMENDATIONS UNDER THE PARAGRAPH TO ATAC.
THE PROVISION OF INCENTIVES FOR THE PURCHASE OF FUEL EFFICIENT VEHICLES WILL NEED TO BE LOOKED AT IN THE CONTEXT OF THE GOVERNMENT'S CONSIDERATION OF THE ESD AND IC INQUIRIES.

THE ESD TRANSPORT WORKING GROUP IS CONSIDERING THE SCOPE FOR FACILITATING THE INTRODUCTION OF VARIOUS FORMS OF LOW GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSION TRANSPORT VEHICLES, INCLUDING ELECTRICALLY-POWERED VEHICLES WHICH SEEM LIKELY TO BECOME MORE PRACTICABLE WITH DEVELOPMENTS IN BATTERIES, ELECTRICAL CONTROL SYSTEMS AND SOLAR RECHARGING FACILITIES AND MORE ECONOMICALLY COMPETITIVE IN A REGIME IN WHICH FOSSIL FUEL PRICING REFLECTS THE ENVIRONMENTAL EFFECTS OF GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS.

THE GOVERNMENT AGREES THAT EFFICIENT CAR USE PRACTICES, INCLUDING CAR POOLING, IS A PRIORITY AREA FOR ACTIONS THAT CAN BE TAKEN IN THE SHORT TERM WITH MINIMAL COSTS TO THE ECONOMY. THE STATES HAVE PRIMARY RESPONSIBILITY IN THIS AREA. LOW COST ACTIONS COULD INCLUDE SPECIAL LANES FOR HIGH OCCUPANCY VEHICLES, LIMITING PARKING IN CBD'S ETC. THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT WILL ADDRESS THE BREADTH OF RELATED ISSUES IN CONSIDERING THE OUTCOME OF THE ESD AND IC PROCESSES TO ENSURE THAT SUBSEQUENT DECISIONS ARE CONSISTENT WITH AN INTEGRATED NATIONALLY AGREED APPROACH TO TRANSPORT AND THE ENVIRONMENT. COOPERATION OF ALL LEVELS OF GOVERNMENT WILL BE ESSENTIAL.

AS REGARDS CAR AND TRUCK REGISTRATION CHARGES GOVERNMENTS ARE PRESENTLY CONSIDERING REFORM OF HEAVY VEHICLE CHARGING ARRANGEMENTS, WHICH MAY INCORPORATE BOTH FUEL AND DIRECT MASS DISTANCE CHARGES. FUEL CANNOT BE USED AS THE SOLE CHARGING BASIS FOR HEAVY VEHICLES BECAUSE FUEL CONSUMPTION IS ONLY LOOSELY RELATED TO ROAD WEAR. ANALYSIS UNDERTAKEN BY THE INTER-STATE COMMISSION INDICATES THAT IF GOVERNMENTS WERE TO CONSIDER A MORE RATIONAL CHARGING SYSTEM FOR LIGHT VEHICLES A FUEL ONLY CHARGE MAY BE FEASIBLE.
Paragraph 7.20

The Committee recommends positive discrimination in favour of developing the use of LPG and natural gas as transport fuels. As part of this process the Government should provide guarantees concerning the maximum amount of levy to be placed on alternative transport fuels in the next 10 years.

THE TRANSPORT WORKING GROUP SET UP UNDER THE ECOLOGICALLY SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVE IS CONSIDERING PRICING POLICIES TO FOSTER A GREATER DEGREE OF SWITCHING TO ALTERNATIVE FUELS, AND OTHER ISSUES, AS PART OF ITS ANALYSIS OF TRANSPORT AND RELATED ENVIRONMENTAL MATTERS.

THE AUSTRALIAN TRANSPORT SECTOR ACCOUNTS FOR AROUND 27 PER CENT OF NATIONAL ENERGY CONSUMPTION ON A FULL FUEL CYCLE BASIS. THEREFORE GOVERNMENTS ARE WELL AWARE OF THE NEED TO DEVELOP PRACTICAL AND ECONOMICALLY SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE FUEL OPTIONS WHICH MAKE GOOD ENVIRONMENTAL SENSE. IN VIEW OF THE POTENTIAL OF ALTERNATIVE FUELS, FUNDING IS ALREADY BEING PROVIDED UNDER ERDC PROGRAMS TO DEVELOP THESE OPTIONS AS TRANSPORT FUELS.

IN THE CONTEXT OF THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT IT IS SIGNIFICANT TO NOTE THAT COMPRESSED NATURAL GAS HOLDS BENEFITS IN TERMS OF REDUCING AMBIENT AIR POLLUTION AND GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS. LPG ALSO HAS AMBIENT POLLUTION BENEFITS, BUT ITS PROVEN GAIN IN TERMS OF GREENHOUSE IS LOWER.

THE COMMITTEE HAS OBSERVED THAT ONE ESTIMATE SHOWS THAT DOMESTIC SUPPLY OF LPG IS SUFFICIENT TO MEET ABOUT 7 PER CENT OF VEHICLE FUEL NEEDS, APPARENTLY BASED ON THE 1987 AMEC ESTIMATE THAT LPG COULD MEET A MAXIMUM OF 7 PER CENT OF PETROL DEMAND IN THE YEAR 2000. EVEN THIS ESTIMATE MAY BE TOO HIGH IF THE GROWING NEEDS OF TRADITIONAL LPG USERS IN INDUSTRY, HOUSEHOLDS AND THE PETROCHEMICAL SECTOR ARE TAKEN INTO ACCOUNT. CURRENTLY, LPG SUPPLIES OVER 4 PER CENT OF PETROL DEMAND AND DEMAND IS GROWING MUCH MORE RAPIDLY THAN THAT FOR PETROL. AT CURRENTLY PROJECTED RATES OF PRODUCTION AND DEMAND, AUSTRALIA MAY SOON FACE A GREATER NEED TO IMPORT LPG.

THE ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS OF LPG SHOULD NOT BE EXAGGERATED. THE BENEFITS OF LPG USE VERSUS MODERN VEHICLES EQUIPPED WITH CATALYTIC CONVERTERS AND USING LEAD FREE PETROL ARE NOT CONSIDERABLE. ALSO IT IS IMPORTANT TO MAKE ASSESSMENTS OF ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS ON A FULL FUEL CYCLE BASIS, TAKING INTO ACCOUNT FOR EXAMPLE THE CARBON DIOXIDE EMISSIONS WHICH MAY BE ASSOCIATED WITH NATURALLY OCCURRING LPG PRODUCTION.
Paragraph 7.21
The Committee also recommends that the Government encourage further research into the use of lower carbon fuels such as natural gas for transport sector use.

IN 1987 THE GOVERNMENT MADE AN ADDITIONAL $5M AVAILABLE FOR RD& ON NATURAL GAS IN VEHICLES. AUSTRALIAN KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE IN THE USE OF LOWER CARBON FUELS, SUCH AS NATURAL GAS, IS THUS WELL DEVELOPED.

A REVIEW BY DPIE IN JANUARY 1991 OF THE RESULTS TO DATE FROM THIS RESEARCH AND DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM CONCLUDED THAT NATURAL GAS HAS SIGNIFICANT POTENTIAL IN THE TRANSPORT MARKET IN AUSTRALIA AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR DIESEL FUEL IN HEAVY VEHICLES. THE GOVERNMENT'S POLICY OF WORKING CLOSELY WITH INDUSTRY TO FOSTER AND CO-ORDINATE RD& IN THIS FIELD HAS BEEN WELL SUPPORTED BY THE GAS INDUSTRY. AS A RESULT NATURAL GAS IS NOW APPROACHING THE POINT WHERE IT CAN BE WIDELY ADOPTED AS A FUEL FOR URBAN BUSES ON A NORMAL COMMERCIAL BASIS.

THE ESD WORKING GROUPS ON ENERGY USE AND TRANSPORT ARE BOTH EXAMINING THE ECONOMIC AND ENVIRONMENTAL IMPLICATIONS OF THE USE OF LOWER CARBON FUELS IN THE TRANSPORT SECTOR. A KEY FACET OF THEIR REPORTS WILL BE AN ASSESSMENT OF THE PROBABLE FUTURE PATH OF RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AND ITS IMPACT ON TECHNOLOGICAL INNOVATION IN THESE AREAS.
(E) ENERGY MANAGEMENT IN INDUSTRY AND COMMERCE
Paragraph 7.22

The Committee notes that both the Victorian and New South Wales Government demand management initiatives make use of the energy audit process, and intend in the first instance providing free energy audits. The Committee commends this initiative and recommends that it be adopted in the other States.

DEMAND SIDE MANAGEMENT WAS IDENTIFIED AS A KEY ELEMENT OF A GREENHOUSE STRATEGY IN THE AMEC REPORT ``ENERGY AND THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT''. THE AMEC ENERGY MANAGEMENT CONFERENCE IS CURRENTLY UNDERTAKING DETAILED STUDIES OF THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE ROLE OF DEMAND SIDE MANAGEMENT IN EACH STATE.
Paragraph 7.23

The Committee considers that energy audits of industry should, in the longer term, become an integrated part of industry practice, as is now the case with other standard industry practices such as pollution control and occupational health and safety. For this reason the Committee recommends that within 10 years, regular energy audits in industry should become mandatory.

THE GOVERNMENT HAS SUBSIDISED ENERGY AUDITS FOR MANY YEARS. AN EARLIER ENERGY AUDIT SCHEME, ANNOUNCED IN OCTOBER 1980 AS PART OF THE NATIONAL INDUSTRIAL ENERGY MANAGEMENT SCHEME, HAS NOW BEEN REPLACED BY THE ENERGY AUDIT SUBSIDIES WHICH FORM AN INTEGRAL PART OF THE COMMONWEALTH'S ENERGY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM ANNOUNCED ON 23 OCTOBER 1990.

AS PART OF THAT PROGRAM, THE GOVERNMENT ALLOCATED ADDITIONAL FUNDING TO SUPPORT A NEW PROGRAM OF ENERGY AUDITS TO FACILITATE AUSTRALIAN FIRMS' ACCESS TO ENERGY EFFICIENT PROCESSES AND TECHNOLOGY WHICH WILL BOTH REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS AND IMPROVE PROFIT THROUGH EFFICIENT USE OF RESOURCES. THE ENERGY AUDIT PROGRAM IS BEING DEVELOPED JOINTLY BY DPIE AND DITAC AND WILL BE ADMINISTERED THROUGH THE NATIONAL INDUSTRY EXTENSION SERVICE (NIES) IN COLLABORATION WITH THE STATES.

THE GOVERNMENT BELIEVES THAT THIS PROGRAM SHOULD BE REVIEWED AFTER A PERIOD OF TIME (PERHAPS THREE YEARS) AND THE NEED FOR ITS AMENDMENT AND SUPPLEMENTATION (EG. THROUGH MORE ASSISTANCE OR REGULATORY MEASURES) EXAMINED AT THAT TIME. IN GENERAL, HOWEVER, THE GOVERNMENT WOULD BE WARY OF IMPOSING MANDATORY AUDITS ON INDUSTRY UNLESS THE THRESHOLD LEVEL OF ENERGY USAGE WERE STIPULATED.
Paragraph 7.24

The Committee is concerned that as energy auditing becomes more common, there may be a shortage of qualified people to conduct the audits. The evidence received during the inquiry indicated that there are only a small number of people in Australia at present with the necessary experience and qualifications. The Committee recommends that the Department of Employment, Education and Training, in consultation with AMEC, investigate the likely demand for energy auditors, and initiate a program to ensure that future demand for energy auditors can be met.

ENERGY AUDITING AT THE HIGHEST TECHNICAL LEVEL IS A SPECIALISED FIELD OF CERTAIN PROFESSIONS, PARTICULARLY THE ENGINEERING PROFESSION. THE INSTITUTION OF ENGINEERS(AUSTRALIA), WHICH IS CURRENTLY PREPARING A REGISTER OF ENERGY AUDITING ORGANISATIONS ACCREDITED UNDER THE ENTERPRISE ENERGY AUDIT PROGRAM, IS CONCERNED TO ENCOURAGE MORE WIDESPREAD PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN THIS AREA.

ANALYSIS OF THE LABOUR MARKET AT SUCH A DETAILED OCCUPATIONAL LEVEL WOULD BE TOO RESOURCE INTENSIVE. THE DEPARTMENT OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING (DEET) NEVERTHELESS IS NOT AWARE OF ANY SIGNIFICANT SHORTAGES OF ENERGY AUDITORS. DEET HAS BEEN ADVISED OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THIS REGARD.

THIS RECOMMENDATION HAS BEEN REFERRED TO AMEC FOR FURTHER INVESTIGATION. IF THERE IS A DEMONSTRATED NEED FOR ADDITIONAL SKILLED PERSONNEL IN THIS AREA, THE MATTER WILL BE BROUGHT TO THE ATTENTION OF PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS AND DEET.
Paragraph 7.25

The Committee recommends that AMEC, in consultation with industry and with the assistance of the Treasury, develop a range of measures to provide incentive and assistance for industry to implement energy conservation measures. These measures should be developed as an agreed package (including funding arrangements) by the end of 1991. Implementation should be phased in over a 10 year period.

THE GOVERNMENT HAS IMPLEMENTED A RANGE OF SPECIFIC PROGRAMS TO ENCOURAGE INDUSTRY ADOPTION OF ENERGY CONSERVATION AND EFFICIENCY MEASURES INCLUDING THE PROGRAM OF ENERGY MANAGEMENT MEASURES ANNOUNCED BY THE GOVERNMENT IN OCTOBER 1990. THE ISSUE OF BARRIERS TO UPTAKE OF CONSERVATION AND EFFICIENCY MEASURES IS CURRENTLY BEING CONSIDERED BY THE ESD WORKING GROUPS, TOGETHER WITH THE RANGE OF OPTIONS WHICH MIGHT BE IMPLEMENTED TO REMOVE BARRIERS AND ENCOURAGE GREATER ADOPTION OF SPECIFIC MEASURES. THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.
Paragraph 7.26
The Committee recommends establishment of comprehensive demonstration programs to show-case cost effective technologies to the industrial and commercial sectors.
THE GOVERNMENT HAS SUPPORTED A WIDE RANGE OF DEMONSTRATIONS THROUGH THE NERD& PROGRAM AND ADDITIONAL DEMONSTRATIONS ARE PLANNED THROUGH THE COMMONWEALTH'S ENERGY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM.

DPIE ACTIVELY DISSEMINATES INFORMATION ON THE BEST TECHNOLOGY AVAILABLE INTERNATIONALLY. THIS INFORMATION IS OBTAINED THROUGH MEMBERSHIP OF THE INTERNATIONAL ENERGY AGENCY'S (IEA) CENTRE FOR THE ANALYSIS AND DISSEMINATION OF DEMONSTRATED ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES.

A RELATED DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM IS ALREADY BEING DEVELOPED UNDER THE ENERGY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM ANNOUNCED IN OCTOBER 1990, INVOLVING DEMONSTRATIONS OF ENERGY EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGIES IN COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS, USING GOVERNMENT BUILDINGS AS MODELS.
Paragraph 7.27

The Committee recommends the potential offered by renewable technologies to provide some of the energy requirements of industry, particularly for low temperature heating, be exploited wherever possible.
THIS RECOMMENDATION IS JUST ONE OF THE AREAS WHERE ACTION IN THE INDUSTRIAL SECTOR IS BEING EXAMINED AS PART OF THE PROCESSES OUTLINED IN PARAGRAPH 7.25.
Paragraph 7.28
The Committee recommends that a CSIRO project be established to investigate possible applications for renewable energy sources in industry.

CONSIDERABLE WORK IS UNDERWAY INTERNATIONALLY TO APPLY RENEWABLE ENERGY OPTIONS IN INDUSTRY, INCLUDING IN MULTILATERAL AGENCIES SUCH AS THE IEA. NUMEROUS STUDIES HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN IN AUSTRALIA SINCE THE MID 1970'S AND SEVERAL NERD& PROGRAM PROJECTS, NOW ADMINISTERED BY THE ERDC, ON THIS TOPIC ARE UNDERWAY. CSIRO IS CURRENTLY ASSISTING ELCOM NSW TO IDENTIFY POSSIBLE AREAS SUITABLE FOR WIND POWER GENERATION.
Paragraph 7.29

The Committee also recommends that practical demonstration projects of renewable technologies in industry be established and funded under the auspices of the Commonwealth Energy Research and Development Corporation.
THE OBJECTIVE OF THE ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION (ERDC) IS TO STIMULATE EFFECTIVE RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENT AND ADOPTION OF TECHNOLOGIES WHICH:
- INCREASE THE EFFICIENCY OF ENERGY UTILISATION;
- ENHANCE THE DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF A STABLE, SUSTAINABLE, ECONOMIC, RELIABLE AND DIVERSE ENERGY SUPPLY IN AUSTRALIA;
- REDUCE THE COST OF SUPPLYING ENERGY;
- REDUCE THE ADVERSE ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL IMPACT OF ENERGY PRODUCTION, DISTRIBUTION AND USE;
- STIMULATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A LOCAL INDUSTRY IN ENERGY TECHNOLOGY AND SERVICES; AND
- STIMULATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF EXPORT POTENTIAL FOR ENERGY TECHNOLOGIES, PRODUCTS AND SERVICES.

``NEW AND RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES AND SYSTEMS'' IS ONE OF THE THREE ERDC PRIORITY RESEARCH PROGRAM AREAS AND ALTHOUGH RENEWABLE ENERGY REPRESENTS ONLY AROUND 6 PER CENT OF TOTAL DOMESTIC ENERGY AVAILABILITY, ERDC COMMITTED OVER 25 PER CENT OF ITS FUNDS FOR NEW PROJECTS TO THIS AREA IN 1990.
Paragraph 7.30

The Committee recommends active encouragement of local manufacture of energy efficient technologies. To achieve this, the Committee recommends the Commonwealth Government implement changes to the taxation system to assist companies seeking to commence manufacture of new technologies which have been identified as offering significant energy efficiency improvements and export potential. The Committee also recommends that other methods of establishing such industries such as availability of low interest finance be investigated and implemented.

IN ITS RECENT INDUSTRY STATEMENT, THE GOVERNMENT RE-AFFIRMED ITS COMMITMENT TO THE PACKAGE OF MEASURES ADMINISTERED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE TO ENCOURAGE THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW TECHNOLOGIES BY AUSTRALIAN INDUSTRY. THESE MEASURES INCLUDE THE TAX CONCESSION FOR R&, GRANTS FOR INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AND THE NATIONAL PROCUREMENT AND DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM.

BOTH THE ESD WORKING GROUPS AND THE INDUSTRY COMMISSION ARE EXAMINING THE ISSUE OF NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.
(F) BUILDINGS
Paragraph 7.31
The Committee recommends that the following measures be introduced to improve energy efficiency in the commercial sector:

- Building codes should be changed to require energy efficiency targets in new buildings or buildings undergoing refurbishment to be set. This will involve Commonwealth, State and Local Government. In the case of Commonwealth Government buildings, the ACS should be given the power to require amendment of any design which fails to meet energy efficiency targets. The design brief for government buildings must ensure that the efficiency target will be met. This requirement must extend to buildings constructed by Government owned business enterprises. The Committee commends the important work being carried out by the Public Works Committee in the area of energy efficiency in Government buildings.
- An ongoing information campaign should be conducted to increase awareness of the possibilities for energy efficient design and savings to be made by identifying deficiencies in existing buildings.
Where proven cost effective, automatic controls of building services such as lighting and heating should be incorporated in all new buildings, and whenever major renovations are carried out.

- Commercial buildings should be energy audited at least every three years. These audits should be mandatory. Where the payback period for energy efficiency improvements is less than three years, there should be a requirement that the audit findings be implemented. This should apply to both Government and private sector buildings. The ACS should be given a brief to examine the energy performance of existing government buildings and should be empowered to implement the recommendations flowing from energy audits of Commonwealth government buildings. Buildings owned by Government Business Enterprises, where not subject to local building regulations, should be subject to the same provisions as government buildings. Similar mechanisms should be put in place at the State and Local Government levels.
- Permits to build or renovate commercial buildings should require provision of an independent assessment of likely energy consumption resulting from the design.
- Owners of commercial buildings should be required to provide prospective tenants with a statement of the energy consumption of the building and associated costs.
IN OCTOBER 1990 THE GOVERNMENT ANNOUNCED A PACKAGE OF INITIATIVES TO IMPROVE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS. IN RELATION TO BUILDINGS THE PACKAGE INCLUDED:

- A NEW PROGRAM OF ENERGY AUDITS OF INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL ENTERPRISES, DETAILED STUDIES OF ENERGY USE AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT POTENTIAL IN INDIVIDUAL INDUSTRY SECTORS AND ASSOCIATED TECHNOLOGY DEMONSTRATIONS
- DEMONSTRATIONS OF ENERGY EFFICIENT TECHNOLOGIES IN COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS, USING GOVERNMENT BUILDINGS AS MODELS
- DEVELOPMENT OF CODES OF PRACTICE FOR ENERGY EFFICIENT CONSTRUCTION OF RESIDENTIAL AND COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS
- A SERIES OF INITIATIVES TO UPGRADE ENERGY MANAGEMENT IN THE GOVERNMENT'S OWN OPERATIONS, INVOLVING
- NOMINATION OF ENERGY MANAGERS IN GOVERNMENT DEPARTMENTS AND AUTHORITIES
- REQUIRING ANNUAL REPORTS FROM DEPARTMENTS AND AUTHORITIES ON ENERGY USE AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY IMPROVEMENT INITIATIVES
- SETTING HIGH ENERGY EFFICIENCY REQUIREMENTS FOR GOVERNMENT HOUSING AND COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS CONSTRUCTION AND COMMERCIAL BUILDINGS LEASES, AND,
- THE ESTABLISHMENT, IN CONCERT WITH THE STATES, OF A FULLY INTEGRATED ENERGY MANAGEMENT ADVISORY CENTRE AS A MODEL FOR DEVELOPMENT OF SIMILAR CENTRES AROUND AUSTRALIA

IN TERMS OF AN ONGOING INFORMATION CAMPAIGN TO INCREASE AWARENESS THE GOVERNMENT IS CONSIDERING AN ADDITIONAL INITIATIVE TO INVITE PROFESSIONAL AND INDUSTRY ASSOCIATIONS TO IDENTIFY EXISTING ENERGY EFFICIENT BUILDINGS, AND PROVIDE FUNDS TO DOCUMENT AND PROMOTE THEM TO KEY DECISION MAKING GROUPS.

WORK HAS BEGUN ON THE PROCESS OF DEVELOPING STANDARDS, WITH INITIAL EMPHASIS BEING GIVEN TO THE RESIDENTIAL SECTOR. WHETHER SUCH STANDARDS ARE MANDATORY OR NOT IS A MATTER FOR DECISION BY INDIVIDUAL STATES AND TERRITORIES, AND THEY ARE THEREFORE INVOLVED CLOSELY IN THE OVERALL INVESTIGATIONS. IT IS ALSO ESSENTIAL THAT ANY WORK DONE IN THIS AREA IS CONSISTENT WITH THE BROADER BUILDINGS REGULATIONS REVIEW BEING CARRIED OUT BY THE DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE, AND FOR THIS REASON THE BUILDING REGULATION REVIEW UNIT (WITHIN DITAC) IS A JOINT VENTURER IN THE OVERALL PROCESS.

IN PRINCIPLE THE GOVERNMENT DOES NOT ACCEPT THAT THE INTRODUCTION OF ONEROUS REGULATION IS THE BEST WAY TO ADDRESS ENERGY EFFICIENCY IN THE COMMERCIAL SECTOR. THE COST BURDEN TO INDUSTRY AND TO GOVERNMENT OF SUCH MEASURES WOULD SEEM EXCESSIVE COMPARED TO ALTERNATIVES. RATHER THE GOVERNMENT BELIEVES THE ISSUE WOULD BE BETTER TACKLED BY A COMBINATION OF MARKET MEASURES AND AWARENESS AND INFORMATION PROGRAMS, SUPPLEMENTED BY REGULATION AS NECESSARY.
Paragraph 7.32

The Committee recommends that the Federal and State Housing ministers, in association with representatives of Local Government and national housing industry groups, develop and implement residential energy consumption targets for new housing over a ten year period.

GENERALLY THE GOVERNMENT NOTES THAT MOST OF THESE ACTIONS FALL WITHIN THE PROVINCE OF THE STATES. THE ESD WORKING GROUPS ARE CONSIDERING THE DESIRABILITY OF THE ADOPTION OF COMPREHENSIVE REGULATORY MEASURES RELATING TO ENERGY EFFICIENCY IN HOUSING, BEARING IN MIND THAT THE ISSUE IS COMPLEX GIVEN THE IMPORTANCE OF CONSUMER PRACTICE AND BEHAVIOUR AS WELL AS CONSTRUCTION AND EQUIPMENT. THIS IS ALSO A SECTOR WHERE MARKET MEASURES HAVE WIDE POTENTIAL APPLICATION. THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.

WORK HAS BEGUN ON THE PROCESS OF DEVELOPING STANDARDS, WITH INITIAL EMPHASIS BEING GIVEN TO THE RESIDENTIAL SECTOR. WHETHER SUCH STANDARDS ARE MANDATORY OR NOT IS A MATTER FOR DECISION BY INDIVIDUAL STATES AND TERRITORIES, AND THEY ARE THEREFORE INVOLVED CLOSELY IN THE OVERALL INVESTIGATIONS. IT IS ALSO ESSENTIAL THAT ANY WORK DONE IN THIS AREA IS CONSISTENT WITH THE BROADER BUILDINGS REGULATIONS REVIEW AS DISCUSSED IN THE RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATION 7.31 ABOVE.

THE STANDARDS SETTING PROCESS DISCUSSED ABOVE WILL PROVIDE A BASIS NOT ONLY FOR SETTING MINIMUM STANDARDS OR TARGETS, BUT ALSO FOR INSTITUTING A RATING SCHEME FOR NEW HOUSES AS A MEANS OF PROMOTING PUBLIC DEMAND FOR PROGRESSIVELY HIGHER STANDARDS OF ENERGY EFFICIENCY IN HOUSING.
Paragraph 7.33
The Committee recommends that all States set market penetration targets for solar hot water heating.

THIS RECOMMENDATION HAS BEEN REFERRED TO THE AMEC WORKING PARTY ON THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT WHICH WILL EXAMINE THE MEANS OF INCREASING THE USE OF SOLAR POWER IN THE RESIDENTIAL SECTOR, INCLUDING THE USE OF SOLAR HOT WATER HEATING. THE ESD WORKING GROUPS ARE ALSO CONSIDERING THIS ISSUE AND THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.
Paragraph 7.34

The Committee recommends that information about passive solar heating be made available to all prospective homebuilders. This information should be actively promoted by building authorities rather than simply being supplied on request.
DPIE IS PUBLISHING A REVISED EDITION OF ``ENERGY EFFICIENT AUSTRALIAN HOUSING'' WHICH COVERS ALL MATTERS RELEVANT TO EFFICIENT DESIGN AND RETROFITTING, INCLUDING PASSIVE SOLAR HEAT GAIN.
Paragraph 7.35
The Committee also recommends that new subdivisions be laid out to facilitate the construction of housing following passive solar principles wherever possible.

THE GREEN STREET JOINT VENTURE, MANAGED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF INDUSTRY TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE IN COLLABORATION WITH STATE GOVERNMENTS AND INDUSTRY, PROMOTES REDUCED ENERGY USAGE THROUGH EFFICIENT URBAN DEVELOPMENT. THIS AIMS AT LOWER RESOURCE USE IN THE DEVELOPMENT PROCESS, REDUCED TRAVEL DISTANCE, EFFICIENT SITING FOR SOLAR ORIENTATION, VENTILATION AND CLIMATE PROTECTION, REDUCED SITE MAINTENANCE AND REDUCED INFRASTRUCTURE PROVISION.
Paragraph 7.36

Some States are moving to implement insulation standards for roofing and walls. For example, Victoria is in the process of introducing minimum insulation standards for walls and ceilings of all new dwellings. However, it has taken fourteen years for this proposal to be implemented-it was first announced in 1976. The Committee commends this initiative and recommends that insulation standards for new houses be set in all States within one year.
THIS RECOMMENDATION HAS BEEN REFERRED TO THE AMEC WORKING PARTY ON THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT WHICH WILL EXAMINE THE FEASIBILITY OF ESTABLISHING INSULATION STANDARDS FOR NEW HOMES.
INSULATION IS BUT ONE ELEMENT OF HOUSING ENERGY EFFICIENCY, ALL OF WHICH WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO THE STANDARDS SETTING PROCESS DISCUSSED IN PARAGRAPHS 7.31 AND 7.32 ABOVE.
Paragraph 7.37

The Committee also recognises that existing housing requires improvement. The Committee accordingly recommends that within 10 years, all existing housing be required to meet minimum roof insulation standards, where it is structurally feasible to fit.

THE GOVERNMENT BELIEVES THAT EVEN IF A PRESCRIPTIVE APPROACH IS ADOPTED TOWARDS ACHIEVING ENERGY EFFICIENCY IT WOULD BE UNDESIRABLE TO SINGLE OUT SPECIFIC FACETS FOR MANDATORY REGULATION. FOR INSTANCE, THE IMPOSITION OF MINIMUM ROOF INSULATION STANDARDS MAY RESTRICT THE USE OF OTHER CHEAPER AND PERHAPS MORE PRACTICAL MEASURES. A PREFERABLE APPROACH WOULD BE TO SET ENERGY PERFORMANCE STANDARDS FOR ENTIRE BUILDING STRUCTURES.
(G) HOUSEHOLD ENERGY USE
Paragraph 7.38

The Committee recommends that information campaigns be conducted to inform householders of the cost savings which can result from measures such as insulating hot water services. The Committee further recommends that insulation standards for hot water services be increased, and that manufacturers be required to fit owner-adjustable thermo-stats to hot water services.

THE COMMONWEALTH IS COMMITTED TO A MUCH EXPANDED LEVEL OF ENERGY CONSERVATION AND ENERGY EFFICIENCY PROMOTION. PREVIOUS PROGRAMS, WHICH CONCENTRATED PARTICULARLY ON THE INDUSTRIAL/COMMERCIAL SECTORS, HAVE BEEN EXPANDED AND NEW PROGRAM INITIATIVES HAVE BEEN UNDERTAKEN IN THE RESIDENTIAL SECTOR. AS PART OF THESE INITIATIVES THE COMMONWEALTH'S BUDGET FOR CONSERVATION PROGRAMS DOUBLED TO ALMOST $1M IN 1989-90, WITH AN UNDERTAKING FOR A FURTHER INCREASE OF $1.32 MILLION IN 1990-91.

INFORMATION ON THESE MATTERS IS CURRENTLY BEING DISTRIBUTED TO EVERY HOUSEHOLD IN AUSTRALIA, AND IS DESIGNED TO SHOW CONSUMERS HOW TO CONSERVE ENERGY AND USE IT MORE EFFICIENTLY, AND THEREBY REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS.

``THE ENERGY GUIDE'' IS ONE OF THE LARGEST UNDERTAKINGS OF ITS KIND IN THE WORLD AND WAS PRODUCED BY DPIE IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE AUSTRALIAN CONSUMER'S ASSOCIATION. THE GUIDE DISTILS AN ENORMOUS AMOUNT OF RESEARCH AND DETAILS ENERGY-SAVING PRACTICES IN THE KITCHEN, THE LIVING ROOM, THE BATHROOM AND THE LAUNDRY. THE GUIDE ALSO OFFERS TIPS ON FUEL-EFFICIENT DRIVING, PRACTICAL INFORMATION ABOUT BUYING HOME APPLIANCES AND OTHER INFORMATION WHICH ENABLES PEOPLE TO MAKE PERSONAL CHOICES THAT WILL HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS ON REDUCING THE EMISSIONS OF CARBON DIOXIDE AND THUS AMELIORATING THE POSSIBLE HARM FROM THE GREENHOUSE EFFECT.
Paragraph 7.39

The appliance labelling system in Victoria and New South Wales is well established and has proved to be a useful method of improving appliance efficiency. The Committee recommends that the other State Governments immediately introduce the appliance labelling system currently in use.
AND
Paragraph 7.40

The Committee recommends that the States introduce minimum appliance efficiency standards within two years. These standards should apply to all major energy using appliances (including heaters and hot water services), gas and electric, be at least equivalent to those currently in force in the United States, and should be regularly reviewed.

THE ENERGY MANAGEMENT CONFERENCE OF AMEC IS CURRENTLY DEVELOPING A NATIONAL LABELLING SYSTEM FOR DOMESTIC APPLIANCES. THE CONFERENCE IS ALSO EXAMINING THE FEASIBILITY OF INTRODUCING MINIMUM ENERGY EFFICIENCY STANDARDS FOR DOMESTIC APPLIANCES AND WILL EXAMINE EXTENDING THE LABELLING SCHEME TO COMMERCIAL APPLIANCES. Paragraph 7.41

The Committee recommends that the electricity utilities actively promote the use of energy saving devices such as low flow shower heads. The Committee further recommends that the energy utilities implement a financing system to allow consumers to purchase energy saving equipment and pay back the cost over an extended period through normal energy charges.

THIS RECOMMENDATION HAS BEEN REFERRED TO THE AMEC ENERGY MANAGEMENT CONFERENCE FOR CONSIDERATION. THIS RECOMMENDATION HIGHLIGHTS ONE OF THE POSSIBILITIES FOR DEMAND SIDE MANAGEMENT BY STATE ELECTRICITY UTILITIES (SEE RESPONSE TO RECOMMENDATION 7.22).
Paragraph 7.42
The Committee recommends that a comprehensive information campaign be conducted to promote the energy efficiency advantages of natural gas used for these purposes.

``THE ENERGY GUIDE'', WHICH HAS BEEN DISTRIBUTED TO ALL AUSTRALIAN HOUSEHOLDS, PROVIDES COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION ON THE USE OF NATURAL GAS FOR A VARIETY OF HOUSEHOLD APPLICATIONS COVERING BOTH ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND GREENHOUSE BENEFITS.
Paragraph 7.43
The Committee also recommends that all new State housing should have natural gas heating and cooking appliances installed at the time of construction where gas is available.

THE GOVERNMENT RECOGNISES THAT THERE WOULD BE CLEAR EFFICIENCY AND GREENHOUSE BENEFITS IN SUCH AN APPROACH IN THOSE STATES USING FOSSIL FUELS FOR ELECTRICITY GENERATION PROVIDED CORRECT INSTALLATION TO ENSURE THAT ANY HEALTH RISKS ARE MINIMISED. HOWEVER THIS IS A STATE RESPONSIBILITY. THE ISSUE HAS BEEN BROUGHT TO THE ATTENTION OF THE STATE GOVERNMENTS.
Paragraph 7.44
The Committee recommends that sales tax on gas appliances be reduced to improve the competitive position of these items.

THE ESD WORKING GROUPS ARE CURRENTLY EXAMINING THE VARIOUS EXCISES, ROYALTIES, RENTS AND TAXES, LEVIED BY GOVERNMENTS AND INCORPORATED IN PRICES TO ENERGY USERS. A KEY ISSUE FOR THE ESD WORKING GROUPS IS THE ADEQUACY OF THE LEVEL AND STRUCTURE OF CURRENT END USE ENERGY PRICES:
- IN PROVIDING ALL CONSUMERS WITH AN INCENTIVE TO USE AN OPTIMAL AMOUNT OF ENERGY, AND,
- IN PROVIDING CONSUMERS WITH APPROPRIATE SIGNALS TO MAKE CLEAR CHOICES BETWEEN DIFFERENT FORMS OF ENERGY.

THE GOVERNMENT AGREES THAT CONSUMPTION OF NATURAL GAS IN DOMESTIC USES SHOULD BE CLOSELY EXAMINED IN LINE WITH ITS VIEW THAT ENERGY SUBSTITUTION TO LESS POLLUTING FUELS, WHERE PRACTICABLE, IS FUNDAMENTAL TO REDUCING GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS IN THE SHORT TERM.

THE GOVERNMENT AGREES WITH THE NEED TO EXAMINE BARRIERS TO FUEL SWITCHING TO IMPROVE ENERGY EFFICIENCY AND REDUCE GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS. THE ESD WORKING GROUPS ARE CURRENTLY EXAMINING THIS ASPECT OF TAXES AND CHARGES AS WELL AS THE BROADER ISSUE OF ADEQUACY OF LEVEL AND STRUCTURE OF THE VARIOUS EXCISES, ROYALTIES, RENTS AND TAXES, LEVIED BY GOVERNMENTS AND INCORPORATED IN PRICES TO END USERS. THE GOVERNMENT WILL TAKE ACCOUNT OF THE SENATE COMMITTEE'S RECOMMENDATIONS IN THE CONTEXT OF ITS CONSIDERATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF THE WORK OF THE ABOVEMENTIONED GROUPS.
(H) RESEARCH
Paragraph 7.45

The Committee recommends that the Federal Government establish a system for identifying `projects for national priority development' and make available appropriate funding to foster their development and implementation, particularly in the area of renewable energy technology.

IN SEPTEMBER 1990, THE PRIME MINISTER REQUESTED THE AUSTRALIAN SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY COUNCIL (ASTEC) TO PREPARE AN ISSUES AND OPTIONS PAPER ON ` `RESEARCH DIRECTIONS FOR AUSTRALIA'', AS A MAJOR INPUT TO A WHITE PAPER ON SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY TO BE RELEASED IN 1992. THESE PAPERS WILL AIM TO SET BROAD AND CO-ORDINATED GOVERNMENT GUIDELINES FOR RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT POLICY IN AUSTRALIA, WITHIN WHICH DEPARTMENTS AGENCIES AND RESEARCHERS CAN SET MORE SPECIFIC STRATEGIC AND OPERATIONAL PRIORITIES. THE ASTEC PAPER IS EXPECTED TO BE RELEASED IN SEPTEMBER 1991.

RESPONSIBILITY FOR COMMONWEALTH SUPPORT OF NON-COAL RELATED ENERGY R& NOW RESTS WITH THE ENERGY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION (ERDC), ESTABLISHED IN JULY 1990. THE CORPORATION'S CHARTER IS DESIGNED TO ENSURE THAT GOVERNMENT FUNDED ENERGY R& IS RESPONSIVE TO THE NEEDS OF INDUSTRY AND THE WIDER COMMUNITY AND OPERATES FLEXIBLY.

THE ERDC RESEARCH PRIORITIES ARE BASED ON AN ONGOING ASSESSMENT OF THE CURRENT STATUS OF THE VARIOUS ENERGY INDUSTRIES AND THE NEED TO MINIMISE ADVERSE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS IN THE SHORT, MEDIUM AND LONG TERM. THE ERDC PRIORITY RESEARCH PROGRAM AREAS ARE:
- ENERGY UTILISATION AND CONSERVATION;
- FUEL SOURCES AND DELIVERY; AND

- NEW AND RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES AND SYSTEMS(ALTHOUGH RENEWABLE ENERGY REPRESENTS ONLY AROUND 6 PER CENT OF TOTAL DOMESTIC ENERGY AVAILABILITY ERDC COMMITTED OVER 25 PER CENT OF ITS FUNDS FOR NEW PROJECTS TO THIS AREA IN 1990).
Paragraph 7.46

The Committee recommends that the ERDC create a separate Technical Standing Committee for photovoltaics. The Technical Standing Committee should be given a mandate to develop a specific photovoltaic program and to encourage and coordinate longer term activities relevant to photovoltaics.

ERDC HAS DECIDED THAT IT WILL NOT USE A SYSTEM OF STANDING COMMITTEES TO EVALUATE PROJECT PROPOSALS.
