The Committee believes that companies should also be encouraged to claim the 150% R &D tax concession to promote the research and experimental development of new technologies. However, it is alarmed at plans to reduce this concession to 125% after 1993, and urges the government to maintain the tax concession at the existing level. Further the Committee recommends that the concession be granted for a period of 10 years to provide certainty and to truly encourage industry to commit funds to research and development.

FOLLOWING THE INDUSTRY STATEMENT, THE GOVERNMENT DECIDED THAT THE TAX CONCESSION BE REDUCED TO 125% BUT INSTEAD OF TERMINATING IN 1995, IT WILL BECOME A PERMANENT FEATURE OF THE INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT ACT. THE GOVERNMENT BELIEVES THAT THIS LEVEL OF TAX CONCESSION WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE SUFFICIENT INCENTIVE FOR INDUSTRY TO INVEST IN R& AND AT A LOWER COST TO REVENUE.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter relates very much to the matter I was speaking about a moment ago in the MPI that we have just debated. As I have said in the Senate before, the question of the development of a greenhouse effect is the most important environmental problem that we in Australia and everybody in the world face. The inter-governmental panel on climate control's scientific committee reported in May of last year that it was necessary for the world to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 60 to 80 per cent as rapidly as possible. That IPCC report, translated into Australia's terms-we are very profligate users of greenhouse gases; we have in the recent past been the world's worst polluters in relation to CFCs and halons and we are about the world's third worst polluters in terms of CO2 emissions-means a 92 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the criterion which must, above everything else, guide the development over the next 10 to 15 years out into the more distant future. It is quite clear from that imperative that investments which are made in energy efficiency devices must be very carefully crafted. One of the things which the report Rescue the Future points out is that many energy investments are, of their very nature, massive, take a long time to repay and are therefore very difficult to change in the short term. When one builds a thousand megawatt power station one is spending roughly $1 billion of investment which will be recouped over some 25 or 30 years.

The best scientific evidence-I am sure that most honourable senators in this chamber unfortunately are not interested in the best scientific evidence; they do not read and they do not understand the best scientific evidence-on which we should be basing our judgment is that within the next 10 to 15 years the evidence on greenhouse will become incontrovertible. I believe that it is quite clear that the majority of Australian people do not want to leave a damaged world behind for their children and for their grandchildren. When that evidence on greenhouse becomes incontrovertible, when it is not possible for governments to argue, as this Government response does with its `Well, let's wait and see' approach, then the Australian people will be demanding that we meet those very stringent standards and that we do attempt to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions not by 10 or 20 per cent but by much larger amounts.

The one thing we must not do-the report makes this quite clear-is lock ourselves into massive expensive energy developments which cannot meet the sorts of targets which in 10 years time will become absolutely imperative and which we will not be able to avoid making and for which there will be a very strong public clamour. We should not be investing in more power stations if we can possibly avoid it.

We should be investing in those sorts of technologies which can achieve small gains if the pay-back times are very short. We should be doing everything possible to put in place the energy efficiency measures which can avoid those massive investments so that when it becomes clearer and more politically acceptable for the community we can then move to the more radical technologies, many of which are emerging on the scene, and which we can then implement. We will not have made our investments which will have used up our capital and which will not allow us to make alternative investments.

This Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology is totally inadequate. I remind the Senate that when I first suggested to the Committee that it look at the greenhouse effect and specifically said that the reference should be how one heads off greenhouse-as far as that is possible-what are the impediments to that and how does one overcome those impediments, there was strong and consistent opposition from people in Government and from government bureaucracies to that reference. They were saying, `Why not address the problem of how to collect a bibliography of the information on greenhouse? Why not address the problem of how one adapts to greenhouse?'.

The idea that the Committee might actually come up with some suggestions which would reduce the effect of greenhouse, as far as that was possible, and the idea that it might come up with a report which would look at the inefficiencies in many of the bureaucracies, particularly in relation to electricity generation, and make specific suggestions for quite radical change, were strongly resisted. It took nearly a year for that Committee to successfully get that reference before it.

When the Committee was taking evidence from Government departments, including the Treasury, transport and energy and resources portfolios, it was quite clear that the Government had appointed to those bureaucracies people whose specific task was not to address the problem of greenhouse but to work out how the Government could avoid addressing the problem of greenhouse.

I well remember a former Liberal colleague in this place, Senator Peter Baume, sitting opposite six of those senior bureaucrats who had been specifically appointed to one of those government bureaucracies to address the problem of greenhouse and saying, `I have been in the Senate since 1974. I have been on many committees. I have listened to a great deal of evidence. That is the worst evidence I have ever heard'. They were not my words; they were Senator Peter Baume's words straight to six senior bureaucrats appointed by the Government to address the problem of greenhouse. This report continues that same total misunderstanding of the importance of this very vital issue.

The Government has had this report Rescue the Future since February. We were given a response today at a quarter past three. We were expected to address the Government's response later this afternoon. Had there not been an MPI we would have been given the Government's response and been asked to debate it immediately. That is totally unsatisfactory and it indicates yet again the disregard and the misunderstanding that the Government has of this very important issue.

It is quite clear from the Government's statement that in looking at greenhouse it simply regards that as one other issue along with many others. If the others were given a higher priority, greenhouse would simply not enter into its calculus as to what should be done in the energy sector. That is not the situation. Greenhouse is an imperative which must be addressed. We cannot put it aside for other issues.

I am sure that if this Government talks to the people in some of the Pacific islands, the coral atoll islands, and talks to people in Bangladesh it will find that they do not regard greenhouse as an issue that we can either take up or leave aside. In 30 or 40 years they may well be swimming for their lives, quite literally. This country may be faced with massive problems of what have been called environmental refugees. What are we going to do then? Are these the sorts of problems we should leave for our children?

The best scientific advice is that the consequences of greenhouse will be significant climate change, with a very considerable impact on agriculture. We do not yet know exactly what those impacts are going to be, but to go on rejecting that these things must be faced up to-to be turning aside, addressing other issues and avoiding facing up to greenhouse-is simply leaving the problem far too long.

Because we are not sure of exactly the rate of onset of the consequences, and the size of those consequences, we should be doing everything in our power to slow down the rate of onset of greenhouse effects. It may well be that where we have set aside national parks to protect particular species and to protect particular ecologies, every one of those national parks may be in the wrong place. The consequence of that is quite massive global extinctions. How we and our children cope with that is something this Government clearly has not yet come to face seriously.

Let us look at the consequences in terms of agricultural production. What happens if Western Australia becomes considerably drier? What happens to its production? We have a government which is hell bent on increasing the population of Australia, particularly in Perth where the ground has been overexploited and, quite seriously, mined rather than managed. What happens to the water supply if the rainfall decreases significantly over there? South Australia is becoming significantly drier. Large parts of the agricultural areas of South Australia should already be returned to mallee scrub. What happens to the fruit growing areas of Victoria when the frosts fail because the weather has warmed up by a couple of degrees and we no longer grow stone fruits in those areas?

We have seen very considerable disruption to agricultural production in Australia already. What happens when we superimpose these environmental effects on our agricultural production, particularly when the variability from year to year is such that we will not really know for a while exactly what is happening? Farmers will struggle on, thinking that these seasons will return to what they were 10 or 15 years earlier, and it will not be until the change is persistent for some years that they will say, `My God, we cannot continue with production in this area. We have to change to something else'. These are the sorts of effects that the Government is simply not addressing, not taking seriously. Indeed, we find this right through the report. I quote from the Government's response:

However, in setting the interim targets, the Government recognised that it would be imprudent for Australia to proceed with measures which have net adverse economic impacts nationally or on Australia's trade competitiveness in the absence of similar action by major greenhouse gas producing countries.

Our report Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect shows that a very large number of changes can be made which will reduce the amount of energy used for a given unit of production, reduce the amount of resource used and the amount of greenhouse gas emission and significantly improve the economic situation.

If we want to talk about competitiveness-and we are moving into a greenhouse world-surely it makes a great deal of economic sense to build those industries in this country which meet the criteria of greater energy efficiency and lower greenhouse gas emissions so that 10 years, 20 years or 30 years down the track we will have precisely the sorts of industries which will be of benefit to other countries, and they will be beating a path to our door to buy those technologies from us. We do not see the Government accepting that as a fair and reasonable assessment of the world which we face, the world which our children must face.

The Government talks about its action in relation to CFCs. In that respect, Australia has performed quite well. It needed to. Australia was the very worst polluter in the world in relation to CFCs and halons, but it certainly needs to move a great deal more briskly in these other areas. The Government's response says that the interim planning target on greenhouse gas reductions was endorsed by the States and Territories at the Special Premiers Conference in October 1990. The general thesis that there is a requirement for the Commonwealth and the States to cooperate in these matters lies right through the Government's response.

In the States we find that there is a total disregard-it is even worse than at the Commonwealth level-to meeting targets. In my own State in South Australia, the Government talks about building a multifunction polis in an area of land below sea level covered by eight metres of soft, saline, corrosive mud, which will have to be removed and replaced with about 13 metres of good soil before building can even begin. The energy costs of that operation have not even been taken into the calculus of the MFP.

We find that the South Australian Government is progressively closing down public transport. To say that the Special Premiers Conference has come up with some agreement is simply pushing aside what is really happening; that is, the States are not addressing this problem and, as far as one can gather from their actions, they have no intention whatsoever of doing so.

The Government then goes on in its response to talk about the energy guide as one of its initiatives. It is now being distributed to every household in Australia. That is a perfect example of blaming the victim. Australian consumers are very much the victim of unlevel playing fields in the energy sector, very often playing fields which have been made unlevel by government bureaucracy-I refer here specifically to the tariff charges for electricity-such that consumers are forced to make decisions on unbalanced economic grounds, which inevitably involve the use of greater amounts of energy. To turn around and promote to people an energy guide, and say, `You should buy this', when very often there may be a great capital hump in the way of buying this rather than that, is simply being very cruel to the Australian public.

Governments must address the problem of properly levelling the playing field and properly representing the prices. In this the Democrats rely entirely on properly constructed market forces and on properly levelling the playing field. If people are given the proper price signals, they will make the proper judgments on price and these will also be the best economic decisions.
To give an example-and I mentioned our alternative Budget in my previous speech-we are proposing a very small tax on fossil fuels which will raise $500m per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —A little tax!

—A little tax, yes, because in the case of petrol the tax would be 0.4c per litre. This tax would be targeted to addressing the capital difficulty faced by many people wishing to buy energy efficient devices, but unable to do so. Let me give an example. If a potential consumer is faced with a choice of buying an electric or a solar hot water service, it is quite clear-and I think every honourable senator would know this-that to buy the solar hot water service costs a great deal more money. But the moment an electric hot water service is plugged in, $1 is demanded from the electricity utility for every watt which that consumes of capital equipment, but the consumer does not pay that amount. The total capital cost of making the electric choice is far greater than the capital cost of making the solar choice, but the capital cost of the electric choice is largely picked up by the utility and amortised into its costs over the next 25 years.

SPEECH.PARA: By using the fund which would be created by our fossil fuel levy to bridge that capital impediment, so potential consumers would see the capital costs of a solar hot-water unit as exactly the same as an electric hot-water unit, most people would then buy the solar unit. Of course, over time the solar unit is an incredibly cheaper option and very substantially reduces the consumption of electricity. In South Australia about 20 per cent of electricity generated goes into water heating; that figure ranges down to as little as 5 per cent in Queensland-a very significant reduction in the consumption of electricity and in the release of greenhouse gases.

Admittedly, there would be a very small initial increase-a 0.12 per cent increase in the inflation rate-but it is one-off and temporary because as that reduction in energy consumption starts to bite the overall amount of electricity consumed falls, the total amount of money spent on energy falls and there is a strong negative impact on the inflation rate. These are the sorts of things which the Government should be looking at. These are the sorts of things which are suggested in the report Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact off the greenhouse effect. These are the sorts of things on which the Government has turned its back.

Further on in the Government's response, we find the Government praising energy labelling on new appliances. Again, that is blaming the victim. Okay, give potential consumers information on energy consumption at the time of making particular purchases, when selecting one refrigerator compared with another, but if the more energy efficient refrigerator costs considerably more than the less energy efficient one, many poor people will simply have no choice. The Government is placing on them the additional burden of wanting to do the right thing and then giving them a bad conscience because they know that they have done something which is more damaging to the environment but they are incapable of making the correct choice. These are the sorts of areas which the energy fund that the Democrats would create under its alternative Budget would help to bridge, to level the playing field so that people would make the correct economic choices which would also be the correct energy efficient choices.

I stress the word `fund' because in relation to each of these electricity energy efficient devices we suggest that the extra capital be made available through the electricity utilities in each State so that, again, that capital difference could be amortised over a period of time into the electricity bills. That would mean that that extra capital would actually flow back to the utilities, back to the fund, and could be reinvested again and again in increased energy devices.

Investing $500m a year from the fund would provide 500,000 solar hot-water services at an approximate cost of $1,000 each. Within a few years every home in Australia could be equipped with a solar hot-water service out of that fund with very substantial savings in greenhouse gas emissions and with a recoupment to the fund so that money could then flow into other energy efficient devices.
On page 3 of the Government's response we find a description of the policy framework. It states:

. . . a policy framework for the energy sector will necessarily encompass not only the National Greenhouse Response Strategy, but also many matters, such as access to resources, and returns to the community from resource use, that have little connection with greenhouse.

That is a total misreading of the situation. Greenhouse must become the imperative. As our report showed, addressing that problem can also address the problems of resource use and economic returns. The Government has simply not properly understood that fact.

The Government refers to the Industry Commission's report on the cost-benefit implications for Australian industry with the international consensus in favour of a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. Madam Acting Deputy President, having looked at a couple of Industry Commission reports recently and having commented on them, you should not hold your breath. The Industry Commission, despite its charter, despite what it should be doing, is not addressing the problems of the environment. It is taking a very cold econometric view of everything to do with the environment. It is not addressing the environment in the ways in which it should be under its legislation.
The Government in its response refers to not taking a 10-year energy plan, which was recommended in our report, as a rigid tool. It says:
Rather we will be looking to establish a clear policy framework within which the energy sector can operate dynamically, with the flexibility to respond to emerging issues.

In light of the very large amounts of money which are invested in energy using parts of the economy-I have mentioned $1 billion for a power station with a pay back time over 25 years; think of the transport system in a city with the built infrastructure-to talk about operating dynamically with the flexibility to respond to emerging issues is an absolute nonsense. It is a misreading of the foundation on which a sensible greenhouse policy needs to be built.

We must take a longer term and a very careful view. As I said earlier, we must look to making those investments which can address the problems of energy efficiency in the short term, whatever that energy efficiency is, in terms of those things which have short pay back times. We should be avoiding the massive investments as long as possible because the situation in relation to greenhouse-the amount of time available to address it, the rate of onset, the severity of the effect-will, according to the best scientific evidence, become much clearer over the next 10 to 15 years. The Government's response also says:
The Government supports encouragement of cogeneration where it is feasible to do so.

The Committee saw the work being done by CSIRO on the solid oxide fuel cell, work which could address directly the problem of greenhouse in that it could double the direct efficiency of generating electricity and could also provide, through the heat from the fuel cell, an efficiency which would probably approach 90 per cent compared with a current effort of somewhere between 25 per cent and 35 per cent, depending on whether brown or black coal is used. That work in CSIRO is languishing for want of proper government support. I simply cannot take seriously the Government's statement that it supports the encouragement of cogeneration.

This Government needs to do a great deal more. It needs to seriously address the problem of greenhouse. It has not done this. This is too little, it is probably too late, and the Government really needs to go back and rethink the whole response to this very good report entitled Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak to the Government's response to the Industry, Science and Technology Committee report entitled Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect. As is inevitably the case, this response follows a considerable time after the Committee started the inquiry. When we started the inquiry we came in at the latter end of a group of inquiries into various aspects of a similar subject. At that time it was a very hot subject. As various reports were handed down and as the matter settled down, it lost some of its heat. Our lifestyles exist in a world where people in virtually every country insist on a guaranteed energy supply. We are still in the early stages of determining the greenhouse effect-its level and effects and whether it is a phase or a pattern. We are still waiting to get more information on that.

SPEECH.PARA: When we commenced this inquiry we took the attitude that, even if there was no greenhouse effect, our recommendations would be valuable and useful to the community at large. Much has and is being done. In my cursory glance through the Government's response, I noticed that in many of the areas in which the Committee made suggestions the Government has either referred these matters for action to various places or those matters are already being acted upon. I am pleased that we can say that things have got that far.

The biggest industry that I can see coming up in the next decade is waste management and pollution control. Australia is well placed not only to improve its own situation but also to do an enormous amount in other countries where the problem is so great and requires such close attention. We must also bear in mind that, while there are general disagreeable features of coal burning and the manufacture of electricity from coal, the coal industry has made tremendous advances in the last decade and is working on considerably greater improvement in the next. That industry is interested in trying to increase the amount of efficiency it is getting from coal. It can now do considerably more about pollution, which in the past has always been an unsatisfactory aspect of its operations.

This applies also to gas. There have been various issues as far as the use of gas is concerned which are being attended to and on which progress is being made. One of the Committee's recommendations deals with the use of petrol in cars. We noted the degree of improvement which has come about due to the use of the catalytic converter, and so it goes on. As people become more conscious of this question and the problems it creates in the community, they are doing more about it. We need to give credit for the fact that that is happening, and we should ensure that we do not put obstacles in the way of its happening further.

We will get a lot more by educating, encouraging and demonstrating than we will by legislating. Over the next few years we will get a lot more if we encourage people with facts and figures rather than over-sensationalising, as has been the case in some of the material that I have read in the past few years. I have been given some highly coloured material that is claimed to be authentic when clearly it has been anything but. That has not done the cause any good. We should take this in a very rational way. We have to deal with it in a sustainable manner that will do the right thing by the country and the rest of the world in the years ahead.

There are several references in the Government's response to the fact that this is largely a State issue. I am one of those who believe in the Federal system. The States are entitled to make their own decisions. However, there needs to be greater cooperation, not only between the Commonwealth and the States but also among the States. This is one area where there is still room for improvement on a large scale. I believe that the States will cooperate further. Discussion is currently under way about a south-eastern grid or an eastern States grid for power and/or gas. Our Committee is probably about half a lap behind on that matter, as we were when we started the inquiry into the greenhouse effect. By the time we produce our report there will probably be half a dozen reports that have been put down just ahead of us. Nevertheless, if it is a matter of getting people to think about it and make submissions about it and getting the States to consider the necessary degree of cooperation, it will have been useful.

We owe it to the next generation to look at how we treat our resources and how we look after the planet that we currently and temporarily occupy. We have to ensure that in our planning for the future we use our resources wisely and well. We in Tasmania are now in that interesting stage when, having decided many years ago to have a hydro-electric system of pollution free, reusable material, rechargeable in every way, we have changed the plans, which has left us in a rather difficult condition. At the moment our water resources are about 27 per cent of capacity. We are not using water as effectively or as efficiently as was originally planned and as we could have done. Water is a beautiful, non-pollutant material. It is replaceable, but we are not using it adequately. We now find that we are belching smoke from an oil-fired power station, costing Tasmanians a quarter of a million dollars a day for the privilege. We are now being offered the alternatives of establishing a coal-fired station in one of the two worst inversion gullies in Tasmania-the Tamar Valley and the Fingal Valley-of connecting to the system that is now available in Victoria or of considering a gas connection.

In the next five or 10 years, while this is being determined and planned and while the funding is being discussed, we will run grave risks of committing our next generation to non-employment in Tasmania. We want to be able to provide a livelihood for the next generation of people who wish to work and to utilise the resources that the State provides. Unless we provide guaranteed energy to those people, Tasmania will continue to stagnate and decline. We need to look after the environment and to ensure that we provide the energy that will keep the employment environment and the living environment in a condition that those of us who currently enjoy them can pass on.

For some time I have been very interested in the development of the dry oxide fuel cell. I believe that that is ultimately going to be of great assistance to most places, and certainly places like Tasmania. It will be of great assistance to substantial industries, which would be able to supply their own power as well as fit in with a cogeneration grid. But here again, do we go ahead and put in a cable joining Tasmania to Victoria now? Do we wait to see whether we can get that more quickly or more slowly than it takes to develop the dry oxide fuel cell? Do we need both and will either of those preclude our capacity to get gas, which I believe is the fuel that we particularly require? These sorts of decisions have to be made even while we are waiting for something else to happen.

We have to consider that the world will not stand still while we either try to resolve the problems of the past or pontificate about the possibilities of the future. Those things have to be done at the same time. We do need to concentrate largely-more than we do in Australia-on what is happening in the northern hemisphere. Our greatest problem is certainly going to be how we can assist the northern hemisphere to clean up the atmosphere and the environment generally.

We have to continue to investigate the possibilities brought about by climatic change, in case it happens. I think it is much too early to come to any firm conclusions, but we do need to accept that there are many parts of Australia and many parts of the world that would achieve great benefits from climatic change, as well as areas that would suffer to some extent. The most likely scenario is that if there were a change, for instance, Tasmania would get less rain and have worse problems with its power generation than it has at the moment.

The Committee's report, which of course I have not had an opportunity to study at any great length, does place a lot of emphasis on what the States may or may not do. I do believe that we need to encourage our State colleagues to work very closely with one another and to sort out the State matters in which we have no direct participation.

The motor vehicle and the generation of electric power are the two particular issues that we need to deal with. Most of the issues in the report have been referred already to either the Australian Minerals and Energy Council or the Australian Transport Advisory Council for attention. I am of the opinion that this Parliament should allow the Government the opportunity to see how it can deal with these matters, having referred the various issues to those two bodies. If we are not satisfied that in due course the Government has made sufficient inroads into the problems, then we have the right to either have another inquiry or try to negotiate with it to achieve some improvement. In the meantime, while that process is happening, we should allow it and encourage it to continue.

We have discussed energy audits at considerable length. In spite of assurances that the matter is well under control, I am still of the opinion that many electricity users are unaware of the services that may be available to them which ensure that energy is used as efficiently as possible.

The solar power issue is one that I believe we really have to come to grips with. I certainly agree that we have to be able to use solar power, particularly in water heating, over as much of Australia as possible. It will relieve the pressure on the use of electric power from a variety of other sources. Solar power could easily provide us with the necessary power extension that we are currently looking for to cover the next 20 to 25 years if we were able to encourage people to use it where it is appropriate and applicable.

I did not rate the Government's response to the Committee's report very highly. I thought it was a bit patronising and perfunctory, but it does cover many of the issues raised. I hope that, with cooperation from ATAC, AMEC, the States and the electricity authorities, we may be able to make some progress in the years ahead. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the comments that have been made by Senator Archer. I was holding back because I thought that Senator Childs, who is the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, was going to say something.

SPEECH.PARA: In its response to the report entitled Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect, I feel that the Government needs to do more than pay lip service to areas such as making the transport system and the energy generation systems in this country more efficient and more environmentally sensitive. I believe that all of our recommendations have been referred to some other committee, and Senator Archer made that point in his usual erudite manner.

We need to look at the use of power and the use of our energy resources, whether or not people believe in the greenhouse effect. As much as anything else, this country needs to look at the economic advantages of being more cost effective while making sure that something is done in the environmentally sensitive area as well. Whether this is done with cooperative State approval or by the Commonwealth taking over the responsibility for some areas, it is up to the Government of the day to decide which way will achieve the best result.

For example, the coalition has a program called Auselgrid, which aims to have electricity-which is on a stand alone system at the moment-integrated into a grid system across the eastern States of Australia. Taking it to its final stage of electricity sharing, excess power loads generated in Tasmania would be put through the grid system in Victoria. That would be the last stage of electricity sharing, but it is still a way of making ourselves more cost efficient and making our industries better able to cope with problems with the greenhouse effect in the future.

I thank the Government for its report. I make the point that this report was embargoed until the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, brought it down. That makes it difficult, when the reply to a report is as long as this, to be able to give it as good a response as we should.

I concur with the remarks of Senator Archer. I hope that we now have better cost efficient energy sharing and a better understanding of the problems of environmental concerns in some of the areas, notwithstanding the fact that at the moment we have a coal based electricity system in Australia which will be here for a long time to come. We require it to be sensitive to the needs of the community. Nobody would like it if the lights were turned out because we did not have enough electricity generated while we were thinking about all these other innovative things that Senator Coulter said should happen more quickly than they obviously will be able to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make the point briefly that due to another commitment and the fact that the Government's response to the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, entitled Rescue the Future: Reducing the impact of the greenhouse effect was late coming to the chamber, I have not had the opportunity to do more than skim through it. It is unsatisfactory, when we laboured so long on the report. The greenhouse issue is very complex, as can be shown by the various areas that the recommendations are to be sent to. We should be able to give consideration to the detail of the Government's response. There are some things that I am very happy with, and there are some things that I am very unhappy with. On another occasion I would like the opportunity to develop those arguments. The whole point of the Committee's proposal is that we want to stimulate discussion on this issue. There cannot be a more important point, regardless of how important people think it is. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the Inquiry into the conduct of the 1987 Federal Election and 1988 Referendums-Who Pays the Piper Calls the Tune: Minimising the risks of funding political campaigns. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The response read as follows-

GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO REPORT NO. 4 OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS: INQUIRY INTO THE CONDUCT OF THE 1987 FEDERAL ELECTION AND 1988 REFERENDUMS: WHO PAYS THE PIPER CALLS THE TUNE-MINIMISING THE RISKS OF FUNDING CAMPAIGNS
Recommendation 1.
The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide the Australian Electoral Commission with the power to conduct spot audits of the electoral activities of registered political parties.
Response

Agreed. The Government accepts the need to allow the Electoral Commission to be able to conduct spot audits of registered political parties to ensure that they are complying with the operations of the funding and disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act.
The Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill (the Bill) incorporates the necessary amendments to give effect to this recommendation.
Recommendation 2.

The Australian Electoral Commission in all future reports on the operation of Part XX of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 publish a record of all spot audits undertaken, the reports to provide detailed information on audits only where breaches of the Act have occurred.
Response

The Government has decided that the Electoral Commission must publish in its reports on the operation of the funding and disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act a record of all spot audits undertaken and will amend the Act accordingly.
Recommendation 3.
The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for the full disclosure of all forms of income and expenditure by registered parties.
Response

Agreed. The Government supports full disclosure of all forms of income and expenditure by political parties registered under the Act. The Bill contains the necessary amendments to enact the Committee's recommendation.
Recommendation 4.

Section 305 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so that during one disclosure period third parties are required to disclose income and expenditure which relates to any election and not just the election bounded by the current disclosure period.
Response
The Government accepts this recommendation and will present the necessary amendments in the Bill.
Recommendation 5.
The Australian Electoral Commission in all future reports on the operation of Part XX of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 publish its current listing of third parties.
Response
The Government accepts the recommendation. The necessary amendments are included in the Bill.
Recommendation 6.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for the full disclosure of all the income of and expenditure by third parties publicly listed by the Australian Electoral Commission in its reports on the operation of Part XX of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
Response

The Government accepts the need for third party disclosure of income and expenditure which relates directly to the electoral process. However, the recommendation would require disclosure of all income and expenditure whether related to the electoral activities of the third party or not. The resulting invasion of confidentiality and privacy cannot at this stage be justified. The Act will be amended to require disclosure by third parties of gifts made to political parties or auxiliaries thereof. The powers of the Electoral Commission to conduct spot upon third parties will be enhanced as discussed below per recommendation 7.
Recommendation 7.

The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide the Australian Electoral Commission with the power to conduct spot audits of third parties known or found to have a financial relationship with a registered political party.
Response

The Government accepts the recommendation that the Electoral Commission should be able to conduct spot audits of third parties who in the view of the Electoral Commission are or may be required to disclose electoral expenditure or party political gifts under the Act.
Recommendation 8.
The Broadcasting Act 1942 be amended so as to provide for a system of allocating free time for political broadcasting on television and radio for elections in Australia.
Response

The Government does not support the recommendation which discriminates in favour of existing and particularly major political parties represented in Parliaments or legislatures. The Bill will amend the Broadcasting Act to prohibit the broadcast of political advertisements, thereby achieving the Committee's objective of reducing election costs more equitably than as proposed by the Committee.
Recommendation 9.

An independent committee, such as the Party Political Broadcast Committee in the United Kingdom, be established and that it have responsibility for allocating free time to parties and candidates and the determination of time slots.
Response
This recommendation will not be relevant given the Government's response to recommendation 8 above.
Recommendation 10.
No minimum time period be set for political advertisements broadcast on radio and television.
Response
As per recommendation 9 above.
Recommendation 11.

The Broadcasting Act 1942 be amended to ensure that the policy launches of major parties be broadcast free of charge at reasonable times. The Australian Broadcasting Corporation campaign launch broadcast times should remain as presently allocated.
Response

The Bill provides that Broadcasters may broadcast one policy launch at the request of a political party during an election period. The broadcast must be free of charge. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be empowered to issue guidelines on the time at which a policy launch may be broadcast.Recommendation 12.

Section 116 of the Broadcasting Act 1942 be amended so as to remove responsibility for administrative arrangements for the electronic blackout from the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and place the responsibility on the licensees.
Response
This recommendation will not be relevant given the Government's response to recommendation 8.
Recommendation 13.

The Broadcasting Act 1942 be amended so as to provide for the official logo or name of the party or individual appearing for as minimum of 1 second at the conclusion of political advertisements, to be sufficient identification under the Act.
Response
This recommendation will not be relevant given the Government's response to recommendation 8.
Recommendation 14.
The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal should resume collection of statistics on total time of telecasts and broadcasts of political matter on television and radio stations during election periods.
Response
This recommendation will not be relevant given the Government's response to recommendation

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue before us has been canvassed ad nauseam over the past few days so I do not intend to speak at great length. It is worth noting that the Government's response comes two years after the event and, after the events of the last few days, it bears no relevance to the direction in which the Government is now going.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the debacle of this Government abusing the report entitled Who Pays the Piper Calls the Tune: Minimising the risks of funding political campaigns to attempt to ban at all times all advertising on radio and television. It has brought down a response when it knows that, somewhat reluctantly, some of our Democrat colleagues on the other side-and I am not referring to the one present, Senator Kernot-did not oppose this rather outrageous attempt to ban advertising in Australia and thus attack one of the basic elements of democracy, and that is, freedom of political expression.
I would like to refer to a couple of the responses of the Government. Recommendation No. 3 in the report states:
The Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended so as to provide for the full disclosure of all forms of income and expenditure by registered parties.

The Government agreed to that. Disclosure has been a fairly major issue. It was not canvassed at great length by me in the recent debate, but I thought I would touch on it today so that everyone knows exactly where we stand on this.

As we know, the so-called `ad ban' Bill-the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill 1991-has been referred to a select committee. There are two issues on disclosure that I and my Party are concerned about. The first is intimidation. That is the concern expressed most often by those in society who would like to support the Liberal Party of Australia, the National Party of Australia or even the Australian Democrats, simply because philosophically they agree with the Liberal and National Party policies and despise what the Australian Labor Party has done and continues to do to drag our great country to Third World status.

Everyone knows that if someone wants to intimidate another person or a group, all sorts of penalties can be and have been applied by both incumbent governments and trade unions throughout this country. It is worth the Senate reflecting on this very subject. Back in 1985, Senator Ray-who is now a Minister-in debate with former Senator Sheil subtly warned Lindsay Fox from the transport industry that he would be unwise to make a donation to the Liberal Party. I quote from that Hansard as follows:
He has a very large and efficient transport operation in this country which has relatively good relations with the unions.

The threat was there that if Lindsay Fox made a donation, and it was made public, his relationship with the trade union could be in jeopardy. I refer also to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune and a comment made there by former Senator Sir John Carrick:
It is a strong deterrent against private or corporate donation.
This is disclosure. To continue:

It provides a ready-made and published `hit list' available for punitive action by a mean-minded and vengeful government. President Nixon's socalled `enemies list' as revealed by the Watergate inquiry reveals the grave dangers of the corrupt use of the list of disclosed donations.

I point that out because, whilst we have said that we support completely full-blooded disclosure, we believe that it must protect anyone, whether an individual, a corporation or anyone else in society, who makes a donation to a party of their choice. I would sincerely hope that one of the things this Committee will look at is that area of intimidation because it is vital to the continued democracy of this country and the freedom of people to be able to make a contribution to people of their choice.

A second aspect of intimidation is the intimidation or coercion of individuals or companies, or even unions, to make donations. When it occurs I would call this unadulterated corruption. It is going on-right here and now. In the Cook inquiry in Queensland the Clerks Union officials were asked why, at a meeting with the Premier, Mr Goss, they, the Clerks Union officials, agreed to affiliate, at a cost of around $30,000 a year, with the Australian Labor Party. The response in the Cook report is interesting. The response was that it would enable the union to influence policy and have ready access to Ministers. The flip side, which was unsaid but clearly visible and transparent, was that without affiliation they could not influence policy or get access to Ministers. I make these points-and I am being bipartisan about the whole thing-because intimidation is very real.

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not sound very bipartisan to me.

—If the honourable senator looks at the Cook report he will see it in black and white. I will give him a copy of it, if he wishes. What has come out, for instance, of the Royal Commission into WA Inc. and the infamous gold lunch with the Prime Minister? A donation was required to ensure the Hawke Labor Government took a course of action in respect to the gold tax. In other words, a policy direction would be taken, not because it was necessarily right, but contingent upon a donation being made.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the fair and equitable element. This is important when we talk about disclosure and donations to political parties. If the Government is genuine about disclosure, let us ensure that donations are fair and equitable. The Labor Party is not the party of all Australians; it is the political arm of the power brokers and the trade union movement-not the workers, but the power brokers who determine whether an individual can earn a living or not. Hence the signs on construction sites all over the country, and at the waterfront, `No ticket no work'-and there are the Comcar drivers where there is a closed shop. The Transport Workers Union tells them, `You cannot cross the picket'. It does not have a meeting and it does not enable the drivers to have a meeting; it tells them. To work, a vast number of people must pay union dues-they have no choice. The dues are tax deductible. If a union decides to affiliate the amount of money is taken without reference to that worker who paid the dues, and it is then paid to the ALP.

Because of the difficulty of getting information on these affiliation fees, it is hard to come up with accurate figures. However, it can be conservatively estimated that the affiliation fees represent an annual contribution of around $5m a year. No wonder the Australian Workers Union chief in Queensland, Bill Ludwig, with that sort of muscle was able to tell Queensland members of parliament that, if they did not do what he wanted in the leadership tussle between Mr Hawke and Mr Keating, they would be politically dead. What would have been the reaction of the Labor Party and the media if an industry organisation, or the Australian Family Association, for instance, made the same threat to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, or to me as a coalition member? There would have been justifiable outrage. This, however, is only part of the story.

No-one would deny that unions in Australia today are big business. They get commissions on transactions, including compulsory union superannuation. They have investments; they own property. Some are so big in property investments that I understand there is a union in New South Wales which does not need any members. It is not commonly known that all income on union investments is free of income tax and free of capital gains tax. So if a union owned the casino at Wrest Point, for instance, its income would be tax free. If it sold a central business district building it would be free of capital gains tax, so a union is given special consideration. When any union then makes a donation to the Labor Party, it is income tax free money.

They are the sorts of questions which must be addressed. The question is: is that fair and equitable? That sort of tax free status is just not available to any other political party in Australia. It is quite clear that these two points I have raised have to be a major consideration in the Joint Standing Committee's review of the ad ban Bill, the Bill on political advertising. As I mentioned earlier, this has been canvassed ad nauseam.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—I notice, for instance, that many of the recommendations really are no longer valid because, even though the Democrats went to and fro a lot-certainly the Leader of the Australian Democrats in the Senate did-they have at long last been dragged, struggling and screaming, to the point where they will not accept--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kernot interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly at this stage, Senator Kernot, they are not supporting the ban on advertising-though I would not like to say that will be so tomorrow or next week-but they are prepared to support disclosure provided, I hope, it is fair and equitable and that the areas of intimidation are covered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to comment on the extraordinary fact that this Government response to this report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Who pays the piper calls the tune has taken two years. We are talking about a report printed in June 1989, and here we are in August 1991. It is always wise to ask in politics: why is this so? There are some really obvious reasons that we can look at. Certainly the funding of political campaigns is an incredibly topical subject. I wonder whether this Government response two years down the track has anything to do with the sorts of things which are in this 1989 report.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I notice is the ALP submission. Under the heading, `The Democratic Principle', the ALP says:
The Democratic Principle would provide that:
* a limit be set to the aggregate amount of advertising time which can be made available by each broadcaster for use by, and on behalf of, political parties.
It says:
* a formula be established for allocating advertising time, recognising the rights of parties represented in the parliament and of minority parties with a significant level of community support;

So it is not a ban, but a limit. The Committee considered a range of options to minimise the risks of funding political campaigns-options designed to break the nexus between the cost of political campaigns, the corresponding need for huge donations and the question of the political influence which may reside with such donations.

This Committee considered a wide range of options. A lot of these options have not been canvassed in this debate ad nauseam. These options included increasing the level of public funding to take account of the greater cost of election media advertisements, tax deductibility of political donations, imposing a ceiling on paid political advertising, imposing a complete ban on political advertising and providing free time for political advertising. The Committee report states:
While some viewers may support a complete ban on political advertising, it would have a direct affect on freedom of speech by reducing opportunities for discussion during election periods.

This Committee report, out of all the options that I just listed, opted for free time as the most suitable option for allowing parties to advertise their policies. Yet the Government, in its response today, does not accept this recommendation and has opted instead for the modified position of a ban on advertising during election campaigns. Again, we ask: why all the interest? Why this change of position?

I will refer to some of the comments made yesterday by Senator Powell. She said that the whole question of election funding has become a matter of concern in a range of countries recently for three basic reasons: firstly, a number of studies, especially in the United States, have shown that special interest contributions to political campaigns do influence legislative behaviour and results; secondly, the rapidly escalating costs of political advertising, particularly on the electronic media, have placed enormous and growing pressure on participants in elections to raise very large sums of money; and, thirdly, the number of scandals in several countries have shown that legislation giving favours to particular groups, businesses or even individuals can be traced to donations made during election campaigns.

We are seeing evidence of this in Australia in a range of royal commissions. The reports of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct in Queensland and the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales have expressed concern about the dangers of political corruption associated with the existing system of election fundraising and advertising.

A specific recommendation of this Committee report was that all political parties should be required to disclose all donations, gifts and income, and that the Australian Electoral Commission should be given power to conduct spot audits of political parties. The Government, in its response to this Committee report, has accepted both parts of that recommendation. I want to return to that a bit later.

I place on record yet again that since their inception the Australian Democrats have had a clear policy of support of full disclosure. People here would know that we have pursued that commitment with vigour. We believe not only that a requirement of full disclosure is correct in principle but also that the electorate is entitled to know the source of donations and it wants to have that information available to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very admirable, but how do you keep down the cost of campaigns?

—We made some suggestions about that, and I will turn to that later. I now refer to the submission the Australian Democrats made to this Committee. The Democrats have said that there should be a minimum period of three minutes of political advertising. We have heard-shock, horror-that three minutes will turn people off. Quite the contrary. We say that anything less than a three-minute block of advertising is not conducive to the dissemination of substantial policy information.

SPEECH.PARA: In our submission we argued that financial resources alone should not determine which political party, or which party's policies, attract the most media coverage. Political advertising, at least during Federal election campaigns, should be done on an equitable and informative basis. We have heard a lot about `equitable', but not a lot about `informative'. There is too much emphasis on the 30-second superficial grab. We also said-there has not been a lot of discussion about this-that television and radio stations are licensed by the Federal Government and, therefore, as public facilities they should provide a certain amount of free time for the purpose of political advertising. This should be made a condition of licences.

We said that all political advertising should be regulated so that the obligations that apply to companies with regard to truth and accuracy in advertising under the Trade Practices Act would also apply to political advertising under the Electoral Act. This has often been called the licence to lie. That is what we want to eliminate.

Our submission to this Committee concentrated on the nexus between political and economic power, on minimum timeframes, on informativeness and on truth in advertising. I think it is interesting to note what happens in overseas countries. The Committee noted that some form of free political broadcasting on networks exists in many Western democracies and that, at least in Western democracies, there is widespread regulation of political broadcasting.

It showed that out of the 19 countries for which data was obtained for this report, only two countries-Norway and the United States-do not provide some form of free party political broadcasts. Of the same 19 countries, only five countries-Australia, Canada, New Zealand, the United States and West Germany-allow paid political broadcasts. So the system that we are accustomed to in Australia is not the norm for Western democracies. Before we become hysterical about freedom of speech and its connection with democratic government, I think we should at least acknowledge the existence of systems in other countries which we would call democracies.

At this point I think it is important to look at the cost of political advertising, which is the reason that the Government was motivated to introduce its recent Bill. As the report mentions in its preface:

The rising cost of television advertising time has coincided with the growing use of that medium for political advertising. This has greatly increased the reliance of parties on corporate sponsorship. The Committee is concerned that heavy reliance by parties on such sponsorship risks the distortion of our open democratic system.
It goes on to say:

The electoral system should ensure that large financial sponsors, having paid the piper, do not also call the tune. The wider membership of political parties should not lose its influence within the respective parties.

If we look at what has been spent recently in Australia at election times, we note an extraordinary growth in expenditure. In 1984 the ALP spent $4.7m; in 1990 it had escalated to $14.6m. In 1984 the Liberal Party spent $4.8m; in 1990 it had escalated to $11.86m. In 1984 the National Party spent $2.73m; in 1990 it had escalated to $3.4m. In 1984 the Australian Democrats spent $0.47m; in 1990 it had escalated to $1.13m. Because we spend so much money and we need to raise so much money, the issue of where the money comes from is extremely important.

There are some important things said in this Committee report and in the Government response about the issue of disclosure. In the original Committee report the Committee said that there is some concern about the extent of parties avoiding the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act. When asked how many donations were being caught by the present disclosure provisions, the Electoral Commissioner replied that the AEC did not know. The Electoral Commissioner did not believe there were major abuses occurring, but he added:
There is the disquieting fact that the affairs that have become public knowledge, and that have led to further investigation by the police--
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about certain attitudes to the issue of full disclosure. I was referring to the comments of the Electoral Commissioner in the report Who pays the piper calls the tune. The Electoral Commissioner said that he did not believe that there were major abuses occurring. He added:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there is the disquieting fact that the affairs that have become public knowledge and that have led to further investigation by the police and to prosecutions and the like, have invariably come about not as a result of any natural interpretation of the evidence but as a result of some internal controversy within the organisation or between organisations that has caused somebody to dob someone in. This is slightly worrying. If they do not fall out, then we never get to know.

I guess a recent example that we could ponder is with whom did ALP Secretary Bob Hogg fall out? I think we could argue that maybe Mr Hogg made a genuine mistake in failing to disclose a large number of small donations. But in any case, I think the important point is that it did happen. It is not good enough for disclosure to rely--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think there is a matter before the courts in relation to this. Under those circumstances, you should be very careful about what you are saying.
—Mr Deputy President, I will just talk about the general principle that disclosure should not in any way rely upon the internal party politics of any political party.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I think it is interesting to note the views on full disclosure that the Liberal and National Party members of the Committee expressed in their dissenting report. If we look at what they said in this report, we can perhaps conclude that some members of the parliamentary Liberal Party have come a long way since then. They said that they find the recommendation on full disclosure to be offensive. They said that it is offensive for a party to disclose all of its income and expenditure. They go on to say:
This sort of detailed information about a political party could not be of interest or value to anybody, except perhaps the party's political opponents.

To that I say: indeed, who else would have a legitimate interest in the source of donations to a political party and the connection between donations and political and economic power. Of course, it is the people of Australia whose lives are affected by those political decisions. The submission went on to say:

The existing public funding provisions include an important safety valve which enables party supporters to give to the maintenance costs, as opposed to the campaign costs, of the party of their choice without fear of the inherently intimidatory aspects of the disclosure requirements.

We all know that there has been a great deal of interest in this particular loophole. I think we have seen in the time since this report was published that it is that very loophole which has been the vehicle through which major parties have failed to disclose important large donations.

The view expressed in this submission that this safety valve of non-disclosable maintenance donations should be preserved would, I believe, still be the view of the Liberal Party administration. So I think we have to ask the question: where do both the Government and the Opposition really stand on the matter of disclosure? To answer that, let me look at recent events.
The Government says that it supports full disclosure and, indeed, it says that in its response to recommendation 3, which states:
The Government supports full disclosure of all forms of income and expenditure by political parties registered under the Act.

The parliamentary Liberal Party says that it has reversed its previous opposition to full disclosure. It now supports the principle, but it wants to see amendments to deal with intimidatory aspects and equity in respect of donations by the trade union movement. I think it is true that the Liberal Party seems to have moved significantly since the publication of this report, but just yesterday both the Government and the Opposition failed to support the opportunity presented to them by the Democrats to implement this commitment.

I acknowledge the views expressed by the Opposition speakers that the Government's Political Broadcasting and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 does contain some defects, but not major ones in the disclosure clauses; and amending legislation is what we do here. But the Opposition had no amendments ready to propose. I think if those opposite were at all serious about full disclosure, they could have anticipated that at one stage of the Bill's passage they might have been asked to put forward their amendments. But they did not appear to have any amendments ready.

I ask: since when did the criterion of perfect legislation apply as a prerequisite for voting on clauses of any Bill? It has never applied as far as I know. Yesterday was a really disappointing and, indeed, almost shameful example of the lack of action-perhaps even the hypocrisy-of both the Government and the Opposition with regard to the matter of full disclosure. I hope the matter can be rectified. Both the Government and the Opposition have the opportunity to support the private member's Bill on disclosure which was introduced by Senator Powell yesterday.

I find it very difficult to accept the excuses for this failure to act yet again. It is the electronic advertising clauses of the Bill which are contentious, not the disclosure clauses-if one believes what Government and Opposition speakers have said in this debate. Yet because of their combined action, Australians are being asked to wait yet again to have access to the full information about who gives how much to which political parties. Only with full disclosure will we have the information from which to draw our own conclusions.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Health and Medical Research Council

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 May, on motion by Senator Herron:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 May this year, I spoke on this report, but since then two significant events have occurred. The National Health and Medical Research Council is the peak medical research body in Australia and was founded in 1936, together with the medical research endowment fund, from which money is appropriated for medical research in Australia. The Council is a type of sorting body for these funds and in 1990-91 over $95m has been appropriated for allocation around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Over all these years, the National Health and Medical Research Council has been an outstanding success in the way in which it approaches the dispensation of funds. However, the Council has some critics. It has 30 members, including representatives from each of the State health departments and, in addition, representatives of the Public Health Research and Development Committee and the Medical Research Ethics Committee; nominees of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, the Australian Council of Social Service and the Australian Academy of Science; and the First Assistant Secretary of Health Research and Services Division of the Department of Community Services and Health.

At the time I spoke, all 30 members were academics or bureaucrats; there were no practising medical practitioners or nurses. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, was approached in this regard and refused to include a nominee of either the Royal Australian Nursing Federation or the Australian Medical Association.

The Minister has subsequently recognised the validity of my statement and has appointed a nominee of the AMA to the National Health and Medical Research Council. However, other events have occurred which are not as beneficial. Since the review of the NHMRC, changes have occurred regarding the provision of ethical advice to the Council. The Medical Research Ethics Committee has been responsible for a series of guidelines dealing with many aspects of ethics in medical research and has been recognised and commended nationally and internationally for its contribution to the ethical debate. Following the review of the Council and its committees late in 1990 and the position of the National Bioethics Consultative Council and its advice to Ministers, it was decided that the Medical Research Ethics Committee should be incorporated into the National Bioethics Consultative Council.

The Australian Health Ethics Committee will have a broader focus than medical research ethics. This expanded role for the Committee was supported by the Medical Research Ethics Committee, following an increase in the number of requests for ethical advice and decisions on clinical or public health issues. The new Committee will be chaired by Ms Robyn Layton. The composition and membership closely resemble that of the former National Bioethics Consultative Council. Only one member of the MREC, Professor Ross Kalucy, the former MREC Chairman, has been appointed to the new body. Most members of the MREC are disappointed that the work of the Committee may not continue and that their involvement has ceased. Members are concerned that the very important role of the MREC-to advise, support and review the international ethics committee system-will not be a high priority for the Australian Health Ethics Committee and that the unique system of institutional ethics committees will be damaged. It is the view of the ex-members that the research expertise should have been maintained.

There is now no place for lay persons, and thus the membership does not mirror that required of IECs according to the National Health and Medical Research Council supplementary note 1 of the statement on human experimentation. It is obvious from the composition of this Committee that the ethical debate has been hijacked and that the focus of the National Health and Medical Research Council has shifted radically from its role as the peak body in the allocation of funds for medical research.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report of the Australian Agricultural Council is for the meeting which was held in Nelson, New Zealand, in February this year. The meeting occurred at a time when the Australian rural sector was facing a very pessimistic future. In fact, the outlook continues to be bleak, with this week's news that an industry which is already facing considerable hardship-the wheat industry-is being knocked by the sale of Saudi Arabian wheat to our trans-Tasman neighbour, New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: I noted that in the Ministers' policy session a number of major industry crises were considered. These included the wool industry, the current agricultural scene and policy settings, Australian agricultural and related trade policies post-GATT round, sustainable development, drought policy and research policy. It would have been interesting to have been an observer at the meeting.

I have already made what seems to me in only the past number of years many speeches on each of these subjects as they have become more and more critical not only in terms of our national financial welfare but also because they involve the disintegration of a lifestyle and society which has served Australia well in the past. I believe that if we fail any-and I reiterate the word `any'-of our rural industries now, we will possibly see the disintegration of rural Australian society as many of us have known it.

When the Ministers were discussing the current rural crisis, there was much talk about the highly contentious consequences of a national heavy vehicle regulatory and road charging system proposed by the Inter-State Commission. I noted that page 1 of the report states that the Australian Agricultural Council agreed that a submission would be made to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the effect that the Council believes that any national heavy vehicle regulatory and road user charging system should take full account of the legitimate economic and social interests of the remote areas of Australia. I do trust that the Prime Minister did take note of that resolution, though evidence to date has not been indicative of this.

It is distressing to note that the profound shift in Australia's export earnings from farm products to other economic sectors has left primary producers with shrinking incomes. These changes mean that we cannot afford simply to sit back and wait for the farm sector to be virtually depopulated. That really is what is starting to happen all over Australia. It is happening not only in the South Burnett where I come from but also in so many other rural areas. It is in the interests of everyone to control the process, to ameliorate its worst effects and to approach the whole issue with a balance of sympathy and energy.

The Government cannot claim that the rural crisis has only just hit. It has been warned continuously for years, and the evidence to show just what is happening outside our major cities has been around for some time. Similarly, it is not much use to so rationalise our rural sector that we eventually see the demise of the family farmer. This is what has happened in a number of our major industries, including the wool industry, which came under particular discussion at the meeting. The Ministers focused on what were at the time recent decisions concerning the pricing and marketing arrangements for wool which were outlined by the Commonwealth. It included details of projections of stock and financing costs under various scenarios. I do trust that not much attention was paid to those projections, as we all know how inaccurate they were. In fact, during the first half of this year, the Parliament frequently had to grapple with the continuing crisis in the wool industry and the failure of this Government to properly anticipate what would occur as a result of various pieces of its own legislation.

The issue of the GATT Round would obviously have led to a more generalised discussion of free trade and tariffs. This came under considerable spotlight in the Senate in June when we addressed the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. Many other matters were raised at this agricultural Ministers council, but I do believe that as we think about the problems in the rural industry, some of which I have been speaking about, we want to remember that the Prime Minister promised in his rural policy speech in Griffith in 1983:
I make an unqualified commitment to maintaining the viability of Australia's great rural sector and the provincial infrastructure.

I regret to say that the Federal Labor Government has not lived up to this commitment. Effectively, it has stripped away from Australian agriculture those measures which shielded it from the corrupt practices of the international market. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
