DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Independent Review of Asbestos in Defence

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 June, on motion by Senator Durack:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight to the Government's response on the report entitled Independent Review of Asbestos in Defence. I am glad to see that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) is present in the chamber tonight. The report of the independent review, completed by Mr Enfield, on the use of asbestos in the Department of Defence is an important contribution to the literature concerned with asbestos issues. As Mr Enfield notes in his report, asbestos and asbestos related illness are highly emotive topics. It is to his credit that he takes a professional, dispassionate approach in his review.

SPEECH.PARA: The report contains a number of important recommendations. These relate to issues such as training and instruction; the identification, labelling, enclosure, encapsulation and removal of asbestos; medical counselling; and improved processes for handling compensation claims. The Minister has accepted all these recommendations in principle. It is to be hoped that this in-principle acceptance translates into established practice. An extremely disturbing finding of the review was the observation by Mr Enfield that the Defence instructions on asbestos were inadequate. He pointed out:
There is a multitude of instructions in Defence relating to asbestos. In the course of my review I concluded that these instructions were inadequate . . .
He goes on to say:
The instructions seemed to me to reflect the concerns of the originators rather than the needs of users.

Mr Enfield, in light of these inadequacies, recommends that Defence instructions relating to asbestos be rationalised and revised and provides a number of suggestions on how this might be achieved in relation to both occupational and non-occupational exposure to asbestos.

The implementation of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act 1990 will help facilitate this. Importantly, Mr Enfield notes that an adequate level of funding will be needed to provide the necessary training, though he fails to say how much this will need to be. It is of some concern that these last recommendations, dealing essentially with defence policy, are necessary after 23 years of tardiness and inefficient and potentially life-threatening administrative practices. The Minister has indicated that the Department is addressing these administrative failures as a matter of high priority, and I welcome this. In a briefing I received from Mr Enfield in November of last year, it was foreshadowed that for those diagnosed as suffering from mesothelioma he would be looking to extend compensation to include counselling and psychological support as opposed to rehabilitation. I am pleased to see that this has emerged as a specific recommendation in his report.

Mr Enfield also advocates a humane approach from the Commonwealth in regard to the acceptance and rejection of mesothelioma claims. He argues that mesothelioma should continue to be specified as an occupational disease caused by exposure to asbestos, even if it means accepting claims where mesothelioma could have been caused by inhalation of airborne asbestos fibres outside the workplace. This is valid on both humane and expenditure grounds.

The Department of Veterans' Affairs has recently completed a review of the scientific literature relating to exposure to asbestos. At about this time last year, I asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs how many compensation claims had been made for asbestos related illness and was informed that as at 29 May 1990 there had been approximately 300, although for a variety of reasons that was likely to be understated. Approximately 65 per cent of claims considered were accepted, with over 30 per cent rejected. Significantly, at that time there were still nine outstanding appeals to the Veterans Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It is totally unacceptable that ex-servicemen having been diagnosed as suffering from mesothelioma or asbestosis find themselves, in the last months of their lives, fighting to convince the bureaucracy of the validity of their compensation claims. I hope that the Department will note carefully and adopt the humane approach advocated by Mr Enfield in relation to procedures for mesothelioma claims.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the set of guidelines set out by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, for the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, its councils and its committees on the performance of its functions. The paper sets out the guidelines as three sets of priorities, namely, economic priorities, social priorities and budget priorities. I will speak very briefly to the first two of these.

SPEECH.PARA: The economic priorities include guidelines which are at variance with the legislation which the Minister has attempted to rush through the Parliament. The guidelines state:
. . . the removal of unnecessary regulations and other impediments remains central to the Government's approach.

Yet before the winter recess we debated two Bills which attempted to over-regulate and create difficulties for the education industry. I am referring to the renamed Education Services (Export Regulations) Bill and the Training Guarantee (Administration Amendment) Bill.

The National Board of Employment, Education and Training is urged by the Minister to be mindful of certain economic priorities, namely, increasing participation in education and increasing opportunities for the upgrading of skills and retraining. Perhaps this augurs well for the future, but the Senate inquiry into adult and community education has found that there are huge problems related to re-entry into education and training courses, that there is insufficient expenditure on migrant education, and that there is a deplorable lack of literacy in this country which is an indictment on the whole education system.

The Board is also urged to be mindful of improving the efficiency, effectiveness and flexibility of education and training, including that offered by private providers. Yet the Minister has created a national unified system for training and so, far from allowing training to be flexible, his legislation confines it within the range of a very narrow definition.

The Board is also urged to help reduce institutional barriers between different education and training systems. Again, I feel that this is a pious hope rather than a reality. The reality is that there is very poor articulation between different courses, let alone between different institutions.

Under `Social Priorities', the Minister states that the Government's fundamental objective is to develop a fair, more prosperous and just society. A key element of his just society is a fair and equal access to essential services, such as education. Yet the Senate inquiry into adult and community education showed that there are still impenetrable barriers to education for some people, such as distance, gender, ethnicity, language and ability.

The Minister reminds the Board that the Government has substantially expanded the number of higher education places. So it has: with disastrous results. The Government has expanded the number of places, but without additional resources, with the result that universities are bulging at the seams. There may be more students at universities but, without increased staff and additional facilities, student overcrowding is currently damaging morale and creating an intolerable situation in higher education.

The Board is reminded of a particular priority for the Government in ensuring income support arrangements for young people in education, but the recent debate on the Student Assistance Amendment Bill in the Senate gives the lie to this, and students are finding it more and more difficult to get assistance to further pursue their studies. The Minister reminds the Board of the Government's priority to improve literacy in this country, but we are way behind. There are not enough resources to increase literacy. Finally, under `Social Priorities', the Minister urges the Board to facilitate re-entry into the work force, but this is a real problem when there are no jobs.

I want to make two final comments in relation to this document. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) urges Australia to become the `clever country', but his Minister for Employment, Education and Training has not one word in this document about the encouragement of gifted children. Much of this document refers to young people and new programs and assistance for those who are unemployed. It is a sad situation when a government has to devise guidelines for a national board to cater for massively high unemployment rates. One-third of our young people are out of work and the plans outlined in this document do very little to help them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 August, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Police Ministers Council's report on national common police services for 1989-90 reports on basically three components: the National Police Research Unit, the Australian Police Staff College and the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. I wish to briefly address the work of the National Police Research Unit, as reported, and comment on a number of matters that are not covered in the activities of that research unit.

SPEECH.PARA: The record of the work of that unit is impressive. In the review of activities, we read that major research is progressing on a national strategic crime trend forecasting facility, on armed robbery, on vulnerability of the aged to criminal exploitation, on violent criminal apprehension programs, on electronic surveillance, and so on.

What I find lacking in this document is any attention being given to our prison facilities throughout Australia. There is an obvious reason for that: clearly they are a State responsibility and it seems that the activities reported in this document have a national focus. However, the Australian Police Ministers Council is composed of police Ministers who have State responsibilities-they are State police Ministers. I believe it is time that this Parliament addresses itself to the question of how our prisons are administered, what they do to the people who are inmates of them and what happens when these people leave our prison system.

I speak with some degree of personal experience since my son, a community worker, at one stage was in charge of a halfway house for ex-prisoners from Boggo Road gaol in Brisbane. I visited him twice and my experience-and his-adds up to the view that a system that can do what we are doing to human beings in our prisoners is a rotten system.

I know it is difficult to create a national strategy and to bring measures into being on a national basis when the specific responsibilities are at State level; however, there are precedents where the national Government decides on a general policy, sets standards and provides grants on a tied basis. I believe the time has come to look at a strategy of that type.

In pursuance of that view I have included in this year's Democrat alternative budget proposals a number of items for prison reform in the portfolio of the Attorney-General. In the first instance the Democrats believe that the problem-and it is a problem-starts with the attitude, the level of education and the professional capacity of prison officers. It is time to ensure that prison officers are provided with the education and training they require to be able to change their attitude to the task they face in rehabilitating prisoners, not in just detaining them.

I believe we need to review the existing curricula of the training courses for prison officers and establish new courses with the aim of substantially upgrading threshold qualifications for their employment. Those officers who are not prepared to take part need to be given redundancy packages. We need capital expenditure to improve prison facilities; we need increased funding for vocational training and general education of prisoners and we need a transition program, including counselling, to assist them in coping with current conditions `outside' and in finding employment, housing, social contacts and so on.

Recently a program was started in Victoria by Fabian Dattner which was called Second Chance. Fabian Dattner approached employers asking them to employ prisoners who leave our institutions to give them a second chance. I fear that program has now come to an end. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advances to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I wish to speak to Government document No. 28, Advances to the Minister for Finance-Supporting Applications of Issues, June 1991. In particular, I want to deal with the child-care fee relief element of the document which involves an additional requirement of $422,792 for the Department of Community Services and Health. This, on top of the original appropriation plus extra funds of $2.8m from the Advance to the Minister for Finance already, brings the total expenditure on this project to something like $136m.

These additional funds are required because they relate to the approval of additional new places and more eligible fee relief users commencing with approved services. Apparently, based on commercial services it was decided that there should be 33,000 places originally costed in the Budget and approximately 36,700 are now being taken up, and as well there are other demands on the services in the non-commercial user end. What intrigues me about this additional funding requirement is that it points to the impact of the recession on the Government's budget and on the Budget to be brought down next Tuesday. The supporting documents asking for this extra $422,000 in June say:
There is evidence that the above factors are outcomes of the recession.
That is, the increase in demand for funding for child-care places. It continues:
The trend of reduced incomes of families using child care and the increased utilisation of family day care could be direct effects of recession.

This is the Government's own department talking; it is not the Opposition being a carping critic. It is the Government's own department explaining why it has to keep going back to the taxpayer for more and more money to cope with the consequences of the recession that this Government proudly states it engineered. The documents go on:

Labour market figures demonstrate that workers are losing overtime and the rate of part-time employment is increasing. These changing work patterns mean reduced family income through loss of overtime or hours of employment, but often without a corresponding reduction in hours of child care needed. As the Fee Relief entitlement is dependent on family income, that is, entitlement is higher for lower levels of income, a fall in family income will result in higher Fee Relief payments by the Commonwealth.

That is exactly what is happening now. It is one of those continuing and broadening consequences of economic incompetence, and it will either be seen next Tuesday night in a substantial increase in required government spending to meet these programs of assistance or be met by cuts in assistance. It will be interesting to find out which of these two options the Government follows. All we know is that there is already evidence of substantially mounting demand for the services that the Government must fund under its present programs to assist those people who are, it appears, very vulnerable to the consequences of the Government's own incompetence.

This is only one of the many programs-I pointed some out yesterday when this matter was before the chamber-that now require, because of the massive increases in demand, substantial financial support if they are to continue. Austudy required in the month of June alone an extra $53m in the Advance to the Minister for Finance to meet its requirements. Austudy is used to provide funding for young people who would otherwise be joining the dole queues. The number of people who have disappeared out of the labour force figures and have been funded by Austudy to go back to school to a large extent indicates something like a 44 per cent youth unemployment rate-that is, taking into account people who would otherwise be looking unsuccessfully for full time work. As it is, the unemployment rate for young people under 20 looking for full time work is a horrendous 28.5 per cent, certainly far worse than in the recession of 1982-83.

I finish on the note of funding pressures that emerge from recession. The national income figures today clearly reveal how different this recession is from the 1982-83 recession. The national income figures reveal that it was a fall in farm incomes that pushed down the economy in 1982-83, whereas this time farm incomes have actually been increasing over the period of the recession while the rest of the economy has collapsed. Those national income figures today certainly show how dramatic and dangerous the level of economic activity is now in Australia and how severe the fall has been-a fall generated by the Government as against the drought pushed and world stimulated recession of 1982-83, which the Government continually points to.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the 31 July 1991 attack on a Lithuanian border post and the killings of seven border guards during that attack and calls upon the Government of the Soviet Union to vigorously investigate this incident and prosecute those responsible for these deaths;

(b) regrets that Soviet troops remain in occupation of important installations in the Baltic States, including the Vilnius television station seized by force in January 1991, and urges that these troops be withdrawn;

(c) calls upon the Soviet Government to accept the rights of the Baltic States to independence and to constructively negotiate a new relationship with the Baltic States as individual sovereign nations; and
(d) urges the Australian Government to support Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in their continuing quest to regain their freedom and independence.

I raise again the issue of the Baltic states because I think it is important for this Parliament to demonstrate support for Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in their continuing struggle for freedom and independence. Regrettably, as we have outlined in the terms of this motion, since the Senate last met they have experienced once again the tragedy of violence. The violence, unfortunately, follows a continuing pattern.

In this instance, it was on 31 July that a Lithuanian border post was attacked and seven border guards and police were killed. Although the attackers are unknown, the Lithuanians have accused the internal security force, Omon-or the black berets-of being responsible. President Gorbachev has said that he regretted the killings and has promised that they will be investigated. But, as I said, the attacks are part of an ongoing struggle between Soviet authorities and each of the three Baltic states over the border posts. A number of posts have been forcibly dismantled by Soviet forces over the last six months.

When we last debated the situation of the Baltic states in their struggle for freedom, we made reference to the 13 unarmed Lithuanians who were killed when opposing the illegal seizure of the television station. Later, five people were killed, again when the special police unit, Omon, otherwise known as the black berets, stormed the headquarters of the Latvian interior ministry. There is no doubt that these actions are designed to terrorise the peoples of the three states and to force them back into submission. The black berets have repeatedly carried out attacks on border posts in each of the three republics, and tonight I have detailed only some of the killings that have occurred.

In June, Soviet troops again set up check points in Vilnius and were arresting people. It is no coincidence that these check points tend to be concentrated around the centre of democracy in Vilnius, that is, the Lithuanian parliament building. In the earlier instance, the Soviet Government attempted to avoid responsibility for these events. The Soviet prosecutor, for instance, attempted to blame the Lithuanians themselves for the deaths in Vilnius, a view which was flatly contradicted by credible eyewitness accounts of those events.

In other statements, the Soviet Government suggested that its troops were acting on their own initiative. The Soviet Government, and in particular the President of the Soviet Union, must take responsibility for the actions of Soviet troops. It is an inadequate excuse to claim that when armed forces terrorise people they are acting on their own initiative. When President Gorbachev received the Nobel Prize he claimed that world peace depended on the success of perestroika and, therefore, the West must support his program. He argued that perestroika could be successful only under a strong central leadership.

President Gorbachev must understand that he cannot hope to establish a stronger system without making it more just. A fair and just state cannot be built on the denial of the rightful independence of the Baltic peoples or of the desires of the peoples of the Soviet Union. What should the West generally and Australia, in particular, be doing to help the Baltic peoples in their continuing quest for freedom?

It seems to me that Australia could be doing a lot that it is not presently doing. One issue is the provision of aid to the Soviet Union. We know that President Gorbachev has been seeking significant aid from the West. It is the opinion of those on this side of the chamber that the West should not provide aid for any program designed simply to strengthen the Soviet state without fundamental democratic reform. In our opinion no true peace can be built on the basis of a stronger Soviet state which continues to deny its various peoples their fundamental rights.

Australia has some influence through the newly established bank-the European Bank for Reconstruction, I think it is called. We are yet to hear from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) as to what is Australia's position in relation to foreign aid to the Soviet Union whilst it does not permit the basic reforms that are necessary to allow freedom for its own people. As I understand that the Minister is not participating, perhaps his spokesman in this debate will let us know the Australian Government's position on that particular issue.

The US Secretary of State, James Baker, recently made clear that aid for the Soviet Union would not be forthcoming unless, among other things, the aspirations of the Baltic peoples for independence were peacefully resolved. In early June the British Prime Minister, Mr Major, also affirmed that Western aid for the Soviet Union would depend on a recognition of the human rights and an acceptance of the right of self-determination of the peoples of the Baltic states. There is a precedent being set by other Western nations. We on this side of the chamber want to know the position of the Australian Government and we would urge that it not be party to aid to the Soviet Union whilst the Soviet Union opposes freedom for the Baltic peoples.

As we know, compared with some issues, the voice of the Australian Government on this issue of fundamental freedom has really been quite muted. Following Lithuania's declaration reaffirming its independence, the Government issued a statement acknowledging the resolution and calling for negotiations. Later, after the unprovoked killings in Vilnius and Riga, the Government issued a statement urging:
The many complex legal, political and economic issues involved . . . not be resolved at the expense of the progress thus far achieved in the area of human rights and democratic reforms.
That is a very soft statement in view of the violence that was being exerted upon the Baltic peoples.

I simply draw to the Government's attention for its consideration the fact that these mild statements contrast poorly with the Government's sentiments on questions such as political reform in South Africa-an issue upon which Australia has been outspoken.

For some time the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) was even reluctant to use the word independence in relation to the Baltic states. I hope that attitude has now passed and that his spokesman in this debate will make it absolutely clear that, in the view of the Australian Government, the Baltic peoples are entitled to their independence and that they should have it now, not later. The issues of stability in the Soviet Union and so forth will not be advanced by going soft on the issue of independence for the Baltic peoples.

I should make it clear that this attitude expressed by the Australian Government is in contrast with the view that we have vigorously maintained. I will quote the words of my own leader on this subject, Dr Hewson. He made his position absolutely clear in a recent media release when he said that the Government:

should take a lead in strongly pressing the Soviet Union, both in its own right and in conjunction with other governments, as well as in the United Nations and other appropriate international forums, to end its illegal occupation of the Baltic states and restore their legitimate independence and sovereignty.

The Opposition believes that the Government can take a number of other steps in support of independence for the Baltic states. It can actively pursue this issue in the United Nations General Assembly and in the United Nations Human Rights Commission because the Soviet Union is clearly in breach of very fundamental human rights in its behaviour in relation to the Baltic peoples. This would give maximum publicity to the rights of the peoples of the Baltic states and considerably increase pressure upon the Soviet Union.

The Australian Government can and should direct its embassy in Moscow to increase substantially its direct contact with officials of the Baltic republics. This will both underline Australia's view that these officials are legitimately elected representatives of their nations and send a message to the Soviet Government. This course of action has already been pursued by a number of other Western governments.

For example, during his visit to the Soviet Union earlier this year, John Major made a point of meeting with some of the elected leaders of the Baltic republics. On a lower level, Canadian and American diplomats were sent to the Baltic states to observe the referendums there and have been active in reporting on Soviet attempts to intimidate the elected governments. The Australian Government could be initiating similar action but to date it has not. I would invite it to do so.

The Australian Government could also help by inviting government spokespersons from the Baltic states to enable them to present their case to the Australian people. As we know, the Hawke Government has been quite generous in providing this sort of support to groups struggling for self-determination in the Pacific and in South Africa. Why not apply it also to those struggling for freedom in the Baltic region? Unlike many of the figures that the Government has previously invited, the representatives of the Baltic republics have at least been chosen democratically.

A further possibility that should be explored by the Government is the awarding of training scholarships to the three republics. Training courses can provide valuable assistance for states struggling to establish functioning democratic administrations after 50 years of crushing bureaucratic rule. Australia has provided this assistance to other states which are coming out of periods of oppression or which have not had the opportunity to develop democratic institutions. If we are prepared to offer such assistance to others, why not also to the Baltic states? I draw that suggestion to the attention of the Government.

The Government could also contribute to the establishment of the economic independence of the Baltic states by further fostering trade ties, something that the Government's spokespeople have put to it. There is no better way in which the democratic institutions of the Baltic states can be supported than by developing their economies and their independence from the Soviet Union.

In this brief contribution, I have attempted to set out a number of initiatives that the Australian Government could take in support of these people if it were really prepared to act rather than simply mouth reasonable sounding sentiments from time to time. These people need action in support of their fledgling democracies, in support of their quest for freedom and independence, not just simply rhetoric. I raise this issue again because these people need Australia's support and the support of the whole free world.

It is important that we note and deplore the violence that is continuing as these people go forth in their quest for freedom. It is even more important that we look for ways in which we can constructively support them in their very reasonable aspirations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has put before the Senate this evening. A great many of the remarks that he has made will enjoy very broad support around the chamber, including from the Government side. I will take issue with one or two points which he made in the course of his contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: We are witnessing an utter tragedy in the Baltic states at the moment. That is recognised not only here in Australia but also by international opinion. It is not possible, of course, to look at the Baltic republics without looking at the history of Europe over the past half century. I refer in particular to the infamous Ribbentrop-Molotov pact of 1939 in which Nazi Germany and Soviet Russia divided eastern Europe between the two dictatorships. That effectively meant the destruction of Poland and the illegal incorporation by the USSR of the three Baltic states within its borders, and a war between the USSR and Finland.

The situation in the Baltic republics of violence, contrived disorder, intimidation and tension cannot be divorced from the current situation in the Soviet Union overall. At this point I make specific mention of negotiations towards the conclusion of a new Union treaty. Amongst the various republics that currently make up the USSR, all three Baltic republics have indicated to date that they are not prepared to sign the new Union treaty. Negotiations are under way on the basis of a new political and economic relationship.

With all that perestroika has brought in terms of reductions in international tensions and all the opportunities it has brought for the betterment of mankind, within the Soviet Union itself grave problems have arisen. This is recognised by people in Moscow as much as it is recognised beyond the borders of the Soviet state.

The nationalities question has arisen within the USSR in any number of regions. There have been declarations of independence in republics as different as the Baltic states and Georgia. That has resulted in a certain fragmentation within the USSR, and accordingly there have been great tensions within that country.

There is no doubt in my mind that the nationalism that has been expressed in the Baltic states ought to be regarded as entirely legitimate. There is no question about the degree of popular support for independence movements in those countries. There is no doubt about the degree of popular support for the economic nationalism that is being expressed, for people to be able to determine their own economic future as well as their own political form of government. There is no doubt either that, overwhelmingly, efforts have been directed at a peaceful transition from a circumstance where the republics have been integral parts of the USSR to a circumstance where they can regain their independence, that short-lived state that existed prior to the onset of the Second World War. There is no doubt also that they have elected representative parliaments broadly reflecting opinion in the three states.

Here I take issue with Senator Hill, although I say again that I can agree without hesitation to much of his contribution this evening. I turn to the position of the Australian Government, which was perhaps best outlined by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, in the Parliament on 9 May 1990 in answer to a question from my colleague Senator Colston. Senator Colston referred to the declarations of independence by the Baltic states of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, asking:
Would the Minister outline what the Australian Government's position is in relation to those declarations?
Senator Evans replied:

Australia has already recognised for many years the legal right of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia to exist as independent states. Like many other Western governments, we have refused to accept in international law their incorporation into the Soviet Union in 1940 rejecting the self-proclaimed Soviet sovereignty over them. The Government believes that the recent declarations of independence by their freely elected Parliaments do reflect the aspirations of the Baltic peoples to achieve economic and political independence through peaceful and democratic means. Equally, we do fully appreciate that it is the unprecedented process of reform in the Soviet Union which has made it possible for the newly elected Baltic parliaments to express these aspirations. We urge-I take this opportunity to do so again-the Soviet Government to respect those declarations and to refrain from actions inimical to the interests of the parties concerned.

I might add that there could not be a clearer expression of opinion on the part of the Government in relation to the independence declarations of the three Baltic states or a clearer expression of view for the Soviet Government as to the nature of the position taken by the Australian Government on this important matter.

The history of the Baltic states of recent times has been that they were caught in a terrible tide of war between fascism and Stalinism. It was a history of tragedy during the 1940s under the occupation forces of the Nazis; a history of suffering. There were very brave partisan movements formed which fought against the Nazis. It was a period of repression. That repression followed hard upon the heels of a period of very real suffering at the hands of the Soviet authorities under Joseph Stalin. I point out that, only a week before the outbreak of the Second World War on the eastern front, only a week before Operation Barbarossa began on 22 June 1941-to be specific, on 14 June 1941-widespread deportations commenced in the three Baltic states which resulted in some 600,000 deaths of people from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. It was a terribly tragic period.

Senator Hill has made reference to the Soviet security forces. I agree with his assessment of the nature of the attacks being made by the black beret forces, the Omon forces. It is also instructive to note that the Soviet Government has deployed paratroops in some parts of the Baltic states. The Soviet paratroops are the most ideologically aligned forces in the Soviet military; they are also elite forces. It seems strange that in a circumstance such as this the Interior Ministry troops were not those dispatched to maintain order.

There is no doubt at the moment that Defence Minister Yazov is loyal to the President of the Soviet Union, Mr Gorbachev, but given some of the remarks which have been made in the Congress of People's Deputies by those who are aligned with the Soyuz group, with the military group in the Soviet Parliament-and I refer particularly to Colonel Alksnis and Colonel Petrushenko-there is a real danger of certain elements of the Soviet military getting out of control. Colonel Petrushenko, of course, is most famous for telling the New York Times in the earlier part of this year that a military coup in the Soviet Union would be totally unnecessary because eventually the politicians would simply hand over power to the army. That was a truly chilling statement.

The challenge of perestroika for the international community has been met on a number of counts and in a number of political circumstances in terms of reduction of tensions, in terms of opening doors to greater economic cooperation and in terms of negotiations on arms control. As I said earlier, perestroika brings with it certain dangers in regard to the Baltic states and also in regard to Yugoslavia, about which I will say a little more later this evening.

The real test of perestroika now is achieving the successful conclusion of a new treaty on matters affecting the Soviet Union with the republics of the USSR, and enabling the Baltic states to determine their own political and economic destiny, free of interference, intimidation and the kind of attacks that we have seen recently on the border posts. President Gorbachev has said that the matters will be investigated. He has promised that no less a body than the KGB will investigate these matters. That is a real test for the Soviet security services. The people concerned with this violence must be brought to book; they must be brought to account.

The Soviet leadership talks about changing the country from a situation of unfettered central authority to a circumstance where the rule of law prevails. A very good place to start would be in the Baltic republics. That is a challenge which faces the Soviet authorities tonight, as it is a challenge which faces our Parliament in terms of an appropriate Australian response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The killing of seven Lithuanian border guards on 31 July this year certainly represents a disturbing development in the Soviet Union; we believe that the Soviet Union's handling of this appalling incident deserves to be condemned. One of the most remarkable features of this border incident was that it took place on the eve of the visit to the Soviet Union by the President of the United States to discuss aid and a number of other issues of international significance. This highlights what little regard those who murdered the seven Lithuanian guards have for international opinion in relation to independence for the Baltic states.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that we in the Australian Democrats remain a little disappointed that during his visit to the Soviet Union Mr Bush failed to press the Soviet Government on the matter of the killings. According to some of the media reports on the visit, the President of the United States was far more concerned not to raise any matter which would stand in the way of a strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union or, indeed, any issue at all that might cause his Soviet hosts some discomfort. Remarkably, at one point during his visit Mr Bush went so far as to advise the independently minded republic of the Ukraine to also desist from any efforts aimed at achieving independence.

The Australian Democrats believe that all democratic nations should provide strong support to the peoples of the Baltic states. After all, it is they who in their long and determined struggle for independence have suffered so much in the last 50 years and who, by these recent murders, continue to endure an unacceptable level of grief. We believe that this Parliament has a moral responsibility to share with the Lithuanian people the grief which they are currently suffering and to do all in our capacity to help them to achieve their goals.

As honourable senators will undoubtedly recall, the Lithuanian, Latvian and Estonian people all expressed their unequivocal support for independence when referendums were held in all three states in February and March of this year. The referendum results in these republics revealed an overwhelming desire by the Baltic peoples to achieve the independence which is rightfully theirs.

In the Lithuanian republic, for instance, more than 90 per cent of the population voted for independence, which means that a significant proportion of the non-Lithuanian population of that republic also supports the idea of an independent Baltic state. The Soviet authorities initially claimed that the Russian minority in the Baltic states feels persecuted and needs to be defended by Russian troops against the nationalists who are now in control. Clearly, this is not the case. More recently, the Soviet authorities have enforced economic sanctions against Lithuania in particular and, as the Senate is aware, the Soviet military has also been sent in and now occupies key installations around the breakaway republic, such as the television station in the capital, Vilnius.

The latest threat being carried out by the Soviet authorities is in connection with the draft union treaty which the Soviet President has drawn up and which all Soviet republics have been asked to sign. We understand that six of the Soviet republics have so far refused to sign the treaty-Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia as well as Armenia, Georgia and Moldavia. All six of these states face the threat of stiff economic sanctions if they do not sign the draft treaty. Such threats are totally unacceptable. We condemn the Soviet Union's dogmatic stance in dealing with independently minded republics.

We believe it is more than appropriate that the Australian Parliament and our Government call upon the Soviet Union, in the strongest terms possible, to respect the rights of the Baltic states-this is particularly important as it reflects the wishes of the Baltic peoples, as expressed in their elections-and to finally and totally acknowledge the independence that rightfully belongs to the Baltic states. We must recognise here again that the Baltic states are seeking to do no more than to restore their own independence.

Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania have all been illegally suppressed for more than 50 years in a union which has never been sanctioned by the peoples of these three tiny republics. As the Senate has been reminded today, the three Baltic states were never asked for their opinions on unification. It was forced upon them against their wishes by the notorious Molotov-Ribbentrop pact of 1939.

Remarkably, the Soviet Union's own congress of people's deputies has itself now recognised that the 1940 annexation of the Baltic republics was illegal and invalid. In this context, we believe that the Australian Government should be using every available opportunity to provide strong support to the Baltic republics and to call upon the Soviet Government to recognise their independence. Iceland has done so, and the Government of Denmark has recently exchanged letters of recognition with the Lithuanian Government. The Baltic republics have a right to independence. They have expressed their desire for it and we, as representatives of the Australian people, should show our solidarity with their cause. The Australian Democrats commend Senator Hill for moving his motion and we will be supporting it tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion moved by Senator Hill is one which will attract unanimous support in this chamber although, to my way of thinking, it does not go far enough. Originally, the motion was a proposal which focused on the killing of seven border guards on 31 July 1991. Obviously, the debate has ranged far broader than that, and it is not my intention tonight to canvass all of those matters that have been raised by my parliamentary colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: The first part of the motion reads:

That the Senate . . . condemns the 31 July 1991 attack on a Lithuanian border post and the killings of seven border guards during that attack and calls upon the Government of the Soviet Union to vigorously investigate this incident and prosecute those responsible for these deaths.
It appears, from the material that I have seen, that not only is the Soviet Union not vigorously investigating the incident, but it is also making excuses.

Let me deal with what was stated by the Soviet Union at the time. The Soviet Union denied that it was involved. The response to that by the Lithuanians was as follows-and I quote what President Landsbergis said about the official denials by the USSR Defence Ministry, the KGB and the Interior Ministry of involvement in the murder of the seven border guards at Medininkai. President Landsbergis said:
. . . since these departments-
that is to say, the Defence Ministry, the KGB and the Interior Ministry-

concealed the perpetrators of the murders of innocent victims in Vilnius in January of 1991, and intentionally circulated lies and disinformation, their present statement concerning Medininkai cannot be fully trusted.

I admire the Lithuanians for not overstating things. Here is President Landsbergis making the understatement that those departments `cannot be fully trusted'. Of course they cannot be fully trusted. Their record does not give one confidence to trust them.

Senator Bourne mentioned the apparent weakness of President Bush when he was in Moscow at the time of these killings. I, too, was concerned about that apparent weakness. It now appears that President Bush has tightened his approach. In a letter written to Prime Minister Vagnorius of Lithuania, President Bush makes it rather clear that he is linking these killings with the ones that occurred in January and also with the Soviet opposition to the legitimate aspirations of Lithuanians for their independence.
President Bush in responding to Prime Minister Vagnorius's letter of 31 July said that he was `appalled and sickened by this senseless act of violence'. He also said:
Actions of this kind can only set back the process of peaceful dialogue that is the only viable avenue toward fulfilling the legitimate aspirations of the Lithuanian people.
After he conveyed sympathy, he said this:

Soviet authorities-including President Gorbachev-have expressed their commitment to assisting the Lithuanian Government in investigating this crime and bringing the perpetrators to justice. As I have said previously, a situation has been created in the Baltic states that itself leads to violence, and that situation must be changed. We will continue to press the Soviet Government to exercise control over the actions of its forces in the Baltic states and to make clear our belief that Moscow is ultimately responsible for acts committed by its personnel.

That seems to be at least a belated change on the part of the President. But clearly more is required. Before I get to what I mean by that, I make the point that the Lithuanian Government commission of inquiry, which was appointed in the aftermath of the killings, asserted in a public statement on 8 August that:

. . . representatives of the USSR Procuracy and the USSR Internal Affairs Ministry do not provide any concrete aid to the law enforcement institutions of the Republic of Lithuania, do not fulfil many assignments, and hamper and disrupt the investigation.

This motion is asking that the Soviet Union vigorously investigate this incident and prosecute those responsible for the deaths. It is apparent that up until now the Soviet Union has not been doing that and, indeed, according to the commission that was established by the Lithuanians themselves, certain arms of the Soviet Government are hampering and disrupting the investigation. That is unfortunate because everyone in this chamber desires a peaceful situation which would enable the legitimate aspirations of the Baltic states and those of the people of Russia to be recognised and allowed to flower so that peace, security and development can proceed.

The question is: how can we in Australia and nations with whom we have close relationships assist in this process? Honourable senators who spoke prior to me gave some examples of how this can be done. We know that the Soviet Union needs technology transfers, money and assistance in order to develop and overcome the problems that have been caused by the imposition of the communist state. Clearly, a message should be given to the Soviet Union.

But more than that, I believe the one thing that will truly show the Soviet Union that we are fair dinkum is to give diplomatic recognition to the states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia and nominate an ambassador to those countries. If we took the lead and did that and if others then followed, clearly that would be an undeniable message that the process of democratic reform in these countries is irreversible-that the process of true freedom in these countries is irreversible.
I remind the Senate that this year I moved a notice of motion which calls upon the Senate to note:
(i) that 50 years ago whilst the West was preoccupied with dictator Adolf Hitler, the Soviet Army invaded Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia,

(ii) that last year, after years of Soviet imposed terror, forced exile and gross violation of human rights, the seven million people in these countries freely elected their own governments and parliaments, and
(iii) that today, whilst the West is preoccupied with dictator Saddam Hussein, the Soviet Army is again attempting to subjugate the Baltic States;
(b) ongratulates the people of the Baltic States for their courageous stand for democracy and human rights and the restoration of their national independence;
(c) calls on the Australian Government to:
(i) immediately recognise and establish diplomatic relations with the new, democratically elected Governments of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia and nominate an ambassador to those countries,
(ii) strongly condemn the recent atrocities perpetrated against the Baltic States for their stand for democracy, human rights and self-determination,
(iii) demand that all Soviet troops and the KGB be immediately withdrawn from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, and
(iv) take a leading role with other democratic nations to provide practical assistance to the peoples of the Baltic States and to raise their right to self-determination at the United Nations.

It is my view that we must act urgently, that the Federal Government must take action. It has gone some way, but it must start taking the initiative. It appears that it has not gone beyond what other nations with whom we have close trading and other relationships have done. We are not necessarily tied to what these other Western nations do.

In view of what has occurred in the Baltic states, and in view of the responsibilities that we have to the peoples in those countries and also to the many Australians of Lithuanian, Estonian and Latvian descent, we have the responsibility, I believe, to take the lead. I am calling for Australia to recognise and establish diplomatic relations with the democratically elected governments of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. My motion, of course, is not up for debate at this juncture; the motion of Senator Hill is before us. I am supporting that motion and I hope that it is unanimously adopted by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to speak briefly to Senator Hill's motion and in very strong support of it, particularly the final clause, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . urges the Australian Government to support Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in their continuing quest to regain their freedom and independence.
I fully support the remarks of my leader, Senator Hill, and of the other speakers who have participated in the debate, in particular, my friend and colleague Senator Harradine.

We are considering a very important matter. The peoples of the Baltic nations are small in number. The total population of the three nations-Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia-is only of the order of 8 1/2 million people in a world approaching five billion people. But the way in which those people have, with great integrity and dignity, fought for the restoration of their legitimate freedom and sovereignty over a period of 50 years is to me a great example to the rest of the world and a very important example to us in the free world.

I visited the Baltic nations two years ago after having many years of association with the peoples from those nations in Australia. That visit had a lasting impact on me and I came to appreciate, even more than I had before, the courage and indomitable spirit that those peoples have exerted and shown in fighting for the very things that we in this country take for granted-the whole basis of democracy, freedom and liberty, the right of free speech and so on-which they have never had and which is rightly theirs.

What this debate around the world is all about is no more than the restoration of the legal, legitimate independence that was usurped from the peoples of the Baltic nations through the infamous, secretive Molotov-Ribbentrop pact of 23 August 1939, which is within a week of being 52 years ago. I will not go into the history of that pact because it is well known to members of the Senate and I am sure it is now known throughout Australia. However, that pact led to the mass deportation and murder of Baltic peoples commencing in June 1940 which, in turn, led to the loss of life and/or the disappearance of more than 600,000 people, or more than 10 per cent of the population of the combined nations of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. Since then those nations have experienced 50 years of illegal, frequently brutal, subjugation; Russification; denial of basic human rights and freedoms; inability to exhibit any of their own national characteristics; and inability to follow their own cultural heritage-all the things that we in Australia take for granted.

I have similar views to Senator Harradine concerning the attitude of the United States in this matter. I say this with some sadness because I am a strong supporter of most of the international efforts of the US and I support it in its aspirations, at the end of the day, for the Baltic states. But I share Senator Harradine's view that more should be being done by the United States in particular to give leadership in supporting the cause of the Baltic peoples. I am also concerned about the bottom line attitude of the Soviet Union, and in particular President Gorbachev, on this matter. I have always believed, perhaps hopefully, that his aspirations for the Baltic states are the same as those of the Western world and most other freedom and peace-loving nations-namely, in the end, independence for those nations.

The actions of the Soviets were under what appeared to be the cloak of the Gulf War. Taking actions of a quite brutal nature in Lithuania around the turn of the last year-1990 moving into 1991-is a matter of considerable concern. I do not think that the actions of the Soviet Union and President Gorbachev since then have assuaged the doubts and concerns that I had at that time.

There is a very real need for the West to take a stronger leadership role in this matter. Within the West there is a very strong obligation on our nation to be up-front for the sort of reasons that others in this debate have expressed. We have in Australia a community of peoples whose countries of origin were the nations of the Baltic states. These people have been tremendous Australians. Some of them now occupy leading positions in Australian business and society. All of them have been a great attribute and have made a great contribution to Australia over the last 30 or 40 years.

I believe that Australia does have an obligation to our Australian Baltic communities, and through them to their countries of origin, to do as much as we possibly can to see that the Baltic nations have restored to them what is nothing more than their legitimate sovereignty and independence which they had until it was illegally usurped in 1939-40. As I said earlier, in those 50 years they have been subjugated to an illegality that should never have occurred. So we are simply asking for the restoration of sovereignty and independence that should always have rightly been theirs.

Therefore, I have great pleasure in supporting Senator Hill's motion-as I am sure the whole Senate and the overwhelming majority of Australian people do-and, in particular, that part of the motion urging the Australian Government to support Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in their continuing quest to regain their freedom and independence. My only remaining hope is that that legitimate aspiration be achieved as soon as possible because those people of the Baltic nations should expect nothing less.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I join with others in supporting Senator Hill's motion. The struggle for freedom by the Baltic states and other captive nations of the Soviet Union has been a matter of major significance to the Opposition. The Opposition has consistently supported their struggle.

SPEECH.PARA: In February, almost coincidental with the seventy-third anniversary of the independence of Lithuania and Estonia, the coalition successfully moved a motion here reaffirming the right of the peoples of the Baltic states to regain the independence illegally taken from them in 1940 and calling on the Soviet Government to observe at least minimum human rights, including the right to peaceful self-determination. In March, we successfully moved a resolution that the Senate:
(a) notes the overwhelming votes in Latvia and Estonia on 3 March 1991 and in Lithuania in 9 February 1991 in favour of independence from the Soviet Union;
(b) calls upon the Government of the Soviet Union to respect the results of these referendums and to concede the right of independence to the Baltic states;
(c) demands that the Soviet Government unequivocally renounces the use of force in its dealings with the Baltic states and respects normal modes of dealing between states; and
(d) believes the Australian Government should join with other likeminded Governments to press the Soviet Union to give to give early practical effect to the three referendums.

There is no doubt that this year, 1991, has been a very significant one in the struggle for freedom in the Baltic states. As with all struggles for just causes, there is a tendency for violence to erupt, for passions to be aroused and, regrettably, for there to be deaths.

There is no doubt that those who died at the border post on 31 July will be seen, and quite properly, by their compatriots as martyrs to a cause. I know that the Opposition will support me. All I can hope for in this struggle is that there is no need for further martyrs to this cause and that the cause will be triumphant. I have a great deal of pleasure in supporting Senator Hill's motion urging the Australian Government to support Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia in their continuing quest to regain their freedom and independence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address briefly the matters raised by Senator Hill's motion. There are a number of matters which are common to the Baltic states-Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania-and the states which currently comprise, under a degree of obvious compulsion, the country of Yugoslavia-Serbia, Croatia and Slovenia.

SPEECH.PARA: The United Nations Charter on Human Rights guarantees the independence of people, in contrast to the independence of nations which was guaranteed by the Charter of the League of Nations. I think we have entered an age not only in Europe but the world over where people are now claiming their sovereignty, in a personal sense and in their communities.

Having recently visited the countries of Eastern Europe-in fact, I returned after 40 years-I became conscious of the strength of their will to have self-determination, their cultural and national identities guaranteed and their future determined.

Several questions arise from the tragic situation in Slovenia and Croatia and the no less tragic situation in the Baltic states. In the face of plebiscites, which show that it is the will of more than 90 per cent of the people to be independent, why does the Government hesitate to recognise these aspirations? Why does it not take the next step, the obvious step, and recognise those communities as independent nations?

In Europe, the feeling is growing that, in time, there will be a united Europe that will include those countries. There is no reason-I have been told this by a number of representatives from various governments-why communities based on regions rather than nations, as they are now constituted, could not become members of the European Community.

In this context, it is clear that the Government must catch up with the prevailing mood, with the national aspirations of people in Eastern Europe and recognise these countries. It is obviously necessary to send an international observer team to Croatia in the immediate future and, even before that, to send humanitarian aid to relieve the suffering in that country. However, I leave this question with the Government: why has there been hesitation in refusing to recognise the justified aspirations of these people?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to replace the motion which is on the Notice Paper with a new motion. I will now read it, and then seek the appropriate leave. In explanation, there have been some discussions during the course of the day between the parties as to whether there is the possibility of further strengthening the terms of this motion, and it is as a result of that that I am going to seek to replace it with new words. As I propose that it be debated, it will read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) deplores the violence, loss of life and destruction of property that has taken place in Slovenia and Croatia, where more than 300 civilians are reported to have been killed, largely as a result of the attacks of terrorists supplied by the communist led Federal Army and attacks by the Army itself;
(b) notes the potential for further conflict if aspirations for self-determination expressed through democratic plebiscites in the Yugoslav Republics are confronted by military force;
(c) welcomes the efforts of the European Community to act as a mediator to prevent further conflict;

(d) calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav Republics, which will avoid conflict, achieve the independence the peoples of Croatia and Slovenia demand and protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities; and

(e) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition.
I seek leave to move the motion in those terms.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate:

(a) deplores the violence, loss of life and destruction of property that has taken place in Slovenia and Croatia, where more than 300 civilians are reported to have been killed, largely as a result of the attacks of terrorists supplied by the communist led Federal Army and attacks by the Army itself;
(b) notes the potential for further conflict if aspirations for self-determination expressed through democratic plebiscites in the Yugoslav Republics are confronted by military force;
(c) welcomes the efforts of the European Community to act as a mediator to prevent further conflict;

(d) calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav Republics, which will avoid conflict, achieve the independence the peoples of Croatia and Slovenia demand and protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities; and

(e) further calls upon the Australian Government to recall its Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on how Australia might, consistent with a desire to preserve peace, support the newly evolving independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition.

It is clear that Yugoslavia is breaking up. It is equally clear that it cannot be held together at the point of a gun and, in my opinion and the opinion of my colleagues, the international community should vigorously oppose any attempt to do so. It is easy to understand the initial reaction of the United States and some European states some months ago to seek the continuation of Yugoslavia out of a fear that the break-up would not resolve the ethnic and religious differences, and of course also a fear of a violent transition. But not even superpowers can today hold together these artificial states if the separate nations which comprise such states desire otherwise. It is clear from the referendums and the declarations that the Slovenian and Croatian peoples wish to exist in independent states. In our opinion, we should therefore understand, respect and support that reasonable aspiration.

As we now know, Macedonia will also hold a plebiscite on independence on 8 September and the President of Bosnia-Herzegovina has now ordered a plebiscite to decide the future of that republic. All around Yugoslavia decisions are now being made about whether individual component republics will continue to seek a future in the form of independent sovereign states. As I said, we know that two-Slovenia and Croatia-have already made that decision, although the declarations of independence may have been suspended for three months.

We are unsure of the picture in Serbia. We are aware of the aspirations for a greater Serbia claimed by Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian President, but that seems to be breaking up, particularly if it seems that Bosnia-Herzegovina is going to move in a different direction. There is a highly complicated situation in Bosnia itself, because over 40 per cent of its population is Muslim, with just under 30 per cent being Serbian and 18 per cent Croatian. Although there has been speculation for some time that there might be a move to divide it in some way between Croatia and Serbia, it looks as though the people in Bosnia themselves are taking action to ensure that does not happen. However, whether its diverse communities are going to accept that it continues as one sovereign state is something that they will have to decide themselves and it will be a difficult issue for them.

Of course there is also the complication that Albanian people, particularly in the province of Kosovo, are again looking to restore the autonomy they enjoyed until last year. We are all aware of the human rights abuses that have occurred and have been perpetrated on them, but it is unclear also as to what they are going to seek for the future. Whether that part can be taken out of Serbia is something that obviously still has to be determined.

I suggest that it is also unclear what the borders of these new states will be. That raises difficult issues such as that of the Serbian villages within Croatia, but it seems to me that it is impossible to carve up Yugoslavia purely on ethnic lines alone because whatever the boundaries of the new states might be, there will always be minorities and states will have the responsibility to protect the interests of those minorities. Of course the international community also has a responsibility to protect the interests of minorities, something it has been prepared to support elsewhere with varying degrees of enthusiasm. I suppose the most recent example is the modest efforts taken by the international community to protect the interests of the Kurdish minority in Iraq.

We have been distressed by the violence that has occurred and we condemn it. We condemn the early role taken by the federal Yugoslav army, which has been referred to in this motion, when it was ordered into action in both Slovenia and Croatia.

We commend all those people who are trying to facilitate a peaceful transition to whatever the new structures for Yugoslavia might be. I mention particularly the continuing efforts of the European Community. It has been able to negotiate a cease-fire of sorts, although, sadly, individuals are still being killed, but at least it has been able to hold off war whilst the complex negotiations can take place between the Yugoslav republics as to exactly what form they wish for their future. Clearly, war between the Croats and the Serbs would be a tragedy and a contradiction of all that was envisaged in the new world order.

There is no doubt that this new world order is much more complex than some envisaged, but once the pressure cooker lid of communism was lifted from these states so that the nationalities within them had a reasonable opportunity to express their aspirations for the future it was inevitable that, in the case of Croatia and, to some extent, the Soviet Union, different nationalities would see their futures in independent terms. I for one do not see that that is something that should particularly concern the international community. It provides a new challenge for the international community, but it simply means that, consistent with its desires, the international community has to find ways to accommodate these new states. There is no doubt that Europe will do that. In the case of Slovenia, it already has well developed economic relations with Austria. There is no doubt that an independent Croatia would be readily absorbed within the European Community as well. Obviously, there will be difficulties, but they are simply challenges that have to be overcome.

We recognise the changes that are occurring within this highly complex situation, but we do say that the Australian Government must address them, as any other international government must, and look for ways in which it can be supportive, and it should be realistic. So far-again, consistent, I regret to say, with the previous motion that we have just debated-apart from what might be described as some soothing rhetoric, the Australian Government has taken little action to either support the peaceful transition or to support what will be the reality of newly independent states. We say that it is now time that it faced up to its responsibility in that regard. It can do so by taking note of this motion-in particular that part of the motion which calls upon the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the republics, which will avoid conflict, of course, but will achieve the independence that the peoples of Croatia and Slovenia demand, and will help protect the interests of ethnic and religious minorities.

We believe that the Government can now constructively take a step forward by recalling the Australian Ambassador to Yugoslavia for consultations on ways, consistent with our obvious desire to preserve peace, in which we can support the newly evolving independent states, including the most appropriate time to give diplomatic recognition to those states. That in itself, I readily acknowledge, is tricky because, although, as I said, the declarations were passed, they were suspended. During this period of cease-fire that the European Community leaders have been able to negotiate, the Yugoslav republics are to negotiate on their future form.

Therefore, it seems to us-certainly we would not wish to see Australia or any other of the international communities take action that might in some way inflame the difficulties-that there must be a correct time in which diplomatic recognition for these newly evolving independent states will facilitate that process of peaceful evolution rather than hinder it. At the moment I do not think the Australian Government is facing up to its responsibility in that regard, rather it is hoping that it does not have to make these decisions. It should be addressing these matters. A way in which it can start to do that is by getting our Ambassador back, getting the best information that it possibly can and starting to address the correct timing that can best facilitate a peaceful transition to the newly independent states.

We therefore constructively produce this motion tonight after consultations. I particularly mention Senator Harradine, whose contribution in discussions has led to the strengthening of several parts of this motion, but strengthening in a way that we think is in the best interests of the various peoples of Yugoslavia, and will earn some respect for Australia and indicate to the very large Australian community of Yugoslav origin-from Yugoslavia in its various forms-that Australia is really interested and concerned about what is happening in its homeland and is anxious to take positive steps to facilitate and to contribute to the peaceful transition that is going to be necessary. I commend the motion in its amended form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to contribute briefly to the debate on the proposition that Senator Hill has advanced this evening. As with the earlier proposition on the Baltic republics, it is not possible to view the circumstances in Yugoslavia without looking at the history of the region over the twentieth century. I refer in particular to the wartime agreements between Winston Churchill and Joseph Stalin which governed Eastern Europe at the end of the war and which related to Hungary, Yugoslavia and Greece. It is a matter of fact that Churchill and Stalin agreed that in the state of Hungary in the postwar period the Soviet Union would have 75 per cent of the influence and the British 25 per cent; in Greece the figures would be reversed, with the British having 75 per cent of influence and the Soviets 25 per cent; and the two powers would share influence in Yugoslavia on a 50 : 50 basis.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also a matter of history that this was communicated between the two wartime leaders by way of Churchill noting this suggestion on a slip of paper at one of the conferences-Yalta, I believe-and passing it to Stalin, who glanced at it, ticked it with a blue pencil and passed it back to Churchill. We see in that agreement the beginnings of a number of the problems that are faced in Yugoslavia tonight.

The circumstance in Yugoslavia at the moment is truly terrible. Security forces appear to be out of control. There is internal tension that spills over routinely into bloodshed. The Yugoslav federal army is seen as an arm of one of the participating nationalities. We have had indiscriminate attacks upon civilians. There has been communal violence. We have all the elements needed to turn Yugoslavia into a fragmented state.

The history of Yugoslavia, unfortunately, has been one that suggests that there was never a real unity, not since the country appeared at the conclusion of the First World War. There was for a time an imperial system which maintained a semblance of unity between the wars. In the postwar period the Tito Government maintained a certain unity through an authoritarian system, mild by Eastern European standards in a number of respects but nonetheless authoritarian. One element has united all the peoples of Yugoslavia, and that has been a determination to fight against the various invaders who have appeared upon their soil. I think it is instructive to note that in 1941, after the destruction of the modern Yugoslav state by Nazi Germany, the country was actually partitioned five ways-between Italian-occupied Albania, Germany, Hungary and Bulgaria, with some other territory being ceded to Italy.

That circumstance then led to a very bloody partisan war in which large numbers of the Yugoslav people died, and in which large numbers showed great courage. Here again, there were great divisions. Some Yugoslavs sided with the forces of occupation while most actively opposed, but Josip Tito emerged a wartime hero of great courage and stature. He enlarged upon that stature in the eyes of many people, not only in Yugoslavia but beyond, by being a great anti-Stalinist. One need only read Milovan Djilas's magnificent little book Conversations with Stalin to know how difficult that was at the time.

The Tito system was very authoritarian internally. There is no question of that. Of course, that led to the great break-up with Djilas. The publication of Djilas's book The New Class about the Yugoslav bureaucracy, like the bureaucracy of Eastern Europe, led at one point to his fall from grace. By way of background, the death of Tito meant the gradual fragmentation of the post-war Yugoslav state to a situation where the federal presidency has become largely impotent and the different republics that make up the country war one with the other.

There is a real test here for the European Community, a real test for the Europeans, to act in concert-something which they have singly been unable to do. Of course, we have various positions occupied by different European powers. Spain and France with their own minority problems-the Basques and the Corsicans-favour a federalist Yugoslav state. Germany openly supports independence for Croatia and for Slovenia. Britain and the Netherlands look to the United States to act in concert with the Americans. There is talk of intervention. The Germans have great problems with the concept of intervention, given their constitution, and Ireland is a declared neutral country. It may be that European forces are peacekeeping forces only. I doubt that a European intervention is possible. An article in a recent edition of Newsweek stated:

The crisis in the Balkans represents a major test of Europe's willingness to sacrifice individual national interests to the cause of a stronger collective presence on the world scene. The EC's apparent effectiveness in July raised hopes that the Twelve might develop a true ``political union,'' including common foreign and defense policies, by the end of this year. But the collapse of European mediation efforts in Belgrade strengthened the sceptical view that Western Europe is nowhere near ready to ``speak with a single voice.''

That struck me as an accurate analysis of current European conduct, looking to reach a solution but unable to act in a unified manner. The Australian position was set out by Dr Blewett on 27 June when he said:

The Australian Government is closely monitoring events in Yugoslavia but we regard it as premature to be contemplating recognition for Croatia and Slovenia. At this stage the two republics do not meet fully the criteria for statehood under international law.
The proclamation of independence by Croatia and Slovenia on 25 June should be seen as the commencement of a process rather than its culmination.
Dr Blewett's statement went on to say:
