While the two declarations follow plebiscites in which the people voted overwhelmingly in favour of breaking with the existing Yugoslav structure, both republics acknowledge that their declarations require further negotiations to bring them into full operation.
Dr Blewett concluded his statement by saying:
Australia will continue to follow the situation closely . . .

That is why the Government will be unable to agree to the final point in Senator Hill's proposition. Withdrawing our ambassador at the current stage would be an act of futility. It would have nothing by way of diplomatic impact to recommend it. It would not add to our capacity to make our presence felt. It would deny the Australian Government a first-hand account of events. It would deny the Australian Government a first-hand capacity to intervene by way of counsel and it would achieve little, perhaps nothing at all. While there is little difficulty with the first four points of Senator Hill's revised proposition, the Government cannot accept the fifth point.

I conclude my brief remarks by saying that what is happening in Yugoslavia is a part of the process by which the map of Europe is being redrawn. Just as we saw the Baltic states exercising a legitimate nationalism, we see an outbreak of nationalism in Yugoslavia in no sense less legitimate than nationalist commitments elsewhere on the European continent. It is a real test for the European Community-one which it cannot fail. The Europeans are the most insular and selfcentred in their politics. They demonstrate that continually with their trade policies. If they fail the test in Yugoslavia, they cannot be taken seriously as a political entity with a common approach. This is not a test that the EC can afford to fail.
The Australian Government's position was best set out by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in a news conference at Parliament House on 4 July in which he said:

We deeply hope that the relations between what had been the constituent parts of Yugoslavia will be able to be resolved peacefully. Of course as far as Australia is concerned if Slovenia and Croatia come to a point where they satisfy the requirements of independent statehood, then we would recognise them. But the important point to make, I believe, is the one I have, that we want to see these matters resolved peacefully and in an acceptable and orderly fashion. . .

Again, we are witnesses to a tragedy in Yugoslavia. The response of the Australian Government has been entirely appropriate in pressing for a peaceful solution. The response of the Australian Government has been entirely responsible in monitoring events very closely and very carefully. The community in Australia with its ethnic origin in the various parts of Yugoslavia is to be commended for the enormous restraint it has shown in the conduct of community relations in Australia.

There is no doubt at all that a tragedy of great proportions has been unfolding in recent weeks. Unfortunately, to date, the European Community has not been equal to the test. I have no doubt that over time the international community will be equal to the test in assisting in the arrival at a peaceful solution. The Australian Government's response has been entirely proper and appropriate in the circumstances. For those reasons, while the first four points of Senator Hill's proposition are eminently reasonable, the fifth point is not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the time remaining tonight for debate, I will keep my remarks fairly brief. I start by saying that we saw the final wording of this motion at only 10 minutes to 10 this evening. It is unfortunate that we did not have more prior notice than we did that it was going to be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: Along with a great number of Australians, we have been profoundly disturbed by the events of recent months in Yugoslavia. As Senator Hill has mentioned, the whole world has been witness to an increasingly disturbing trend of vicious and brutal acts of violence in the republics of Slovenia, Croatia and Serbia.

The Australian Democrats support the efforts of the European Community to find a peaceful settlement to the crisis in the Yugoslav republics. Certainly, it is now apparent that the various Yugoslav republics have gone beyond the step of turning back. They appear to be unable to reverse the situation and to restore calm themselves. There is no reason to assume that communists in Yugoslavia can defy the dominant political trend of the late twentieth century. Events in Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Romania and the Baltic states show that it is foolhardy for Yugoslavia's Federal Government to believe that it can avoid a similar fate.

The wishes of the Slovenians and Croatians have been unambiguously declared at the ballot-box. They are no less entitled to self-determination than any other group in Europe or elsewhere on the globe. The right to freely determine their political status and freely pursue their economic, social and cultural development is specifically proclaimed in the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights. Whatever their wishes, it is gravely perilous for Yugoslavia's Federal Government to believe that the yearning of a large proportion of its peoples for self-determination and democracy can be indefinitely repressed.

There is no more sure way of alienating Slovenians and Croatians than by turning the might of Yugoslavia's defence forces against them. The purpose of any country's defence force is to protect, not to kill or intimidate its citizens. The EC Ministers got it right when they said that the best place for Yugoslavia's army is in its barracks. That is why we support the European Community's efforts to find a resolution to the crisis.

The European Community is clearly working on the basis that the Yugoslavs can be encouraged to sort out their own affairs if presented with the right mix of sticks and carrots. We understand that the European Community is presently considering a variety of military and diplomatic steps, including economic sanctions, to tackle this crisis. There now appears to be a faint glimmer of hope that growing violence and social and political disintegration in the Balkans may be avoided.

We feel great sympathy for the hundreds of thousands of Australians with fears for the safety of family and friends in this troubled part of Europe. The Australian Government has a responsibility to the vast number of people with relatives and friends living in this volatile area. Obviously, there is a limit to what Australia can achieve to stop an all out war from breaking out. However, we believe that Australia must apply every possible influence to try to bring about a peaceful resolution.

Politicians in Yugoslavia have failed their people badly. In recent years the people have endured great economic hardship. It is appalling to see now that they are facing death at the hands of aggressive and vindictive armed forces. The Democrats will be supporting this motion which Senator Hill has moved tonight in relation to Yugoslavia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too will try to be brief. I support the motion that Senator Hill has moved because I wish to represent the vast number of people, particularly those in Tasmania, of Croatian and Slovenian extraction who have contacted me, as they have contacted other members of parliament all over Australia. These people have a great concern for their friends and relatives in those states. I understand that some 500,000 Croatians and their families live in Australia. The Croatian and the Slovenian communities in Australia have been collecting money for medical supplies for their friends and families in those countries. I know that these people have a very deep love for their countries.

SPEECH.PARA: We all have a love for our own country and our own States. I felt a little, perhaps, of what the people here are feeling about what is happening in Croatia and Slovenia when I read the article in the Canberra Times in which Ian Warden had a cheap shot at Senator Walters and Senator Harradine for continuing to come up here from Tasmania. It upset me when he referred to my State as `that miserable little island they come from'. That might be his opinion, but it is certainly not mine; that stirred my hackles. So I can understand how the people of Croatian and Slovenian extraction living in Australia must feel when they know that their homeland and their friends and families are being threatened. I can understand, when they read about their friends and relations being murdered, maimed and mutilated, just how concerned they must be.

Although Senator Hill's original motion has been changed, I do not believe that the part of the motion that calls on the Australian Government to support international efforts for a negotiated settlement between the Yugoslav republics goes far enough. I think that Australia should go further than just talking about this issue. The EC team, as Senator Loosley pointed out, has been effective to a degree. We saw how action by the UN resolved the Gulf crisis. If that sort of pressure were put on the Serbian communist regime I wonder whether it would withdraw.

When the three-month suspension of the declaration of independence expires, Australia should recognise Croatia and Slovenia as independent republics. Such recognition could lead to building up sufficient international support which may have the effect of stopping the Federal Government of Yugoslavia and the Serbians from continuing this senseless killing and mutilation. It has to stop.

I know that Australia has a fear of setting a precedent. In the past we have been fearful of that, and I can understand that. For instance, it would have been foolish to recognise Bougainville when it tried to separate from Papua New Guinea. We certainly did not recognise the insurgent movements in Sulawesi and Sumatra in 1957, but we did recognise Bangladesh when it seceded from Pakistan in 1977.

Much has been said tonight about Australia's position on the Baltic states. Senator Loosley referred to Senator Evans's statement in May 1990, but this case is different. An article written by Des Moore, a well-known political commentator, states:

The 1974 constitution of Yugoslavia provides specifically for the right of republics to withdraw from the federation, and overwhelming majorities in Croatia and Slovenia have recently voted in referendums for independence. Both republics have governments elected in free and democratic elections. The republics have their own administration structures, public services, armed forces and police enabling their governments to exercise effective control throughout their territories. They thus satisfy the essential criteria for diplomatic recognition.
The people have also shown their willingness to fight and die for independence. The article continues:
At this point in world history, continued dominance of the democracies in Slovenia and Croatia by a hardline Communist establishment in Serbia would clearly be an anachronism.

Many people argue that Croatia and Slovenia are small states. Croatia has a population of 4.8 million people; Slovenia has a population of 2 million people. There are sovereign states in Europe which have smaller populations, such as Iceland, Malta, Luxembourg, Cyprus and even Ireland. Mongolia, the country I visited last year, has a smaller population.

On 3 July, at the request of the Croatian community in Tasmania-and along with others around Australia-I wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) expressing my concerns. I still have not received a reply, of course; nevertheless, I made my views known. It is interesting to note that at a press conference on 4 July the Prime Minister stated:
If Slovenia and Croatia come to a point where they satisfy the requirements of independent statehood, then we would recognise them.
On 27 June, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) stated:

The Australian Government is closely monitoring events in Yugoslavia but we regard it as premature to be contemplating recognition for Croatia and Slovenia. At this stage the two republics do not meet fully the criteria for statehood under international law.

From those comments it seems that Australia has adopted the same sort of line as the Americans and is just marking time, waiting for good company. In the meantime, the Yugoslav Army, along with Serbs and Chetniks, are out to crush these fledgling states. If we took the lead and recognised Croatia and Slovenia, we could do it on a principle, that principle being that we should support the right to self-determination of two communities which have their own cultural identities and democratically elected governments and have voted for independence in a referendum so that they can join the free democratic society of western Europe. If we did recognise the States--
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish this evening to pay tribute to a former long serving member of the Federal Parliament and a most prominent and distinguished Territorian, John Norman Nelson, who died on 20 June 1991 in Alice Springs. Jock, as he was commonly known, lived most of his 83 years in the Northern Territory and was, without doubt, one of its all-time favourite sons and respected citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: Jock Nelson served as the Territory's Federal Labor member of the House of Representatives from his election in 1949 to his retirement in 1966. Tonight I would like to place on record the appreciation of this Government and the Australian Labor Party of his long and distinguished service to the people of the Northern Territory and of Australia, both inside and outside parliament. I know that Senator Tambling will join me this evening and also pay his tribute to Jock Nelson.

A dedicated Labor man from a strong and dedicated Labor family, Jock held a staggering number of jobs in his lifetime, working as a jackeroo, a water boring contractor, a cattleman, a commission agent, a member of the armed services, a foundation member of the Northern Territory's Legislative Council, the Territory's Federal Labor member for 17 years, the first elected Mayor of Alice Springs and the first Territorian to be appointed Administrator of the Northern Territory.

Jock was born on 28 May 1908 at Mount Perry in Queensland, the son of Maude and Harold George Nelson. When Jock was five the growing family moved to Pine Creek and later to Darwin where Harold became the leading force in the burgeoning local union movement and, indeed, was the instigator of the Territory's most famous political event. Jock had strong childhood memories of this event, watching his father lead a deputation in 1918 of more than 1,000 workers who waited on the Commonwealth's first and very controversial Territory Administrator, Dr John Anderson Gilruth, whom they invited, not very politely, to leave town-an invitation he eventually accepted.

Next, Harold Nelson led the fight of `No taxation without representation' to demand that the Territory be given representation in Federal Parliament, a campaign which was successful. In the 1922 election which ensued, Harold became the Territory's first Federal representative, serving in that capacity until 1934 when he was finally defeated by the conservative candidate, Mr A.M. Blain. Although Harold did not have a vote, he was such an effective orator that it was said that parliamentarians from both sides of the House listened intently whenever he spoke, always strongly advocating the Territory's cause.

Because of the logistics of getting to and from the Territory to Melbourne and Canberra in those days, the days before regular air flights and the still to be completed transcontinental railway, the Nelsons moved to Melbourne and then Sydney during Harold's parliamentary career. However, as soon as Jock had completed his schooling he returned to the Centre and got his first job as a jackeroo on a station near Alice Springs. In 1928 he brought a mob of several hundred sheep from Oodnadatta, but when the drought of 1928-29 wiped out his flock he began to work as a contractor boring for water on government stock routes.

In 1934 Jock married Peg Bloomfield, the daughter of another pioneering Territory family, and the young couple moved to Tennant Creek to join the search for gold and to operate a much needed butcher's shop in the embryonic township. The family returned to Alice Springs in 1936 where Jock worked as a contractor and agent before joining the Australian Imperial Forces.

During World War II, Jock served with the Royal Australian Engineers both in Australia and overseas. At war's end he returned to Alice Springs where he acquired an interest in a Central Australian cattle station and began following in his father's footsteps of working towards the political and social reform of the Northern Territory. He became an active member of the Northern Territory Development League and in December 1947 was elected as a foundation member of the first Northern Territory Legislative Council-formed, I might add, through legislation passed by the Chifley Labor Government. He was one of 13 members, six of whom were elected and seven appointed. It is worth while noting that during his maiden speech as the member for Stuart, Jock said that he would not rest until the Territory had a fully elected governing body.

In order to work more effectively toward achieving this goal, Jock stood for the Federal Territory seat in 1949 and, despite the fact that the Chifley Government lost the general election, his personal popularity ensured that he won the Territory seat from the man who had defeated his father. In his maiden speech he referred to the importance of the pastoral and mining industries and drew attention to the need for improved road construction in the Territory. He also referred to constitutional development, giving credit to the Chifley Government for setting it up but strongly pointing out that the Council now needed to be a fully elected body, urging the Menzies Government to proceed with that. It was not until a Whitlam Labor Government was elected that that reform was achieved in 1974.

Like his father before him, Jock was a voteless member when he was elected. Eight years later, after persistent appeals, he finally achieved a vote in the House, although only on matters affecting the Northern Territory. Nevertheless, he pursued the Territory's interests relentlessly. It is a great tribute to him that he was re-elected to Parliament five times, twice unopposed. During his parliamentary career he was a member of the Select Committee on the Voting Rights of Aborigines, in 1961, and the Select Committee on the Grievances of the Yirrkala Aborigines, Arnhem Land Reserve, in 1963. He also served as Secretary to the Parliamentary Labor Party between 1956 and 1966-a decade.

After 17 years in politics, Jock allegedly retired and returned to Alice Springs to live. By this time most people would have had enough of public life, but five years later, in 1971, he was persuaded to stand as the first elected mayor of Alice Springs, winning the position in a landslide victory by relying primarily on his track record of public service and a very low-key and inexpensive campaign centred around the slogan `Give Jock a trot'. Between 1968 and 1972 he was also the Northern Territory delegate to the Labor Party's Federal Executive. He served as Alice Springs Mayor until 1973, when he became the first Territorian to be appointed Administrator of the Northern Territory. It was indicative of his commitment to Territory self-government that in his very first interview as Administrator he said that he hoped he would soon be out of a job and that the Territory would soon be completely self-governing.

Jock and Peg served in their vice-regal posts with distinction, particularly in the very difficult period following Cyclone Tracy, which devastated Darwin on Christmas Day 1974. Less than a year later, when the Whitlam Government was dismissed from office, Jock Nelson felt so strongly about the events of that time that he stood down from the office of Administrator to contest once again the Federal seat for Labor. Although he was not elected, the principled and self-sacrificing position he took during those difficult days served as an inspiration for many Labor people such as I, who made a renewed commitment to the Party and its policies. In 1977, the year that I entered politics, that renewed commitment resulted in the Labor Party coming extremely close, within a few hundred votes, to winning government in the Northern Territory-the closest we have ever come.

When Jock Nelson finally did retire to his beloved Alice Springs in 1976, he continued to serve the community, always finding the time when asked to give advice and support to people on all sides of politics. For his long and untiring service to the Labor Party, he was given life membership in the Northern Territory Labor Party. It is an indication of the esteem in which he was held that several of his former Federal colleagues, including Clyde Cameron and Frank Crean, both of whom gave their maiden speeches at the same time as Jock Nelson, were present at Jock's funeral in Alice Springs. At his eulogy it was said:

Love, concern and care for others went out into the community where this humble, self-effacing man never sought honour, only to serve his country and its people, particularly those from the Territory.
I am pleased to pay tribute to Jock Nelson, who served both the Territory and Australia so effectively for such a long period and who was a friend to and inspiration of many.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly very pleased to endorse the comments that Senator Collins made about the late Jock Nelson. Jock Nelson was an icon in the Northern Territory. He was a man of great inspiration to many territorians and he was certainly loved throughout the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a close association with Jock Nelson for as long as I can remember-as a child growing to maturity in the Northern Territory, and during the period that Jock was a Federal member of parliament. I believe that he had a great influence in my own home and on many occasions I learnt a lot from him. I also had the great privilege of being a member of the Administrators Council during the period Jock Nelson was the Administrator of the Northern Territory. At that time I was an elected member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly. During the period that he was Administrator it was indeed a privilege to serve as a member on his Council.

Like Senator Collins, because of personal associations I would also like to pay a particular tribute to the role that Jock Nelson played in that important year following Cyclone Tracy in Darwin. I can remember spending time with him in the days following the cyclone and noting the important leadership that he gave as Administrator on that occasion.

To me, Jock Nelson was one of the pioneers of Northern Territory politics. He was first elected as the member for Stuart in 1947 in the then Northern Territory Legislative Council. Subsequently, as Senator Collins said, he was elected a member of the House of Representatives from 1949 to 1966. In 1971 he was elected as the first mayor of Alice Springs. Then, probably to top off his career, he was appointed the Administrator of the Northern Territory from 1973 to 1976.

The Northern Territory has come a long way politically since Jock Nelson was elected to the Federal Parliament in 1949. So much has happened. What we need to reflect on is his vision of a truly developed north of Australia. Jock Nelson's maiden speech to this Federal Parliament contained this inspiration. Like Senator Collins, I have reviewed that speech in the last few days. I found that Jock Nelson certainly had a great vision for the Northern Territory.

Jock Nelson made his maiden speech in this Parliament on 15 March 1950. I have identified 10 major issues that I find are still threads which run through the debates that Senator Collins and I engage in so passionately in this place. I think the three of us-Jock Nelson, Bob Collins and I-would take pride in putting these points forward. The 10 points that I identify from Jock Nelson's maiden speech are as follows: the development of Northern Territory resources; road construction; the pastoral industry; mining and its future; the lack of water with regard to development; the planning of Darwin as a very significant capital city in Australia; his concern for social issues in terms of his Northern Territory constituents and the need to achieve certain goals; the reorganisation of the legislature within the Northern Territory to enable it to play a more effective role; a fully elected and voting representation of the Northern Territory in whatever parliament is established; and, finally, the very important issue of defence and north Australian security.

Of course, in his maiden speech Jock Nelson referred to the fact that the bombing of Darwin had taken place some eight years before. He spoke about the lapsing memories of people and the need to be always very vigilant in that part of Australia. Probably his final point related to populating the north. All of these goals have common themes and threads running through them.

Jock Nelson certainly had a distinguished career and he can only be described as a person who had a close identification with the constituency he represented. Throughout the 70-odd years that he lived, worked and finally retired in the Northern Territory we can see that Jock Nelson was a man who cared. He was a man who got involved; he was a man who delivered what he said he was going to deliver.

At all times, I found Jock Nelson to be a man of great personal integrity, honesty and character. He provided an example that I am sure historians will take a great deal of pleasure in constantly reviewing when they examine not only Jock Nelson's life and contribution, but also the era in which he served publicly in the Northern Territory. That period ran from 1949 until his retirement as Administrator in 1976. He certainly led a very distinguished life.

At the same time, I also pay tribute to the very great role played by his family and his role as a family man. Jock Nelson's wife, Peg, is equally a character of the Northern Territory and a much-loved lady. She and her daughters have the sympathy of all Territorians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.46 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 3 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many cases are currently being litigated where the amount of the penalty imposed by the Australian Customs Service is less than the threshold figure of $300, which the Minister advised the Senate on 28 May 1991 was the figure below which it is the practice of Customs not to proceed with litigation.
(2) When was the threshold figure of $300 introduced.

(3) For all cases since the relevant date in (2), where a penalty of less than $300 has been imposed by Customs and the case has involved litigation, will details of the following be provided (a) the name of the appellant; (b) the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or other identifying reference number; (c) the amount of the penalty imposed by Customs; (d) the date the penalty was imposed; (e) the amount of the duty originally short paid; (f) the cost incurred by the Commonwealth in proceeding with litigation; and (g) the reasons why these cases were prosecuted, given the stated Customs practice of not proceeding in cases where the amount of penalty is less than $300.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Nil. The threshold figure of $300 refers to the minimum amount below which the Australian Customs Service administrative penalty guidelines recommend that a penalty not be imposed. It is not a litigation threshold as stated in the question.

(3) There have been no reviews by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) of ACS penalty remission decisions where the original penalty amount was less than $300. It should be noted that where a review is undertaken by the AAT, the ACS remission decision is placed in abeyance and the AAT is required to determine afresh whether any remission should apply and, if so, the appropriate level. In a recent case a penalty of $799 was imposed against A &M Topper and was 85 per cent remitted by the Customs Service on application for review. The Customs agent representing the company has rejected the penalty remaining of $119 and has actioned the matter before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, which is yet to give its decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 4 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Employment, Education and Training use different indices to index Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) fees and HECS debts and repayment thresholds; if so, what are these indices and why were they chosen.
(2) What have the semester fees and HECS debts and repayment thresholds been set at each year since the introduction of HECS.
(3) If the real value of the debt differs depending on the year in which it was incurred, what is the justification for this.

(4) If the HECS fees are indexed to maintain a set proportion of the average cost of a higher education place (a) what is this proportion; (b) why was a proportion chosen; and (c) why was that particular proportion chosen.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Employment, Education and Training use the same indices as prescribed in Sections 40 and 68 of the `Higher Education Funding Act 1988' and the `Higher Education Funding Amendment Act (No. 2) 1990'.
(2) The Annual Course Contribution, HECS debts and repayment rates since the introduction of HECS are:

The HECS debt for a semester is calculated by higher education institutions in accordance with the `Guidelines for Calculating Standard Student Load and Equivalent Full-time Student Unit Values'. In 1991 the HECS payment for a full-time student undertaking a standard program of study is $1,993 ($996 for each semester). The semester debt depends on the proportion of the standard student load being undertaken.
Financial For taxable incomes be applied to
Year in the range of taxable income

(3) The HECS debt is indexed on 1 June each year for the portion of the debt which has remained unpaid for 12 months or more. The indexation factor to be applied each year is based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) figures produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics after the March quarter (7.2 per cent and 8 per cent respectively for the years 1989-90 and 1990-91).

In any one instance the `real value' of the debt will depend on a number of factors including the rate at which the debt is being repaid and the difference between the real rate of interest and the CPI applying in different years.
(4) (a) The HECS Annual Course Contribution represents approximately 20 per cent of the average cost of a higher education place.

(b) In establishing HECS the Government considered the recommendations of the `Report of the Committee on Higher Education Funding', April 1988, which found that on historical and overseas precedents it would not be unreasonable to expect higher education users to contribute around 20 per cent of the average costs incurred by the Commonwealth Government.

(c) The Committee also found that in 1988 a contribution of $1,800 per full-time student equivalent would represent around 20 per cent of the total Commonwealth outlays in higher education (excluding the cost of student income support).

(5) Mrs Strickland's selection was based on Telecom's judgement, given her experience in these matters, that she would perform the functions of the Arbitrator effectively. Her appointment was confirmed after consultation with consumer groups through the Telecom Australia Consumer Council, and with 0055 Service Providers through the Telephone Service Providers Association of Australia.
Telecom did not take the petitions into account in deciding the appointment of Mrs Strickland.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to veterans who qualify for repatriation health care and associated benefits in Western Australia, but who are refused reimbursement for pharmaceuticals prescribed in conjunction with an operation in a private hospital, why is it that they are treated differently from similarly entitled veterans in New South Wales, who are re-imbursed in such circumstances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The entitlements of war widows and veterans to health care services apply uniformly across all States as set out in the Veterans' Entitlements Act (the Act) and the associated Treatment Principles.

Under the Treatment Principles, veterans and war widows who have an entitlement to hospital care and who do not obtain prior approval for a private hospital admission are not eligible to be reimbursed for the costs of that care. The prior approval requirement does not apply to admissions where there is a specific agreement with a individual country private hospital, provided the admission is not for elective surgery. The requirement does not apply also where the admission is an emergency. In these cases payment is made of all costs of treatment, including drugs, which are clearly related to the reason or reasons for admission and which are related to continuing care.
If any individual veteran or war widow has any particular concerns with these arrangements, he or she should contact my Department's Deputy Commissioner in his or her State of residence.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the extent of the Commonwealth Government's involvement in activities with the Bowen Basin gas field in north Queensland to date.
(2) What role is envisaged for the Commonwealth in the development of the Bowen Basin and the Galilee Basin coal-bed methane deposits.

(3) Has the Government considered introducing a non-conventional fuel tax credit system similar to that which has operated successfully with the growing coal-bed methane industry in the United States; if so, what is the Government's position in relation to a non-conventional fuel tax credit scheme; if not, will the Government undertake to consider such a scheme for application in Australia.
(4) Are there any other present or planned Government measures which would assist with the development of alternative energy sources in Australia, such as coal-bed methane.
(5) What is the Government's assessment of the importance of the Bowen Basin and/or Galilee Basin gas reserves in satisfying Queensland's and Australia's future energy requirements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Energy Research and Development Corporation is funding the following research and development (R&) activities associated with coal- bed methane:

(i) Prediction of natural gas production from coal seams in Queensland, $370,900, by a joint venture comprising MGC Resources Pty Ltd (75%) and Mount Isa Mines Ltd (25%); MGC Resources Pty Ltd is a subsidiary of Mitsubishi Gas Chemical Co. Inc. of Japan.
(ii) Relative permeability of coal for methane production, $247,850, by CSIRO Division of Geomechanics.
(2) The Government is currently funding R& in coal-bed methane.
(3) No. The Government considers that the coal- bed methane resource development is a matter for the private sector when the resource is competitive with the production of conventional natural gas.

(4) The Government aims to provide a suitable economic environment so that the private sector can introduce alternative energy sources such as coal- bed methane on a commercial basis at the appropriate time. However, the matter is currently under consideration by the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Groups.

(5) The total coal-bed methane resource in the northern part of the Bowen Basin alone is estimated at 3,850 billion cubic metres. This compares with a demonstrated economic natural gas resource of 1,030 billion cubic metres. The potential to produce substantial quantities of methane from coal therefore exists.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 19 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the Report on Consultations organised by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, held on 22 and 23 April 1991, and chaired by Dr Don McMichael, and to the question of substantiation of much of the data contained in the Draft Proposed Third Runway EIS, specifically the working papers which do not contain adequate information to substantiate many of the comments made in the Draft EIS, what proposal does the Minister have to rectify this situation in the Draft version of the EIS.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: My colleague, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, has written to me forwarding Dr McMichael's report on the consultations held on 22 and 23 April 1991 between her Department, the Federal Airports Corporation, and groups both for and against the third runway proposal. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 20 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Under what program has British scientist, Ms Wendy Seabrook, been funded to complete a study of cane toads, based at the National Parks and Wildlife Service at Lismore, NSW.
(2) What is the duration and amount of funding involved in the grant.
(3) Are grants for such research normally made available to overseas citizens.
(4) Were any resident Australians considered for such a grant; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Ms Seabrook is currently undertaking doctoral studies on cane toads under the Commonwealth Scholarship and Fellowship Plan (CSFP) through the University of Sydney.
(2) The CSFP Scholarship is for a period of three years from February 1989; the allowance granted amounts to $14,472 per year.

(3) Under the CSFP a reciprocal arrangement exists whereby up to 40 Australians undertake doctoral studies in Britain and four British citizens are permitted entry to Australian universities each year for the same purpose.
(4) CSFP is one of many programs specifically for bilateral educational exchange at postgraduate level. Australians are offered similar opportunities for research in many other countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs, upon notice, on 21 June 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) For the period 1 July 1989 to the present how many applications were received for remission of penalties imposed by the Australian Customs Service (ACS).
(2) How many of the cases in (1) resulted in the ACS granting 100 per cent remission of those penalties.

(3) For the cases in (2), will the Minister provide details of (a) the name of the applicant; (b) the ACS penalty reference number; (c) the amount of the duty originally shortpaid; (d) the amount of the penalty imposed by the ACS; (e) the date the penalty was imposed; (f) the date of the decision to grant the remission; and (g) the reasons for granting full penalty remission.

(4) Will the Minister direct the ACS to regularly provide details of this nature to Customs Agents in a similar fashion to the ACS Summaries of Penalties issued by the Import/Export Section of ACS in Sydney.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Small Business and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Between the period 1 July 1989 and 12 July 1991 the Australian Customs Service (ACS) received 713 applications for remission of administrative penalties.
(2) Of the 713 applications received by the ACS for remission of administrative penalties, the ACS granted a 100 per cent remission in 120 cases.

(3) (a) It should be noted that the names of the applicants in the 120 cases have not been provided as the ACS considers the disclosure of such information would constitute a breach of s.16(2) of the Customs Administration Act 1985.
(b) to (f) The following schedule provides the information requested.
Penalty No. Shortpaid Amount Remit Imposed Decision
Penalty No. Shortpaid Amount Remit Imposed Decision
Penalty No. Shortpaid Amount Remit Imposed Decision

(g) The above administrative penalties were granted a full remission on the basis of the delegate's consideration of the matters contained in Sub-section 243U(4) of the Customs Act 1901. The types of considerations involved included:
Minimal risk to revenue, as well as no prior penalties or convictions incurred by Customs agent or owner of the goods;
Capacity to avoid error diminished by outstanding tariff classification disputes;
Genuine attempt to voluntarily disclose error prior to detection by ACS;

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 8 July 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Department of Defence undertaken work on a Defence Industry Book.
(2) What is the purpose of this project.
(3) When did work on this project start.
(4) Has a consultant been engaged; if so (a) who; (b) when was the consultant engaged; and (c) how much was the consultant paid.
(5) Is work continuing on this project; if not, why not.
(6) When is the project to be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The purpose of the project was to:
(a) facilitate identification of priorities for defence industry development;
(b) guide Australian industry involvement in major capital equipment projects in accordance with the above priorities;
(c) provide a quantitative basis for defence input to non-defence industry policy issues; and
(d) facilitate presentation of defence policy for Australian industry.

(5) No. Work ceased following an appraisal of the project after receipt of the consultant's report. The costs of completing and maintaining such a comprehensive book substantially outweighed the benefits.
(6) There are no plans at this stage to further progress on the project.
